text: Cute place with friendly owner.  We sampled the black sesame and ordered the ube.  Both were very good.
name: KRĒM

text:
We had Brunchuru at Ichicoro Ane in St. Petersburg this past Saturday and it was simply delightful.
For starters we had lightly tempura fried Cauliflower Bao Bun that were garnished with a pickled cucumber, carrots and micro greens laid on top of hot sauce! Can you say love at first bit, because that's exactly what it was.
My youngest daughter indulged in the Bubble Waffle. This is a French toast bubble waffle stuffed with guava and cream cheese, served with guava syrup. So beautifully delish, sorry I don't have a picture, just try it!
My oldest daughter and I both had Miso Ramen topped with Ajitama (half-boiled egg in a soy sauce). The Miso paired with carmalized onions, mushrooms,  bamboo shoots and impossible burger were like a symphony playing in my mouth.
The ladies topped their entree's off by sharing dessert. They had the Halo-Halo! It comes in a tall sundae glass and is comprised of shaved ice, condensed milk, ube ice cream,
flan, adzuki beans, black sesame, shaved
coconut, guava candy. So yummy to the tummy!
I topped my Miso Ramen off with So-Shu ( Shōchū ) a distilled smooth beverage that puts you in the mind of light bodied whiskey.
I could have So-Shu as a after dinner drink on most occasions.
Our waiter Huan H. was very polite, easy going and helpful. He makes dining at Ichicoro Ane top notch.
Ichicoro Ane is a great way to start the weekend.
name: Ichicoro Ane
categories: Ramen, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, Japanese, Bars, Cocktail Bars

text:
Hands down, the best soft serve ice cream I've ever had in my entire life!!!! I love anything taro flavor, so I had to get the "ube-be-baby." I wasn't sure how I would feel about the cake since ice cream is already sweet itself, but the vanilla cake was sooo complimentary to the ube flavor. It was perfection!  definitely my new go-to dessert spot!

Update: came back and tried the vanilla + black sesame combo and O. M. G. that was just as delicious as the Ube! Another favorite!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
I have been to this location about three times total, so far.  Here are my thoughts on the restaurant and my last outing there:

Overall:
Each time, the dining room and the bathrooms have been clean and acceptable.  (I don't understand the absence of a urinal in the men's bathroom.)  The food has been good, not great.  Something is not exactly right with the tofu.  Perhaps it gets old quickly, but generally, the tofu I get here is tougher than I think it should be.

The Food:
On this most recent visit, I ordered the Bangkok Curry with beef.  The meat was good, but just didn't seem right; a little too soft and odd shaped.  I found the dish to be filled with vegetable, black sesame, and noodles (go figure).  I would certainly get this again.

The Service:
I think I primarily dealt with the manager on this last visit, and he was quite accommodating.  He provided my friends and I a complimentary rice krispies treat for dessert.  That was appreciated.  I always like a dessert to settle my meal. Hehe.
name: Noodles & Company
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Italian, Thai, Comfort Food, American (New), Fast Food, Mediterranean, Noodles, Salad, Pasta Shops

text:
K & S is great for specific things. It's not really an all round grocery store, but if you like to experiment and cook Asian or Indian, or Mexican  food, it's a good cheap place to buy cheap ingredients.
Their produce section is impressive. You can find all kinds of exotic mushrooms here for a fraction of the price of gourmet stores. Oyster mushrooms and enokis are an especially good deal. They also have produce that is just downright difficult to find in other places, like yucca roots and cactus leaves. They have sales on bulk packages of vegetables like cucumbers or tomatillos. 
I buy my tofu here because they often have packages on sale for under a dollar. 
Asian condiments are abundant and cheap. Pick up some sweet chili sauce or black sesame seeds. They have entire aisles of noodles and rice. 
I was a little freaked out by the meat and seafood sections, so if you have a weak stomach, you may want to avoid these parts of the store. I did see a guy buying a live eel, which the sales clerk wrapped (alive!) in shrinkwrap on a styrofoam tray and weighed while still wiggling. Be prepared for sights like these. The meat section has parts of animals that I have no business eating, but apparently people do. Still, it's an experience.
name: K & S World Market
categories: Ethnic Food, Grocery, Food, International Grocery, Specialty Food, Imported Food

text:
Yummy. 

This was my first experience with authentic ramen. DH's, too. We had been wanting to check it out for a while but hadn't gotten the chance, so tonight we double dated with our friends M and C and decided it was a good night for ramen. 

It was definitely a good night for ramen. I don't see the whole having to wait outside thing being effective during the summer months, but fortunately it's cool enough now that it isn't a big deal. Tonight, it was cold (well, cold for Tucson, at least). And the line was long, so obviously many people aside from us thought tonight was a good night for ramen. 

There's a pretty good drink selection including wines, Asian craft beers and sodas, as well as soft drinks. The appetizers all looked delicious (hey, I haven't eaten much today) but we opted for the gyoza, which were some of the best I've ever had. M ordered edamame, which came out in a heaping bowl (and we all shared, yum) and C had the pork with bamboo shoots. 

Now the ramen, the most important part. 

Holy smokes. 

I have a child of the 80s fondness for Cup O'Noodles,  as many of us do. I've always drank the broth then eaten the noodles, followed by those vaguely vegetable-like bits of dehydrated corn and carrot. This is not that. 

We got huge bowls filled with delicious broth (DH and I had the black garlic and so should you, just saying), the perfect amount of toppings (fried onions, pickled ginger, black sesame seeds, etc), bamboo shoots, and a piece of pork so delicious and tender that I might write a poem about it later.  And also, if I could make eggs that fantastic, I'd quit my day job. 

It was an awesome experience. Food was great, service was good (I could have used a refill on my drink hence the four stars) and that ramen broth is awfully fun to slurp. 

Sorry, Cup O'Noodles, you've been replaced.
name: Raijin Ramen
categories: Noodles, Japanese, Diners, Restaurants, Ramen

text:
If you're looking for affordable, yet quality sushi, one of my favorite spots to recommend would have to be Crazy Sushi in the Rittenhouse area. An added bonus? It's BYO! 

It's a slim, sleek space with comfortable seating and a sushi bar at the end. 

Salad
 
Salad was fairly standard with fresh Romaine. The ginger dressing was clearly freshly made. 

Vampire Bowl [$9]
Spicy tuna tartare, avocado bowl
  
A must order in my mind is the Vampire Bowl, their unique take on tuna tartare. I loved the contrast in textures with the crunch from the tempura and the creaminess of the avocado bowl. The sweet wasabi mayo was balanced by the light heat from the spicy tuna. 

Vegetable Tempura [$5]

The GF's a sucker for veggie tempura and this didn't disappoint. A thin layer of tempura coated mushrooms, sweet potato, and carrots. It came accompanied with a light tempura dipping sauce. 

Beef Negimaki [$6]
Scallion, thin-sliced beef, teriyaki
  
On this trip, the negimaki was a bit disappointing. The beef could have been more thinly sliced and better seasoned, though I appreciated the bite of the scallion amidst the teriyaki glaze. 

Triple Sushi [$25]
Tuna, salmon, yellowtail, tuna roll

The triple sushi featured some of our favorite nigiri rolls, including salmon, tuna, and yellowtail. All very clean-tasting and fresh, the platter also came with a tuna roll. I appreciated that the tuna was whole and not minced within the sushi. 

Uni Sushi [$8]

I was also in the mood for uni so asked for an order of uni sushi. Then again, when am I *not* in the mood for uni? Sourced from California, these were creamy, light, and buttery. 

Bloomingdale Roll [$13]
Spicy tuna, spicy salmon, spicy kani, spicy yellowtail, spicy shrimp, avocado, longan
  
I was also intrigued by their Bloomingdale specialty roll. The pink seaweed seemed a bit more delicate in texture and taste, supporting the sweetness of the lychee. This contrasted with the subtly spicy mixture of tuna, salmon, crab yellowtail, and shrimp (whoa!). Due to the laundry list of items, the flavors were a bit muddled, but definitely veers toward the sweeter side of a sushi roll. Interesting! 

Sweet Potato Roll [$5]

Of course, we also had to try our standard sweet potato roll. Crazy Sushi has one of the best iterations, with a wonderful juxtaposition of creaminess from the sweet potato and a light crunch on the exterior. The black sesame seeds studding the surrounding rice made for a perfect bite. 

So if you're not looking to go omakase and want a relaxed sushi meal, I'd recommend checking out Crazy Sushi. Whether you're looking for Americanized rolls or nigiri done right, they've got you covered.
name: Crazy Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
They have the most creative sushi I've ever had. Start to finish, from the wine to dessert, everything was amazing. Wine list is solid, and the cocktails looked really interesting even though we stuck to wine. The dumplings and kobe spring rolls were insanely good. We got a lot of sushi, but the standout was by far the Old City roll. If that was the only sushi I could ever have again, I'd be a happy camper. The black sesame ice cream was also to die for!

Oh and shout out to the best waiter ever, Brion. If you're lucky, you'll get him as your waiter too!
name: Tuna Bar
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese

The place itself is small and there's cards if you want to play games. It's a little proceed for the soft serve, about $7 and you can add pocky for another thirty cents. Overall, the place was clean and can be a good hangout for groups.

text:
This was one of my fav memory about Reno!! This place is awesome, it's aesthetically pleasing, it will satisfy your instagram dreams & your tastebuds! 
We tried the black sesame with chocolate cake which was absolutely DELICIOUS! The cake was BOMB like actually good quality cake & it paired so well w the black sesame. As for the Matcha we paired it w/ the vanilla cake w strategy sauce & it was also a HIT, the strawberry paired w the matcha was BOMB, it had real pieces of strawberry which added a nice touch. Your tastebuds will definitely be pleased. As for customer service, they were super nice & super helpful, we took a while to choose because it was our first time & they were great tie breakers. Great place to get good ice cream & chill.

text:
This new restaurant was very busy and happy we made a reservation for 5PM.  We went in and there was one person in front of us waiting and then another 10 or so arrived while they were trying to figure out the reservation and seating.  Maybe it was working out the new restaurant kinks but it took a bit of time to be seated.  We were seated right at the back on the lower level seating.  There's also seating upstairs.

For 3 of us, we decided on the meat lover's dinner for two.  The salad, edamame, and fried chicken karage came out pretty quickly.  The salad was good and we all liked it.  The edamame serving was bigger than I thought it would be.  The karage was fresh, hot and with a crisp to it.  So far, we were enjoying our dinner.

Next, the meat came out.  It was beef except one spicy pork and we also have buttered corn wrapped in foil.  Cooking on the grill was simple and the meats are thinly sliced so it didn't take long to enjoy it.   There was a bit of a break and we thought we were done dinner, but more meats arrived.  The grilled was replaced a few times during our cooking.  The meats didn't need a lot of sauce as it was marinated but there were 3 sauces to select from.  A bit more variety would have been nice.  Two bowls are rice for 3 of us would enough since we had all the meats to consume.

The service throughout our visit was attentive and friendly. Our meal ended with lychee and black sesame ice cream.  We spent about 2 hours here and we enjoyed the experience.  I had the app so I was able to get a free pop and also scanned our receipt to get points that I can redeem for our next visit.
name: Gyu-Kaku Japanese BBQ
categories: Restaurants, Barbeque, Asian Fusion, Japanese

text:
I really wished I'd had a better food experience. Most everything else about Milk and Honey was enjoyable. Perhaps I bear some of the blame for coming here for dinner rather than breakfast/brunch? Maybe I should have began my relationship with M&H by focusing on its strengths? I dunno.

Despite all the fanfare around the opening, I hadn't been in a rush to come to M&H. I'm not the sort to automatically discount chains but I do like to give the local counterparts my initial attention. Add to this the fact that I don't get to The Gulch that often* and M&H fell further and further down my list. But after a night of wondering around the neighborhood, my buddy got hungry and suggested we check it out. He'd been to M&H before and was a fan. So, off we went.

First thing I noticed was the build out. It's impressive. A deft use of indoor/outdoor space, the color black and good lighting makes one want to spend time here. The next thing I noticed: the employees were all really kind. From the gent who showed us to our table, to our waitress, to the manager, to the food runner... everyone was authentically engaging and not nice for nice's sake. It was almost shocking. A sad commentary, I know. Things were headed in a good direction. I pumped the brakes on the vibes by telling my waitress about my tricky gut and gluten issues. I told her it wasn't a huge deal and I would get a salad if a plate of food wasn't an option. She asked the kitchen and came back to tell me about my options. It worked in my favor because my eye was on the Cali Grilled Chicken and it was safe for me to eat!

When the plate arrived at the table... I was disappointed. To my mind, the description didn't live up to the execution. The first disappointment was the presentation. For a plate that reads 'Grilled chicken breast, avocado, sweet potato, brown rice, black sesame, beet, pickled red onion, garlic, kale, feta, white bean purée, carrot, buttermilk cucumber sauce, and chili', I was a bit shocked at how pedestrian everything looked. 'Hospital cafeteria' came to mind. But, the aroma was nice and food is to be eaten, not Instagrammed so I pressed on. I took a bite and... okay. It was okay. Honestly, I found the plate a bit boring and under seasoned. For so many bold flavors (on the page), I didn't understand how 'meh' it tasted in my mouth. Not finding success with the dry components, I mixed everything together and topped the plate with the three accompanying sauces (coconut-chili, another chili and, I think, a lime juice). By then the plate looked *really* unappealing but it tasted better.

Maybe breakfast/brunch is the better call?

*Although lately I have been there a lot!
name: Milk and Honey Nashville
categories: American (New), Restaurants, American (Traditional), Food, Breakfast & Brunch, Coffee & Tea, Pizza

text:
Very rarely do sushi restaurants impress because good sushi is simply good fish. Many places try to stand out with creative specialty rolls, but they often try too hard and go overboard. But none of this is the case at Izumi. 

We came in for date night during East Passyunk Restaurant Week, so this review is for that menu. Upon stepping in, there's definitely a very intimate feel with the dim lights, sleek furniture and votive candles. Thankfully, we made a reservation and were seated right away at the bar, which was great because there is zero standing room in this cozy spot (which we overheard someone complain about on the way out). 

For the first course, we chose then crab spring rolls and pork belly starters. The long crab spring rolls were uniquely wrapped in seaweed and then a dough wrapper. They were accompanied by spicy mayo and citrusy avocado sauces. The pork belly was deliciously glazed and flavorful, served atop Japanese risotto that resembled creamy polenta with a couple of sliced mushrooms thrown in. 

Next was a sushi sampling that was well-presented and consisted of tuna dressed in a sauce with like zest, a whitefish (I believe) with a black sesame sauce, and salmon with a sweet foam. The first two were delicious and creative without being over-the-top, while I was not a fan of the overly sweet foam on the salmon. We both agreed that the black sesame was our favorite part. 

The third course is a shrimp and asparagus tempura maki roll with lightly seared salmon and wasabi aioli on top. It's not really fancy, but it really exceeded our expectations. The plump shrimp was cooked well, and the asparagus is a nice touch. We were skeptical of the cooked salmon as part of a roll, but it was sooo good! 

Dessert was a dish of cinnamon sugar donuts and salted caramel dipping sauce. It was kind of an afterthought for me, but it was still good. 

The service was friendly and never too overbearing. We liked watching the steady (and very calm) action at the kitchen. Can't wait to return and try some of their regular menu.
name: Izumi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Desserts, Food, Japanese

text: Came here after dinner for the first time and was surprised how much I really enjoyed the UBE Black Sesame flavor. I never knew this place existed when driving by. It is small place but clean and bright. The worker was really nice, totally positive and all smiles. He encouraged us to try the flavors that we're available and even stated that a new flavor inspired my a Mexican desert will be available soon and it sounded really good. The cake and sauce that comes with the soft serve was very delicious and moist. They also have some board games onsite if you decide to stay and hang out.

text:
Embarrassed to say that we actually drove 60+ mile RT to have this treat. It was in the afternoon before 3 pm.  I had called before heading to Reno to make sure that the limited 4 flavors were available.  We got there and several people were going in.  We were being polite in our masks/social distancing but a couple families stepped in front of us. No big deal, we can wait.  Got in and able to order.  They only had three flavors and one was vanilla... After making the Ube sundae, we noticed that there was NO CAKE.  Out of cake?! THAT was the deal, fun flavor, cake, topping...  We asked about the cake.  Out of the cake.  "Do you want a topping" (that is supposed to go on the cake btw)  Ok.  As an ant walked across the sundae cup, he poured on some evaporated milk, flicking off the ant.  He handed it to us. We paid $5.74 (full price for the cake sundae) for some soft serve, (the soft serve was hollow... you know, not all soft serve - which might be ok if there had been cake inside the void) not the flavor we wanted Black Sesame; without the cake that had and ant flicked off! 
Maybe they could have placed a notice on the door that said NO CAKE and the flavors still in stock. Kind of a waste of time, waiting for others after driving over 40 minutes then disappointment with the no-cake-included treat that we paid full price for
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: Only time having ramen in Tucson. I tried the white tonkotsu and my boyfriend tried the black garlic tonkotsu. The white tonkotsu broth was very flavorful and had a creamy silkiness to it that was great. The add-ins were all great only they forgot the egg in both of our bowls. We asked the server about this and he quickly brought us out eggs. The only add-in that I could have done without was the pickled ginger. Everything else blended together well except for that.  The black garlic tonkotsu was the same as the white only had the added garlic, black sesame seeds, and maybe some sesame oil? It was pretty garlicky but had a nice, earth taste to it. However, this taste became overwhelming after awhile and my boyfriend and I switched bowls so he could get a break from it. I'm happy this place opened so we can still get our ramen fix when we're in Tucson!
name: Raijin Ramen
categories: Noodles, Japanese, Diners, Restaurants, Ramen

text: This was my second time visiting Krēm, and to my surprise they were serving black sesame soft serve! A very welcome surprise, as I was hoping they'd add the flavor to the menu since it's one of my favorites. It has a nice, nutty flavor, and isn't overly sweet, and in it's curated sundae form (adorably named "The Penguin") it had a nice balance of flavors. Both times I visited, the staff were super nice, coming around to ask us how our ice cream was and making sure we were having a good time. Definitely a place Reno needed!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Very good kaiseki restaurant with attention to detail, though a number of things were disappointing.

There is a menu from which you select dishes you would like as part of a 7 course meal. If you are (hopefully) dining with another person, then you'll be able to try almost everything on the menu. There are 7 courses, but I was able to try nearly 14 different dishes (!):

- #1 Assorted Appetizers -
I love variety and this "platter", if you will, had many distinct items - wagyu beef or pork belly, abalone, fish cakes, fried tofu, and jellyfish. The abalone was very tender and flavorful. Pork belly was unctuous. Fish cakes and tofu were surprisingly good -- great texture and flavor. Fantastic start!

- #2 Soup -
a. Clear soup with egg cake
b. Clear soup with steamed tomato
Both nothing to write home about. More of palate cleanser, I suppose?

- #3 Sashimi -
GORGEOUS presentation. Chef's selection was salmon from Japan (less oily than American), squid, and red snapper (?). The sashimi itself was nice, but not much more. I do very much appreciate the real, grated wasabi though.

- #4 Grilled Dish -
a. Lobster tail with red miso - Pretty good
b. Duck breast - Even better! They marinate this in a delicious sweet soy sauce and the tenderness is unreal. I'm glad they kept the skin on with its fat, because that added a lot to the flavor.

- #5 Steamed Dish -
a. Marinated sweet fish with roe - Awful. The flavor was extremely heavy in terms of its sweetness and smokiness. It was like eating mushy tar.
b. Steamed rock fish simmered in sweet broth - Overly sweet and salty, although quite nice

- #6 Sushi -
Chef's selection: Crab leg, scallop, and Santa Barbara (!) uni
I was expecting more. The crab leg and scallop didn't have much flavor and the uni was good, but I've had better.

- #7 Dessert -
Both desserts came with a wedge of dried persimmon, which we were instructed to eat first
a. Black sesame custard - Not very sweet, had plenty of black sesame flavor
b. Green tea custard - Very nice, wish I had more than a few spoonfuls!

Overall, the good outweighed the bad -- I'd rate it more like 3.5 stars. The food was clearly conceived by a skilled kaiseki chef. Our server was pleasant, helpful, and attentive.

Unrelated to the food/service, but I thought the interior design was strange. It was very Japanese in that it was simple with natural tones, but with Denny's-style hanging lamps over the tables, and an almost anachronous chandelier and ceiling-mounted A/C unit.

For $100, it's a reasonable price for a 7-course meal. Just make sure you don't pick some of the items I mentioned above and you'll have a lovely experience!
name: Yoichi's
categories: Restaurants, Nightlife, Japanese, Bars

text:
TLDR: Eat here now!

This is easily one of the best restaurants in New Orleans, and is my favorite Asian place I've been to in town. Chef Hao Gong and his staff are very friendly, the decor and atmosphere are perfect, and the food is incredible. My wife and I started dinner with the Malla Holla (I could eat 10 lbs of this), then the Dragon Boat and Pagoda (both were incredibly fresh). We finished off with Mama's Dumplings and the Spicy Dan Dan Noodles, both of which satisfied the broth craving that inspired our visit today. We were going to order the Black Sesame Coconut ice cream, but they we sold out, so we told them we didn't need dessert. In kindness, they gave us a scoop of the Magnolia Black Tea ice cream on the house and it was so good! Overall, tonight was one of our favorite dining experiences we've had in a long time.
name: LUVI Restaurant
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Chinese, Japanese, Shanghainese, Pan Asian, Noodles

text: We went here for a birthday dinner.   Everyone was masked and the seating was distanced appropriately so a very safe environment.  Jenna was our server and she was fantastic and very attentive.  We ordered the Whipped Feta, Cauliflower Latkes, Avocado Crispy Rice with Steak, and Fried Chicken and for dessert we had the Caramel Apple Napoleon and Black Sesame Mousse.  The Whipped Feta is absolutely amazing and the pitas they serve with it were warm and perfect.  The Latkes were delicious and you get three total.  The Avocado Crispy Rice was really good as well.  However, it didn't occur to us to ask about how the steak would be cooked so it arrived really rare which wasn't to our liking.  Jenna immediately offered to order another but we declined.  It would be delicious without any meat added and has just the right amount of heat.  The Fried Chicken was absolutely amazing and a has some heat to it.  It's perfect.  And both desserts were really delicious.
name: Butcher & Bee
categories: Middle Eastern, American (New), Restaurants, Mediterranean, Southern

text:
The closest I'll ever get to Hawaii 

tried the new spot in Collingswood: Aloha Poke Bowl

It was a delicious and great choice! 

I got the rice and spring mix with spicy tuna and spicy tofu with all the toppings offered and some black sesame seeds 

Food was fresh , portion was generous and friendly service! 

Definitely a must try I'll def be back!
name: Aloha Poke Bowl
categories: Seafood, Japanese, Poke, Food, Restaurants, Hawaiian

text:
Great additional to Reno. The owner/worker was super friendly and was eager to offer samples of their flavors.   
I personally love Ube but didn't really feel like the Ube was that strong. Matcha and black sesame were good. We resorted to black sesame with vanilla cake and condense milk. It's a great combo but I think it would taste better if the cake was sprinkled on the top or of it was layered on. It was hard to eat all the soft serve on top first and then eat all the cake on the bottom. 

Overall, $4.80 by itself or $6.80 with cake. Give them a try if you like unique asian flavor soft serve!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: I found this Ice Cream shop from Youtube and was intrigue. I love ice cream...who doesn't. They have 4 different soft serve flavours and I was able to try all 4 before choosing. I ended up ordering the Ube/Matcha combination. It was very delicious. The other 2 flavours Milo and a cereal version was good too. Since it was my first time at Yelo'd I opted for just the soft serve. However, they have many unique cookies as well and I had to also purchase the black sesame/chocolate chip cookie. Yes I was a pig! But I live in Toronto and I don't know when I'll ever come back. They do make really good cookies. If I ever come back I would get their ice cream sandwiches. Overall, this is a great Ice Cream shop on Whyte Ave. Hopefully I could come back someday.
name: Yelo'd Ice Cream
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Bakeries

text:
I saw a friend post about this place and it looked delicious so I had to try! Everything was phenomenal! I went with two friends and we decided to order multiple things to share so we could try a variety! I will definitely do more of the raw items next time because those were all delicious!

We started off with a special, the tuna meatballs. Those were actually my least favorite; they were cooked, which made them have a fishy taste.

From the raw bar, we did the Shanghai Bund which I could have had a whole plate of. So fresh and who would have thought manchego and raw fish? Amazing! We also did the Sunny D.

We did the Spicy Dan Dan Noodles, which were good! Could have used a little more flavor in them, but still good and the Mama's Dumplings!

My favorite part besides the raw bar was the dessert! We did the Pink Lady and a triple scoop of ice cream with all three flavors: Black Sesame Coconut, Dragon Fruit and Magnolia Black Tea Ice Cream! The Pink Lady was amazing; I will dream about this dessert and the coconut ice cream!

A friend also had her kid with us and the chef was so sweet and brought him a lollipop! Everyone was so kind! Will definitely be back!
name: LUVI Restaurant
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Chinese, Japanese, Shanghainese, Pan Asian, Noodles

text:
I LOVE the flavors offered here. They had matcha, ube, vanilla, and Thai tea soft cream. The matcha flavor is very strong and actually tastes like matcha; not like the sugar bombs you would get at a sushi ayce. Their flavors rotate and I cannot wait to go back when the black sesame is offered. 

We got a matcha and ube swirl with vanilla cake and red bean sauce. My favorite part is that the whole sundae was not overwhelmingly sweet. I can taste each individual flavor and it was absolutely delicious. The price is a little high, but we thought it was perfect for sharing. 

The owner was super friendly and let us taste the flavors. He let us know about the process of creating his flavors. Would definitely be back when new flavors are available!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
We finally have something new in Reno! This dessert shop is definitely instagram worthy, from their cute neon sign, to their presentation of the desserts. This is definitely a place for my Instagram foodies! 

I mean, let's be real, who doesn't love cake and ice cream?! However, this place definitely takes it to a whole new level. Their soft serve are Asian inspired so they have choices such as matcha, ube, and their newest flavor, black sesame. If you want more basic flavors, they also have your classic vanilla and chocolate. My favorite is their Ube soft serve paired with vanilla cake, drizzled with condensed milk.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: Looooove the matcha ice cream with red bean sauce!! The customer service was excellent. Hoping to try the black sesame next time. The whole family loved it.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: We arrived around 2:30pm on a Saturday and it was pretty busy, but there were still tables available. We ordered the #2 ube-be baby, #3 the Sunday, #4 the penguin. Overall, the ice cream was okay. It's a little icy and I wish it was creamier. Out of the three that we got, enjoyed the penguin the most. The black sesame had good flavor without being too sweet. The vanilla in the Sunday tasted exactly like McDonald's soft serve, except a little sweeter. I didn't enjoy how the cake was at the bottom of the cup and ice cream on top. I might've looked nice, but I couldn't enjoy them both together. We ended up asking for a cup and scooping out the ice cream.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: Went back in for my first time under new owner ship and was greeted poorly, if you could even call it that. I ordered the ube and a black sesame. These were both much smaller portions with barely any cake and both flavors were not as refined as they were. Both were very plain. I am saddened to see the old owner gone as he was extremely pleasant. The whole places energy is different. Hopefully some healthy changes are made quickly.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
KETO PARADISE!!!!!

If you live in this area and are on a Keto diet and are struggling to find places to eat out... this is the place for you. All you can eat meat and veggies cooked in a stock with sauces you curate yourself. You have complete control over everything and it's so much fun too. They even have spiralized veggie noodles and shirataki in case you miss carbs. 

I really loved Noboru as a sushi buffet. I also love Noboru as a Shabu Shabu restaurant. I only can recommend it for dinner (I have not been for lunch) where the protein options are all you can eat and there is a large buffet of vegetables, tofu, fish cakes, and noodles (including veggie noodles.) They even have dumplings!!! 
I like the multiple broth options, and I LOVE the huge vegetable and noodle buffet. I wish the pots were larger as mine tend to boil down twice. I also wish the sauce bar had a few more premade sauces maybe a peanut sauce or something a little sweeter. 

Other than that, I love dumping mushrooms, onions, tofu, and shirataki in the vegetarian broth, adding chicken to eat as I go dipped in a sauce made from ground black sesame, soy, sesame oil, and garlic; and finishing the meal with some ramen, sweet potato, or carrot noodles cooked in a very flavorful broth.
name: Noboru
categories: Restaurants, Buffets, Food, Do-It-Yourself Food, Hot Pot, Sushi Bars

text: Really liked the black sesame seed ice-cream, the people were upbeat and nice. I was not a fan of the cake but I'm picky about cake in general. Awesome concept.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: I love ice cream and this place really does something special. The flavors they have are outstanding and very friendly staff. Gotta go back to try the black sesame!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Cool restaurant with a cool vibe. Luvi (pronounced Lou - V). The restaurant is named after the owners two daughters Lulu and Violet. How cute is that?! I came here with my husband for New Year's Eve Dinner. We made reservations the night before. It was a four course dinner for the price of $65 per person and included a 20% gratuity. They offered two seatings, a 6:00 pm and an 8:00 pm seating. We went to the 6 pm seating. We arrived 30 min early as we Uber(ed) and didn't want to be late. They were nice enough to let us in but told us service didn't start until 6. That was nice of them. As 6 pm approached the restaurant started becoming packed as everyone started to arrive. The owner was also working the line with his staff. I love seeing this. He was super cool and friendly. We sat at the bar where he was working on cutting fresh fish. The staff was nice and the food was good.

The dinner on this day was from a pre-fixe menu. What I loved was that everything was served family style throughout the restaurant. Meaning they prepared everyone's dish at once and served each course to everyone at the same time. Although, everyone came with their respective guest and we didn't know one another it felt like a big family dinner. It was nice. 

There was two options for each course and three for dessert. My husband and I ordered the opposite of one another for each course and shared so we could taste everything. We started with some edamame. It was light and yummy. We also had drinks as well. That were tasty. I had the Lady in Pink and my husband had an Old Fashion.  We had Tomato Roasted Garlic Soup and Steamed Egg Custard with Gulf Shrimp for course 1. We shared Raw Scottish Salmon and Sashimi Quality Tuna for course 2. We shared Seared Jumbo Scallops and Beef Short Rib for course 3. Last, we shared the Black Sesame Coconut Ice Cream and the Magnolia Black Tea Ice Cream. All four courses were amazing. The food was fresh and the quality of ingredients was good. This was my first time having raw salmon and I must say chef aced it! I was hesitate at first. However, it did not taste fishy at all. It had a good flavor and the texture was better than I thought. The ice cream was also really good. I thought by the name of the flavors it would be very odd. However, I was wrong. My husband and I devoured both scoops of ice cream within minutes. The appetizer and main course meals were also nice and flavorful. Overall, Luvi is a good place to dine. Good people, good food at an affordable price!
name: LUVI Restaurant
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Chinese, Japanese, Shanghainese, Pan Asian, Noodles

text: Nice little place to chill out with friends. The ice cream is great, my favorite is black sesame!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
The waitstaff here is on top of things. Apologizing for long wait times and constantly topping off our drinks. 

This is the second time I have been here. Once for brunch and once for dinner. 

We started with the potato ban chan, Korean fried chicken, kimchi pancake, beef jap chae, black sesame cheesecake, and peach panna cotta.

The portions here are all very tiny. I would recommend one appetizer, one entree, and one dessert per person. 

The potatoes were nice and soft. Slightly sweet and salty. The perfect way to start off the meal. 

The Korean fried chick was good as well. We got half soy and half spicy. Nice a crispy and the meat was cooked all the way through. I wish there were more wings but oh well there are other places for that

Kimchi pancake was one of the best I have had. Small and savory. Perfect. 

The beef in the jap chae was dry like beef jerky and also had no flavor at all. The other ingredients in the jap chae were tasty. Lots of veggies. It felt healthy to eat!

The peach panna cotta was light and squishy. Almost jello like consistency and the peaches ere sweet and the oatmeal/granola was nice a crunchy. 

The black sesame cheesecake was single handily the worst dessert I have ever ordered. They must have forgotten to add sugar. It tasted like something I would spread on a bagel. Detestable. If I planned on ever coming back here I would have complained about this dish to my server. But I ain't coming back. Please take this dessert off the menu and fire your pastry chef immediately.
name: Southgate
categories: Breakfast & Brunch, American (Traditional), Korean, Restaurants, Gastropubs, Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars

text:
Uh, yum! I don't know why I always blew this place off... maybe because it's so obnoxiously "chainy." We were hungry tonight and had minimal time, so Noodles & Company it was. The place was almost empty so it was even quicker than expected!

First things first. Can you imagine how huge the smile on my face was when I found out they serve wine?! I've never been so happy to see a glass of chardonnay in my life! Granted, it was probably from a four dollar bottle, but I didn't care a bit. Unexpected wine = the best dinner experience ever, no matter the location.

And a whole restaurant dedicated to my all-time favorite carb? And in American, Mediterranean, and Asian? Pretty sweet deal! I tried to be "healthy" so I ordered the Chinese chop salad, which comes with sesame soy tossed mixed greens, Asian sprouts, cabbage, red pepper, cucumbers, carrots, crispy wontons and black sesame. I got mine with grilled chicken, and I couldn't stop eating! My other half got the Japanese pan noodles and he liked them but complained a bit about the portion size. You men and your appetites. 

I like this place! I probably won't frequent it, but when I have a carb craving I'll gladly stop in.
name: Noodles & Company
categories: Comfort Food, Restaurants, Italian, Asian Fusion, Food, American (New), Noodles, Pasta Shops, Salad, Fast Food, Specialty Food

text:
Very fresh flavors and unique. Asian inspired company and ice cream. Limited flavors but they have the standard vanilla. 

It's a standard price 6.80 per serving, mix and match on your toppings if you like or go with their paired suggestions.   

I did like the unique factor. Black Sesame as an example, different for sure. If you want to try something different, go here it's worth a visit.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
I've visited Southgate on two separate occasions. Once, after work for a beer and wings. A second time for restaurant week with a group of six. I'll definitely come back during HH for the wings (I believe $5 or $6 at that time) and a beer.  I've only had the spicy korean wings but they were great. 

The second visit with the group was underwhelming. I had the potatoes, spicy cucumbers, wings, the galbi jjim and the black sesame cheesecake for dessert. Many in the group shared that the food was inauthentic and the galbi jjim was pretty dry. I wouldn't go again for the price of restaurant week with what they were offering. (For example, the bibimbap was being served without protein and not in the stone bowl). The saving grace was the wings.

A better bet during HH or for a quick bite.
name: Southgate
categories: Breakfast & Brunch, American (Traditional), Korean, Restaurants, Gastropubs, Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars

text:
Such a great addition to Reno! The owner is very friendly. During my first visit, he was kind enough to explain the ice cream flavors and what inspired him to make them. The inside is very cute and totally instagram worthy. The soft serve ice cream itself is always on point. What I appreciate about the ice cream here is that it's not overly sweet. I absolutely love the different flavors. 

I do not enjoy the cake though. It is a bit dry and doesn't really compliment the ice cream in my opinion but that's why I get it without the cake now. 

My favorite flavors are the black sesame, Thai tea, and ube. Once the owner mentioned something about a mango lassi flavor so I am definitely looking forward to that. Can't wait to see what other flavors are added!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
This place definitely has a hipster vibe and I've been coming here a lot to taste all the flavors!

First of all, service has always been great here! The servers and owners always greet their customers upon entrance and also check on them. This place is relatively new and has great potential to grow. Parking is not bad, but the location can be easy to miss because it is located on a heavily trafficked area. 

The place is 5/5 on cleanliness and 5/5 on interior design. They also have a few small board games including UNO, miniature Connect 4 and 2 decks of regular playing cards.

Most importantly the ice cream.
I've gone here three times and so far, all my experiences have been great! I've played around with the menu a lot and I can say I have my favorites down. 
So what to get?
You can get just soft serve if you want with whichever flavor you want. They do switch out flavors though and only four flavors at a time are available. They do have combinations of soft serve, cake and sauce to choose from but you can also customize you're order. So basically pick your ice cream flavor, pick a cake, pick a sauce and you get an option to add pocky for an additional $0.60.

1st visit: I got matcha and ube swirl with vanilla cake and Red bean sauce with cookies n' cream 
2nd visit: I got Black Sesame Ice cream. (Forgot what cake and sauce)
3rd visit: I got pumpkin spice and vanilla swirl with vanilla cake with chocolate ganache and chocolate pocky. My friends got Matcha with vanilla cake and condensed milk with strawberry pocky.

So far my favorite has been my third visit. I enjoyed the pumpkin spice and matcha a lot! Although on every visit, I noticed that the cakes were quite dry. I felt it needed more of a moister cake or more sauce, one or the other. I didn't enjoy the red bean sauce too much becuase it was a little too concentrated for me, but I did enjoy the chocolate ganache a lot! Their matcha soft serve has the perfect concentration of matcha--it isn't too concentrated (which is what I was expecting). I also enjoyed the black sesame soft serve because it wasn't overpowering at all. On my next visit I want to try the Ube-Baby-Baby (I think that's what it was called).

They used to use plastic to put the ice cream and cake in and now they use paper cups. I personally like this better because I can reach for the cake with sauce much faster. I do enjoy the ice cream a lot, but I personally want to eat them all at once. With the plastic ones I had to finish the ice cream first before I got to the cake and sauce. 

I do wish sauce was added to the ice cream and had more toppings, but overall I do think this place is still pretty awesome!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
A friend of mine brought me here while I was visiting her family in St. Peters, and it was all that she described and more! We sampled a few macarons (black sesame, red velvet and I think hazelnut...) and they were all very tasty. I also ordered a pain au chocolat and a latte, and my friend ordered a tiramisu brownie, and everything was delightful.

I knew that my boyfriend would love The Darkness croissant and he also loves toffee, so I picked those up to take home. They were kind enough to double wrap the croissant for my trip back, and I kept it frozen until we ate it. It was a great item to share- it's so rich. We also like that the toffee is tasty and does not feel like you're going to break your teeth, lol. I will definitely go back whenever I am in the area!
name: La Patisserie Chouquette
categories: Cafes, Food, Bakeries, Restaurants

text: Housed in the airy and sunlight filled Mosaic Centre, it looks like they have what will be a great patio in the summer outside. Service is friendly and hands down the place to go for brunch in the city (within city limits). Simple, fresh and well executed is what you expect from the woodshop eatery. Booking was a breeze as we had a larger party with kids and I called ahead. Kids menu check. Specialty coffees or spiked coffees for tired parents? Check. Great brunch items? Double check. Uses local ingredients and suppliers like Irving Farms bacon, 4Whistle Farm eggs and Bon Ton Bakery breads? Check. On site gardens to harvest herbs and greens once we get our 3 months of summer? Yup! I somehow mistaken the burger for a steak sandwich, and should have added the aged cheddar as their housemade tomato jam needed more salty savory to balance out each bite. The burger was a bit in the dry side... but the winners were the brunch items: the bbq smoked brisket eggs benny and the fried chicken and waffles. One of the best buttermilk fried chicken I've had in a while... and the kids loved it.. on of my gfs only ended up eating her waffle cuz her kid ate all her chicken lol! Have a friend who happens to work nearby and they knock it out of the park for catering. We were pretty stuffed and share desserts - a velvety smooth creamy creme caramel with saskatoon compote and almond tulle, and we loved the layers of light airy chocolate mousse and flourless chocolate cake paired with Pinocchio's excellent sesame icecream and raspberry jam. If they had added a touch of black sesame element to cake to tie it in with thr icecream, would have blown that dessert out of the water. Overall a great place for brunch, with the option of letting restless kids stretch their legs in the roomy atrium of the centre (tired them out so they dont fuss!) that features a living greenery wall).
name: The Workshop Eatery
categories: Restaurants, Canadian (New)

text:
I am a sucker for IG-worthy desserts (Don't judge me - technically I'm a millennial so can't help it) and adore soft serve so when traveling through Reno, KRĒM stood out as the best spot for a post-dinner treat. The idea is simple: Clear plastic cones filled with cake and sauce, topped with a tall swirl of ice cream. Their menu lists four curated options, or you can put together your own custom treat. There are four flavors of ice cream (I think this may change, but on our visit, it was matcha, ube, vanilla, and black sesame), vanilla or chocolate cake, and four sauces: strawberry, chocolate ganache, sweetened condensed milk, and red bean. 

My hubby kept it simple, ordering "I Love You So Matcha" off the "pre-set" menu. I like to make things complicated, so put together my own: chocolate cake and ganache + ube and black sesame swirl. They offer to add Pocky sticks but I declined....why?! Though they were consistently busy, orders were prepared within no more than five minutes. Conveniently, they are served with a spoon, so you can dig down past the ice cream into the cake and eat it all together. The cake was basic, but good. Fairly moist, with large crumb. My ganache sort of melded into the cake, so it was difficult to try it separately, but nothing tasted artificial, so I'm happy with that. I wasn't sure what my husband would think of the red beans, but he liked them! For the ice cream, matcha is not shy AT ALL - it is green and grassy, and if you love that tea, you'll be all about it. I found it a tad overwhelming for my taste, but again, it was natural, so no complaints. The black sesame ice cream was my favorite. It was sweeter than I imagined, with none of the bitter notes (that I enjoy!) usually accompanying sesame, but it did have good nutty flavor. The color is a stunning dark grey. Ube had no noticeable flavor beyond "sweet," but again, killing it in the color department with that vibrant purple. My one complaint: The ice cream almost hardened on the outside. Not unforgivably icy, but also not luscious and rich, almost like it had a base made entirely of milk or with added water. 

The interior is small, but there is enough seating for 15 or so people. It was clean, with self-serve water available. Employees were sweet as can be. At just under $7 per cone for good, if not stupendous ice cream, just own up to the fact that you want a cool IG photo (can't beat the "I licked it so it's mine" neon sign), and you still get a pretty decent dessert out of it, too.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Hello to my favorite new Dunedin restaurant! First of all, I have a soft spot for old houses turned into restaurants. I just love them. The Honu has a dining area, a bar, and a great dog-friendly patio with ample umbrella shade. Bright colors and cute interior throughout the restaurant. Parking is limited, but welcome to downtown Dunedin. Most restaurants will require you to park down the street and walk. 

The menu has lots of items I was interested in and most could be made vegetarian or vegan. They have everything from local craft beer to mimosas, or specialty cocktails. They also offer alkaline water in addition to "Dunedin's finest tap". They also have a delightful iced tea flavored with juice. We ordered the white bean and olive dip with house made sage crackers. The presentation on this appetizer was surprising and lovely. It was great! I ordered the poke and my vegan gentleman friend had the white bean and olive burger with sweet potato fries. The poke was excellent. It came with a nice stack of sushi rice, perfectly marinated tuna, scallions, and black sesame seeds. The veggie burger was big and flavorful. 

All of their menu items seemed delicious and everything we saw had excellent presentation. Add in a delightful staff and a restaurant that's family and veteran owned, I am in. We will be back soon!
name: The Honu
categories: Poke, Breakfast & Brunch, Parks, Mexican, Soup, Nightlife, Food, American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Music Venues, Active Life, Sandwiches, Tiki Bars, Hawaiian, Seafood, Arts & Entertainment, Dog Parks, Tex-Mex, Salad

text: I love their black sesame ice cream! I think they had it for a short period of time. It was different but good! Their Ive and green tea ice cream is a must to try when you go to this place. Although it's a little pricey for an ice cream, I think it's worth the price since matcha is expensive. Customer service is excellent as well.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Saturday Sweetness

Food

Black Sesame, Matcha, Ube!? It was a little different than your typical visit to Dairy Queen, but real good.

I opted for the Matcha / Ube swirl with, Vanilla Cake, drizzled with Condensed Milk. And to top it all off, Pocky. Because I was feeling a little extra that night, I opted to get them all. Cookies and Cream, Chocolate, Strawberry, and Matcha.

Service

By chance I got the opportunity to meet one of the owners, Casey. He took the time to let my girlfriend and I ask all of our curious questions and sample every flavor available before we made our selection. 

I would reccomend this place to anyone looking for a light sweet treat.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
As a poor college student, "luxury" ice cream isn't really something I can get on the regular, but when I'm craving it, KRĒM is always my first choice! The soft serve flavors are incredibly well balanced and not too overwhelming while also maintaining a smooth and creamy texture. The real secret of KRĒM though is mixing your soft serve into the cake; you never realize how great the combo is until you mix it together. 
On top of the quality of the food, the staff is always incredibly friendly and I'm always greeted happily whenever I go in with friends or family! 
You have a wonderful staff and environment with good ice cream all for an extremely reasonable price! If you love asian inspired flavors (ube, green tea, black sesame), then KRĒM is the perfect ice cream shop for you!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
From the cute decorations inside, to the amazing flavors, to the customer service, KRĒM exceeds my expectations of ANY ice cream or frozen yogurt shop. 

You've probably seen Instagram pictures of their notorious "I licked it so it's mine" neon sign, which is most certainly one of the best backdrops for an ice cream picture ever. But besides the aesthetics, when me and my boyfriend came into the shop we were greeted with very cheery faces. I felt so welcomed and excited to be getting a delicious treat! The owner was working, and he greeted us with samples of the Black Sesame flavor. It's a very interesting taste, and not really my cup of tea, however I'm sure that other people would like it. Personally, I loved the Ube and Matcha flavors - sooooo good! While we waited for our orders to be made, the owner chatted it up with us (he's super nice!). 

There's so much more I could say about this place. Overall, I loved it and highly suggest you go try it out :)
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
The all you can eat style dinner is one of my favorite meals for winter - a nice warm broth, loads of meat and seafood, extra humidity for those with parched skin? What more can you ask for. Edmonton seems to have exploded in hot pot restaurants, with Asian Express Hot Pot the first to serve individual pots. Then came Urban Shabu by the dim sum owners of Urban China. Not long after, 97 Hot Pot right across the street. If three hot pot restaurants wasn't enough for Edmontonians, two more have opened since my last hot pot review: Bobo Hot Pot (15326 Stony Plain Road) and Chili Hot Pot (7219 - 104 St), and with another Asian Express Hot Pot location on the way! Bonkers.

Anyways! I've been to Urban Shabu numerous times now and have enjoyed all of my visits. I'm going to say I never blogged about it because all my photos were of lamb slices piled over top of each other every time I went out with Joe and his friends. They love lamb. This time around, my dinner dates ordered a good variety of meat cuts, seafood, vegetables, and noodles though so I figured a post was due. 

Individual pots are the way to go. You can keep track of what you put into your soup and not have to worry about what everybody else is doing! I won't lie, there's been times when I've forgotten a thing or two in the pot and by the end of the meal it's more of a guessing game of what it actually was.

My go-to dishes are the handmade mashes and that goes for any hot pot place. It's hard to compare the taste of the mashes when my visits are so far and few in between but Urban Shabu's is still delicious. I don't know why I enjoy sectioning off pieces of mash and watching them expand into balls in my soup pot, but I do. Call me a weirdo. Make sure you section it into pieces though (roughly 3 - 4 pieces per order) or else you'll just get one large lumpy ball of seafood. Other favorites of mine: lamb slices (Joe rubbed off on me!), beef tripe, fried bean curd (unpictured), and mounds of baby bok choy and spinach!

It was a Wednesday night, so service was excellent as the restaurant wasn't jam-packed with people. I've never seen the sauces at the sauce table empty before which leads me to believe they maintain it quite often, refilling the popular ones such as soy sauce, hoisin sauce, and oyster sauce. The best part of Urban Shabu is the concern for the "post hot pot" smell. If the restaurant was full, and fifty little pots of soups and spices were boiling away, cooking whatever your heart desired... that steam has to go somewhere. I'll tell you where it goes! It goes into your hair, your skin, your clothes! You can't go anywhere else after hot pot, the shower is your destined location. But with Urban Shabu, it's not so bad. The ventilation is the best of the three restaurants in Chinatown, plus they have purple seat covers for your jackets if you request them. Thumbs up!

Another thing people like about Urban Shabu? Dessert. They offer more than your usual vanilla or strawberry ice cream. They've got sweet tofu pudding, mango creme sweet soup (it's served cold, with tapioca), and a delicious version of longan berry jello ("cake" on their menu) that won't fall apart on you when you pick it up. Love. They also have Japanese style sesame balls which I haven't tried yet, and green tea or black sesame ice cream.

My personal preference is Urban Shabu and it always has been. I think the clean modern look, clear windows with no condensation, and the way my hair smells afterwards is a big factor. Food wise though, they're all pretty similar. 97 Hot Pot had more of a consistency with how they plate their dishes, especially the meat cuts, making it easier to gauge how many plates to order. I also thought 97 Hot Pot had fresher cuts of meat as well. The mashes, like I said, are hard to compare. Service wise, Urban Shabu does a good job even when it's busy. Some of my friends love 97 Hot Pot though because of their service button, just press it at your table and tada! Help is on the way. If you need a full array of sauces and easy access to them though, Asian Express Hot Pot takes the cake. I believe they're cheaper too? I haven't been there in a while. OH! And Urban Shabu doesn't do half pots, you know, where they split the pot with a divider so you have a spicy side. Best get your sauce concoction down and add some heat there instead. Does it all really matter though? Not really. Hot pot = WIN.
name: Urban Shabu
categories: Chinese, Soup, Hot Pot, Restaurants

text:
I came here twice in one week because it was so yummy. You can't go wrong with ice cream and cake especially when it's in a cute presented really pretty! its simple- pick your cake (chocolate or vanilla), ice cream ( green tea, taro, black sesame), and syrup (condensed milk, chocolate, strawberry). Highly recommend giving this place a shot!

PS the only bummer part is that its a bit difficult to scoop the ice cream and cake in the cup.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Came by one night for dinner with friends, and I have to say I was a little underwhelmed. This is a chain restaurant specializing in the Japanese yakiniku dining experience, however, you do have to cook all the meats yourself. It's not an all you can eat restaurant, so to really get full, you end up having to order a lot of meat, or a lot of side dishes. Perhaps the restaurant was over hyped and I had very high expectations, but it definitely hasn't been something I've been craving or wanting to go back for.

First we started off with the Spicy Cold Tofu, Spicy Cabbage Salad, and Steamed Chili Dumplings. All three of these dishes pretty much had the same flavour profile topped with a lot of crunchy garlic. Although it was very tasty, I felt like we were eating the same dish over and over again.

Next up was the Fried Bacon Chips and Fried Chicken Karaage. Both dishes were nice and crispy. Fried to a perfect golden brown. Nothing bad to say about these dishes, but nothing that really impressed me either. We also tried the Shrimp Garlic Noodles that everyone has been raving about. Best dish of the night, but was still lacking in umami and garlic flavour.

We then moved onto the BBQ meats. We ordered the Harami Skirt Steak, Kalbi Short Rib, Toro Beef, Pork Toro, and Duck Breast. The meat was all well marinated and tender. However, because you are cooking it yourself, you have to be very attentive as all the cuts are very thin, and you risk overcooking them!

Lastly, we finished off with Taiyaki Pancake, and Frosty Tropic Sorbet. Be careful not to burn the Taiyaki pancake! You end up having to flip it every 10 seconds. Flavour was good and it came with a choice of green tea or black sesame ice cream. The sorbet was nice and refreshing. Great way to end the meal. 

I did really like the ventilation system they have. You don't end up leaving smelling like BBQ meats all night! I would probably give this another try during their happy hour, but I just didn't feel like it was worth it for dinner.
name: Gyu-Kaku Japanese BBQ
categories: Restaurants, Barbeque, Asian Fusion, Japanese

text:
First off I love their carson location and I think this might have even been tastier!!!!!! 

Yelp 25 % off ayce with yelp check in, score!!!!

The inside is so pretty and well decorated, and I love the location! It's so so so close to my condo, and traders Joe's where I shop.

So after mom and I went to traders we squeezed in during the last 30 minutes till close, and they were totally cool about it. I recognized the owner from the carson location in the back.

The rolls omg just that perfect thin layer to cover but not over shadow the seaweed and fish, stick and sweet and tangy (rice white vinegar and sugar, held together seamlessly on all the rolls.

Mom ordered the Fuji and said the raw fish was some of the freshest she has had anywhere local, including minatio and hinko. The shrimp inside had a lovely crunch with out being too oily.

I order three rolls and loved the presentation on all of them as well as the spicy level.

The cici with no salmon (they were totally cool about it too) had wicked hot white sauce on it spicier than sriracha, but I loved it!!! The scallops were super fresh and the other tangy sauce paired nicely with the ripe avocado and the cream cheese was a needed to balance out the spice level. 

The moon dog poppers had crunch jalapeño with the seeds taken out so it was much less spicy than the other roll, paired well with spicy crab and a crispy tempura case, and cream cheese filled innards.

Then the two next rolls were sooooo artistically done both my mom and I were taken back. Plated on craved wood the sauce designs were truly magical as you can see in the pictures!!! 

The volcano had the delicately fried out side, and was pipping hot, with the soft eggy sweet tamago inside and huge sweet scallops on top with a spice sauce and sauce all around the plate to drag through. 

The samurai was prob my fav. The huge chunks of pecans were such a lovely bit of nutty texture, to the cream cheese and fluffy fried shrimp, topped with again huge chunky scallops and black sesame seeds with 2 creamy spice sauces. Then again plated like a a piece from a museum!!

I can't not wait to go back and try more of the unique rolls and see the art they dish up.
name: Kei Sushi
categories: Asian Fusion, Desserts, Sushi Bars, Food, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Only place I could find in the area that has ube soft serve!!!!

Conveniently located across the street from the Atlantis Tesla chargers, so we can park the car and walk over for some dessert :P

They rotate flavors, with only about 3 - 4 different ones per day.
It's not like your standard froyo place, so don't expect the typical flavors or a huge selection.

They have flavors like ube, horchata, matcha, and black sesame, and you have the option to have it over some cake!

I went with just the soft serve since we had AYCE KBBQ right before, and it was delicious! so we'll definitely be back for more!

Small parking lot in front, friendly employees, Instagrammable decor ;), treat your tastebuds and give it a try if you haven't already!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Black Sesame ice cream was FREAKIN AMAZING! Came across this place while on vacation in Reno. So happy we did. The man and woman behind the counter were so nice and friendly. You are able to taste the flavors available that day before you choose your dessert. They had black Sesame, macha, ube, and vanilla. Don't get me wrong the ube and macha were good but the black Sesame was different and it was DELICIOUS. The best way to describe it was a smoothly almost coco chocolate taste. You can select the ice cream of your choice, cake (place on the bottom) a sauce of your choice like strawberries, chocolate, and condensed milk. 
Ugh...I've been crazy the ice cream, badly!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: Love this place! I've come here a few times and every time is is awesome! The flavors are always delicious and very authentic to the original thing. Like the Ube reminds me of when I was younger and would get that flavor for a birthday cake... and the Thai tea legit tastes like the real deal. Matcha green tea is also delicious as well as the black sesame! If you grew up with these Asian flavors it'll make you feel nostalgic! Also the owner is so nice! Highly recommend!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
As other Yelpers have mentioned this is a great concept and the first of its' kind in Tampa. The tapas\sushi conveyor belt idea is fun and interesting. All of the bubble saucer plates, shouts from the cooks, "Yo Yo", put us into sensory overload. If you are an indecisive person this is not the restaurant for you. The plates of sushi and other dishes swirl at  a fast pace. I grabbed at least 2 plates on impulse. Bring a calculator because each plate is a different price based on color. For example the green plate is 3 dollars and the yellow plate is 7 dollars ( I wonder if color blind people pay more because of this). Breakdown of some of items  that I tried:

Iced Green Tea: Matcha based, excellent quality, and free refils: 5/5
California Roll (purple plate): Average flavor not real crab I have had better at most resturants: 2/5
Black Sesame Dorayaki (purple plate) Love the raspberry sauce, great sesame flavor, ate 2 plates: 5/5
Chicken Fire Cracker Rice (orange plate): Decent well seasoned, not spicy, not much chicken: 3.5/5
Chicken Katsu (orange plate): Solid choice, good sauce, fair portion: 4/5

In the future I will avoid the sushi and order more hot entrees. I enjoyed most of the chicken dishes. For lunch with tip my wife and I payed just under $50.00 dollars and were still hungry. Next time I will control my impulses and study the menu more before grabing plates.
name: YO! Sushi
categories: Sushi Bars, Fast Food, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Review #141 - 2019

About a year ago, I came here & left disappointed because they were closed for 5 days while I was here around Thanksgiving time--which was understandable & forgivable.

Luckily, this time we showed up during summer since the kids had just finished school & I wanted to take them out to enjoy a few days of good eating.

We showed up around 6 PM on Monday, June 10th, and the place was actually pretty quiet.  I expected it to be a lot busier considering it was 93-degrees out, but I was fine with not having to fight the crowd.

The 3 kids got almost exactly the same thing, the matcha/vanilla, while my other nephew got the ube & I went with the ube/black sesame.

I really wanted to give this place a 5-star review since the people here are very friendly & accommodating.

The place is small, but clean and still felt comfortable with the table arrangements.  I love the cute set up, especially their Instagram wall.

The kids really enjoyed their dessert & I liked mine too, but I wish it was a little less sweet & a little creamier.  It didn't really taste like soft serve ice cream, more of a sorbet texture, which I wouldn't mind if it was more of a fruity flavor.

Portion seemed much bigger than I expected so I couldn't finish the whole thing, even with my daughter's help.

The kids had a nice time hanging out there playing Uno for about an hour.

We'll definitely be back in the future.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
If you are a lover of home made pot pies but want to skip the cooking, this is THE place.  It's taken a while to get here, as our pups' vet and groomers are located in this strip center, but this will certainly be in our regular rotation.

After checking out the reviews on Yelp! I scanned the pix for the menu, as the website doesn't list ingredients.  I placed the order online Monday for a Tuesday afternoon pickup (pups at the groomers).  Ordered the chicken and the beef/Guinness pot pie as well as a beef/mushroom and pork/yam empanada.  Super easy to do, just remember that the pies are usually made fresh and take about an hour...so keep that in mind...perfection takes time!!).  Without fail, the pups were done 2 hours early, so called to see if we could move the order up.  They said they had the chicken ready, but the beef/Guinness would take about an hour.  So they offered the Gumbo in exchange, which they had ready for inventory.  The empanadas only take about 8 minutes to make.  That worked great for us.

The place is set up for take out only, though there are picnic tables set up that are shared with another eatery.  You walk into the place and you are hit by the savory smells of fresh baking pies (they should make a candle in this scent!!).  Very helpful, friendly staff and had my order ready to go in minutes.  Had to ask how to reheat non-frozen pies (300 degrees for about 30 minutes, though a meat thermometer is highly suggested, as the pies are fully cooked and just need to be heated to serving temperature).  Smelled so good in the car they almost didn't make it home!

Unless your ravenous, the pies are easily sharable, as are the empanadas.  These are real pot pies, with flakey, buttery crust encasing the fillings.  We had the chicken pot pie along with the beef/mushroom empanada.  More than enough for the 2 of us for dinner.  After popping them in the oven for around 20 minutes, they were hot and ready.  The pot pie filling was absolutely delicious, complimented by the savory crust.  Filled with onions, carrots, celery, corn, peas and lots of chicken.  The beef/mushroom empanada is encased in a black sesame dough, filled with beef, mushrooms and peas in a dark savory gravy.  Again, perfect size for dinner...though I could have easily overeaten, it was soooo gooood!!!

We'll have the other pie and empanada for dinner tonight.  2 dinners for under $30 with the taste of homemade.  Yeah, we'll be back to try the other items.  

Highly recommend this place as a regular go-to.
name: emPIEnada
categories: Event Planning & Services, Restaurants, Empanadas, Caterers, Food, Desserts, Comfort Food, American (Traditional), Food Trucks

text:
I came around 7 pm on April 14th. The quality of the dessert here combined with the delicious exotic flavors make this place the most delicious ice cream I've had in ages! The soft serve is so creamy. I got black sesame flavor and it's sweet and mildly nutty and creamy, so good! The cake they use is so moist and buttery. (I got vanilla with condensed milk) I was very surprised and now obsessed. 

The guy working was so nice and helpful describing the flavors. He had a great attitude and so friendly! 10/10 service
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
My favorite ice cream in town! Everyone who works here is extremely friendly and welcoming. My favorite flavor is black sesame so try it when you can! As far as COVID, they're taking all the precautions with face masks, gloves, blocked off seating etc. but special mention to the owner (I believe) for taking extra time to clean all the door knobs and chairs outside frequently. 
I appreciate you, Krēm please never leave me!
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text: I ordered the chocolate wasted.  The soft serve was very good, the cake was a little dry but still tasty. The location is convenient and trendy inside with friendly staff.  I also tried the matcha and black sesame flavors. I enjoyed them but couldn't eat an entire serving.
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
Went to Krēm today! I was SO excited to try it out after all the hype I saw on Instagram. Walking in, I was a bit disappointed because the ambience didn't add up to the one being boasted on insta. THE ICECREAM IS TO DIE FOR! So delicious. It's a generous portion as well. Super pleased with it overall and can't wait to go back! 
PS: I recommend the black sesame
name: KRĒM
categories: Restaurants, Creperies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Food

text:
I came back from visiting the Missouri Botanical Garden over Labor day weekend.  My timing was perfect since I was able to catch the Japanese Festival.  However, I was really tired and just wanted to check-in without dealing with airport parking, etc.  After reading some reviews, I opted to park temporarily in the 15 minute space to see whether my Gold membership got me some perks.

CHECK-IN AND PARKING ****
$10 for 24hr parking but Gold membership got me $5 for parking.  Someone on Yelp mentioned getting free parking but I don't mind the $5 discount.  The front parking gate card reader was denying access after front desk programmed my room keys.  I tried the back parking gate reader as well with same problem.  At least the back parking lot had a speaker button which dialed to front desk so that they could open the gate for me.  

Front desk searched a bit for room upgrade.  Eventually, she found corner king suite with 2 rooms- separate bedroom and living room.  YESSS!!! I overheard the guest checkin a few minutes later looking for similar room.  Beat him to the room within minutes.  The front desk also got me free fountain drink voucher, appetizer voucher, and breakfast buffet voucher.  ALL THREE- THE TRIFECTA!!!

KING SUITE ****
Missing Peter Thomas Roth body wash so called room service.  Got 2 bottles within minutes from housekeeping.  Great view of the airport from both bedroom and living room.  Dropped off my luggage and went downstairs for quick bite to eat.

RESTAURANT ****
I had a ginger ale with Ahi tuna seared with black sesame seed crusted.  Quick and wonderful service.  Would have liked to try local brew but voucher only good for non-alcoholic drinks.

SWIMMING POOL ****
Yes, there were many families but loved the 9ft deep end to go for dives.  Housekeeping was there to stock up on towels for us.  I did a couple of laps and then headed to room for the night.

FITNESS CENTER ****
Woke up early to get a workout in.  Found the stairmaster similar to the one in the Double Tree Chesterfield.  Got my 30 minutes in before a morning shower followed by breakfast buffet.

BREAKFAST BUFFET ****
Got an omelet made to order at the grill.  The rest of the buffet was wonderful with plenty of fruit.  I also found small boxes of almond milk and chose the chocolate flavor.  I also found a nice spread of smoked salmon but didn't want to risk it.  The coffee was quite bitter.  Overall, I loved this hotel which reminded me alot of George Clooney's "Air Up There".  I would recommend this to anyone who needs a relaxing vacation.
name: Hilton St. Louis Airport
categories: Event Planning & Services, Hotels & Travel, Automotive, Parking, Hotels

text: I came here on a Tuesday night and it was really crazy. The organization of this place was pretty messy. The register is located at the back of the store, which is pretty confusing. You have to pay for your order, then wait for them to call your name, instead of waiting in a line. The staff has to go around shouting your name and searching around the store for you in order to start making your ice cream, which is pretty inefficient. We waited over 30 minutes before being called...I do appreciate the unique Asian flavors this place offers such as Thai tea, taro, and black sesame. The decor and music was nice. It's not the best ambiance to hang out in as it is super loud from all the chopping. The place cod just use more structure and organization. They also have two boards with the ice cream flavors, but nothing displaying the toppings, so it took everyone a lot of time asking the staff every time. The ice cream is on the pricey side, $8. It was tasty, but a bit unnecessary chopping. I've been to several rolling ice cream places where they smash the toppings into the ice cream, but instead this place just adds it on top. Lastly, the spoons were not durable at all. It kept bending every time you would try and scoop up your ice cream. Although I appreciate the twist on flavors, the chaos and disorganization made the experience underwhelming.
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
A little expensive but the ice cream is pretty good! I got the black sesame (dark matter) and added some strawberries.

Great location and atmosphere though

Would recommend, the flavors are unique and not your typical vanilla or chocolate etc
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: I was a little apprehensive when walking up to the building wondering how this little place could have such good reviews.
