I am glad I listened to my fellow Yelpers and continued inside because the food experience was remarkable!  The restaurant outside is deceptive as to the food that you'll experience inside; the interior has dark wood booths, three chef's tables and a bar in a separate area and is low lit at night with it's red glass hanging lights and strung mini Italian lights. There is a small section for nightly entertainment as well, and tonight we enjoyed the music of a very talented piano player who upon request played "our song" In My Life.  He had a good voice and played a variety of music.  Our server, Alyssa, was warm and friendly and made good suggestions of what to try on the menu.  She provided very good service and allowed us to leisurely enjoy our meal.  We ordered sangrias upon being greeted...him the house, me the chai. Refreshing and fruity.  Chill is all about small plates and sharing. Not your typical tapas, Chill's portions are plentiful for small plates. There is a wide variety of choices from salad, soups, cheeses, pasta, seafood and meat. We sat at one of the chef's table and watched the chefs in action.  The chefs, Steve and Paul, create fantastic food that can compare to any upscale restaurant in my hometown Chicago. Beautifully presented, the food at Chill is incredible. We started with the goat cheese tapenade terrine, goat cheese layered with sundried tomatoes, figs and olives finished with a sherry reduction and served with crostini.  Very tasty.  Next, we had the roasted stuffed dates, which were the size of a golf ball, filled with Gorgonzola and wrapped in prosciutto then roasted and served on wilted spinach with a blue cheese drizzle and a balsamic glaze. An explosion of gooey goodness in my mouth!  I've never tasted stuffed dates better than these...sorry Meson Sabika.  Then we had the ahi tuna, encrusted with white and black sesame seeds and seared to perfection. This sushi grade tuna was served rare and came with a wasabi cream, ginger and a yummy seaweed salad.  Next we enjoyed the margherita flatbread, a crispy thin flatbread topped with tomatoes, garlic, mozzarella, basil leaves and pesto. I loved the texture of the crust layered with flavors against the melted cheese...yum. We were full at this point but the danger of watching the chefs in action meant we had to try just one more plate....so we had the Kobe beef sliders.  Kobe beef topped with Gorgonzola mousse, mushrooms, port wine reduction on a pretzel roll and served with rutabaga fries.  What??  I would never eat a fry again if I could find these yummy vege fries on other menus. By the way, the sliders were ahhhmazing!  I cannot say enough good things about this wonderful little restaurant. The atmosphere at night with music, the great service and the delicious food ... yup, I will put this on my list for my next vacation to St Pete Beach. By the way, Chill serves breakfast and brunch, too. I can only imagine....
name: Chill Restaurant & Bar
categories: Restaurants, Tapas Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Seafood

text:
My friend and I came here on a Wednesday for Center City Sips and ordered exclusively off of the Center City Sips menu.

We started off with $6 cocktails - I had Charlie's Punch (changes daily) and my friend had The Red Sparrow (red raspberry infused hornitos plata, lime, agave). We also each had a $4 beer off of the Center City Sips draft specials - the Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold and the River Horse Roly Poly Pils. Both were solid beers on the lighter side.

To eat, we shared the Potato Croquettes and Korean Style Fried Tofu. The croquettes were slightly crispy on the outside and pillowy soft on the inside. The chipotle aioli served with them was amazing - I don't know how they were able to achieve something so mayo-like with no dairy or eggs, but it was addicting. We also shared the Korean Style Fried Tofu (spicy glaze, black sesame, garden pickles). It was pretty spicy, but delicious.

I can't wait to come back and try some of the other cocktails and food!
name: Charlie Was a Sinner
categories: Bars, Nightlife, Kosher, Burgers, Tapas/Small Plates, American (Traditional), Vegan, Seafood, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Vegetarian

text:
A vegan cocktail lounge that has a fantastic and creative drink menu.  I've been here for drinks before, but a bunch of friends and I decided to go one night for dinner this past weekend.  We were fortunate enough to grab a table on Open Table and I highly recommend you make reservations if you want to dine here so that you don't have to wait a long time.

I was super excited to try the food here, as I've thoroughly enjoyed the drinks (4-stars for them).  It's a great cocktail spot, and as much as it pains me to say it, their food did not do it for me.  I wanted to like it so bad, but it was either bland and tasteless, some of the flavors just didn't work, or the texture was completely off/weird.

If you're into smoky drinks, definitely get the penicillin - comes with smoky candied ginger pieces on it too!

Spring Rolls - three long spring rolls served with this chunky sauce (the chunks are said to be pineapple, based on the menu, but it tasted more like apricot).  The spring rolls barely had any filling in them and honestly, tasted just like regular spring rolls from a Thai or Chinese restaurant.  The sweet potato was completely drowned out by the shell and tofu.  The sauce is also difficult to use because it's extremely chunky - you need a spoon to essentially spread it on, you can't dip it.

Smoked Cauliflower - complete MISS.  Now, it was my fault for going in thinking these were either going to be fried or similar to a smoky Korean bbq style, but it was neither - pieces of cauliflower that were brushed with some burnt smoky flavor.  The raisins and pine nuts are nice compliments with the smokiness of this dish, but you would taste the burnt flavor on the first bite, but the cauliflower is so hearty, that you then just taste dry raw cauliflower immediately after.  These either need to be smoked for longer, or soaked in something.

Avocado Toast - this was pretty good.  The bread was crispy and charred, so everything would fall apart when I'd try to take a bite.  There's real slices of avocado on it, which is slightly different than what I've been used to.  The habanero mayo is a really tasty touch. Definitely worth trying.

Bao Bun - my favorite!  This little sandwich was delicious!  The bun was delicious and melted in your mouth...it was slightly sweet, which was a perfect combo with the strong bbq taste from the sandwich.  This was savory and a bit too salty for a few of my friends.  Highly recommend this dish!

Crab Cake - personally, I didn't like the texture of this dish at all.  It was very stringy zucchini, and I guess they're trying to resemble actual crab cake (one of my friends who isn't vegetarian mentioned that this is the closest resemblance of crab cake she's ever seen), so if you're into that, go for it.  I wasn't.

Korean Fried Tofu - this was definitely my 2nd favorite dish.  I was quite shocked it was tofu when I took my first bite because the tofu was very heavy and firm...almost paneer-like texture, which I don't mind at all.  The sauce was sweet and spicy, with black sesame seeds.  It was very good, but I think it needs to eaten with something - rice or noodles - for it to be complete.  Also, I don't think the term 'bbq' quite describes it, as it wasn't really barbecued, but more fried with this darker sauce.

Overall, we at least enjoyed ourselves and it's always fun to try new places.  I'll definitely come back from the drinks (good date spot), but I won't stay for the food.
name: Charlie Was a Sinner
categories: Bars, Nightlife, Kosher, Burgers, Tapas/Small Plates, American (Traditional), Vegan, Seafood, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Vegetarian

text:
I've had my eye on this cute, trendy cafe for a while, so yesterday, after a long, hot day at work, I decided to stop by and give myself a treat. The cafe was clean and modern, with excellent decor, tantalizing pictures of food, and bright colors abound. I ordered a sesame egg waffle (only $2.75!), grabbed a table, and watched the young server behind the counter make the waffle right in front of me. 

She looked bored and angsty, so I smiled and commented on her demeanor. After a couple of exchanges, she asked if I knew Chinese. Yes, both Mandarin and Cantonese! Turns out her sour service earlier was simply due to a long day and inhibited conversation with English-speaking folks. She transformed from a sour waitress to a bubbly expressive one once the language barrier was removed! (So, 4 stars for service.)
 
The sesame waffle was handed over to me wrapped in wax paper in a brown paper bag. It smelled amazing. I didn't know how to eat it so I ripped off the bulbs in the waffle one by one. (Whereas normal square waffles have pockets, these have the opposite -- they bulge out.) The inside was fluffy, soft, and sweet, and infused with black sesame. It was heaven.

Look on the walls across from the counter for three delightful paintings of Chinese cooks in the act of preparing pizza, noodles, and stir-fried vegetables. I don't see art featuring Asian-Americans much, so I asked to take pictures of them to save.

Took a menu with me to go. Everything was translated into perfect English. I can't wait to be back to try the green tea waffle, shaved ice, and the kimchi rice. If you are looking for a drink, go across the street to Bread Top House --- much cheaper there, but of excellent quality (fresh fruit!!!)
name: Cube Cafe
categories: Asian Fusion, Coffee & Tea, Chinese, Restaurants, Food

text:
I said it before and I will say it again.  Take whatever trend is happening in LA and 5 years later it will make its way to Santa Barbara.  We finally have a Thai ice cream place here and the business was booming.  Its a little like coldstone creamery.  They mix a cup of ice cream base and your choice of flavor on a super cold piece of metal, flatten it out, and chisel/push it off the surface with a metal spatula so it looks like giant chocolate shavings.  They have some unique Asian flavors that you don't see in McConnells or Ben and Jerry's such as Thai tea, taro, and black sesame.  

I got the Thai tea, which needed to be stronger in tea flavor.  Kids got the oreo and cream (good and basic) and banana and nutella (very fresh banana flavor).  Each ice cream came with 3 free toppings.  I liked the chewy mini mochi, pocky sticks, and the fresh fruit toppings.  There were also chocolate chips, m&m, sprinkles, oreo, gummy bears, etc.  

There were quite a few stations to make the rolled ice cream, but despite the numbers of employees, the wait was still very long because each order was made to order.  I can think of three small changes to make the ordering process less chaotic.  First, have a sign direct patrons to the cashier or place the cashier right by the front entrance.  Second, turn down the party music by a notch or two.  I wasn't the only one who couldn't hear my name being called.  Third, instead of copy off Starbucks and call customers by name, just assign a number instead.  This will give people a better sense of where they are in line so they don't have to pester the cashier and ask if their name had been called.
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: This is the most unique and entertaining way to eat ice cream. When I first walked in and was amazed by all the toppings they had. I tried several favors in the passed week and I really love black sesame. The owner was super nice and explained everything in details. I would come back every day if I can. Super delicious
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Phenomenal.  

Really - I have nothing bad to say about Copia.  I went for a work lunch and was pretty excited since I'd hard good things about it and never went before the fire destroyed it a while back.  We walked in and my eyes grew to the size of saucers - the bar/ restaurant is beautiful!  From the glass waterfall separating the bar area from the rest of the restaurant to the beautiful tiling used throughout to the gorgeous light fixtures, I almost forgot I was there to eat.  (Blame my having an Interior Design degree.)

We were then led out back to the stunning wine garden.  It was like being transported to a relaxing, tropical resort given the retractable roof, soothing fountain in the middle of the patio, and being surrounded by palm trees and Hibiscus plants!   So relaxing.

Our server was extremely nice and helpful with tips about what was good to eat there.  And lucky us - the Executive Chef Dave Rook was there that day and had just whipped up a new lunch special - beef tenderloin on baked ciabatta bread with cheese and veggies and some sort of delicious sauce on top.  And apparently when the chef whips up a special, it's best to try it as you won't be disappointed.  My two co-workers both had it and were very happy with their choice!

I had the Goat Cheese Salad - BEST. SALAD. EVER.  Mixed greens, roasted chicken, sweet onions, sliced strawberries tossed in a cracked pepper berry vinaigrette and topped with a ball of warm 
sesame-encrusted goat cheese.  Oh, heaven in a bowl.  I about licked my plate clean, it was that good - and it was under $9!  You can't beat that.

Copia seems to have a great variety of lunch and dinner items, all which have interesting food combinations.  I can't wait to go back and try the Flash Fried Calamari, Spicy Mango Chicken Pizza, Grilled Chicken Lasagna, or Black Sesame Seared Ahi.  And I can't ignore their abundant wine selection, either.  

Copia's website states that "Copia is the Roman goddess of abundance, wealth, pleasure, and harvest."  I agree - Copia was definitely a pleasure to visit and I plan on going back many, many times.
name: Copia Restaurant & Wine Garden
categories: Arts & Entertainment, Restaurants, Food, Bars, American (New), Wine Bars, Wineries, Seafood, Nightlife, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Steakhouses, Southern

text: Delicious poke bowls. Really enjoyed the touch of watermelon along with black sesame in the yellowtail bowl. Nicely done. Friendly staff, chill vibe.
name: Big Eye Raw Bar
categories: Japanese, Food, Live/Raw Food, Poke, Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text: One of the best vegan brunches I've ever had. The French toast especially was so delicious. Usually vegan french toast is just glorified toast but this actually tasted like french toast. We also got black sesame and coconut doughnuts and the forbidden breakfast burrito. The beet lemonade was unexpectedly delicious. We will be back!
name: Sprig & Vine
categories: Vegan, Vegetarian, Restaurants

text:
Legit Indian food at an upscale type place. I had the vegetarian thali (sampler) at lunch (see photo). Everything was above average. Highlights include the black sesame seeds on the naan (genius) and the paneer makhani (tomato-based gravy, kinda like tikka masala and just like that of butter chicken, for all you dummies out there). The sweet potato chips were good and went really well with the mango chutney but I'd rather fill up on that filthy delicious curry, know what I mean?

Nobody was there at lunchtime (during the week). My server was super nice (Josh I think) 

You'll pay a bit more than average and you probably shouldn't dress like a hobo like I normally do. Cheaper buffet type places are more my style but I'd come here a couple times a year.
name: IndeBlue Modern Indian Food & Spirits
categories: Cocktail Bars, Food Delivery Services, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Food, Bars, Event Planning & Services, Caterers, Restaurants, Indian

text:
The rolled ice cream hype has finally made it to Nashville! Just for that alone, you should make a visit. The shop is fairly small and has only 3 windows for making ice cream so expect a decent wait (20-25 mins) when there's a small line. The flavor options are good and you can choose a base flavor, pick a add in to mix with your base, and then choose 2 toppings. I ended up ordering a red bean ice base (they were out of green tea and black sesame), mixed it with banana, and then added coconut shreds and a wafer stick to top it off. Overall, pretty good flavor; however, I have to say I prefer Jeni's for the quality and variety of flavors they offer (goat cheese and cherry and the expresso will always be my jams). Price is fairly steep at around $7 a cup. 

The novelty alone made it worth the wait. Plus, it's very insta-worthy. 

#getyarollon
name: Supreme Kreme
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Bubble Tea, Food

text: We had gyoza as appetiser, they were good! Not greasy but they would have been better if they pan fried them a little longer. We had the signature ramen and black sesame ramen. We both prefer the signature ramen, the broth was rich but not heavy, full of pork bone flavor. The black sesame was ok, has better ones in Hong Kong though! The noodles and half boiled soft soy egg were really good! I think they were missing some toppings like a sheet of seaweed, fresh crushed garlic, etc. Minus the pickled ginger in the ramen too... It should be put on the side not in the soup. But I would go back to try other ramen another day just because we don't have many good ramen joints in our area in Boston.
name: Terakawa Ramen
categories: Japanese, Ramen, Ethnic Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Food, Specialty Food

text:
My wife and I had our 2nd wonderful dinner experience at the Sprig & Vine.  Besides  the oil and salt, we thought they were tremendous vegan menu items.  We arrived at opening (5 pm) on a Wednesday and we're the first patrons seated.  Not surprisingly, we had excellent service since that first hour and a half was rather slow.  The waitress had time to recommend dishes and help us make choices, which was helpful and added to the experience.  Our first dish:

EDAMAME FALAFEL............................................................7
black sesame tahini | pickled radish
 
This appetizer was great, both the falafel and the tahini sauce - we both enjoyed the dish.  There is a photo of the appetizer w/in the review pictures.  As far as the entrees:

GARLIC & TAMARIND-GLAZED PORTABELLA............................20
fried green tomato | green tomato chutney | apple, 
avocado & cashew raita | butternut-basmati rice | 
coconut & green chile-creamed swiss chard & chickpea

ROASTED CAULIFLOWER STEAK ...........................................20
tomato, garlic, caper, green olive & herb sauce | seared
potato pavé | golden raisin & pine nut-local greens

The greens (swiss chard?) w/ the raisins and pine-nuts was very tasty and well prepared as was the glazed portabella.  Sadly the glazed portabella was on top of a bed of basmati rice.  We really would have preferred brown rice - or at least the option.  Although the criticisms are truly minimal, since we really enjoyed the meal.  We finished w/ a delicious tiramisu.  It was splendid - when you have sugar, you don't need milk or eggs to make an amazing vegan dessert.   The atmosphere was nice and the restaurant stylish - an overall charming experience.
name: Sprig & Vine
categories: Vegan, Vegetarian, Restaurants

text:
My friend's choice and since I had not been in years (literally) I thought, "Why not?"

I got the Japanese Pan Noodles which consisted of caramelized udon noodles in a sweet soy sauce, broccoli, carrots, shiitake mushrooms, Asian sprouts, black sesame seeds and cilantro.  It was really good.  It's offered in two sizes and the small was more than enough for me. Since I didn't get anything else and I cannot remember what she got, that'll about do it for the food side. BTW, I'd order that dish again---really, it WAS good.

I guess things have not changed much, because I kinda agree with Liz B about the staff. Very, very nice and helpful in helping me figure out what I wanted.  But I did feel the rush after we were served...we kept our seats because it's out catch-up-visiting time so we were in no hurry.  Though we are always aware of the crowds and the need for seating, that was not a problem when we were there.

All in all, it's a good, solid, healthy choice...I even bought a gift card to use next time!..and I have to really like a place to do that!
name: Noodles & Company
categories: Restaurants, Comfort Food, Chinese, American (New), Mediterranean, Pasta Shops, Salad, Specialty Food, Food, Noodles, Italian, Asian Fusion

text: Amazing mochi!! Particularly loved the passionfruit, green tea and black sesame. Hand rolled ice cream is pretty good but thought the flavor options were just okay - would like a bit more filling added which would lend to better flavor. Had the coffee and fererr rocher and the flavors were both very subtle. Would like to try one of the Nutella flavors next time.
name: Seventh Heaven
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Thai, Vegan, Desserts, Japanese, Food, Restaurants

text:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. There are so many flavors to choose from. They even let you choose 3 toppings at the end, while other ice cream places usually charge you extra for toppings.

My favorites are the matcha-cha (matcha green tea) and dark matter (black sesame)! So good. They're literally rolled with love. I can't wait to try out the other flavors!
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: $8 minimum on credit card. Staff were attentive and knowledgable. Very trendy cafe with good lighting and ambiance. Overall, the baked goods were not that impressive. Mini-muffins were dry and noticeably bland. Interesting mix of tofu smoothies and straight soy milk. Specialty soy milk is eclectic. Had a black sesame soy. Freshly made soy milk is very different than what you get in the grocery store and super tasty. Will probably give this place another shot some time and try their hot breakfast foods.
name: Soy Cafe
categories: Restaurants, Vegetarian, Vegan, Coffee & Tea, Food

text:
Today, July 4, was my first time dining in at Ekta. My older parents and I were looking for a place to eat (and having a tough time finding one!); finally we saw that Ekta was open, though we then discovered that it was due to close in 40 minutes. 

I am deeply grateful to our server, Owen, for never making us feel like we were inconveniencing the staff by arriving so close to closing, and for going out of his way to help my mom (who has limited mobility) to navigate the steps both when we arrived and when we left. He situated us at a table just next to the door, which was even more helpful.

As for the food itself, my dad was delighted with his garlic kabob, and I really enjoyed the Chandrakala (first time I'd ever encountered these dried-fruit-and-coconut dumplings) and our bread selections (Lachha Paratha and Ekta Naan, the latter kind of an adaptation of the Peshawari Naan concept but with black sesame seeds included). My mom and I both guzzled our delicious lassis (mango and pomegranate). 

Though toned down at our request, the Alu Gobi was still a bit spicy for me, but tasty nonetheless.
name: Ekta Indian Cuisine
categories: Restaurants, Pakistani, Indian

text:
Pretty decent, I have been wanting to try a quality ramen place and that is what I got when I went.  

I went the other day with my siblings.  I got the mayu ramen which is a pork bone based noodle soup and garlic oil, bamboo shoot roast pork, boiled egg, scallion, kikurage, red ginger, my sister got the miso ramen which is a soy bean based noodle soup and bamboo shoot, roast pork bean sprout, boiled egg, scallion, kikurage, and my brother got the terakawa ramen which is a  pork bone based noodle soup and bamboo shoot, red ginger roast pork, boiled egg, scallion, kikurage.  Out of the three I would rank them like this miso, terakwa, and then mayu, the broth with all three were different.  The mayu broth had a black sesame taste which was just okay, it was also kinda bland compared to the terakawa and miso. I woulda enjoy the other two. My favorite part of the ramen was definitely the egg, which was cooked to perfection and tasted real good. 

With the ramen we got the lunch special so we got to each pick one side order so we ordered the gyoza, charsu, and chicken curry.  My favorite out of the three was the charsu, which is braised pork they use for the ramen that they put over rice. We also got the takoyaki which was my favorite dish overall. 

I think this is a decent noodle place, and later that night I was thinking about it and wanted to go and eat there again.
name: Terakawa Ramen
categories: Japanese, Ramen, Ethnic Food, Restaurants, Local Flavor, Food, Specialty Food

text:
What a disappointment! Because my two boys 4 and 9 are obsessed with Diners Drive ins and Dives, we decided to give this one a shot. Maybe our expectations are too high or maybe I've watched way too many Kitchen Nightmares and have developed a Gordon Ramsay complex....either way, this left a lot to be desired.

We ordered the Truffled Cheesesteak empanadas as per Mr. Fieri, and they had WAY too much truffle. Truffle is one of those ingredients that it's either amazing or if over used, it's bad. Someone had a heavy hand on the truffle oil. 
The calamari was so flat and tasteless. It had no seasoning aside from the black sesame seeds. We salted it ourselves but it barely helped. 
My kids both had the Shrimp Po Boys. The flavor was good but there was way too much bread. The shrimp were small and chewy.
My husband had the Good dog burger and said it was "good" bu nothing to write home about. 
Myself I had the BLT. Again way too much bread and it was way too hard.

Service was good and the waiter was attentive. That was about the only good thing...aside from all the dogs on the walls
name: Good Dog Bar
categories: American (Traditional), Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Burgers, Sandwiches, Soup, Pubs

text:
Seoul Fried Chicken opened its doors earlier this month, promising to spread the growing Korean fried chicken craze to Edmonton's hungriest. 

The storefront is tucked away in the outer corner of the small shopping complex off of Whyte Avenue, a complex that I've always refer to as "the one where Dream Tea House" is. To Korean fare fans, SFC takes place of the old Lee House. Chef Jake Lee is a part of the famous Lee family, now in Chinatown.

It was a packed house on both of my visits. With mostly tables for two and a single table for six, it's the one thing missing from SFC: seating. Since Lee House's closure, they've cut the dining room almost in half in order to expand the small kitchen area. Definitely designed for some quick drinks and eats. 

SFC OG: Golden crispy, moist and seasoned to the bone. This really is the OG (original gangster). The batter is noticeably crispy and the meat tender and moist. As a base for all the chicken made at SFC, this is a must order on your first visit.

SFC BBQ: Dad's famous Korean spicy BBQ sauce. Between my friends and I, we all remember Lee House's sauce to taste a bit different. Jake explained that although the sauce is the same, the technique is different: his dad wok-frying the chicken instead. Jake wanted a crispier chicken, with little potential to become soggy from sauce. Definitely accomplished that, a soggy piece of chicken not in sight while we were there although somehow not as memorable as his father's. OG Mr. Lee takes this one, sorry Jake! Most notably, SFC's BBQ sauce is quite gochujang-strong, whereas I prefer a spicy-sweet combination instead.

Onion Lover: Sweet hot mustard topped with shredded green onion. It sounds so deceivingly simple, the words "hot mustard" really throwing me off. This became one of our most memorable flavours and one of the best. The "hot mustard" is actually based of what Jake calls a "yellow wasabi", only found in Korean markets. It's also one of the most popular fried chicken flavours in Korea right now. I can see why. Addictively sweet and hot. I'm not even a mustard lover to begin with!

Cilantro Lime: SFC OG basted with cilantro lime chimichurri. Deliciously bright from the lime, I appreciated a different flavour profile on the menu! Something tells me that the word "chimichurri" on the menu would come from somebody who has a culinary background and not just "in the family business" kind of experience. Sure enough, Jake told us that he's worked at XIX (Terwillegar) before starting SFC. 

Garlic Soy: SFC OG basted with soy sauce and garlic. Basted is a loose terminology, it was doused in a soy glaze! Looking for something salty and messy to eat? This is your kind of fried chicken!

Golden Kari: SFC OG basted Japanese curry powder. Much like the Onion Lover, I would have thought this was my least favourite flavour from just looking at the menu. 'Lo and behold, it ended up being one of my favourites! Japanese curry lovers, you'll need to get this. Nay-sayers, get this too because I think it will surprise you in the best way possible!

You can order Half Chicken (10pc) for $13-14.50 depending on the flavour, or a Whole Chicken (20pc) for $23-27, which is enough to feed 4. Best deal: the 5pc Chicken SET ($11) for your choice of single flavour, any 1/2 order of salad, & your choice of house fries or corn fritter, & can of pop. SAYWHAA? Sides not your thing? Then get the 5pc Chicken + Domestic Beer ($10.50). Pay the additional $0.75 and upgrade to import.

The cold Mac n' Cheese Pesto salad was creative and delicious, but the Sesame Potato Slaw has my vote: a shredded potato, cabbage, and yam slaw mixed with a black sesame dressing. That dressing is killer. House Fries appear to be fresh cut, done well (slightly crispy on the outside, soft on the inside) although nothing noteworthy.

And as if you're not full enough (and I'm not writing enough), there's dessert. The "Almost Famous" Walnut Red Bean Cake Pops - 10, 15, or 20 pc ($5/7.25/9.25) is made fresh daily and in limited supply. Commonly eaten on the streets of Seoul, I remembered these to be deliciously hot, nutty, and slightly sweet from the red bean paste inside. Saturday's visit gave us a soft, chewy dough with a delicious red bean paste with bites of walnuts. On my 2nd visit, Jake told us that they had changed their recipe to make a firmer dough, a style more in tune with how it's made back in Korea. I personally preferred the chewy texture but to each their own! The one thing I really had hoped for when I saw the machine behind the till was that it was made fresh to order! The Vanilla Coconut Chia Pudding ($4) that I took home later to try was delicious, thick in consistency and full of coconut flavour. I don't think desserts is really needed on the menu, but it's there if you've got a strong hankering for it.

Take home notes: go with friends, try everything. Oh, and start a stamp card. Because you'll be back.
name: Seoul Fried Chicken
categories: Chicken Shop, Korean, Restaurants

text:
I am in a coma. A sushi coma. Well, I'm actually recovering from my sushi coma. 

I have wanted to come here since I first heard of this place. Not sure HOW long it's been, but it's been far too long.

Went there for lunch today. I went without any expectations. I went in just knowing that I was going to eat a $hitload of sushi. I've seen great reviews, I've seen some not so great reviews. One reviewer stated that someone yelled at their wife for taking the last piece of sushi. Um, ok.

So with that said, I want to go back... and again and again. I had sushi rolls that I have never heard of or thought could be possible. Before my post-coma brain forgets, there's this one roll with Beef, Cilantro, Cucumber and Avocado. It has a sauce on top of it (not spicy, just savory)... and Oh. Em. Gee. That has got to be the best non-seafood roll I've tasted. If I could haven taken the whole platter it was sitting on, you know I would!! As far as the other sushi items are concerned, my mouth was also full of heaven. I like that they have more than just 'rolls'. I like the squares. I am a sushi lover, not a sushi snob, so I don't really know the proper term for these items, but they were so good! Everything was fresh and full of flavor. I wish I had a pen and a notepad with me so I could have written them all down, but I just remember that there were so many varieties that I was thanking the sushi Gods. I know that I enjoyed their Spicy Tuna, then there was a tuna with smoked sesame seeds, a Spicy Scallop item and then there was one that just blew my mind that I had to share it with my non-sushi eating awesome friend who treated me to this lunch. It was salmon, but it was so smoky and full of flavor. It was one of those bricks/squares and man oh man was it good. I guess he liked it. He ate mostly meat (he's a man! grrrr..)

So onto the non-sushi items. I have to say that there's none of that regular Chinese buffet crap there (fried this, greasy that). Everything seemed/looked healthy. I went along the side with all of the salads. I tried the black sesame salad with mushrooms (very different; had a weird fishy taste), a soba noodle salad (delicious! I love Soba Noodles!) and the eggplant (I wish I would have taken more). I was disappointed that the calamari salad was all gone and angry at myself (no, I'm not at all dramatic) that I didn't go back after a while to see if they filled it up. I had some of this fried chicken... little wings, full of meat and bursting with flavor. Just the right amount of spice with some sweetness. My friend detected a peanut flavor going on there with the wings. I did have 2 pieces of tempura (onion ring and shrimp) that lacked flavor. No big deal. I wasn't there for the tempura :) I also tried some Udon soup. This was my first time having it. It was full of flavor, but I didn't really know what to ask to have put in it, so I just asked for tempura shrimp and green onions. I wish they had more choices to go in the Udon soup, but again, no biggie!

Now onto the Green Tea Ice Cream. WOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This stuff was seriously good!!! I am so glad that I didn't make a pig out of myself and overload on food so I was able to have room for the Green Tea Ice Cream. This was the first time for me and all I can say is that I want some more. 

Overall, dining at Minado was a positive experience. Waiters were friendly, staff were friendly. The bathroom was clean, as was the dining area. The only gripe that I have is that when I was ready to leave I started taking pics of the sushi items and the head Chef told me I couldn't take pics of the food. I explained to him that I was a first timer there and I was going to review Minado on yelp. I even said,"Yelp! Y - E - L - P." He smiled, said this time okay, next time no pictures. I just stopped it right there. 

Seriously, though, if I could afford to eat here weekly, I would. It was all that I had expected and more, even without much expectations!

I will be going back for SURE! Wow, what a place! I feel like I can give birth to a baby squid! LOL*


*added per request.
name: Minado
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Seafood, Buffets

text:
Tucked away in a small pocket of New Hope is a brand new restaurant filled with really big surprises.

Owned and operated by Horizons' former Sous Chef, Ross Olchvary, Sprig & Vine is truly an amazing dining experience. 

Our party of 4 was greeted with a warm welcome by their host and we had arrived just after the big dinner slam, so we were promptly seated.

The entire restaurant was glowing with warm ambient light shining from very unique cork light fixtures suspended from the ceiling. After being seated, you can't help but feel absorbed by all of complimentary natural earth tones and the independent track list. 

Our server immediately greeted us with a smile and opened our bottle of wine and poured everyone a glass.

We started with the Fried Baby Artichokes, Edamame Falafel and Tofu Satay....all amazing. You almost feel guilty as your fork disturbs the pristine presentation of each dish, but the flavors and textures are truly out of this world. 

Ever have black sesame tahini? i certainly hadn't. The edamame falafel was delicately placed ontop of light drizzles of the tahini. It was perfect and garnished with pickled radish.

the tofu satay was accompanied by pickled mango and had an amazing coconut-peanut glaze.

We ordered every entree except for the cornmeal-crusted tempeh (only because we were a party of 4 and not 5).

The slow roasted root vegetable pave was like a sunburst on my plate. Featuring local soft polenta, red wine braised shallots, and grilled asparagus, you forget that what you're eating is "100% Vegetarian". You forget because it's kind of hard to believe that such complex flavor is the result of purely vegetarian ingredients.

We also tried the Cauliflower Three Ways, Seared Coconut Risotto Cakes and the Moroccan Grilled Tofu. We had to try one of the side dishes, so we went with the Kennebec Potato Fries.

I really can not say enough wonderful things about Sprig & Vine. After 3 bowls of soup, 3 appetizers, 4 entrees, one side, one dessert and 2 cups of coffee, our bill was only $122 dollars!!!!!!

In the past, i've  paid literally triple this amount for half the quality!

Bring a bottle or two of wine, bring your friends, but also try bringing someone who has never had the opporutnity/privilege to try an all out vegetarian/vegan experience. it will totally change their perspective on food.

Whether you're a vegan, vegetarian, or all out carnivore, do your taste buds and spirit a big favor and stop by Sprig & Vine for a wonderful and reasonably priced dining experience brought to you by a true artisan.
name: Sprig & Vine
categories: Vegan, Vegetarian, Restaurants

text:
My friend really enjoys it here so I met her for dinner, I don't usually go for western chinese food but thought I try it out.  I was pleased to see how big and clean this place was as my expectation was to see old table and chairs, dirty buffet table, overcooked food, small selection and poor service.

We arrived before 5 pm on a weeknight and there were already a few people there.  The food looked freshly made, there were two soups...hot n sour and of course wonton.  The wonton was the usual, there was fried rice, chow mein, shanghai noodle and singapore rice noodles but there wasn't lots of meat with these.  For meat there was sweet and sour pork, lemon chicken, ginger beef, chinese style bbq chicken, pork dumplings, spring rolls, breaded fish, chicken balls and breaded shrimp. There was salad but who really eats salad with chinese food?  Dessert choices were different flavour jello, cake and fruit.  I was hoping for the warm soup type dessert like the red bean or black sesame.

All this was only $16.95, better than the other western chinese buffets.  The waitresses came by frequently to clear plates and refill drinks.  I would recommend this place when you are starving for chinese food!
name: Beijing House Buffet
categories: Buffets, Noodles, Restaurants, Chinese

text:
My boyfriend and I took my cousin out to dinner last night and we decided to check this place out and I'm so glad that we did! The decor is really modern and the chairs are so comfortable! I've been to some new places lately *cough* heritage *cough* that have seats that cause your butt to go numb before your appetizers hit the table! 

We started with the salmon roll appetizer, it came with three pieces which was perfect for us. The salmon was perfectly smoked and it was filled with cheese and topped with a jalapeño, delicious.

For dinner my cousin and I had the salmon dinner (we like our fish!) The dish came with a small heirloom tomato salad and some purple sticky rice with a beurre blanc sauce. Everything on the plate was cooked perfectly and the flavor of the salmon was buttery and smooth, melt in your mouth!

My boyfriend ordered the burger they had that night, it had kimchi and a sweet plum ketchup and on the side it had tempura battered sweet potatoes. When the burger came out it looked pretty plain, but my boyfriend said it was seasoned so well it made his top 3 burger list! Plus he ordered it medium rare and it actually came out that way! 

Lastly (we were hungry!!) we decided on a berry sake soup for desert. All I can say about that is wow! I love fruit in my champagne but there is never enough of it, this dish was like a bowl of all that fruit! There was a quenelle of cream in the center with black sesame seeds, the sake was sparkling a little, the raspberries brought a little bit of tartness... it really hit the spot! 

My only small complaint was that the menu we had seemed to have less options than the ones pictured here, but that may be because we went on a weekday. I think I know where I'm getting dinner Saturday though!!
name: theory
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Bars, Nightlife, French

text:
Its opening kind of came out of nowhere, but I was walking my usual route when I noticed a new restaurant that seemed to have been there all along - it's on a pretty busy street and yet people walk right by without even realizing it's there. It kind of adds to the mystery of the place!

Inside, you'll find the floors, the walls, the ceiling is covered matte black. When you pass by on the street, you're intrigued! But as soon as you walk in, the art deco vibe they have going on actually wasn't executed very well. I just felt they were trying too hard to look cool. The space is pretty large, however. It's three floors. The basement was also a mystery, but there is additional seating on the third floor, which is lofted. High ceilings, dark, but still added greenery near the window. The chairs were pretty comfortable actually.

The food itself is a mixed bag. We ordered the crudites, which were fine. They are cooked slightly, and still maintain a snap and crunch which is great! But the avocado mousse that accompanied them was a little bland. I ordered the scallops which come with 3 large sea scallops over a bed of succotash and diced ham. The plate was dotted with a sriracha type sauce and something that looked like black sesame sauce (not sure if that's what that was). It was good and filling. I would highly recommend this dish. My boyfriend ordered the filet mignon. It was meh. It looks like they use sous vide to cook the steak, which is great because it came out perfectly cooked, but it didn't have that crust or seer that makes a steak great. They cover the "aerated" potato, which was a potato skin with what resembled a cheesy, creamy potato filling, with slices of truffle - which looked amazing, but felt cheap, honestly, after you take the first bite. I've had dishes that contain less truffle but the aroma and truffle flavor just fills the whole dish. This was covered with slices of truffle and I could barely make out the truffle flavor - which makes me wonder if it's a real truffle or where they got it from. Check my pictures - the potato was literally covered with truffle slices and yet the plate was only $30. Something didn't add up. 

I will say that the staff was attentive and I never felt like I was waiting for anything. It wasn't exceptional service, but it was good. 

My general thoughts of the place is that they are trying too hard to fit a certain category of restaurant. Everything was simply "alright" and nothing really stands out, which was disappointing.
name: Talk
categories: Nightlife, Bars, American (New), Cocktail Bars, Restaurants

text:
A nice, cozy cafe with quality vegan/vegetarian options at more accessible prices! 

I particularly enjoyed the black sesame soy drink--it reminded me of the black sesame soft serve that I like to get in Japan. It wasn't too sweet, and the soy milk that was used didn't have a pungent aftertaste and was deliciously silky. The black sesame was a very delicious complement to the elegantly delicate soy milk, and the drink had a very pleasant nutty flavor. If I were to mention something that could be improved, it would be that when the drink was served, it wasn't as steaming hot as I would have liked it to be. 

The hummus is creamy, and the vegetable sticks are crisp, fresh, and delicious. It is so refreshing to have simple food done well at reasonable prices. I wish this place existed where I live!
name: Soy Cafe
categories: Restaurants, Vegetarian, Vegan, Coffee & Tea, Food

text:
Another new place in Chinatown. 
I always get super excited when I discover a new Asian restaurant. And ShangHai1 offers both Shanghai and Taiwanese food. 
I went there on my lunch break to order take out, and the menu was a bit overwhelming. Even though the staff were very helpful, still I was confused. 
I ended up getting the scallion pancakes, Shanghai style udon and sesame rice balls.

The tender beef scallion pancakes were crispy and surprisingly sweet. As I expected, the shanghai style Udon was pretty good. Two thumbs up for the stir-fried chewy and thick noodles with baby bok choy, shiitake mushrooms and chicken in dark soy sauce. Wow, simple, delicious and became one of my favorites.

My meal is never complete without dessert, that being said, getting the sesame rice ball with chinese wine was a big mistake. I opened my dessert container, and the thick and viscous translucent broth-like, that killed my appetite!!!  Challenged, I processed exploring the mystery of my container. I just had to. I picked up a gooey, rubbery and squishy little white yellowish Nerf ball-like. I cut the little ball and the black sesame paste was revealed. It's true: Asian cousin is not known for dessert. 

Three and half Yelps!
name: Shang Hai 1
categories: Taiwanese, Chinese, Shanghainese, Restaurants

text:
I decided to come here for dinner tonight despite reading some mediocre Yelp reviews for this place... and overall, I'm disappointed. The only good thing was that the food we ordered was fresh.

Service was very, very slow. I understand they're busy considering it's a Saturday night, but it took a long time for someone to actually say hi and seat us. 

The menus are due for an update (ink bleeding on the pages and stained). Half of the food came out much later than the rest. I don't recommend getting the chef's special appetizer- it's 5 piles of shredded carrots, radish, krab, seaweed salad, and something black sesame? For $7.50..it's an after-thought...nothing special at all. Finally, it took at least 20 min to get the check after we already finished eating.
name: Ichiban Japanese Cuisine & Sushi Bar
categories: Japanese, Gluten-Free, Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars

text: I was pleasantly surprised to find this place inside the very markets in new hope Pennsylvania I had ordered the tuna Moku bowl. It was delicious and fit in my low carb diets with raw tuna over a bed or seaweed salad with black sesame and pickled radish.  Only wished it had more tuna for value.
name: Moku-Bowls
categories: Poke, Food

text:
ROLLED ICE CREAM IN SB!! YAAAAS!!!

Pretty good stuff. They're new and we went during a rush ): waited 40 minutes for our ice cream, but ITS REALLY GOOD AND WE WERENT IN A RUSH SO ITS FINE!! They had all the stations going and the place was packed. I feel bad for their arms man i would be so tired choppin it up like that nonstop.

We got the strawberry graham one. It's called "for the 'gram" DAAAAANK!! You can taste the real strawberry pieces in it. We got ours with strawberry pocky, strawberry hello panda, and fresh strawberries.. talk about strawberry overload huehue. OH AND WHIPPED CREAM DUHHH.

There's many flavors to choose from and toppings on rotation!! You can choose up to 3 toppings, and whipped cream and a sauce on top. Next time I'm looking to try their matcha, black sesame, or thai tea flavored rolls. IM HAPPY THIS PLACE EXISTS!!

10/10 would recommend
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
This is a place I've been waiting to visit for quite sometime. When a friend told me they were having a special pastry chef come do desserts for a very short time, I felt it a perfect opportunity. 

Jason Licker, acclaimed pastry chef, Iron Chef Thailand Pastry Champion 2014, and James Beard Award Nominee, was doing a dessert pop-up tour, with a short stop in Reno. We had to check this out. 

I'm not normally the type to order dessert regularly, but when I have an opportunity to try some dishes that I've never heard of or seen before, I'm down.

I have to start by saying that I was immediately impressed with the service of Liberty, well before we even arrived. 

We had reservations for 4, on a busy Saturday night, and at the eleventh hour, emergency struck. We had written off our dining experience for the evening. I called Liberty and explained the situation, and I believe Michael may have been with whom I spoke. He was very super understanding. I mentioned that we were really looking forward to this, and he offered to extend our reservation for a later time. Jackpot. 

 After all was well, a few hours later, we arrived. The space is downtown, and right across the street from a parking garage, which makes access much less of a headache. The place was popping. Tons of people were out dining and there was a good energy about the spot.

We were seated, and the good service continued. Being 6'5", I occasionally come across seating limitations, as you can imagine. The hostess was super sweet, and quickly located me a comfy office chair. Brilliant! It was a great way to begin the evening.

We started with some wine, of course. The ladies had a tasting flight, while I started with some Prosecco. We knew we would be ordering every single dessert, so we skipped appetizers. 

I really wanted to try the Chef's Pasta they had going on, which I ordered, only to then be told they had run out of ingredients to make it. Mild disappointment. However, it gave the the excuse to order the Chef's Fish. 

Diver Scallops. Ginger & Chile Lime Asparagus. Crispy Pork Belly. Cauliflower Purée. And a Meyer Lemon Pesto.

It was actually really tasty. The Pesto added a lovely acidic element that really tied the other flavors together. 

My friend ordered the Rigatoni. Coming from a big Italian family, I'm often skeptical of ordering pasta anywhere but my own kitchen... however, as much as I love the Scallops, I wished I had ordered the Rigatoni immediately after tasting it. The Ragu that dressed the pasta had a depth of flavor that you can only achieve with a LOT of time and tender, loving care. It was phenomenal. I made sure only to have one generous bite so I could properly enjoy the wonderful plate of food that I had.

The desserts. I'll attach a picture of the menu and inspiration for each that was included. Jason Licker did some serious work. I checked out his Instagram prior to going and saw all the work that just went into the garnish of one of the desserts. Super impressive. Also, while going to wash my hands I happened to recognize him, and said hello. I could tell he was incredibly busy, right in the middle of service.

Matcha Tart was very interesting. I hadn't ever tasted something like it. It's something he's known for. The green tea and chocolate produced a flavor that went really well with the rich, chocolate ice cream that came with it. The green color of the Tart was just incredible.

The other desserts were all very good, with the berry Crème Brûlée being my favorite of the five desserts we had. It's an iconic French masterpiece, but Jason layered it with a raspberry-yuzu gel under the custard, that was perfection. I've never had a multi-layered Brûlée before, and it was tremendous. Definitely had more of that than the others.

The best component of any dish however, was the shiso gelee that was apart of the White Chocolate-Junmai Sake Cream dessert. That was an explosion of flavor that enhanced all of the different sweet, salty, sour acidic going on. Truly remarkable. 

The Chocolate Bar we felt may have been better if eaten alone, but it was soooooooo rich that it blew out your palette if you ate it before anything else. It was well done. Just really intense.

Finally, the Mandarin & Black Sesame was insane. So gorgeous. I actually watch a short video of Jason making this and all the layers that went into it on his Instagram, and it didn't disappoint. Another unique dish I've never experienced before. The nutty flavor isn't something you can really compare it to except for itself. It was light, full of citrus and fat, all balanced very well. It was great.

Towards the end of the evening, Jason saw me at the table and came over and said hello to everyone and took a selfie with me. He's a super nice guy. That definitely helped make the night that much more memorable.

I absolutely need to go to Liberty again. It was a fantastic first trip!
name: Liberty Food & Wine Exchange
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Event Planning & Services, Specialty Food, Caterers, Food, Venues & Event Spaces, Cocktail Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Burgers, Italian, Pizza, Nightlife, American (New), Restaurants, Wine Bars, Bars

text:
I used to go here when it was Ahi Sushi and was big fan. However, if you order from this place like it is your typical sushi restaurant, you will be sorely disappointed. That was our first and only mistake. The basic rolls are nothing special. You can find those at any place in town. We also got some basic udon. But I think we recovered nicely.

Being the big eaters that we are and out for a birthday, we decided to splurge. We added on the salmon 6 ways and we were very happy with the dish. First, it's displayed beautifully. The waiter basically said we were not allowed to use soy sauce on that dish. Each slice of salmon was dressed differently with subtle but sophisticated differences in flavor that would be masked by soy sauce (I rarely use soy sauce with good fish anyways). We finished it off with green tea ice cream and black sesame ice cream. These desserts do not have a lot of sugar. You can really taste the green tea and black sesame.

We would have tried the omakase meal but it was sold out. The waiter said that they get their fish straight from the Tokyo market, so when they run out, they are really out. I think the shipments come in every two days. We happened to be there on the third day. So we will have to try this out another time.

Also of note, because I think some people care, the sushi chefs were all Japanese.
name: Sun Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
Who is Charlie? I'd like to thank him for being a sinner, because it's almost criminal how much I loved this place. It's waaay sexier inside than I ever imagined. It's very dim-lit with cozy tables, velvet curtains, and tea-light candles on every table. I'd absolutely suggest this place for a date night. I, however, came here with my girls for #SIPS, and it was hands down one of the best happy hours I've encountered in the city.

You should know off the bat that this restaurant is completely plant based. As an avid carnivore, I can say, I was completely thrilled with the variety and flavor of every item I tried. There's a good mix of small plates offered at happy hour. We sampled the Charred Shishito Peppers with Romesco Sauce (red peppers and nuts), Potato Croquettes, Zucchini "Crabcake" Sliders, and Korean Style Fried Tofu, all washed down with the Red Sparrow cocktail. My favorite dish was the potato croquettes with chipotle aioli - it was like a lightly fried ball of the creamiest mashed potatoes, a mashed potato truffle if you will. Honestly, I'd drink a cocktail made with that chipotle aioli. DELICIOUS. 

My least fav was the Korean Style Fried Tofu, and my three friends agreed. It was spicier than I anticipated, and while the texture was perfect, there seemed to be a bit of a bitter aftertaste. Maybe it was the black sesame seeds. Either way, I wouldn't order it again. 

Our server was funny and tolerant of our goofy giggles. He was fairly attentive to our table, but you could tell he was busy, given the time and day. 

Huge fan of this place. I am super keen to come back and try more menu items. I'd avoid coming here with parties larger than four, as it's a narrow, tight little restaurant. However, this is the type of place that's fun to come with a couple of friends and have the ability to taste test a few things.
name: Charlie Was a Sinner
categories: Bars, Nightlife, Kosher, Burgers, Tapas/Small Plates, American (Traditional), Vegan, Seafood, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Vegetarian

text:
I want to give this place 5 plus stars.
I was surprised to see a korean bakery in St. Louis burbs to start off with... this place may be small but have a lot more different types of baked goods than other k bakeries even in Chicago. Although I think Atlanta has the biggest ones I have seen and I know LA has more in number. We lived in Tacoma area and this place reminded me of bakery in federal way. There's just so much to choose from but fortunately, the price is more reasonable than Chicago or Tacoma. I really liked the French toast (crispy and sweet outer, soft interior), the kimchee inside the fried dough (kimchee koroke) was ok... kimchee was too shredded, the hotdog cheese bread is alright. I usually prefer the black sesame mochi bread bec it's not too sweet and it's healthy. I also love chewy mochi texture. The shortbread with half chocolate checker is good too(not too sweet). My hubby picked up a fruit whipping cream cake this summer and I wasn't too crazy about it. Anyway, baked goods r all so good, not too sweet and they havesavory options as Wells
name: Kim's Bakery
categories: Bakeries, Food, Korean, Custom Cakes, Restaurants

text:
Stopped by here on a weekend after seeing this on yelp and let's say I had an eye opening experience 

Started on with an appetizer. Great gyoza with a sweet and sour taste sauce, slight vinegar with the saltiness coming from the dumpling itself.  

Let the food speak for itself and it did, amazing, comparable to any of the top ramen places I've ate at. 

I'm mostly impressed by the Iekei broth, intensely deep, with a strong fragrance of that garlic and black sesame. Noodles were al dente, just how I like them, good sized portions. The egg was cooked to perfection, yolk inside wasn't runny, but very creamy yolk that won't drip and ruin the broth, great medium. I went on a tangent about an egg, but it was amazing, trust me. Now back to the broth, very rich, as advertised on the menu, it was chicken and pork broth, and I'd never had this mix before. After trying it, I think the umami from this combination is a force to be reckoned with! 

And to cool things off, get a nice cold calpico, it's a carbonated drink that's a little sweet and curbs any sweet cravings. 

I'll definitely be back!
name: Neighborhood Ramen
categories: Ramen, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
This place is undoubtedly one of, if not the best Chinese in Reno. 

Last night, a few great friends took me to their special six-course Chinese New Year dinner. My friend had the reservation for nearly two months, and it was one of the best meals I've had in Reno

2019 is the Year of the Pig according to the Chinese zodiac. With that consideration, the First Course was a perfect beginning.

First Course: Tofu Skin Seafood Roll & Roasted Pork Belly.  

It was served with a drizzle of an equally sweet and savory sauce on the plate. 

The pork belly was succulent and mostly melted in your mouth. The top cap was rendered quite a bit and achieved a very crispy/crunchy texture. 

Tofu skin is now one of my new favorite ingredients. The texture was lightly crisp on top and was juicy, but not greasy. The filling was a mixture of calamari, shrimp, and some vegetables and herbs. It was phenomenal.

Second Course: Five Spice Sea Bass & Snow Peas.

This was my favorite dish of the night. The fish was perfectly cooked, enveloped in an incredibly thin batter. It was delicate, well seasoned, and packed with flavor. On top of the sea bass were some finely chopped jalapeño, which may have been pickled; they didn't have that heat component you normally associate with jalapeño, and was a great complement to the dish. Snow peas were super fresh, and added a wonderful texture variation to the dish.

Third Course: Soy Sauce Shrimp with Ginger Scallion Noodles.

The chef changed up the menu slightly, switching the garnish of the shrimp and lamb courses. I'm glad that he did. The shrimp were served with the shells on both ends, for a beautiful presentation, and were delicious. The soy sauce shrimp sauce wasn't what I was expecting, it had a little sweetness to it, that really made the shrimp pop. The ginger scallion noodles were wonderful, eaten by itself and also with the shrimp. The ginger wasn't very powerful at all, and added a nice subtle flavor to an overall tasty plate of food.

Forth Course: Hainan Chicken Rice.

This dish is poached chicken and a seasoned rice. It isn't something you often see on menus in the US. The Hainan Chicken Rice gets it's name from it's origins in the Hainan province in southern China, but it was when the Chinese brought the dish to Singapore that it became famous. 

Absolutely the most flavorful chicken I've ever had. It was juicy, and the rice was cooked perfectly.

The rice and chicken are both well seasoned mostly with salt, green onion, and ginger. It's a dish I would encourage you to try when you have the opportunity.

Fifth Course: Grilled Lamb Chops & Snow Pea Tips.

The final course before dessert was some of the best lamb chops I've had. They were very lightly marinated, which resulted in a delectable caramelization. The snow pea tips were much like chard, beautiful sautéed greens; everyone at the table felt they were one of the best components on any dish.

Sixth Course: Steamed Egg Custard Bun with a Chinese Egg Tart.

The custard bun was something unlike anything else I've ever tasted. It was round, and had the texture of the most soft dough you can imagine. It was coated in a peanut butter powder, and inside was delicious black sesame. It wasn't too sweet, and was a great new experience. The egg tart was very light and creamy, and topped with fruit. The sweetness mostly came from the mango, pineapple, strawberry, and blueberry. Each bite was unique, depending on which fruit you ate with it. I couldn't think of a better finishing dish after a magnificent meal.

In regards to the wine, we started with a cold, crisp Prosecco. Then moved on to a robust Pinot Noir that bursts with cherry, strawberry, and plum flavors with a slightly sweetness that's moderated on the finish with rounded tannins, and finally an unapologetically bold, spice-driven and jammy Zinfandel. 

All of the wine paired really well and elevated the overall experience. The Pinot and the Zinfandel being the favorites.

Danny is the one that runs Kwok's Bistro, and he's a really good guy and often displays a contagious smile. 

Winnie, our server, was an absolute delight. She's very friendly, outgoing, and has great energy and sense of humor, referring to her name as in "Winnie the Pooh!" Winnie made the evening that much more memorable.

One of the best birthdays I've had, with the best people, and some of the best food in our big little city. I feel extremely lucky to have gotten a seat during their New Years celebration.

Kwok's Bistro is definitely deserving of this fifth star, by every measure.
name: Kwok's Bistro
categories: Noodles, Restaurants, Chinese, Asian Fusion

text:
I'm probably missing something here... chopped and rolled ice cream? It seems to me I was paying for the novelty of the experience of this type of ice cream. This would be fine with the understanding that the end product's flavor and texture measured with the delay in gratification met the novelty. 

Thirty five (35) minutes from paying to receiving said product. Only four (4) numbers between me and my turn once paid for. This seems a little long to be waiting on a cool, slow night for ice cream. I knew ahead of time that there would be a wait; still was disappointed. I couldn't imagine the wait on a hot summer night. 

As for the product, mine bland (black sesame); wife's flavorful (oreo & cream). Texture wasn't that of ice cream or gelato or popsicle but rather shaved ice. 

Volume of said ice cream in container is about a scoop (small). Overall, interesting to watch the production but not very satisfying in the end.
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
After going to the Ice district location and liking it, I figured I would give this location a try. Came in on a Thursday evening and this place was so disorganized. With 1 person on food prep, 1 person on drinks and 2 waitresses, it was a complete downhill experience from here. Luckily we got our order taken quite promptly, but we watched others who were not so lucky walk out of this place after being left unattended for 10-15mins. 

We ended up ordering the American style hot chocolate after being told the black sesame hot cocoa was discontinued. We also opted for the double triple chocolate fondue. We waited around 20 mins for our fondue to arrive and boy oh boy.. The waffle was undercooked and cold in the middle and tasted like raw dough. We ended up telling one of the waitress and she completely panicked, apologized and said that they were receiving similar complaints the whole night. (Interestingly enough, the table next to us also complained about the undercooked waffle before us as we were being seated). We were approached by another waitress, who said they would be replacing the waffle and giving us a discount for the inconvenience. We ended up getting a replacement waffle with the same results. By then, we gave up and just ate the fruits and left the waffles as is. 

The interior is really cute and it's such a shame this location is so disorganized and understaffed. I wish the desserts at this place was better. To be honest, I wouldn't pay $20 on fondue to eat cut fruits and undercooked waffles. We ended up getting a 15% discount for the fondue which wasn't worth it. I felt bad for the one staff who was running around making all the food by himself and the other waitresses trying to keep up with all the tables. Hoping management will be able to save this place by hiring more staff to help out.
name: Cacao 70 Eatery
categories: Cafes, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Food, Specialty Food, Chocolatiers & Shops, Desserts

text: Absolutely delicious and unique flavors. We tried the strawberry peppercorn, black sesame, maple bacon and everything flavors and they were incredible!!
name: Kin Bakeshop
categories: Pop-Up Restaurants, Restaurants, Food, Donuts

text:
I'm so happy Tommy decided to bring the joy of mochi donuts to Santa Barbara! Mochi donuts are one of my favorite desserts in a world of endless foodie trends, I'd say this is one to stay. Chewy and airy with endless combinations to incorporate in the dough or the glaze, you have to give them a try. Hoping to see a rotation of flavors like those of Modo Hawaii. 

Anyways, stumbled on this via Instagram and saw the level of care in the presentation by a small business owner and was blown away I had to support. Nicest donut box ever I must say. You must preorder on the website and pay in advance. At this time it's preset flavors as he scales up. Once preordered, there's a set time and day to pick up based on the selection you made and the owner has set up a little table and sign off sheet :).

So far - we have strawberry sprinkles, pumpkin cheesecake, pumpkin cheesecake, and black sesame. All delicious and no complaints. Hoping to see more and more creativity and to try more flavors from them!
name: Kin Bakeshop
categories: Pop-Up Restaurants, Restaurants, Food, Donuts

text:
We have been here before, but recently Little Sheep hotpot has become an all you can eat buffet! The broths are still the same and delicious as ever, without really needing any additional sauces. However, because it has become an ACYE, they have cut back on some of the food that you can request, specifically in regards to meat. Nonetheless, it is still great (we love the pork belly and the hand sliced fatty beef). Over at the self-serve bar, they have a ton of vegetables, seafood, and other add-ins (tofu, sausages, quail eggs, etc.) They even have a little station with dumplings and fried rice (try not to fill yourself up on rice!! you're paying for the meat and seafood!). 

Their service is okay, they have a panel on the table that has a red side for when you need assistance (water, fill up your broth, order more meat) and a green side when nothing is needed. However, sometimes our red side would be up for a little bit and they would not come as quickly as we would like and our broth would reduce a bit too much. Also, some of our vegetables were dirty! Make sure that you are checking some of the vegetables before placing them in your broth. 

All in all, this place is a new favorite and a go to whenever we are craving hotpot. Plus the free ice cream (taro or black sesame) really helps cool the palate after your meal!
name: Happy Lamb Hot Pot
categories: Mongolian, Restaurants, Chinese, Hot Pot

text:
I really enjoyed my first time at Bao with the International Supper Club (ISC). Thanks to Picha for the recommendation and for Sarah S. for making it happen!

I've been eating Chinese bao for a long time... probably ever since my baby teeth came in. So I was very familiar with the food, but I knew that The BAO puts a twist on the traditional bao. I wasn't sure what to expect or whether or not I would like it.

For appetizers, my spouse and I split the Taiwanese Dumplings, which were perfectly pan fried and very tasty. I probably could've eaten mulitple orders of these for dinner and I'd be happy. For the bao, I had the Soft Shell Crab. I really enjoyed the bao, pretty typical fried soft shell crab, nothing special in my book. I did like how the sweetness of the bread and mayo balanced out the bitterness of the arugula. I also had a bite of the Truffle Shroom bao, which was HUGE and really good. The gouda went well stuffed in the panko crusted portabello. For dessert, we had the black sesame ice cream bao. This was basically a small donut cut in half with ice cream in the middle. How could this be remotely bad?

I'd definitely recommend you check this place out if you are looking for Asian cuisine with a twist.
name: The BAO
categories: Acai Bowls, Asian Fusion, Food, Restaurants, Bars, Event Planning & Services, Breakfast & Brunch, Tapas/Small Plates, Chinese, Sandwiches, Caterers, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife

text:
I have loved Chef Kaz for a long time. And I've been missing him since he left Shogun many moons ago. So when I found out he was opening his own restaurant in the Bywater, I was ecstatic. 

The space fits 12 seats, but they are currently only serving 10 for 2 services a night. Reservations are highly coveted! They announce when reservations open on their Facebook. So make sure you are on top of it! From what E told me, their menu is pretty much set each month. 

I had 2 appetizers. Edamame and his fish broth with mixed mushrooms and octopus. 6 courses of fish, 2 pieces per course. According to the menu, you get between 6 to 8 courses of fish. I wish I was lucky enough to have gotten a 7th or 8th piece. Even without it, I left full and satisfied. The last dish was Chef Kaz's homemade black sesame ice cream. 

Apparently, the 830 time slot will be a little bit more lax and you may order extra bites and drinks if you want since they aren't in a rush to serve another group afterwards. Even though I came to the 6pm time slot, I never once felt rushed. 

I paid 75pp, but keep in mind this is not a set price! Depending on the variety of fish and amount of pieces you get, it can get more expensive. Can't wait for my next visit.
name: Nagomi
categories: Japanese, Restaurants

text:

With limited time in St. Louis and the choice between Niche and Sidney Street Café an impossible one we made the only responsible decision available and opted to visit both on the same night, originally planning to enjoy Robert Zugmaier's desserts immediately following Gerard Craft's cuisine at Niche - a plan slightly augmented by the rapidity and small portions of Niche thus allowing us plenty of time to and appetite to also enjoy savories prior to dessert at Sidney Street Café.

Located just down the street from Niche and small from the outside but much larger within our arrival at Sidney Street Café preceded the reservation by nearly 45 minutes but from the moment we arrived we were treated like old friends, first by the maitre d and then by our server, Elissa, who went over the chalkboard of specials detailing each dish and easily convincing me to order more than I would/should have with her exquisite descriptions.  A heavily wooded restaurant with exposed brick walls and dim lighting I will note that on a Saturday night Sidney Street was quite boisterous - almost "bar like" in its atmosphere, but service was professional and the kitchen impeccably timed, every dish coming out at appropriate temperature, execution, and interval.

Moving on to the food itself, I will simply say that while the execution at Niche was excellent, the food at Sidney Street Café spoke to me much more loudly - a menu of personal favorite savories and proteins all executed in unique ways; the gnocchi a bubbling stew served in a cast iron pot and absolutely perfect in texture when matched with the soldiers (and the sauce sopped up with the buttery table bread) and the Foie Gras one of the better preparations I had in 2012 - at once sweet and savory, creamy and crunchy, hot and cold.

Further onward to the desserts - the original impetus for our visit - suffice it to say that if you live in or visit St. Louis and don't experience Robert's desserts you are making a mistake every bit as egregious as missing the Arch or the Missouri Botanical Gardens.  Beautiful, bold, and complex I'd be hard pressed to say which of the three selections was 'best' since each was quite different but as overplayed as the concept is the deconstructed Snicker's was truly outstanding - the variations of each ingredient contributing to the whole and that sorbet something I'd love to see served in a scoop shop anywhere and a reason in itself to visit Sidney Street Café...and possibly even the city of St. Louis.
name: Sidney Street Cafe
categories: Nightlife, Bars, Wine Bars, Soup, Restaurants, American (New)

text:
"Gimme, gimme more
Gimme more
Gimme, gimme more.
Gimme, gimme more
Gimme more
Gimme, gimme more."

Thanks to the baking entrepreneur Tommy, I found my taste buds singing Britney Spear's song "Gimme More" whilst masticating on Mochi Doughnuts for the first time. The shiny, iridescent doughnut box instantaneously transported me to a club with disco balls and LED lights.

For those who are a Mochi Doughnut Newbie like myself, imagine a doughnut with a slightly chewy, stretchy interior texture of gum or gelatin. Then add on unique, fun flavored frosting and toppings for variety.

Today I experienced these four flavors (in order of my favorites):
- Guava: Fruit-forward, tropical, slightly tart, tangy
- Pumpkin Cheesecake: Instantaneous Autumn warmth within, cinnamon, pumpkin butter finger-lickin' goodness, explosion of textures with crunchy bits
- Black Sesame: Smoky, nutty, ground pepper, hint of strawberry on the finish
- Strawberry: Fruity-tootie bubblegum, reminiscent of one's childhood, crunchy sprinkles to top it off

Here's the down-low on how Mōr Doughnuts Pop-Up ordering works:
- Four flavors of doughnuts are posted on the website weekly.
- Online pre-orders open up right at 12pm (noon) on Thursdays. Only a limited batch of 25 boxes are made.
- Choose how many four pack boxes you want, pay with a credit card, and select your pick-up time.
- Show up at either 10 or 11 am on Saturday or Sunday (by 1pm at the latest!), provide proof of identification, drive away, and enjoy!
- Doesn't get any more Covid-friendly than that!

A few tips:
- For freshness, eat sooner rather than later. If they need to sit for some time (particularly in a warm car), leave the cover cracked or open to avoid them from getting hard or crusty.
- Sorry picky eaters, you can't pick and choose your doughnut flavors (as of now). They simply come in a variety pack. I hope to find Mōr Doughnuts at a local cafe soon.

Don't worry Tommy, I'll be coming back for mōr soon!
name: Kin Bakeshop
categories: Pop-Up Restaurants, Restaurants, Food, Donuts

text:
Little Sheep is amazing! I arrived at 5:30 pm on a Friday because that was the time Yelp said it opened. There were other customers already seated so I have a feeling that it opened at 5. Regardless, we were able to get a table right away. I did notice that it got busier around 6 so, but it never seemed like there was a long wait. 

We ordered the half house half spicy broth (the spicy broth is just the regular broth with chili oil and chilis). They charge you per person for the broth, but the waiters and waitresses comes around with additional broth pretty often. The menu prices are pretty decent. Our bill was $55 for two people, but we also ordered wayyy more than we should have. 

Little Sheep also recently started selling ice cream for $3 a cup. One cup is definitely enough for two people, especially after you've just stuffed your face with hot pot. The day I visited, they only had Taro and Black Sesame. I tried the Black Sesame and was very surprised by how much I liked it. One of the waiters swung by our table as we were leaving to ask how we liked it and told us that they will have more flavors in the future. 

What stood out to me the most about Little Sheep was how polite, attentive, and helpful the entire wait staff was. We didn't have a single waiter or waitress, but instead the entire staff attended to us throughout the night as they saw we needed assistance. The restaurant is also very clean and well run. I love that it is perfect for both small and large groups. I can't wait to come back!
name: Happy Lamb Hot Pot
categories: Mongolian, Restaurants, Chinese, Hot Pot

text: I don't usually write reviews.  These doughnuts are out of this world!  If you haven't tried them yet, then you're definitely missing out!  Unlike other doughnuts, these are soft, chewy, and very flavorful!  I can see why they get sold out so quickly every week!  My favorite one was the Black Sesame.
name: Kin Bakeshop
categories: Pop-Up Restaurants, Restaurants, Food, Donuts

text:
Took a few out-of-town business associates to Copia restaurant last Wednesday night, and was quite pleased with the restaurant, food and setting.    We started with a glass of Stag's Leap Cabernet savignon at the bar, until our group of 4 was fully assembled and then told the hostess we were ready to be seated for dinner.  She seated us in their outdoor, covered wine garden which was quite nice, the ambiance of being outdoors but without the street-noise and bustle of many outdoor venues.

We began our meal with a couple of starters, a stuffed portabello mushroom and some flash-fried calamari, both very good.  Specials that night included a bone-in fillet Mignon and a pretty massive 16 oz. beef fillet.  Three of our guest chose the fillet, while I chose the Black sesame Ahi tuna (our server's recommendation), and it did not disappoint.  A bottle or two of the Stag's Leap Cabernet accompanied our dinners and I think everyone had a very satisfying meal.

Was all-in-all quite satisfied with the experience at Copia.  As other reviewers have commented, I was only surprised by the lack of crowd at the restaurant this evening.  Not sure if was due to the lack of the ball team not being in town, or the fact that there are now a number of good choices up-and-down Washington Avenue.
