No matter, for I will definitely return to Copia for both business as well as personal/family occasions in the future.
name: Copia Restaurant & Wine Garden
categories: Arts & Entertainment, Restaurants, Food, Bars, American (New), Wine Bars, Wineries, Seafood, Nightlife, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Steakhouses, Southern

text:
2020 Indy Bucket List: visit an Indy Dough pop-up to score one of the famous, drool-worthy baked goods that appear in your Instagram. This pop-up happens in Studio C, a creative culinary wonderland that consists of private chef dinners, single daily meal specials, morning coffee and this sweet pop-up. 

When Amanda took to creating these artisan donuts, the city immediately flocked. Follow her on Instagram (@indydough) to see the different baked goods she cooks up each week. She usually makes donuts: think everything from cherry vanilla crullers to guava cream cheese old fashioned and black sesame glazed donuts. They're truly cooler than any donuts you've ever tried. 

I saw a post about white cheddar, green onion scones and immediately hopped on it. I messaged Amanda the night before the pop-up and she set one aside, as they usually sell out. This is the kind of place that you will have to arrive incredibly early to even have a chance at scoring a donut. There's a limited amount and they sell out in person within 30 minutes. They'll be a line outside before the place even opens. Go to bed early, get up early, and be ready to wait for the experience!

Thank you Amanda! I gobbled up the scone so quickly and it was so, so, so GOOD.
name: Indy Dough Donut POP-UP
categories: Shopping, Restaurants, Pop-Up Restaurants, Pop-up Shops, Food, Donuts

text:
It was such a joy to watch the chefs cooking in front of us! It's a complete open kitchen and the chefs are right behind the counter. They are so friendly as well. We enjoyed the experience a lot. 
Aside from the experience, we loved the food. We didn't do the tasting menu as we found so many interesting dishes for appetizers and mains on the a la cart menu. The ingredients were fresh and the flavor was on point. 
Starting with the spinach salad, it sounded simple but the pickled cauliflower and purple fingerling potatoes made quite a difference.
The salmon belly had an Asian fusion hoisin sauce and the salmon was fresh and cooked to perfection. The portion is almost big enough to be an entree.
The scallops were very good. They paired very well over rice with the light red curry sauce. 
We got the ice cream and sorbet trio as our dessert. The black sesame ice cream was so special. I've had black sesame ice cream before but the combination with oranges gave it such an interesting twist. The passion fruit sorbet was absolutely tart and refreshing.
name: The Chef and I
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, Bars, Food Delivery Services, American (New), Southern, Restaurants, Tapas Bars, Food, Cooking Classes, Arts & Crafts, American (Traditional), Event Planning & Services, Wine Bars, Caterers, Shopping

text:
I've been meaning to check this place out for a while. It's awesome to have a place with this type of ice cream after seeing videos of street vendors making ice cream "rolls"! 

I love that they have more Asian flavors like black sesame, taro, matcha, etc. I tried the black sesame which was a great mild flavor, not too strong. For most flavors, you can't mix/match. The mix/match flavors come premixed. 

When I went the facility was a little dirty but they were actively cleaning. The decor is cute!

The prices are pretty high for some ice cream - a little under $7 for one size. The ice cream came out with really hard crusted texture, but not sure if that was because I got black sesame. Overall if I have another craving I'll come back!
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
it's cool to have an ice cream place nearby that has asian-inspired flavors - from matcha to Thai tea to black sesame! I tried it and I like how thick and creamy the ice cream is. 

Still extremely busy - with a 30 mins to 1 hr wait, but I think it's because goleta doesn't have really trendy places that are instagrammable and what not, this place fills that void. 
Everything is made to order so it's not the traditional scoop and enjoy, thus it takes about 3-5 mins to make each one. 

There are lots of people taking pictures of the decor and the pretty wing wall! 

It's pricey, but only about 50 cents more (before tax) than the places in LA/SD that I've tried/seen.
 
Can't wait for them to expand with more topping options!
name: Choppa Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Low-star reviews aren't fun. That said, after trying TAP for lunch today I can say that the food was bland and uninspiring for both my friend and I. She ordered the drunken noodles with chicken. The noodles were undercooked, ridiculously long, and unevenly coated with the thick, mostly flavorless brown sauce. Not a trace of wok hei to be tasted (the 'sizzling wok' flavor imbued into properly cooked wok dishes.) There wasn't even a pleasant spiciness to the dish.

I had the green papaya salad with coconut rice. Or at least, that's what the menu called it. Really, the rice was more like white rice with some coconut cream on it, and a few black sesame seeds. The green papaya salad was basically just shaved papaya and some julienned carrot. No peanut, hardly any chili, no tomato, and only a couple of long beans in a basic lime dressing. A sad excuse for an $12 meal, which came to $14.73 after tax and tip. Only the dried chili I asked for on the side saved it for me.

While the bathrooms are gender neutral (win!), the interior is sleek, and there is a patio space which we took advantage of to catch a few rays of winter sun, none of these made up for the lackluster chow. @Lily Z. mentioned that the branch on Upper State is like "Thai food for people who don't want too much spice and flavors." That's what this location was like for me. Did we order wrong? Maybe. But in my book, every dish should be tasty.
name: TAP Thai Cuisine
categories: Thai, Restaurants

text:
This past year has been hard on restaurants, and from what I've been reading and hearing in the Philadelphia food scene, places are still recovering. I get that and I have much grace for that. However, it is still important to at least *try* to bring your A-game. When the kitchen backs up and food is taking long because a world-wide pandemic has drained people from resources and food and their souls, I will smile, be patient, exclaim all the, "I totally understands" as I can muster  and I won't judge *at all*. But when one makes a reservation for a very busy Saturday night to bring an out of town vegetarian for an amazing meal, one hopes that the start of the evening would be appropriately accommodating (I definitely don't need overly accommodating). This was not my experience at Charlie was a Sinner. We walked into a busy restaurant for our outside-dining reservation a few minutes late because the most beautiful weather had landed on Philadelphia and it was the last big weekend of summer and the city was poppin and our 5- minute late arrival was due to very crowded streets as we made our way to the restaurant . I masked up, approached the hostess stand and heard a party of 4 get turned away because they failed to make a reservation. I was glad I knew to make sure I called for a table a week prior and hopeful about the ease of which we would be shown our reserved table. Once I checked in, the hostess told me to wait outside and she would show us to our table. Perfect. We found our place to stand to try to stay out of the fray of the busy sidewalk and servers and I was encouraged to see the empty four top just waiting for diners. I was more than 90 percent sure it would be where we would enjoy our food. But as the hostess came and went out of the door with a few glances our way, I began to doubt myself. Could be for someone else because of COURSE we wouldn't just be standing here for more than 15 minutes if that empty table belonged to US and our 7:00 reservation. Right? I became even more doubtful as I saw her stand and chat and laugh and swap stories with a couple that was standing near the door of the restaurant. This is when I became really curious as to what exactly was happening. It's crowded, tables are in demand, there is an empty one waiting yet we stand while this young woman continues to catch my eye a few times but goes back to her lively exchange with her friends. Remember I'm patient? And forgiving? And truly don't expect special treatment? (All true!) But when she finally made her way over to us (almost 20 minutes later) she  gestured to the empty table and instructed, " You may have a seat at this table."  What?? THIS table? This empty table that I had my eye on since we stood to wait almost 20 minutes ago? I couldn't help my surprise. I sort of looked at her sideways, chuckled and said, "THIS is our table?" She appeared a bit put off. "Yes," she said as if standing right in front of it for twenty minutes while she chatted with other guests was the most appropriate thing to do. There was tension and so as we sat she acknowledged her lack of attention to us by coldly saying, "I apologize for your wait as I was helping another guest". Huh. Not buying it. And that wasn't even an apology and now I've gone on way too long. Sort of like that wait for our table, so I'll get to the food. 

We ordered quite a few dishes off of the tapas style menu. My favorite of the night was the Korean fried tofu. So delicious! Like an explosion in your mouth. Delicately spicy with black sesame. The bao buns were good too, stuffed with pickled slaw and caramelized eggplant. The ricotta was creamy and flavorful. The Charlie sliders were good, but I found that I was desiring more flavor. I ended up spreading some of the ricotta on the burger because the jalapeño jam just didn't show up for me. The curry spiced rice that came with the cauliflower steak was delicious but the cauliflower itself was nothing special. As far as flavoring goes, I detected very little. 

We waited a long time for service. Our order wasn't taken for about another 15 minutes as we sat at the table. But here is that patient part I am willing to impart. It was busy and I could see that and once our server got to us he was efficient and kind. The dishes came out staggered which is one of the reasons I like eating tapas. One keeps getting surprises all through the night. 

The cocktails were good. I started with the Lucy and Ricky which tasted ok. It seemed a bit watered down but was our first drink so not sure if it had been sitting on the bar for a minute before it got to us. The Bullseye, however, was delicious. The bourbon and absinthe was so flavorful and it felt warm going down.

I had been wanting to try this place for a while now. Given the treatment by the hostess and the shall we say, "bad taste it left in my mouth" and dishes that felt a bit tired, I probably won't return. But that Korean Fried Tofu is a happy memory.
name: Charlie Was a Sinner
categories: Bars, Nightlife, Kosher, Burgers, Tapas/Small Plates, American (Traditional), Vegan, Seafood, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Vegetarian

text:
Had my first omakase experience @nagomi, and I was literally on cloud nine 
*
*
*
*
One of my most favorite dishes was the ora of salmon, which basically is the wagyu of salmon  I added the sauce of this dish to the mini poke bowl for one of the courses and it was literally everything. My second favorite has to be the red snapper dripped in yuzu, and oh wow, yuzu is my absolute favorite sauce!!  The blue fin tuna as the course finisher felt like it cleanse my palette for the next course, which was the black sesame dessert.
*
*
The black sesame dessert almost tasted like chocolate Coco puffs!!  Honestly, everything dish melted in my mouth and the omakase experience here is literally one of a kind 

Find me on IG @piggieats_ for more reviews!
name: Nagomi
categories: Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Little Sheep is officially now an AYCE! They revamped the front to a buffet bar where you can pick from small appetizers, rice, noodles, vegetables, seafood, and dipping sauces. It was clean when we went. We did notice that a lot of the originally choices (esp meat and seafood selection) have been erased off the menu but I guess this is the downside of being an AYCE now. 

I really love how they have service cards now (green/red sides) in case you need something or you are good! The price is cheap around $25/person. The broths still taste the same. The free ice cream at the end hit the spot. Taro or black sesame were the choices.

Only cons were that the vegetables weren't washed. I attached a photo of our dirty bok choy!!! Our hotpot stove wasn't turned on and the server never noticed and tried to add our food in for us. We turned the burner on ourselves. Also, it took ages for them to refill our broth at one point even though we flipped the sign to red (need help), we could almost see the 2/3 of our ladle!
name: Happy Lamb Hot Pot
categories: Mongolian, Restaurants, Chinese, Hot Pot

text:
This review is only for their donuts. I didn't really realize that you can find donuts at places other than donut shops and bakeries, so once I discovered Bossie's attractive looking donuts, I knew exactly where to go whenever my next craving for donuts hit.

Some were great while some were only okay. But all of them looked lovely with their colors and toppings. The donuts are more fried than I'm used to, giving the exterior a crunchier texture. I didn't mind this, but they were overall too greasy. Oil heavily stained the box, and my fingers glistened after holding and eating the donuts. Realistically, this review is closer to a 3.5 than a 4 out of 5.

I'm not a classic glazed donut person (too boring for me), so I love the variety of flavor combinations offered. Here's my run down:
- Chocolate and almond toffee: can't go wrong with this one!
- Rose geranium and rhubarb: flavors were faint and could use more rose geranium.
- Cardamom, kumquat, and pistachio: cardamom overpowered the other flavors, and more candied kumquat slices would be great.
- Pistachio cruller: I wish the pistachio flavor was stronger, but the eggy flavor and airy texture of the cruller reminded me of the comforting Chinese fried sugar egg puffs I'd eat at home.
- Honey and black sesame cruller: I was ecstatic to see the introduction of a flavor more commonly found in Asian desserts, black sesame. This was my favorite because I loved the nuttiness and intensity of black sesame.
- Chai cake donut: yum!
name: Bossie's Kitchen
categories: Farmers Market, American (Traditional), American (New), Food, Restaurants

text:
I'm sold! These Mochi doughnuts are not only beautiful, but the texture is soft, pillowy, and chewy. I've seen pictures of the Mochi doughnut trend from other yelper friends outside of Santa Barbara and I'm so happy they are now available here! 

Mind you, this isn't a place that you can just walk into and grab a doughnut. This is a pop-up as of now but I'm hoping they find a permanent location in the near future. I know they would do very well here. They accept online pre-orders on Thursdays beginning at noon. Check out their website to order at: 
https://www.mordoughnuts.com/ 
Pick-up is on Saturday & Sunday and you can choose the time slot they offer. You get 4 Mochi doughnuts for only $12! I thought that was a great deal for what you get. 

Picking up my order was easy. There was a sign on the sidewalk pointing me into the driveway and into the parking lot. So curbside pick-up is the only way to get these right now. Don't forget to wear a mask! 

Each week 4 different flavors are offered. My order consisted of Guava, Black Sesame, Milk & Cereal, and Matcha Wonderland. The Guava was my favorite but then again I'm a fan of all things Guava. The black sesame had a slight smoky, nutty flavor. Milk & Cereal was sweet, creamy and totally reminded me of eating an actual bowl of cereal. The Matcha Wonderland reminded me of drinking matcha tea but the flavor was very subtle. 

I couldn't get over the texture of these! Definitely not your average doughnut. These were very light and chewy just like a Mochi. It was suggested that if we didn't eat them right away to leave the box slightly ajar so they kept their texture. But we ate them right away so all was good. 

It was fun trying each flavor with my son. We cut each one in half and reviewed them by taste in the car lol. Overall kid and mama approved! I can't wait to see what other flavors they offer.
name: Kin Bakeshop
categories: Pop-Up Restaurants, Restaurants, Food, Donuts

text:
Not too shabby for an Indian place in Center City.   Not my favorite, but it works well enough for quick Indian fix.  The mango lassi has pistachios in it, to all those with nut allergies (not me).  It's provides an interesting touch.  The mango lassie here is more tart than sweet, and I definitely prefer sweet.

The sauces for their dishes tends to be on the watery side, where as I prefer mine to be thick and creamy.  The Chicken  Tikka Makhani "Butter Chicken" (Free range / boneless / fresh tomato / cream honey / fenugreek / black pepper / saffron rice) was very good. It was a little in the salty side, but nothing some rice and/or naan can't fix.  

Naan also has black sesame, which I am not a fan of.
name: IndeBlue Modern Indian Food & Spirits
categories: Cocktail Bars, Food Delivery Services, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Food, Bars, Event Planning & Services, Caterers, Restaurants, Indian

text:
I am a carnivore...yeah I said it. I didn't admit it when I went here for fear that I would be blacklisted. I actually made fun of vegans...but I now have a new found respect for them. See a man can change! 
About this place, well it's pretty darn good. I had been to NH several times but this a bit off the beaten path. Our waitress was helpful and nice. Had a great Saturday lunch here. We started out with the olives. They were unique yet yummy. They had a little kick to them. Not a large portion but enough to hold me over...since my philosophy is "a meal is not complete with some sort of meat"...I figured I would leave hungry. That would not be the case. After the olives our main meal came out. I had the Edamame Falafel Wrap (black sesame tahini *sesame paste*, marinated carrot & cabbage, pickled radish, shredded lettuce) which was really good! It had a lot of flavor and wasn't too messy (it could have used some chicken but I digress). Had a lot of different flavors that went well together. A side of their potato wedges which were a bit overcooked and in a mustard type oil...interesting but didn't do the trick. 
Their serving sizes are average. Prices are a little higher than expected but the quality does overshadow this. I would recommend a stop in just for the experience if you have not been to a vegan place. And my meat fix, well it didn't really happen. I was very satisfied with the meal. Relax carnivores, I am not giving up on my meat eating ways but this place does come close to moving the meter a bit. ENJOY!
name: Sprig & Vine
categories: Vegan, Vegetarian, Restaurants

text:
More Sugar is a cute new addition to Chinatown, tucked away on the corner of 11th and Cherry.  Although their sign says "Brunch & Dessert", they also offer a full dinner menu, which is what my friend and I had. 

For our entrees, we ordered the rack of lamb and seared tuna bowl (spoiler: it comes on a plate lol). The lamb was decently tender and flavorful, but the star of the night was the tuna bowl -- I could eat plain rice with their house special sauce and die in peace. 

For dessert, we ordered the sesame creme brulee and tiramisu. I absolutley loved the nutty addition of black sesame to the creme brulee, but it had an unexpectedly thick consistency. The tiramisu also fell a little flat with the thick layer of cocoa powder leaving us in caughing fits. 

Overall, I'd describe More Sugar as the new kid on the block, still figuring its identity. It currently offers a little bit of everything to please everyone, but if they narrowed their focus, perfected their craft, and just ran with it, I believe they could easily become a community favorite. 

I will definitely be back to try their brunch (so rare in Chinatown!) and can't wait to see how this promising little business develops.
name: More Sugar
categories: Desserts, Restaurants, Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Three stars because it was A-ok! The fourth star is for Jeff and Mandie H. haahaa The pork belly nachos were tastier than anything else we tried, wish the other dishes I tried were equally as adventurous. Ahi tuna had a refreshingly different rub on it, rather than the usual black sesame or straight  peppercorn arrangement. The wine here is fine, and can't wait to try a lot more of it. (I did it wrong and ordered a flight of sparkling wines-gross except for the almond variety) The filet was impressive. It had a soft velvety texture, and great buttery flavor, no knife required. At first sight the inner portion of the steak looked like red glass. Mmm the value. The "hairy woolly mammoth shrimp" were tasteless because you can't bread a shrimp with bland flour, and then wrap it in phyllo dough strings of additional tastelessness. It's just wrong! They were worth undressing thoe..just gotta take their "coats" off. I'll be back for the steak, and to correct my grevious flight choice!
name: Cooper's Hawk Winery & Restaurants - Tampa
categories: Event Planning & Services, American (Traditional), Nightlife, Restaurants, Bars, Wineries, American (New), Wine Tasting Room, Gluten-Free, Arts & Entertainment, Party & Event Planning, Wine Bars, Food, Seafood

text:
Try the Pahd Thai, Mango Red Curry, and the Thai Summer Roll with shrimp.  Check this jewel out in Avon, IN.

I have to admit that this place has been around in Avon, IN for three years now and this is the first opportunity we dined there.  The saying, "It was worth the wait" applies in this instance.  We left full, refreshed, and with plans to come right back with friends.  You have not had Thai until you've been here.  Well decorated, very clean, cozy dining room, and well attentive staff are certainly making a presence at this restaurant.  The menu was not cluttered with a lot of variations of the same dish, offered a great variety for everyone's tastes, and coverage the bases to appeal to the most finicky diners.  

We started our meal off with he Summer Rolls topped with fresh shrimp.  They featured a nice, cool soybean wrap and were light and refreshing with the peanut sauce.  We then selected the Spicy Lemon Grass Soup, which was amazing.  Hearty chunks of tomato, onion, lemon grass, and other veggies complimented the clear, lime, cilantro, and green onion medley.  This would make a great lunch for those looking to cut back and eat healthy.  For our entrees, we sampled the featured Mango Red Curry, which was prepared on the mild scale to our liking.  However, we elected to try two other dishes since we were in the state of adventure, since this was a new experience.  

To our further amazement, the Pahd Cashew Nut with shrimp and the Pahd Thai shrimp exceeded our expectations.  Generous portions, fresh selections of veggies and shrimp (I might add they were flavorful and 25-30 count size), along with the very best quality jasmine rice with black sesame seeds for garnish, arrived to our table within a very quick amount of time.  As we dove into the dishes, you could taste why Thai is my new favorite cuisine.  Thai uses fresh herbs, vegetables, and seasonings to enhance the natural flavors of the ingredients. You won't find soy sauce to mask the flavor or heavy, thick sauces.  Crisp, clean, and light, the entrees left use full and content.  We took half of each entrée home as well.  

Sometimes people get intimidated to try new foods from different cultures, but Thai Lanna serves these dishes from a colorful menu with featured dish pictures and menu descriptions.  They also serve any dish with different degrees of heat.  You can go plain with no spice, Mild, Medium, Hot, and THAI HOT.  Try at your risk since I selected "hot" on one dish and it cleared my head with a pleasant and surprisingly HOT bite.  I am not complaining by any means...I loved it.  I am just trying to set the tone so you won't go over board.  Sample, sample, sample and you will enjoy the experience.

The wait staff is truly attentive to every detail.  Fine linen napkins, tidy table tops, and rich atmosphere provided for an unbelievable dining experience.  Our glasses were full, dirty dishes were quickly removed, and the table was well prepared between courses.  We were in and out within an hour and we enjoyed our long conversation with the owner, Kelly, who was on site and working her magic in the kitchen.  We discussed her inspirations for her dishes and complimented her on the experience.

My recommendation is to try a little adventure and visit Thai Lanna in Avon, IN.  The prices are very reasonable for the portions and this is going to be our new home for  while.  I am sure if you are looking for a fresh new place to try out, you will leave pleased and impressed.

I am looking forward to featuring this establishment on my new website that is in pre-launch.  We sure to look for a complete feature with video in the future.
name: Thai Lanna
categories: Tex-Mex, Thai, Restaurants

text:
First things first:  the food is the highlight of K-Fusion.  It's as Korean as possible, while still appealing to an average American palate.  It's advertised as "fusion" so I can't knock it for being 100% authentic Korean, and it meant that my boyfriend could enjoy it since he's not super familiar with Korean flavor combinations. 
Why the 3 stars:  the business model and service just killed any chance that I could give this place more than 3 stars.    

The menu is haphazard mess of different boxes of appetizers, mains, sushi, buffet, lunch buffet add-on prices, sides prices, prices for sides with something, prices for rice, prices for... It's just nickel & dimed to death and incredibly poorly organized.  Add to this that the server we had told us that we could only get banchan (the variety of kimchis and side dishes that typically are brought to you with a meal, and included in the cost of your meal) from the buffet - but then said I could actually get banchan (which she kept calling "sides" and didn't understand what I meant when I said banchan for .99 cents a plate from the buffet - but then the food runner said I could get them only from the buffet, at $25 for the buffet & sushi price on the menu...  Yeah, confused yet?

We finally established that you can either get the all-you-can-eat sushi and "sides" buffet OR you can get your "sides" from the buffet for .99 cents each.  I chose the per plate price of .99 cents. The server asked me twice how many sides I was getting so that she could add them to our tab, and I told her twice that I would need to go see what the options were first since she couldn't tell me. 

The buffet was lacking sorely, especially for a Friday night.  The "House Special" salad is just spring lettuce mix with 2 bottles of store-bought dressing.  There were also sliced apples. The banchan dishes available were a cucumber kimchi, mixed vegetable pickle, yellow curry main dish, rice, and miso soup.   I dished a small plate of cucumber kimchi and of mixed veg pickle.  Before I could finish dishing the server came up to me to ask again how many plates I was getting.  I told her two and went back to the table. 
Adding to the frustration were the cooks who were talking about me as I was at the "buffet".  I know just enough Korean to know they were discussing the "African" in the place. It definitely didn't make me feel welcome.  If there's a way to say I felt like someone was worried I was going to shoplift a side dish because of the color of my skin, this is it.  It was all a bit absurd, and I considered leaving. 

I don't know if K-Fusion took on this pricing model because they had previously given banchan to those who ordered appetizers and there was considerable waste, but it was really disappointing.  We thought the cucumber was good (thick slices, marinated in gochujang, and I think some fermented shrimp paste) and the mixed veg pickle was bright and refreshing, with good firmness still in each veg.  The waitress confirmed that everything was made fresh in-house, including the sauces, and it showed in the quality. 

We ordered Bulgogi (1 of 4 ways to rate a Korean restaurant; the others being their banchan, bibimbap, and kimchi),  spicy pork, and the shrimp tempura app.  I tried to get the BF to order the bibimbap, but he was still scarred from the horrible one he got at Gang Nam and flat refused to try again. 

I was nervous because we didn't see traditional cabbage kimchi anywhere on the menu or buffet, but the server assured me we would get the first one free with our entrees.  

After the confusion the servers had with the food, and Korean food tradition in general, and terrible menu/meal structure I was a bit dubious of how good the food would be.  This is where K-Fusion won us over. 

The shrimp tempura were fresh shrimp with a deep golden and super crispy panko tempura crust.  The shrimp were sweet and cooked just right.  The ponzu sauce wasn't sweet, and added just the right counter note to the tempura.  It was the first bright moment in our meal. 

The Bulgogi and Spicy Pork were spot on.  My Bulgogi was made the traditional way, and I could taste that they didn't use pineapple juice to sweeten and texturizing the beef, but instead went with kiwi.  This makes a world of difference and is much appreciated.  The spicy pork wasn't too hot (it was actually pretty mild), but this allowed for all of the flavors to be tasted.  The rice was cooked well and a few black sesame were added. 

We were charged for the one kimchi they brought after we asked for it.  The server said she'd take it off, but we'd have to pay for the second.  We had to remind her that we were only given 1, after we asked for it...  She adjusted the charge. Ugh.

K-Fusion has promise.  It reminds me of a Korean street market food stand.  It needs more dish options (or specials), better educated servers, complimentary banchan, and it'd be a regular visit for us.  For now, it'll be an occasional take-out place.
name: K-Fusion Korean BBQ
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Barbeque, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars, American (Traditional)

text:
Emeril's is Lagasse's namesake restaurant on Tchoupitoulas in New Orleans. While it is streetside with large windows, it is a beautiful restaurant. There is a full bar as well as a large dining room that looks towards the kitchen that is open to the dining room. We were nearly as far from the dining room as you could be, so I did not see much there.

We had 3 servers who were working with our table. At the beginning of service, they were a little distracted because they were winding down after a busy lunch service (our lunch reservation was at 1PM). Fortunately, we were pretty relaxed and were not overly anxious about being served.

Because of the size of our party and our appetite, we did 3 courses, but we shared so I was able to try many dishes. For our appetizers, we had:

Homemade Andouille and Boudin Sausages: a 3.5" link of a soft boudin sausage (white sausage with rice) and a 3.5" link of smoked andouille were served atop slow cooked collard greens and topped with a piece of toast and beer braised onions with a bit of country mustard on the side. The sausages were great. The white sausage was mild and very well-seasoned. The andouille had a nice heat. The greens were mild and the onions were sweet. The tangy mustard was just right.

Blue Crab and Brie: fresh angel hair pasta was tossed in a brie cream sauce with fresh corn kernels, shredded sweet crab meat and slices of jalapeno. This was a sweet and spicy dish that was well prepared.

Escargots Buorguigon: 4 halves of red potatoes were each filled with escargots and resting in a pool of garlic butter and topped with bacon-breadcrumbs and sweetbreads. I don't like potatoes, and the escargots were a little small, which was a letdown. The sweetbreads were great - very tender and fresh. The herbed butter and bacon breadcrumbs were also great.

Seafood Gumbo: well-seasoned brown based soup with generous chunks of seafood, bits of okra and quite a bit of rice. This was very good - not the best that I have had, but very good.

Shaved Brussels Sprouts Salad: shredded sprouts were tossed with cubes of unripened peaches in a vinaigrette and topped with grated parmesan and half of a soft boiled egg. This (and the sausage) were the two best appetizers. The crispy veggies with the tangy vinaigrette and nutty cheese and rich egg were a nice combination. The peaches were flavorless, but it was very good.

LO1 had the BBQ shrimp for lunch. There were four or five super tender shrimp covered in barbecue sauce made with housemade Worcestershire sauce and topped with chives and served with a little buttermilk biscuit. She inhaled the biscuit so I did not get a bite, but the shrimp were great.

LO2 had a custom made grilled cheese sandwich. A brioche bun was grilled with cheddar cheese and served with housemade French fries. The sandwich was fantastic, and she ate almost all of it!

For our entrees, we had:

Crusted Gulf Drum: my choice was a flakey white fish that was crusted in a seasoned breadcrumb mixture and served atop a mélange of red bell pepper, zucchini and mirliton squash with a flavorful brown sauce. I thought it was amazing. Light fish with a crispy exterior, sweet veggies and flavor forward sauce.

BBQ Roasted Salmon: fantastic fresh salmon with crispy skin was smothered with sweet BBQ sauce and served atop squash and crispy potato pieces and topped with fried onions and some fresh parsley. The BBQ sauce here is amazing. This was definitely one of the best dishes at the table.

Pork Sandwich: a rather large Kaiser roll had a breaded pork cutlet and was topped with provolone cheese, giardiniera, and little tomato. This had almost no flavor - I would skip it.

Pastrami Salmon Rachel: a thin housemade black sesame bagel was topped with smoked salmon, gruyere, country mustard, cabbage slaw, chopped egg and Russian dressing. While it was the most un-kosher deli sandwich, it was fantastic. The bagel was toasted and slightly crispy. The salmon was nice and smokey. The rich and tangy toppings added just the right crunch. Very good.

We shared 3 desserts. The chocolate peanut butter pie was meh. It was basically an Oreo cookie crust with chocolate and peanut butter flavored fudge layers with whipped cream and peanut brittle. It was not very flavorful. The banana cream pie was pretty good - graham cracker crust was filled with custard and bananas and topped with whipped cream and chocolate shavings. It was very dense and rich and the second best banana cream pie that I have had. The best dessert that we had was the chocolate dauberge cake. It was a thin, long slice of the chocolate layer cake topped with malted chocolate balls, candied orange and malt whipped cream. It was a rich, chocolate cake with a light sponge and rich frosting, lovely sweet tangy accents and a little coffee flavor.

The service was excellent and the food was very good. There were some misses - the pork sandwich, the escargot and the desserts. But it was a great experience.
name: Emeril's
categories: Seafood, Cajun/Creole, Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Visited Saturday afternoon to watch the Flyers game. The parking lot is convenient, and it has cameras on the entrance/exit. The decor is fresh, the restaurant and bathrooms look clean, and the layout is nice and open (at least when there are fewer than 30 people there). The first floor bar is covered with TVs, but they're not huge. If your focus is a TV, sit at the bar, not a table, unless you have great vision.
The tap list has a good mix of local beer, big beer, and cheap beer ($3 yuengling drafts are hard to beat). The service was good; drinks were quick, and our waitress was always back to check on us. 
The tuna wontons were fantastic! Raw tuna, avocado, black sesame seeds, and Sriracha aioli on a crispy, fried wonton. It speaks for itself. 
The bbq chicken flatbread was really good, too. The bbq sauce was rich and bold, and the flatbread was nice and crunchy. 
We also had the soft pretzels, which were so hot, soft, and fluffy. They didn't have much of the soda-y crust that would give them a distinctive pretzel flavor, but that didn't stop me from enjoying them with the cheesy mustard sauce.
There are ways to keep Taphouse 23 easy on your wallet, and there are ways to go all-out, but they still keep the number of choices from being overwhelming. 
Highly recommended, at least for a leisurely afternoon.
name: Taphouse 23
categories: Nightlife, American (New), Pubs, Restaurants, Bars

text:
Ah, Froyo. I love frozen yoghurt and I love options. Sometimes, too much is a bad thing, but that's why I love how you can put as much as you want! I've been to my fair share of froyo places, but they tend to have more Asian flavors like taro or black sesame. Here? They have imaginative AMERICAN flavors like Orange Dreamsicle and Blueberry Pecan Pie. Same concept of unlimited toppings, though, and they're pretty similar as well, though they have other items like cereal and granola as well.

I actually struggled a bit when I came in. The staff were busy taking care of orders so I stood by the menu and alternated between studying that and staring at the extensive toppings bar. Then I got distracted by something else. I finally realised that the actual yogurt was behind me. I knew the staff saw me, but I guess they thought I knew how it worked. Would have been nice if they asked me if it was my first time or needed help. I mean, someone can't be so indecisive to stare at the menu and then toppings for 3 minutes, right?

First, I wanted a smoothie, but I already had a smoothie that morning. I was curious about the Froyo Float and was amused by the Beer Float. I saw the crepes (very reasonably priced at around $4 each), but I wanted something cool... though I was tempted by those as well. I can't say anything about the size, but if I came again, I'd probably try one with a smoothie. I ended up going for a custom froyo. 

Something new that they offer are these little dividers to prevent your yoghurt flavors from combining. I added one just for fun, even though they don't really work for me. I love all sorts of flavors and I love trying new things, so I usually have around 4 flavors or so. I added two flavors in each of the two compartments and threw some toppings on top. Their froyo tastes like most of the froyo places I've been to. The flavors were unique to them and mostly distinct. It was good - can't really complain. If I lived in the area, I'd definitely come by if I needed a froyo fix.

Hubby got his iced coffee - cold brew. He's curious about that. He thought it tasted fine... I think he still prefers his coffee hot and black. I tasted it as well since I prefer cold drinks. It tasted a little different. I'm not a coffee connoisseur by any means though I used to drink it a lot (Hubby drinks more than enough for the two of us now), I thought it tasted a little different. Smoother? Different undertone? Either way, it wasn't a bad thing. It also seems like they use Intelligentsia coffee. I'm not familiar with this brand, but I heard of it a lot when I started research of coffee places to visit while visiting the Midwest.

All in all, I love their choices. After you order, they bring it to you (unless you designed your own froyo treat). The place was pretty large and clean with a good amount of customers coming in and out. It would have been nice if they were less passive with their service, though. Despite that, they were pretty nice when they did help.
name: Pearings Cafe + Frozen Yogurt
categories: Food, Specialty Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Internet Cafes, Coffee & Tea, Fruits & Veggies, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Do-It-Yourself Food

text:
Very attentive, polite, nice and just so many words to their employees. Their food was phenomenal it was sooooo good the bread were fresh and the meat was also   Nicely seasoned and their chicken were sooooo crispy and great. I for sure gonna go back there. Just a little btw they add black sesame to their bread which not everyone does making it more special than most place. 
The only thing I think you should avoid is the cheese fries it's a bit over priced for some cheese on the top but that would not change the fact their fries are crispy and salted nicely and also won't change the fact I'm giving this place an direct 5
name: District Donuts Sliders Brew
categories: Coffee & Tea, Food, Donuts, Bakeries, Restaurants, Sandwiches, American (Traditional)

text:
Michelle and the whole crew at Twelve Baskets Cupcakes provided my family and I with a very unique, delicious alternative to your typical dessert. I threw a party for my mother-in-law and had 2 dozen cupcakes delivered. It truly was a show-stopper as people were interested in trying something different: Asian Fusion delicacies. They were an absolute hit at the party as young and old alike were clamoring to try as many flavors as possible. 
The Azukies 'n Cream was truly original. The cake was soft and fluffy and the frosting was succulent. The Miso Caramel Apple was amazing too as was the Red Velvet. But the winner by far (for me) was the Peanut Butter Crumble- perfect balance of sweet, nutty flavor and crunchiness. Just delish! 
We really couldn't go wrong with any of the choices and I will be ordering again ASAP as there a few flavors I want to try. Like the Black Sesame Honey. Or the Lemongrass Blues... You get the idea!
name: Twelve Baskets
categories: Cupcakes, Bakeries, Desserts, Food

text:
Based on the crowd in the restaurant at 8 PM on a Saturday, Ela is doing a nice job of attracting an older audience from the suburbs into the city to dine.  It is clear that the food they are serving cannot be had on the main line.  This does not mean that it is the right choice for someone who lives half a mile away.  There are too many other good options for the money.

We started off with the oysters, 5 for $14 (not a great value, but not an insane markup) that came with fried shallots and a vinaigrette.  They were good, but there was not nearly enough acidity and the shallots tasted exactly like French's out of the can.  The dish was decent, but not memorable.

We then moved on to the scallop noodles and the whipped foie.  The scallop noodles were tasty and an inventive take on the mollusk, but the seasoning fell flat.  Once you got over the fact that they made scallops into noodles, it was a boring dish that tasted like butter and black sesame seeds.  The foie was a huge disappointment.  I honestly did not taste any liver and even if there is some in there, it was impossible to recognize with the other many flavors on the plate, most of which tasted as though they belonged in a dessert (not just fruity, but overly sweet).

Finally our shared entree arrived, a small but very well cooked piece of short rib.  The portion was way too small for $23, when considering that there was basically nothing else on the plate and the meat cost $2.50.  It was very tender and served with a yogurt and pineapple gel.  The flavors worked very well together, but again nothing memorable.

We left hungry (we were aware from the outset that we might have under ordered), but had no interest in trying another dish.  The plates were too small, too expensive, and not tasty enough to warrant a return trip.  I was hoping for better.
name: Ela
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Nightlife

text: This place has some nice pastries but is  bit overpriced compared to what I'm used to paying in Chinatown. It is a chain and I believe they don't make their products from scratch, but rather "bake them off" That said everything I tried was fresh. I like the toasts, but my favorite is the black sesame/pumpkin donut and some kind of french croissant-like pastry w/chocolate. Buns are so-so and like I said you can do a lot better in Chinatown for about half the price. Items at PB tend to range from $1.40- $2.00.
name: Paris Baguette
categories: Coffee & Tea, Bakeries, Desserts, Food, Patisserie/Cake Shop

text:
I seriously love this place. I'm surprised by the average rating. My boyfriend took me here on our first date, and I immediately knew I wanted the keep him. Fast forward, I had a friend coming in town and immediately thought of this place. On Monday they have an awesome half priced special for certain sushi rolls as well as select 2 for 1 drinks. We sat at the bar, always the best decision when you're having drinks. The bartender had a mishap on the wasabi martini and asked if we were interested in trying it. I honestly didn't think I'd like it, but it was ridiculously good. It had a super smooth flavor, a wasabi flavor but not overpowering. 

We ordering 3 sushi rolls off of the half price list, and they were all amazing. We also ordered the rock shrimp appetizer with black sesame seeds. Confession, the gentleman next to us ordered it first. When we asked the name, they let us try it first. Good choice! Sooo... we went with that too. Everything was delicious. James and Mike were amazing bartenders. Funny. Awkward. Entertaining.  I also tried the lychee mule, nice rendition of the moscow. I'd definitely order it again. Can't wait their come back here!
name: Virago
categories: Sushi Bars, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Bars, Restaurants, Lounges

text: My husband and I have never tried sushi. He loves fish I myself can't stand it but I figured we'd give it a shot. Omg I can actually say I like fish now. We had the Omakase with sake pairing. For the 2 of us with a generous tip which our waitress well deserved it was almost 350.00 this was a very special night and we wouldn't normally spend that on an evening. So worth it. The food was fantastic. Each dish was like a work of art. We were started with 2 oysters with Uni miso and salmon roe. Sweet salty and a burst of flavor.(forgot to get a picture of this one but man was beautiful) Then a trio of sushi. California roll with salmon tartar, kimchi sea snail and eel. Wasn't a huge fan of the snail but the other 2 were awesome. Then had seared scallops with truffle mayo. Couldn't really taste the truffle. Black sesame cream soup followed. I would have licked the bowl if I was at home. Then an assortment of sashimi. 3 kinds of tuna, butterfish and octopus with salmon roe. Didn't like how chewy the octopus was but the Tuna and Butterfish was again amazing. Then steak with a miso gravy....Super yummy. This dish was the only one paired with red wine instead of sake. Then came a Uzu (spelling??) Sorbet to cleanse the palate. A sushi dish of 4 in total 2 raw and 2 blow torched. All were delicious. For dessert a green tea creme Brule and mochi black sesame ice cream. Paired with a plum sake similar to ice wine. Our waitress explained everything in great detail. We had just enough time between courses for conversation. Didn't feel rushed at all. For a Sunday night it was rather busy but not too loud. Will definitely be going back.
name: Japonais Bistro
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
This is a great brunch spot!

PARKING - parking is a little hard to find, so you might circle around a few times.

PLACE - interior design is black, both sleek and chic. Beautiful place to take photos of.

SERVICE - great! Server gave us enough attention without smothering us.

MEAL - this restaurant features a seasonal menu
1) Breakfast gnocchi (coddled eggs, bacon, crispy potato skins): I never imagined eating gnocchi for brunch, but now I can see it as a thing. The gnocchi was soft and delicious. The bacon and crispy potato skins were the saltiest part of the meal, which is balanced out by the eggs. Favorite dish of the meal.

2) Cornbread waffle (peanut butter, root beer syrup): I don't like root beer, but I was curious about root beer syrup. This was a good dish with homemade peanut butter (which is so much fluffier than store brand). The cornbread made the waffle less heavy in the stomach. Also a good dish, not my favorite.

3) ELA burger (shitake mushroom jam, aged cheddar,
 black sesame bun, potato chips): this burger is REALLY GOOD. The balance between patty and bun and veggies are perfect. The chips were special because they were house made and seasoned well - it was neither too salty nor too bland.

ELA does a great job of making minor substitutions to their dishes that result in me not feeling as bloated as I normally would, like the cornbread waffle (instead of flour). ELA also does a great job with the balance of texture and flavors. It was a delicious party in my mouth.
name: Ela
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Nightlife

text:
The potential is missed

*Beef moist and delicious
*Chicken is dry with a ton of sesame seeds to add...something. Maybe it's to sell more toothpicks. 
*Lamb is chewy. 
*Chicken wings are lifeless with little flavor. 
*Spicy tatchu Ramon had over coked eggs, oily, with a good spicy burn of a kick. Chewy mushroom. I'll pass. 
*#12 spicy crab $10.95 is good. I like the tiny red bottle of spicy stuff for the kick
*#3 spicy maguro roll, love the sumo sauce, too much mayo that shifts the mood. Too many black sesame adds crunch and sticks in my teeth

I like the patio. That's about it. 
Parking is tough unless you park in the Paseo garage. Service is slow and the food is not great. I'm not telling you, the Yelper, anything you have not already read. So why is management not reading. Let us help you make this place great! 
I want to come back and enjoy meats on sticks!
name: Sachi Ramen And Robata Bar
categories: Ramen, Vegetarian, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text: We used to eat here all the time but ran into a bad patch where the food and service and quality control was consistently bad. So we just stopped going. It's been over a year and today I decided to try it again. The staff was friendly and told me the location had made some changes to improve. I'm happy to report that our wraps were very good, tasted fresh, and the order was correct, the location was clean and the service was quick and friendly. My daughter thought her quesadilla was just okay, the cheese seemed off a little. And we didn't get any of the little black sesame seeds my husband likes. That's why four stars instead of five. But we are happy overall and will go back. We missed it!
name: Crazy Bowls & Wraps
categories: Fast Food, Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Salad, Wraps

text:
Came here Sunday for brunch after Erin Express shenanigans on Saturday. I had a Gilt City voucher for two cocktails and two entrees.

Even just the word 'cocktail' made me cringe at that moment in time, so our server (who was really freaking nice by the way) was awesome enough to switch out the price of the cocktails for two coffees and a side of bacon.The cocktail menu was extensive and creative, though, so if you're in the mood for a boozy brunch I'd definitely come here just for that. 

The bacon though.... if you're a crispy bacon kinda person, this is your kinda bacon. So good. 

Immediately picking up on our hungover, struggle-city state, our server recommended two items to us, the burger and the short rib eggs benny. We decided to trust him on this one and I'm glad we did. 

The burger was served with mushroom jam, chedda, a black sesame bun and (square) tots, and was really good, BUT, it was suuuuuuper rare. As in still moo-ing. But, again, really good.

We ended up having to box up the eggs benny and ate it a couple hours later, but it was still fantastic. 

The meal came with some complimentary chocolate brioche bread which was the perfect accompaniment to the coffee. "No I don't want a piece of warm, chocolately deliciousness fo free," said NO GIRL EVER. 

Love the space, the service was above average, and the food was just what the doctor ordered. Will come again.
name: Ela
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Nightlife

text:
I've been coming to eat at this restaurant since I was a kid. I don't care what the sign over the door says, this place is Benkay and it is delicious. Service is fast, polite, and friendly. The old man who runs the floor may look like a creeper, but he's nice, I promise. 

I always get either a bento box or a rice bowl when I'm here. Oyakodon is a personal favorite--here, it's pretty good, although I liked the one at the now-closed Shintomi better. Katsudon's not bad either. The bento boxes are great--the special box in particular, with an amazing assortment of sashimi, is a treat. They've got these INCREDIBLE chicken wings that I could eat a hundred of. The portions are enormous and amazing. Good, solid Japanese food is always such a treat. 

The grocery store attached to it, though, kicks my level of love for this place up quite a few notches. For years, every time the fam would come here to eat, we would pass through the grocery store on the way out to buy dessert, whether it be the authentic plum candies or Chinese mochis (much larger than the Japanese version white people are used to, filled with red bean paste or black sesame paste instead of ice cream, in my opinion vastly superior), the Swiss rolls or those long rolls of sweet biscuit things that defined my early childhood in Singapore, or the red bean/green tea ice cream that are relatively new additions. You walk toward the bathroom and turn left past the row of Japanese mangas (comic books) and DVDs into nirvana. God, I love it. The woman behind the counter has been there for years. They have all the essential varieties of Hi-Chews and more Pocky than you can shake a stick at.

Come here and stuff yourself for lunch or dinner, then go to the grocery store and buy snacks and candies to sustain you until your next trip here. Good for families, dates, lunch with friends, ANYTHING--this place was vital to my childhood and adolescence, and I can't wait to go home and go back.
name: Sonobana Japanese Restaurant and Grocery
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese

text:
As a Jappy (short for Jewess *not* Japanese) ... and entitled natural beauty with a taste for all things delicious, I'd written this restaurant off simply for its South St. address. 

I am pleased to report that I am now officially over myself. Tonight, I popped my Gaja Gaja cherry. 

The restaurant is lovely. It's serene, the service is really good, and actually let me cut to the most important part: the fish. 

Unlike the four or five other sushi places I've been to in Philly since moving here this year including more notable and celebrated places like Fat Salmon, Gaja Gaja is the only one whose sushi menu focuses on actual fish. 

(In fact I'm really unclear why so many sushi restaurants in Philadelphia feature almost anything BUT fish: tempura/crunchy rolls, mayo everything, sweetened everything, crab stick everything, cream cheese, jelly, bacon ....)

Tonight I had:

Miso soup (delectable - nice complexity to the broth, and perfectly piping hot, just the way I like it)

House salad (standard iceberg w good fresh ginger dressing)

Real California roll (lump crab meat instead of crab stick -- very nice to have the option of real, as crab stick is just crab-flavored weirdness whipped up with flour.) The rolls are studded with white and black sesame seeds -- very nice)

Unagi sushi (a standout)

Yellowtail sashimi and maguro sushi (both were very fresh with velvety texture and clean flavor)

Ikura (honking-big salmon fish roe on slightly unwieldy chunks of cucumber. Sim, the sushi chef - not sure if I'm spelling his name correctly - engaged with me at various times throughout my me, and explained to me that the roe is marinated in sake and honey to achieve a mild flavor. I was very pleased.) 

Very delicious iced green tea.

I wasn't in an alcohol mood so I did not seriously peruse their booze menu. But I couldn't help but notice the wine bottles presented over the sushi bar.  Mondavi, Jacob's Creek, Beringer, probably Kendall-Jackson ... blech ... all bottom of the barrel (ba dum bum).

Beerwise they seem weak as well (eg, Coors Light, Heineken) but they do have Sapporo, which is redeeming. They offer sakes as well. I am not knowledgeable about sake, so I can't offer insight here.

In sum: the food was delish, all presented very nicely; service was ***extremely*** friendly and warm; the atmosphere was refined and chill; and the prices were ridiculously reasonable. 

They also offer a Korean menu -- I'm not a fan of hybrid menus (ie Japanese and Chinese) but fortunately it doesn't detract from their fine sushi.

Highly recommend!
name: Gaja Gaja
categories: Japanese, Sushi Bars, Korean, Restaurants

text: Great food, great atmosphere, great service (especially from Meg)! My mom and I stopped by here taking our chances after seeing the 3.5 star review. This place deserves a much better rating. We had the black sesame and Parmesan flatbread to start (my favorite!), fettuccine Alfredo with chicken and spaghetti carbonara. Everything was great! My mom is typically hard to please and is ready to come back!
name: Porta Via Ristorante e Bar
categories: Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Pizza, Cocktail Bars, Food, Gelato, Italian

text: This spot is amazing for brunch (and it's served all day). They have several gluten free options. We ordered the Banana Chip (which was two HUGE pancakes bigger than my face - the black sesame cream that comes with it takes it to another level), the Fried Pickeled Okra, and the Shrimp & Grits. All gluten free, all absolutely delicious. I'm definitely coming back next time I'm in town.
name: Bearcat Cafe
categories: Coffee & Tea, Vegan, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Food

text:
Wow, I'm in love with these cupcakes! I'm not even a big sweets person and maybe that's why I like them so much (b/c they're not that sweet), but I would have these for desserts all the time! I haven't placed an order with them before, but I just had a tasting of their mini cupcakes tonight at the Yelp's 10th Anniversary Bash -- O M G! You can bet your ass off I'll be making an order at some point in the near future. I won't even need the to deliver, so hopefully pick-up is an option. 

The available selections were: black sesame honey, takes two to taro, miso salted caramel, and azukies' n cream. The GF and I liked them all, but I personally liked the miso, taro, azukies, and then black sesame. I'm already spreading the word to friends that it's the best I've had! Maybe because they're Asian inspired and they hit home for me, but I would definitely recommend them to the adventurous people out there to try.
name: Twelve Baskets
categories: Cupcakes, Bakeries, Desserts, Food

text:
I'm a pizza junky...so nothing makes me happier than when friends pick a great pizza place for dinner.

Typically I'm a pizza purist​ and stick with traditional​​ ingredients but not when I go to CPK, I go straight for the Thai Chicken Pizza ($14.49). It was AMAZING, crisp crust, delicious fresh ingredients with just a little pop of spice.

My husband and I each started with the Petite Wedge Salad ($5.49). I cannot imagine what a BIG wedge salad looks like... this was a big wedge of fresh, crisp iceberg​ lettuce with big chunks of tomato, crunchy bacon and crumbled hard-cooked​ egg with plenty of really creamy flavorful​l blue cheese dressing.

Our friends shared the ​Szechuan​ Chicken Dumplings ($8.99) it was a good size portion of dumplings​ with a slightly spicy sauce, green onions, cilantro, ​and black sesame seeds. They raved about the flavor and lightness​ of the dumplings.

Beyond my Thai pizza,​ everyone else went for a different style​​ of​ pizza. 

My husband had the Thin Crust Sicilian ($16.39) Spicy marinara, Italian sausage, spicy Capicola ham, salami, Mozzarella, shaved Parmesan, fresh basil & oregano. RAVE reviews, crispy, lots of flavors​ and a ton of toppings.

Our friends had an​ Original Hand Tossed Pepperoni ($13.99) piled with big fat slices of pepperoni.

The other friend had the Mushroom, Pepperoni, Sausage ($15.49) with cauliflower​ crust. Really, really well-made​ pizza, great flavors and he didn't miss the regular crust at all.

Our server Chance dod a great job of keeping drinks filled, offering cheese and peppers, keeping the table clear and checking in with us on a regular basis. Great server!

Can't​ wait to go back!
name: California Pizza Kitchen at International Plaza
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Pizza, Salad, American (Traditional)

text: Impressive decor and super comfortable and chic inside kimmel center. We had the prix fixe which includes first, second and dessert. The hamachi was really balanced with acidity except it was very very salty. Halibut was perfectly cooked. And I love the black sesame panna cotta except the yuzu ice cream was melted. I love the open kitchen. What I didn't love was the chefs on their phone texting and looking at their phones in the open kitchen. It was a slow night after 8pm on Saturday. But c'mon...please don't look at your phone in the open kitchen and then go back and prepare the food.
name: Volvér
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Diners, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, American (New)

text: Great new sushi restaurant in the Graduate Hospital area, very close to Rittenhouse and Fitler Square. Good location, nice cozy space with a table for six, three tables for four, and two tables for two, which they can re-organize to accommodate your party size. Well staffed, and cool molded wave tiles on the walls. Nice comprehensive Japenese menu. Started with the avocado salad, it was so good we had to order another one. The Yasi dragon roll was our favorite, also ordered a shrimp tempura roll and other special sushi rolls. All very fresh and made at the bar in front of you, presented on a platform wood plank. Also order the beef teriyaki, delicious! Finished up our meal with green tea ice cream, and black sesame ice cream. We will definitely be back!
name: Kei Sushi Restaurant
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants

text:
Sierra St. Kitchen & Cocktails has a sizeable list of house cocktails, wines, and a respectable assortment of bottled beers to enjoy with its ample menu of small plates. The ambiance is something between modern pub and French bistro, and our server was very helpful and efficient. The room is pretty cozy, so reservations are definitely recommended.

I started with a garden martini of craft gin combined with muddled basil, cucumber, and a splash of soda ($11). Though not as chilled as I'd like, it tasted like a fresh herb salad tossed in a boozy dressing. It made me think of an early summer sunset.

Nearly everything from the kitchen was served with toasted bread rounds and crackers, including a cheese and meat plate with three, thin slices each of prosciutto, salami, and capicola, paired with brie, Jarlsberg, and Manchego cheeses ($18, chef's choice on the day's selection). The first two meats were fine, but the coppa was a step above. Really nice spicy finish; I only wish there'd been a little more on the plate. The cheeses were all good and served at the proper room temp.

Next was a dish of prosciutto-wrapped asparagus spears served atop a spring mix salad, dressed with freshly grated parmesan cheese and balsamic vinegar ($7.50). Though the flavor combination worked, the hefty stalks were a bit woody and undercooked. We followed this with skewered, bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with goat cheese, served with the same greens and balsamic drizzle ($7). Besting the spears, the dates were a knockout combination of savory, sweetness, and texture.

Moving on, we ordered plates of both ahi and beef tartar. The small cake of raw Hawaiian tuna was encircled by a schmear of mildly sweet and sour sauce, sprinkled with black sesame seeds, then topped with avocado relish, a salsa of pineapple and mango, and raw slivers of shallot ($16). It was pretty tasty and easy to share. The mound of raw steak was served in classic style--formed into a bit of a bowl shape with an intact egg yolk nestled in the center--surrounded by portions of slivered shallot, sweet gherkin, capers, and chopped boiled egg ($13.50). Once the "yolk popping" ceremony was complete, we scooped up a bit of everything onto toast or crackers and threw caution to the wind.

Although listed as blue lip mussels, we were served a pound of the green variety with an apology that their supply chain had fallen through ($14). Served in a bath of white wine butter sauce with shallot, garlic, and chili flake, they were tender and more than a bit spicy. I loved this dish and spooned the broth onto a crusts of bread.

A pair of large, seared sea scallops were garnished with sprouts, sprinkled with parmesan, and perched atop a pile of--somewhat bland and slightly undercooked--risotto, surrounded by a moat of chimichurri sauce and citrus beurre blanc ($15). Though perfectly seared, they were noticeably briny and lacking the trademark sweetness of scallop, a telltale sign of wet-pack shellfish. Perhaps another issue with their seafood vendor?

We finished up with bowls of salted caramel and pistachio gelato ($7.50 ea.), along with creme brulee ($8.50),  and bananas foster ($8.50). The gelato was perfect, the creme brulee tasted good but was a bit runny, and the hot, boozy bananas with vanilla ice cream were surprisingly potent. Pro tip: a bit of 80 proof sauce poured over brulee makes for a next level treat.
name: Sierra St Kitchen & Cocktails
categories: Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Salad, Tapas/Small Plates, Cocktail Bars, American (New)

text:
Hands down my favorite spot in the city to grab local chocolates. Almost all the chocolate is made in house, and you can even see some of the process in the back, by the café. They grow their own herbs and farm their own honey in the building as well. The staff is knows their stuff and is always incredibly friendly - they can tell you the differences in their chocolate and how it's made in so much detail, it's amazing. 

Personal favorites include: Black Sesame meltaway, Pistachio meltaway, Earl Grey caramel, Honey Lavender caramel, Mexican Hot Chocolate truffle, Royal Spanish drinking chocolate and their Ecuador single origin chocolate bar.

They also do confectionary history tours, if you're into that.
name: Shane Confectionery
categories: Coffee & Tea, Specialty Food, Desserts, Candy Stores, Food, Local Flavor, Chocolatiers & Shops

text:
PROS: Unique cupcake flavors, not too sweet
CONS: They're not in Philly :(

I was never much of a cupcake person... because most cupcakes out there are just too cloyingly sweet and lacking in flavor complexity to me. However, these cupcakes from Twelve Baskets I do like (very much, in fact). They have interesting Asian-inspired cupcakes, such as matcha, black sesame, azuki, and taro, and they don't taste like pure thickened sugar. In addition to being yummy, the cupcakes are cute-looking (always a plus). Overall, I would hit up their shop every week if it weren't for the fact that they are quite far from me.
name: Twelve Baskets
categories: Cupcakes, Bakeries, Desserts, Food

text:
As an anniversary gift earlier this year, the GF decided to grab us a pair of tickets to the Del Frisco's COOK event! Having been to both the NYC and the Philly Del Frisco's outposts, coupled with my obvious penchant for a proper steak, I was excited to say the least! Chef John Stritzinger, the Executive Chef of Del Frisco's Philly, was on hand to regale and cook for us. 

Bread Service

While we waited for the other diners to arrive, we were served some freshly baked bread, along with some olive oil.

Capostrano Verdicchio di Matelica 
Italy 2013 

Most of the COOK events are inclusive of wine and drink! This Verdicchio had wonderful citrus notes, with nice acidity and good body. Easily quaffable, the glass was never empty and this wine was enjoyed by all.

Tuna Tartare 
Citrus oil, wasabi cream, red onion, capers 

Tuna tartare was marinated for 24 hours in citrus oil, then topped off with a tempered wasabi cream. This was nicely balanced by the addition of red onion and the brininess of capers. A wonton crisp was provided to serve as the scooping vessel.  

Shanghai Fried Calamari

The #1 best seller at Del Frisco's and one of our favorite appetizers? The Shanghai Calamari, which features a 24-hour buttermilk marinade, with the cephalopod then deep-fried in seasoned flower, along with cherry peppers. Tossed with fresh mung bean sprouts and pickled jalapenos, texture, tang, and taste were all there. The sweetness of the black sesame helped to accentuate the delicious sauce. Highly recommended!  

Crabcake
Cajun lobster sauce

The crabcake was one of the better iterations I've had. Whole chunks of Indonesian lump crab with minimal filler came dressed with reduced lobster broth - a simple preparation of cream, lobster base, and butter. Each bite was luscious, sweet, and rich. Pro tip from Chef Stritzinger? When making crab cakes, make sure to pat your crab dry before molding and cooking!

Arugula and Kale Salad
Goat cheese, shallot vinaigrette, cranberry 

Another tip? Apparently most homemade salads aren't dressed properly. Make sure to toss the vinaigrette well - you can always add more vinaigrette so don't over-dress! And finishing with a bit of salt, pepper, and lemon can really make each bite. This was a fairly standard preparation, but certainly well-executed. The bright sweetness of the cranberries helped to cut through the richness of the tart goat cheese. The peppery arugula and substantial kale really stoop up to the vinaigrette and seasoning.

Philip Schell Malbec 
Argentina 2014 

But now, it was time for the steaks. A nice malbec was brought out to pair well with these thick-cut steaks. Bright, fruit forward, but with some light spice and a smoky finish.

Prime Steak Tasting
Sirloin, ribeye, filet mignon

The sirloin showcased great beefiness and perfect seasoning. The ribeye? Unabashedly fatty and luscious. And as expected, the filet was nicely tender and cut like butter. The portions? Repeatedly replenished. Without getting into the specifics, let's just say that I'm not embarrassed to say that even I couldn't handle all this beef. The steaks were accompanied by two sauces. The garlic butter was rich, with bits of garlic floating about. The green peppercorn was my favorite as it had a nice kick, which was perfect to offset the richness of the beef.

Lobster Mac & Cheese

Oh and wait. There's more! Del Frisco's is well known for their lobster mac and cheese. Chef Stritzigner jokingly cautioned that one bite contained more calories than he'd care to share. But I threw caution to the wind and went in for a second helping. Creamy, rich, and with the pure essence of lobster, this is the right argument for a shellfish and cheese marriage.

Shaved Brussels Sprouts
Bacon

On a slightly healthier note, shaved brussels sprouts were on offer. But of course, tossed in bacon fat to support the savoriness of the greens. Caramelized onions helped to round out the richness of each bite.

Dessert
Lemon Doberge cake, strawberry cheesecake, chocolate mousse cups 

A troika of sweet confections were presented to each diner. An off-menu favorite, the lemon Doberge cake was simply stellar. Easily my new favorite dessert, it was rich, moist, and with plenty of lemon zest to punch up the brightness. If you're ever at Del Frisco's - save room and ask for this to round out your meal! The strawberry cheesecake featured a crumbly cookie crust. And the chocolate mousse had some bitter niceties that helped to break up the richness of the dessert course as a whole.   

And with that, we were given complimentary app cards to Del Frisco's along with chocolate to take home, courtesy of COOK. Pro tips? Arrive early and grab seats on the far side from when you enter to get the best seating and views. Make sure to get on COOK's mailing list to know when the tickets are released monthly. The good ones sell out quickly! And be sure to ask questions and engage your fellow diners. The food was amazing, but the night was better.
name: Cook
categories: Adult Education, Specialty Schools, Kitchen Supplies, Restaurants, Cooking Schools, Education, Kitchen & Bath, Home & Garden, Shopping

text: Wonderful bon bons, awesome Mexican hot chocolate and salvadoreño cheese cake with black sesame. Must visit when in Tucson
name: Monsoon Chocolate
categories: Themed Cafes, Desserts, Cafes, Restaurants, Food

text: I've been here a couple times and it's always good. Their prices aren't too bad and their pho is great! The people who work there are also very nice and attentive to customers. They also offer boba tea if you are looking for a boba fix! They are the only place that offers black sesame boba. So good! I have one less star because I wish the broth of the pho was more flavorful. Overall, would go back no problem! Also, their fried tofu is good!
name: Nam Van Noodle Cafe
categories: Creperies, Vietnamese, Ethnic Food, Restaurants, Specialty Food, Noodles, Chinese, Food

text: Such an adorable and endearing place - with great Asian-inspired flavor options: matcha tiramisu, black sesame, as well as other classic flavors like sea salt caramel for their shakes! Their cloud shakes are TALL too, and so cute! Come by and get yourself a delicious summer treat!
name: Aqua S
categories: Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
A high-class Publix in the heart of the city.

I literally did not mean to go to Publix. I was early for a dinner so I decided to walk around a bit and ran smack dab into this building. I didn't even know there was a Publix in this area! Jokes on me, because this Publix is awesome!

You can tell it is new. Everything looks, smells, and feels new. They've pulled out all the stops. Are you a busy on the go downtown professional? They have grab and go two for $5 ready made food options! They have make it a meal packs already created! You can easily stop here and grab lunch/dinner.

I was also impressed by their hippyish options (honestly, that is not the best way to put it, but brands I associate with Whole Foods and Rollin Oats were peppered throughout the store). Don't think they skimped on BOGO, just because they are in demand. I walked up and down the aisles and saw tons of BOGO deals.

This isn't the biggest Publix in the world, but if you aren't looking for an obscure ingredient (I'm looking at you Black Sesame Powder) then you'll probably find what you need here. This is a great addition to the area.
name: Publix
categories: Shopping, Food, Delis, Grocery, Drugstores, Restaurants

text: If you're a fan of raw sushi and nigiri, this is the place to be. Great prices and had the best server named Victoria! I'm not a connoisseur in drinks, but she knew exactly what to recommend and I loved it. (Dragonberry) The fish tasted super fresh and everything was A1. I highly recommend getting the toro nigiri and the sea salt white fish sashimi! Everything was foodgasmic from the miso soup to my black sesame/strawberry ice cream! (Seriously, never have I tried a more flavorful strawberry ice cream)
name: Daiwa Sushi Bar & Japanese Cuisine - Metairie
categories: Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Japanese

text: I'm usually not a falafel fan but this place has converted me. All of the falafels I've ever had were always so dry but Goldie's falafels have a perfectly crispy outer shell and a soft, never dry filling. I've tried the salad and the harrisa sandwich here and both were excellent. But let's be real, the true star is the TEHINI SHAKE. It's life changing and worth the trip to Goldie alone. It's like a milkshake but better because of the oh so creamy, nutty and incredibly addictive flavors of the tehini. If you love the black sesame shake/soft serve from Matcha Love then this will be right up your alley. The tehini shake is definitely a sweet treat and too many may possibly give you diabetes but yolo!
name: Goldie
categories: Salad, Fast Food, Restaurants, Vegan

text: If you love soft serve ice cream, this is the place to go! I managed to get some mini tubs during this pandemic and it definitely fulfilled every sweet dream I've been having. My favorites were the matcha and lychee (dairy free). The lychee was more of a sorbet type of texture, but both were more on the semi-sweet side. The black sesame was alright in my opinion, while the Thai tea was quite milky but good. Definitely would be coming back to try more of their flavors!
name: Aqua S
categories: Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
So fresh and so clean (like the OutKast song). Isn't that what you want out of a place that handles raw fish?

I came in here for ice cream, believe it or not. There's only two places in the world I've ever had Black Sesame, this place and a gelato shop near the river in Florence, Italy. But this place uses the rolling technique you've probably seen in videos of Southeast Asia. 

So the ice cream was insanely good. My fiance chose nutella with fresh bananas (I ended up finishing hers too). 

As I walked out the store, I told the owner (who is super nice and patient) that I would be back for poke. 

Well here I am. Day 2 eating salmon poke with sushi rice and veggies and a sauce he makes personally.  There's a lot of places to eat in SB, but this has quickly become one of my favorites.
name: Choppa Poke
categories: Food, Live/Raw Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Asian Fusion, Poke, Seafood, Food Delivery Services

text:
I come here consistently to treat myself with a misugaru latte. I find myself craving it quite often and the multigrain flavor is nutty (while still being sweet) with a strong black sesame flavor. I would highly recommend trying it! They claim it has health benefits but even if it wasn't true I would still get it because it's so good.

The thickness of the latte has not been consistent (it was very watery once) and the wifi is spotty sometimes, but otherwise, it's a nice, quaint, Asian-themed cafe with plenty of food and drink options.
name: Caffe Bene
categories: Coffee & Tea, Food

text:
All you can eat shabu shabu?! Yes, please! I haven't had shabu shabu in years and after trying it again at rice box kitchen it was worth the wait. It is seriously good. They currently only offer this in the evening and reservation only, but I will take what I can get! They offer two kinds of broth and you can get two of the same or one of each for your hot pot. We got one of each and while the regular was tasty (a nice light broth, but still full of flavor) the spicy was the show stopper. My mouth was on fire and my nose was running like crazy but I could not stop eating!! Since it was our first time back we got almost one of everything. We got udon and ramen noodles (the ramen was killer in the spicy broth), chicken, pork, beef, shrimp, mussels, bok choy, cabbage, snow peas, carrots, broccoli, and mushrooms. It was so much fun cooking the food ourselves; it's quick and easy too! I loved trying a bit of everything to find my favorite combinations. I am hooked on the chicken, ramen noodles, mushrooms, and bok choy in the spicy broth and the pork, udon noodles, cabbage, and mushrooms in the regular broth.
