The night ended with a light dessert which was a strawberry black sesame mochi bar. I was stuffed after dinner but that was the perfect ending to the meal. 

I've also had the lunch menu from rice box kitchen and it's just as good so definitely try it out too, but the shabu shabu has stolen my heart!
name: Rice Box Kitchen
categories: Hot Pot, Dim Sum, Restaurants, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Chinese, Thai

text:
So good!!
Friendly service, very helpful-
The food was delicious and fresh and soo flavorful.
The ice tea was so good! The pork dish was amazing!
Get the black sesame mocchi!!
name: Rice Box Kitchen
categories: Hot Pot, Dim Sum, Restaurants, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Chinese, Thai

text:
Philadelphia is losing a true gem and one of the last bastions of fine dining in Center City when the Fountain Restaurant ends its dinner service on December 27.  Also, all those poor (hmm) people at the Four Seasons Hotel will now have to venture out for dinner until the new Comcast building is built.  My friend and I heard the news about the end of dinner service and quickly made a reservation before this four bell Craig LaBan restaurant went extinct.  

Upon arrival, the hostess checked our coats and promptly sat us at our reservation time.  The dining room is spacious, classic, plushy, woody, and leathery.  It is quiet enough (perhaps because it is so spacious) that you can have a conversation with your dining companion without being disturbed by the goings-on at the next table over.  Service was impeccable, we asked for and received recommendations on everything, from wine, to food, to cheese and all were spot-on.  This is not a place for a quick bite.  Dinner moved along at a leisurely pace, which allowed you to digest each course before starting on the next.  Despite the pace, at no point did I feel that I was waiting too long for my food or drinks.  It allowed me to truly enjoy the entire experience.

To eat, both my friend and I ordered the butternut squash risotto with smoked gouda, curry oil, toasted black sesame seeds, and chanterelle mushrooms.  It was perfectly cooked, deliciously cheesy, and all the flavors complemented each other in a way you wouldn't expect (curry with smoked gouda are two things I would never think to put together myself).  

For my second course, I ordered the duck breast "peking style."  The skin was crispy, it was cooked to my specification, and placed on top of fluffy, buttery celeriac puree in a honey and red wine reduction.  The dish was excellent and tasty and surprisingly had a lot of umami flavor.  

For dessert, my friend and I went with the cheese plate and WOW, it is no joke at Fountain.  When you order, you are presented with a cheese trolley.  Ours had approximately 20 cheese we had to decide between (and our poor server had to describe to us). We went with the three cheese plate.  Portions were more than generous, and each of our selections was stinky, salty, or smokey goodness (as appropriate).

I also asked our server to do a wine pairing with my meal.  He selected the pinot gris to accompany the risotto, a classic merlot to go with the duck, and a port for my "dessert" course.  I was impressed with the selections, as each went well with my dishes and added depth to my dining experience.  

I am sorry that I waited so long to try Fountain, as I would definitely have planned a return visit in the near future.
name: Fountain Restaurant
address: Four Seasons Hotel Philadelphia, 1 Logan Sq
categories: Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, American (New), Sandwiches

text:
Came here on a Monday evening with the family. It was not too busy. We were seated right away. Kids had the Gold Kome basic with extra noodles. They enjoyed it. I had the Gold Kome Cha Shu. Broth was really good. Noodles were the right texture. Pork was a little dry. My wife had the Tonkotsu Black basic. She said broth was good but could have been more flavourful. Noodles were good but not the best she's had. We also had the squid and unagi yakitori appetizers. Really good. We finished with Black Sesame Mochi which was good too.

Service was great. I understand this place is a chain and so will be visiting others. They also gave us a stamp card and if you order 10 ramens you get one free.
name: Misoya
categories: Restaurants, Ramen, Japanese

text:
Blue Sushi has excellent sushi and service and atmosphere. Our server was helpful and pleasant and delightful. We were with another couple and were of the mind to order and then order some more and then order more. We loved the Shishido peppers and the sauce was wonderful. Our server advised us to use it for dipping. The tuna tower is a real treat. My husband even liked our sweet potato roll. The black tuna was wonderful. Several options have a delicious crispy bottom to the rice that added crunch. Desserts were delicious. They had black sesame and lychee mochi ice cream. The chocolate ice cream dessert was great, too. 

As we ordered "waves" we were able to concentrate on the taste of each course. This is the best way to appreciate the delicious detail of the dishes.

I can't wait to take our sushi-loving kids...
name: Blue Sushi Sake Grill
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, Cocktail Bars, Japanese, Bars

text: We stop by here for ice cream after we went took our kids to the aquarium! So glad they have a location in NOLA no need to go far to Houston anymore ! We brought the butter toffee with sea salt and hot chocolate so Yumm !! Our kids both enjoyed ! We also brought 8 small container of ice cream to go ! 3Durian, matcha,Thai tea, black sesame,strawberry and pineapple. Cute little dessert place plus the staff was very friendly! We totally come back when come to NOLA!
name: Aqua S
categories: Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
They had a table set up at yelp's 10th anniversary. I tried the black sesame with (i assume) condensed milk icing. I love asian flavors and the mini cupcake was amazing. super moist and the cake itself wasn't sweet but the icing had the right amount of sweetness to the whole "two bite" size cupcake. 

Tried the chocolate one too, although i'm not a big chocolate eater, i thought it was good too, just not on the same level as the black sesame. Will definitely pick up some when i'm in the area or when/if they set up at other places.
name: Twelve Baskets
categories: Cupcakes, Bakeries, Desserts, Food

text:
I've had lunch here and sipped 25¢ martinis, but this time we came to get serious - or actually get SILLY as the case was. We came for Jazz Brunch!

Notes before you read: the required dress code is one of the best parts of this dining experience, so do everyone a favor and pack your finest if you plan to visit. Don't skirt around the rules in a polo shirt and dark jeans, mmmmkay? People come here to show off and you should too! It's respectful. 

Ok now on to the experience! Because this wasn't just a meal, although the food was tremendous. 

Ordered: 3 course meal, includes an appetizer, an entree, and a dessert (not to be missed).
I had the squash salad - one of the best salads I've ever had. Shaved squash, goat cheese, tomato, and a tangy vinaigrette finished with micro greens and black sesame seeds. My entree was shrimp and grits - slightly spicy, sautéed with peppers and tomato, and creamy dreamy grits. My dessert was the best part - DO NOT MISS the bourbon bread pudding soufflé. DONT. They finish it at the table, after it makes it's way across the dining room all fluffy and jiggly and show-offy, with a bourbon sauce that is to die for. Cut into that bad boy and amaze your taste buds. 
My partner ordered the gumbo appetizer, which we both decided was some of the best we've had in NOLA, smooth and rich and dark as hell. His entree was beef medallions, over small potatoes, perfectly cooked and slightly smoky. His dessert was a giant chunk of cheesecake - he can't ever pass it up. It was fantastic. 
With the meal we had several on-the-menu cocktails, whiskey and bourbon based, and holy heck there's a reason good things come in small packages because these packed a wallop but were mighty delicious. 

Now - on to the experience. Upon arrival you're whisked in to the dining room all gussied up just like the diners, jazz brunch includes balloons and streamers at each table! Once seated we heard the familiar sound of a jazz trio, moving about the dining room stopping at each table. The singer told us they had just started back into indoor dining and performing a few weeks before, and they were so happy to be there. The energy was fun and oh so perfectly New Orleans. When they arrived at our table and asked if we wanted a song played, we asked for "Just a Gigolo" which they happily obliged (don't forget to tip these people!) and we sang along. 
About to dig into my entree when a staff member roused us all up out of our seats and started a second line parade through the dining room. There is something to be said for dancing around one of the finest restaurants in the south, waving a napkin, cheering on other diners in their Sunday best. 

Come for martinis or come for brunch or come for dinner or come for the show. Just come, and put on your finest.
name: Commander's Palace
categories: French, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, American (New), Cajun/Creole, Breakfast & Brunch, American (Traditional), Bars

text:
So I was very confused a few weeks ago when my daughter and I were going on a sushi date and wanted to try the new Tokeo Station downtown, and we get there and there isn't a trace of it. Not even sure what happened there, but it was gone. A week later this Ra Bar was advertising for Edmonton Downtown Dining week. My husband and I despite the Corona Virus warnings decided to give it a try. 

It is nice enough inside. Really modern black with accents feeling. They were just open a week I found out. It shows. Service was not great. Our server took a long time with water, menu, drinks, etc. Which okay if the place was busy (it wasn't) and if restaurants didn't need to clamour for customers, then fine. But both things existed. We went out in this environment and basically there was us and two other couples in the restaurant, we shouldn't be waiting for service.

We decided on the Downtown Dining menu:
Half Japanese Potato Salad - hard-boiled egg, cucumber, pickled onion and fire-roasted corn
Half Wagyu Carpaccio - Brant Lake Wagyu cured with onion ash, arugula, and crispy garlic
Smoked Duck Breast - miso-glazed smoked duck breast, garlic, rosemary, and spaghetti squash
Black Sesame Ice Cream Pie
 and also The Angry Tuna Rolls 

So where service was sloppy food was not. Food came out in a timely manner and it was delicious. We loved the flavours in the tuna rolls. The potato salad was delicious and interesting. The smoked duck breast was tender and tasty although I found the spaghetti squash to be bland. I would like them to do something more about the side flavours in that. The Wagyu was decent, my husband enjoyed it. I found the meat to be a little to "wet". I like my carpaccio to be cured a little dryer to pick up flavours, and it should not be dripping off my chopstick. Sesame ice cream pie was just the right amount, perfect in balance of sweetness and savoury. Would order that again.
 However all in all a decent meal. 

It took forever for the bill (again no idea why) and I ordered a sake (Which was cold and they didn't specify in the menu. So when I said that I didn't know that it would be cold when they brought it out our server just shrugged her shoulders. Really, for professionalism she should of offered to take it off my bill or replace it with another drink). Anyhow they over doubled the price of my sake. It should have been 13ish bucks (and for something I didn't want in the first place) but it was charged with over 30.  Luckily my husband spotted the issue, and pointed it out. It took at least 10 minutes for the bartender to fix it. Again no idea why. And when I pointed out that in most Japanese restaurants they have hot and cold sake sections, he agreed that they were still working on the menu. No compensation, no even sorry.

This is not the way to have regular customers. If the manager is reading this and wants a discussion I would love to have one. I see a lot of potential with the kitchen that will go to shit with the service and management.
 

The current times, restaurants can't afford to make mistakes. Or the can make mistakes and then make them up to the customers by at least apologizing (for the long wait, for not getting what you expected etc.) or to take things off your bill or replace them with something that the customer would like. This place didn't do either of this things. I am thinking that unless Ra Bar shapens up their ship deck they will be going down with the tide. Which is sad, because actually most of our food was delicious. I wished I could have given my tip directly to the chef and not our distant server.
name: Ra Bar
categories: Japanese, Asian Fusion, DJs, Bars, Nightlife, Event Planning & Services, Cocktail Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Restaurants

text:
This is about 4.5 stars in my book. I was undecided if it need to be 4 stars or 5 stars. At the end, I think I can revise it for my revisit next time. This place is big. I definitely like the bar area. It has great tv. 

I was here to try out the newest restaurant in the St. Pete area. This is one of the few restaurants has it own parking lot. It is free parking compare to many area here requiring parking fees. It is a plus. 

I got the pork belly ramen to start. This ramen come with 3 good pieces of pork belly grilled to good perfection. I would add salt or sugar to the pork belly with better taste before grilled. The soup may want to add some black sesame oil to enhance the flavor. This ramen is good, however I think just need a slight improvement to make it great. 

I got the chance to try their category five sushi roll. This is a spicy tuna top with avocado and Kabayaki sauce. In addition it top with imitation crab meat. It is a very good roll. Love the taste. The other roll is the their one of most order rolls- snow mountain rolls. This is a tempura shrimp inside and top with real snow crab meat. I think this is a must order item if you visit them. I would recommend this roll. 

Here are the special:  Monday free miso soup for any guest; Tuesday 2 minor rolls for $10, 2 major rolls for $20 and mixed and match for $15; Monday to Friday $2 off on bento box before 3 pm; Wednesday $2 off on each glass wine and 1/2 off for bottle, Thursday lady night alcohol. 

My service is great. A shout to Sarah who serve me did a great job at the bar. Other worth mentioning is their sake cocktail, sake whisky, sake sangria, and their whisky flight.
name: Sake 23
categories: Japanese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Ramen

text:
The place is clean with a simple design. Workers are friendly and welcoming, offering us multiple samples of different ice cream flavors. The matcha was lightly sweetened and had perfect flavoring. I ended up going with the Vietnamese coffee in a donut which they warmed up!!!! My husband got the bubble waffle with salted caramel which came with his topping of choice, whipped cream and a pocky stock. The waffle wasn't too sweet and slightly crunchy which complimented the ice cream well. I wish it had a little bit more of a buttery taste like the ones from Hong Kong but seriously I'm not going to hold that against this place. I do hope that in the future that they will have more flavors with the waffles, maybe pandan, charcoal or even black sesame. It would also be nice to have other toppings like red bean or li hing mui powder. 

They also offer cookies and macaroons which we did not try but maybe next time :)
name: Sweet Handkraft
categories: Desserts, Specialty Food, Food, Macarons, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I was surprised for my birthday with a dinner at Volver.  I will admit that my expectations were not high as it was Restaurant Week - a period that we generally avoid like the plague.  However, I was pleasantly surprised and frankly blown away by the food that was served.  

We both had the Rose Gold cocktail which was delicious and $2 of each drink went to the Garces Foundation. The $35 Restaurant Week menu was severely limited, in effect a pared version of the $35 pre-theater menu; but we each found dishes that looked interesting/appealing. 

For the first course we had the Hamachi Tartare and the Milk & Cereal.  The tartare was phenomenal, sublime, fresh and delicious, the togarashi flatbread was genius.  The milk & cereal a fun play on a composed asparagus soup with rice flakes, chicken thigh and thyme marshmallows - delicious.  

The second courses were the Veal Hangar Steak and the Pastrami Trout and again, both were surprising in good ways and delicious in all ways.  I had a great by the glass Riesling with my entrée and my partner had a fantastic by the glass Merlot ($28) that was worth every drop.  

We finished with the third and last course with Panna Cotta of black sesame, yuzu meringue, mandarin sorbet, Thai basil and cherry with a black and white sesame crisp that brought it all to a fantastic close. 
 Josh was our server and he was great as was Phoebe who checked in on us all night long and brought us a yummy sparkling wine sent by my sister-in-law to accompany our dessert.  

Based on our experience, I can absolutely say that it was THE BEST Restaurant Week experience we have ever had and we are definitely planning to check out the regular menu & tasting menu plus wine pairing as soon as Restaurant Week is over.
name: Volvér
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Diners, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, American (New)

text: All you can eat hot pot. Perapol is an amazing owner. He truly cares about serving good food. So welcoming and family friendly ambiance. The food is delicious!!!! The broth and dipping sauce are made in house. Meat is cut to order. Presentation is beautiful. Eat, drink, gossip! Finished with homemade dessert, today it was a black sesame seed short bread cookie. Can't wait to come back again!
name: Rice Box Kitchen
categories: Hot Pot, Dim Sum, Restaurants, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Chinese, Thai

text: I am usually unimpressed by wraps, but Sweet Art's Botanical wrap is the best I've ever had and a guaranteed mood booster. It's a hefty portion, packed with tofu (baked, I believe), veggies, and a peanut-curry sauce with black sesame seeds. Came with a little kiwi fruit on the side too. For dessert I treated myself to the vegan brownie. I'm not a vegan, and my prior experiences with vegan baked goods have been unpleasant. But this was one of the most decadent and delicious brownies I've ever had. I don't know how they do it! Free wifi and perfect atmosphere are two more pluses. I just wish they were open on Sundays.
name: SweetArt
categories: Vegan, Arts & Entertainment, Shopping, Restaurants, Vegetarian, Art Galleries, Food, Cafes, Bakeries, Desserts

text:
I have a confession: I don't understand the mochi doughnut craze. And I tried the ones at Sweet Handkraft which are supposed to be amazing!!! Don't get me wrong, they're good and taste less artificial than other doughnuts, but it's still a doughnut. And even though I tried, I just can't get super excited about them. 

That said, Sweet Handkraft does have relatively good doughnuts. We got a dozen and tried all the different flavors. They're doughnuts are easy to rip apart and almost designed for sharing, score! The Black Sesame one is solid. My favorite was the Lychee Rose flavor though. Such great rose flavoring!! A little on the sweet side, but perfect as an afternoon dessert. Cookies & Cream is good and if you like a strong coffee flavor, they've got you covered.

Good mochi doughnuts here, but still just doughnuts. So if I have to pick my sugar vice, I'm going back to something frozen. But should I find myself craving a doughnut, no doubt I'm coming back for Lychee Rose.
name: Sweet Handkraft
categories: Desserts, Specialty Food, Food, Macarons, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
DIMSUM BOX--

Been wanting to try their dimsum since it's pretty much non-existent in Reno, and found out they were open for it on Thanksgiving, so I came right before they opened and got my order in (but I think they prefer pre-orders via Instagram)
Perapol is so welcoming, you feel like you've become instant friends when greeted. 
I got my Thanksgiving dimsum order in and it was ready within 5 minutes. 
I checked my order in the car before I left the parking lot and realized they mistakenly gave me steamed pork buns when I ordered the baked ones. 
I went back in to tell him the mistake and he graciously gave me the baked ones on the house (Thank you!)
Now to the food--
I picked up an order of siumai from Honey Bakery just before stopping by RBK to compare, and they were a pretty close match. RBK's Siu Mai tasted meatier and denser vs. HB's were softer, so I guess it's up to your preference but I enjoyed them both!
The black sesame tapioca pork dumplings were covered in a peanut sauce which paired very well together and even better with some hot sauce!! 
The pork dumplings were steamed pot stickers, so not something I'd usually order but husband would love them. 
They had a large deconstructed ha gow (shrimp dumpling) that had a thicker skin and more chives/green onions that I liked, but that's also a taste preference.
Overall I'm glad RBK is doing dimsum on weekends regularly, but would LOVE if it was daily since it's a bit of a journey for me to get here. Weekdays would make traffic more bearable :P
Perapolm's hospitality + friendliness will make me a regular customer now that I know their dimsum menu varies week by week. Must try ALLLLLL the dimsum!!!!! 
Will also be back to try their shabu because Shabu/HotPot = Life.
name: Rice Box Kitchen
categories: Hot Pot, Dim Sum, Restaurants, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Chinese, Thai

text:
After walking past Volvér a million times, I finally had a chance to make it in for restaurant week. Admittedly, my expectations weren't that high given some of my prior restaurant week experiences at pricier restaurants (see: microscopic portions). However, Volvér was quite generous.

I'll start with my cocktail. I ordered The Cooper and it was phenomenal. Sweet (but not overwhelming so) and rich enough for me to sip throughout my dinner. Well worth the $13.

As for the food, I ordered the hamachi tartare to start, a duck dish that I don't quite remember the name of (all of the photos I took...and not one of them was a photo of the menu), and the panna cotta. The hamachi tartare was a surprisingly generous portion for a small plate. The combination of ingredients were a bit strange to me, but somehow they all came together in a pretty tasty dish (the mango pearls were an especially nice touch). I wish I recalled more specific details of the duck dish, but I do remember the skin being crispy and the meat being tender.

The reason the experience was a 4 for me and not a 5 was the dessert. The black sesame panna cotta wasn't bad, but I didn't enjoy the taste of it enough to finish it. I thought my friend's ultra-rich cocoa choux was much better (which says a lot, as dense chocolate desserts are not my preference).

The service was fast, reliable, and friendly and the overall atmosphere was very classy. The general manager stopped by our table and mentioned that they'll be rotating their menus by country within the next few months (I think he said the first countries will be Italy and Vietnam). Without restaurant week this place is quite expensive, but the concept sounds interesting enough that I might give Volvér a second look. As far as my restaurant week experience went, it was a good value for the price.
name: Volvér
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Diners, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, American (New)

text:
E
X

T

Seriously. Probably the best Poke I've had so far because 1. They have way more seafood options 2. The build your own bowl structure is better 3. It's cheaper.

For less than $12 you can get a build your own bowl with choices of toppings, including Soba Noodles & Forbidden rice (delicious wild black rice that I HIGHLY recommend) for 50 cents more, THREE choices of seafood including surimi salad, squid salad, albacore, tuna and salmon and even octopus! Then all the veggie toppings you want followed by two umami toppings followed by whatever sauce you want and the ending of crispy garlic or crispy onions and sesame seeds or furikake! I had a crazy ton of fun making my bowl of forbidden rice and spring mix, squid salad, spicy tuna, and surimi salad, with like all the veggie, seaweed salad & masago, ponzu, eel sauce and spicy mayo, crispy garlic and onions, and furikake and black sesame seeds. 

Staff was crazy friendly and helpful as I made my way through the process and even let me try the rice and a sauce or two while I made up my mind! Plus, check this page because they were even offering a 10% off if you mentioned Yelp!

Will definitely be back, this was EXCEPTIONAL.
name: LemonShark Poke
categories: Restaurants, Food, Hawaiian, Vegan, Sushi Bars, Poke

text:
I tried Volver for the first time for dinner during Restaurant Week.  I was excited because their menu looked really good.  The restaurant is essentially inside the Kimmel Center, and I heard they also usually have prixe fix meals before Kimmel Center shows.  The inside is very pretty, fancy, and dark.  It definitely has a classy atmosphere.  

Overall, I enjoyed the food, but a big part of their food is also their presentation.  The dishes were plated beautifully!  The portions are not huge, but perfect for a three course meal.  You won't be overstuffed afterwards, but you also shouldn't be hungry.  I ordered the Milk and Cereal, the Hanger Steak, and the Panna Cotta.  The milk and cereal was really cool, like a soup, and came out in a cute little cereal box glass that the waitress pours into the bowl for you.  The hanger steak was absolutely delicious, cooked well and probably my favorite dish of the night.  The panna cotta was interesting, very fruity and had a strong black sesame flavor.  It was cool to try and plated beautifully, but I probably wouldn't order it again.
name: Volvér
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Diners, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, American (New)

text:
I'm not sure I really understand this place as a brick and mortar spot (though I never met it as a truck either).  Walked by with a friend on our way to dinner and we decided to pop in - it's a fun looking space and the door said 'puddin' was inside there.  After trying two of the puddings, black sesame and salted caramel we decided to buy a salted caramel and a...carrot cake maybe? (Not slamming the flavor, just don't remember since it was for delivering to an at home friend).  We were also talked into trying a couple macarons - we chose earl grey chocolate and taro.

The good: it's a cute space, it's creative, the help was nice, you can taste some of the puddings, it's not like anything else in Chinatown.

The not good:  If you're a pudding bakery, in addition to creative choices (pumpkin spice banana) it might be good to sell some classics and do them really well.  Chocolate?  Vanilla? The salted caramel was nice, but not make-that-trip-again nice.  The black sesame that we tried had an uncomfortable firm mousse-like texture and tasted like weak peanut butter, but not sesame.  Again, if you only sell four puddings, and it's part of your identity, you need to nail it.  The macarons were an example of this as well.  As some other reviewers have said, they were kind of soggy and kind of bland.  The earl grey chocolate did taste like those flavors but the cookie was really too chewy.  The taro had a better crunch to chew ratio but tasted like sugar flavor only.

Also, for two puddings and two macarons we were in for $14.  Some of the best restaurants in the city serve desserts at around $8-12 per person and they are amazing.    Nothing that we experienced of Audabon was flat out terrible, but it kind of felt like the desserts were something that I might be happy to eat homemade, at a friends house, but not for spending my treat money.  

I'm not sure how long they have been there, so maybe they are just working out the kinks.  I hope so, I like the idea very much it's just the execution that left me hanging.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
South Coast Deli is my top choice sandwich shop in Santa Barbara. It's pretty good if you like shredded lettuce, arugula, avocado, sprouts, bacon, and chicken breast. It's not a melt in your mouth, gooey cheese kind of sandwich shop. 

I prefer to order a salad because you get far more veggies and meat than the sandwiches, which are a lot of bread. I can never finish the whole salad so it's two meals in one. The Asian Greens with Chicken is my favorite with Napa cabbage, green cabbage, bok choy, chicken breast, shredded carrots, green onions, cilantro, black sesame seeds, and crispy won tons in a sweet & spicy sesame dressing. Buffalo Blue is also tasty but a little salty because of the wing sauce covering the chicken.

The brownies are pretty good - large, thick, and chewy with lots of walnuts on top. They can be a little hit or miss. The Goleta location makes them on a daily basis in the am.

The employees are welcoming and love to take orders over the phone. If you order over the phone your receipt will say,
"PHONE ! !" across the top.

Delivery is now available as well.
name: South Coast Deli- Carrillo
categories: Salad, Sandwiches, Restaurants, Delis

text: I love this place.  Its down the street from my house, so it is very convenient.  The portions they give you are huge and the price tag is small, which makes for a great place to eat when you're on a budget.. and if you're like me and can't eat all the food they serve you, you take home the leftovers and have another meal for the next day.  the veggie rolls are my favorite, especially when craving an egg roll.  They also have a decent little asian market, which is great for when you need some hard to find asian ingredients.  They finally started carrying matcha powder (which is green tea powder) that is a great little ingredient when you want to make an interesting treat (i use it to make green tea cheesecake).  They also have black sesame seeds for a great price (just think of smokey flavored sesame seeds, so good).  I also like to get a pack of the rice candy when checking out..  a nice treat to carry around in my purse.  The staff here is really friendly, so thats another reason to keep going back.  Also, I don't think its on their menu but you can order Thai Iced Tea when checking out..  one of my favorite things to drink (although it can sometimes be a little too sweet).  I don't have a negative thing to say about this place.  I think the owner of International Market also owns PM across the street... so if you're paying attention, you'll notice that employees are always running back and forth across the street to take care of both spots.  I really hope Belmont doesn't run them out... as I've heard rumored before.
name: International Market & Restaurant
categories: Thai, Asian Fusion, Chinese, Grocery, Food, Restaurants

text: I am a huge macaron fan and their flavors attract me so much such as the Matcha Green Tea or the Black Sesame, even though they have flavors that cannot be found everywhere I would not say that they have the best macaron in Philly, but most unique. The macarons are a bit sweet for my taste and I do wish that each flavors should be stronger. The Matcha Green Tea Mousse is amazing though and all the new creations they have it is a place worth a try
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Nice place, but gets crowded and doesn't take reservations, so beware!  Parking may be a little difficult, but we parked at the Paseo Nuevo shopping center a few blocks southeast.  They opened at 5:30 on Monday evening, and when we walked up right at 5:30 pm, there were already several people waiting outside!

Food was fresh, unique, interesting.  Not sure where Sophia D. is getting 1-inch thick sliced rolls!  The roll slice thickness looked right to me--bite-sized.  I'll post a pic for reference.  I love that they had two soy sauce pots--white for low-sodium, black for regular.  The menu had many interesting special nigiri and rolls.  If I lived closer, I'd love to come back every so often and work my way through their menu!  We had yuzu pepper tai, salmon, ginger tuna, ankimo scallops, ume fluke, jalapeno yellowtail, grilled portabella, and ELT (fresh-water eel, lettuce, tomato).  All were very good, but I especially liked the salmon, jalapeno yellowtail, ELT, ginger tuna, grilled portabella, and yuzu pepper tai.  The flavors of the ume fluke was great, but the fish was slightly chewy.  For dessert, we had black sesame ice cream.  Mmmmm....
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
Being the only restaurant of its kind in Edmonton, there really isn't a way to compare it to others. This Chinese dessert house made its way to Edmonton after starting off in Calgary's chinatown. I have heard the prices are comparable to the original location, but it's quite expensive considering the price for 1 bowl is enough to buy ingredients for a whole pot! Of course, we wouldn't be here if everyone could make their own.

There is a ton of items listed, but not available, on their menu. My guess is they either had the food chef leave after opening or they listed it planning for future growth. That or they simply copied Calgary's version of the menu and crossed off everything they weren't offering. Either way, please stop being stingy and reprint your menus. It's been nearly half a year and your second location, so I think you can spare some change and not frustrate the hell out of your customers. It's a problem when half (LITERALLY half!) the menu is crossed off.

Anyways, we are here to talk about the food. It's not worth the price they charge but, I have got to say, the desserts are delicious and made authentically from raw ingredients. The almond drinks/desserts aren't smooth, but it proves they use real almonds versus artificial flavouring. Their tofu fa (or bean curd as they call it) was typical, but they give you the option of adding red bean or black sesame paste to it. I ordered red bean, but their black sesame paste was so amazingly delicious that I regret not being a little more adventurous. Again, their sesame paste was not smooth because it was made from grinding up real sesame seeds! If you order any of their steam egg items, be prepared to wait around 20 minutes as they make it from scratch and steam to ensure freshness. They also have rose tea, bubble tea, and taiwanese drinks available. These are drinks are borderline averagely priced to expensive. One thing to note about the drinks: If you take out, the containers are free. But if you stayed and ordered it with take out containers, they will charge you. No option of staying partly and leaving with a drink? Haha...I'm a little confused over that myself.

Their service was alright. Nothing to rave about or complain about. They did their job, but nothing exceptional.

This place would deeply hurt my wallet if I made this a regular experience, but for group hangouts, this isn't too bad. Oh, as a side note, this place can only accommodate for about 20 people at a time. With how long the food takes to get to you and limited seating, it may take a while for you to get a table/food. Hope you have good company! For those of you like me who have wonderful Chinese mothers who can do it all, I will be ordering these desserts from home. For those who don't, this is a piece of heaven away from home with a slightly higher price tag.
name: The Dessert House
categories: Desserts, Food

text:
3.5 Stars

Arigato is the goto sushi restaurant for my good friends that live in Santa Barbara. I have eaten here before, but it had been awhile, I was excited. We were in sort of a rush so we didn't enjoy everything Arigato had to offer, but we did have was great.

We sat at the sushi bar in front of Brian. Our meal started off with Halibut Carpaccio and Yuzu Pepper Tai sashimi. Both were delicious, the tai sashimi was really fresh, there was a little too much sauce on the carpaccio and it over powered the fish.

Next up we had Ankimo, delicious! The chefs made a few special items for us, didn't know the names or all the ingredients, but they were incredible. The highlight was a thinly sliced seared scallop topped with a crab mixture and tobiko. It was also served with cilantro oil and black sesame sauce, it was awesome.

Looking forward to my next visit.
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
WE ALL SCREAM FOR ICE CREAM!!! had to try a dip ice cream... there are many flavours you could dip your ice cream in! i tried the coffee and it is pretty good! the dip coffee with some coffee grinds! it is a bit sweet and thick but still good! the other flavour is black sesame, it also is delish! will come again to try other flavour.

Only issue is parking :(
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House
categories: Desserts, Chocolatiers & Shops, Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Decided to do something different today. Never been here before but it was about a block away from where I was. I'm sure if you're here for the bar you can just walk in, but we were hungry and waited for someone to seat us. I really liked the whole vibe they have here. Everywhere you look there's something different. It wasn't just the posters or the random things hanging from walls and ceilings-- they have different painting styles on the walls and the furnishings were unique. Very eclectic, and therefore, fabulous! I spotted quite a few pinocchios, so they keep within the expected theme. 

Now for the food: I got the Italian Deli sandwich. Looking at the menu I told my mom the only thing missing from what I'd expect would be pepperoncinis. The waitress was sweet and easy going. Got our drinks: mom had asked for iced tea. She got it back and was surprised. They put a little bit of a fruit flavor in it. Couldn't decide if it was blueberry or blackberry. Still, really good! I got my sandwich and was immediately happy. Picking it up, a pepperoncini fell out! Day. Made. Also the bread was coated in black sesame seeds, pine nuts, and sunflower seeds. Delicious! Also it was a huge sandwich. Ate the first half and wondered if I should eat the second half. Probably shouldn't have, but no regrets, no matter how many pants sizes I went up in there! Also, they batter their french fries. Need I say more? Actually yes, it'll bother me if I don't. They were crispy, salted the perfect amount, and the insides were soft! 

Mom got the veggie wrap. We both have a weakness for blue cheese, and if you are of the same personage, please get that also. So much blue cheese. So much happiness. Yes. I stole a bite if her wrap. I will not be shamed. 

Lesson learned: we will be back.
name: Pinocchio's Bar & Grill
categories: Salad, Italian, Restaurants, Pizza, American (Traditional)

text:
Disclaimer: I am a lover of all things sweet and baked. I have been baking from scratch since I was in elementary school, from cookies to cream puffs to meringues and sponge cakes, and recently finished my baking quest for "perfect macarons," complete with feet! I've probably read almost all of the authoritative articles on macarons that the internet has to offer. That being said...

I know most people love this place. But, I am not a fan. I've tried these twice on separate occasions (other people kindly shared with me) and not been very impressed. When a place is very hyped up, I have very high expectations in mind.

The macaron shells were rather brittle and fragile, and at least for the ones I tasted (Boston Cream Pie and also a Salted Caramel, I believe), they crumbled pretty instantly upon taking a small bite. I was looking forward to a shell with more bite- slightly chewy along with semi-crackly/crumbly. The buttercreams that they were filled in were not memorable to me, and I wonder if it was the same buttercream with just different flavored shells? Was it buttercream? Whipped cream? Vanilla? I remember double checking with my friend, wait, what flavor are these again? The names are creative, but I didn't find the tastes as assertive as I would have expected. (My theory is that the word 'salted caramel' is a buzz word, and sounds so cool that anything called salted caramel will be tasty!)  

Another gripe I have is with the pudding. To me, I like a pudding to taste slightly custardy and very creamy and smooth. The black sesame pudding I tried had quite a few whole sesame seeds in it, and if I had been to make it, I would have increased the ratio of ground sesame to sesame seeds to accentuate the black sesame nutty taste. Texturally, I would not describe it as a pudding, but more of a milky jello, because it was definitely on the stiffer side. 

Sorry! I wanted to like you, Audabon.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: Almost every dish I saw today looked so goopy with sauce!  I still think the north location is the best.  I ordered a chicken salad, and that actually has a lot of arugula on there - just a heads up.  There was black sesame seeds on the chicken, so that's what the chicken meant.  I always like the option of brown rice as sides.  Most entrees are $7-8.
name: Pei Wei Asian Kitchen
categories: Chinese, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Fast Food, Gluten-Free

text:
I like the creativity they put into their hot dog creations.  It is definitely not for the traditionalist.  The wife and I tried their dogs and fries at the USF Earth Day event.  

I had the Japanese version (can't remember the exact name).  It had nori, kewpie mayo, and ginger.  There may have been other ingredients but those are the ones that stood out to me.  The bun was good and the price was as well for the size and quality.  Overall it was pretty good.  I liked my wife's dog a bit more, she had the coalminer dog which had chili, mustard, a good coleslaw and black sesame seeds crushed to create a coal dust.  

The fries were pretty good.  I like mine a bit more crispy, but I like that they left the skin on.  I would definitely try this truck out again.
name: 'Merica Food Truck
categories: Food Trucks, Burgers, Hot Dogs, Food, Restaurants

text: This was such a great restaurant! My boyfriend and I ate here for our one year and it didn't disappoint! We got seated very quickly and the service was phenomenal. Everything we ate was great. The flavor, the platting, everything! The black sesame ice cream is to die for! I never had that flavor before and was skeptic about it at first, but it was really good! The shrimp goyza (pot stickers) were also something to order, as well as the carpaccio and the Nigiri tuna with garlic. Will be eating here again soon!
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
Arigato is a hip joint - contemporary art decor, beautiful people in their fashionable outfits...a place to be seen.

But I go there for the food...

Sure, I have dressed up to meet up with some good looking friends, but I have also been there in my jeans and sweater. I have also seen a family with their two small children. Good good attracts all kinds of people. 

The key to a good sushi restaurant is freshness and Arigato presents freshness in high quality. Their fish melts in your mouth without being overwhelmed by the rice. Yes, it's a small portion to some folks that are used to the "American" portion but if you've been to Japan, you know their size is about right. Another highlight is the innovative sauces - they are so tasty that dipping your fish to the soy sauce would just ruin the taste. 

So...here are some of my favorites:
Tai yuzu sushi - a good start to open up your appetite
Blue fin ginger tuna - another good one to start with
Yellowtail tartar - very tasty. I can eat 2 of these. If you're sharing, ask for spoons.
Seared scallops in black sesame sauce - decadent
Portabello mushroom sushi - a good way to get some veggies in your system
Kobe beef sushi - it's like a sushi hamburger. Hearty.
Snake roll - sweet & filling to end your meal

Couple of helpful hints:
- sit at the bar and get to know the chefs...ask them to make you something from their creation. (but prepare the pay the price)
- If you have a party of odd numbers, you can ask them get you odd number of nigiris (i.e. 3, 7, 9 etc.)
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
I had never eaten here before because none of my friends had ever recommended the place to me. I came here for #FreeSushiDay with my family and decided to order more food to seal the deal. Ordered a spicy tuna roll, pork dumplings, and Korean BBQ Chicken Stir-Fry

Spicy Tuna Roll- Delicious, covered with toasted black sesame seeds, had more tuna than in a standard sushi bar. However, looking at the price I soon realized why it had more tuna; it cost a whopping 11.99 HOO Good lord! A spicy tuna roll will run you 6$ MAX at your local sushi joint. At my local sushi joint it's 4.50 and even with the extra tuna I'm sure it wouldn't be almost triple the price!

Pork Dumplings- Did not try personally myself but my brother loved them, he inhaled these dumplings like it was the last food on earth LOL. #DysonBrother

Korean BBQ Chicken Stir-Fry- Ended up splitting this because we ran out of room. #SoChubby This came with your typical stir fried vegetables: Red peppers, onion, green beans, sweet chili sauce, and the savory kimchi slaw. This was a solid dish however it's not anything I would ever order again, it wasn't memorable. Portion size wasn't all there. I don't consider myself cheap but for 14.50 this should have been bigger. Also the amount of rice they give you is shocking! I've never seen such a small scoop given out before in good conscious. Rice is such a cheap side so I didn't understand WHY. #ShameOnYall

The service was great, and the waitress was SUPER knowledgeable about the in's and outs of the menu which was impressive because I've been to a TON of places that have staff with no idea about what's on the menu. Ambiance is intimate but not a place I'd personally want to go for a date-night. Unless a friend invited me to this place gung-ho on eating here I'd never come back, I'm still in rice shock. #RiceShock #MakingMyInnerAsianCRY
name: P.F. Chang's
categories: Asian Fusion, Gluten-Free, Vietnamese, Chinese, Restaurants

text:
Yum, yum, YUM! Each tasty bite of Audabon Bakeshop's macarons has made me a happy little lady. I attempted to buy macs the day before, but they were sold out after 2.5 hours! I think that can attest to how great Audrey's little creations really are. 

It's not the first time I've had French macarons, but I was really impressed by the unique flavor profiles that Audabon had. I was lucky enough to go early today and picked up a variety of their Lunar New Year flavors among others. I bought: lotus pear, coconut lychee, pineapple rum cake, black sesame mochi, and mung bean lemon. 

It was my first time trying macarons with Swiss meringue buttercream and wow they're amazing. Not too sweet and the fruit compote in the middle of  some of the macarons was a nice surprise that lent a great combo of flavors and textures.

You have to buy the macarons in pairs (c'mon they're only $1.50 each), but they are lovely. I did not try the puddin' but after reading the reviews, I might have to try their salted caramel one! 

The only thing I didn't like about this place is that it's so addicting. Now I have to come back regularly!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: Fantastic! The best sushi I've ever had! They really take it to the next level with everything. Dragon Rolls, shrimp wontons and garlic edamame especially good. Black sesame honey ice cream with strawberries was amazing!!!!
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
While this is my favorite sushi joint, I'm going to stay impartial by ranking them 4 stars (however, I'd give 4.5 stars if I could).

Let's start with the bad and end off with the good: points off for the parking situation... It's a nice restaurant so I wanna look nice when I come here and it ain't easy walking in heels down the brick streets of Ybor City, over trolley tracks and up the stairs to finally get to Samurai Blue. Once you make it in and have waited a while for your table (boo!), the food makes you forget about the journey it took to get there.

The high ceilings and brick walls make you feel like you're not in Tampa anymore.  It's got a cool, contemporary, urban feel. 

As for the sushi... The rolls come out as soon as they're ready (unlike some places where you have to wait until ALL the rolls are ready.  Love it or hate it... I just happen to love it!).  The presentation is wonderful and the rolls are amazing... fresh and delish!  

My favorite rolls are: 
Volcano - overflowing with goodness!
Mexican - classic/must have
Caterpillar - they even shape it like a caterpillar and make cute little eyes out of cream cheese and black sesame seeds
Blue Moon - soft shell crab swimming in a pool of some magical sauce, mm-mmm! 

Drinks are a bit pricey, but taste great. I'd rather spend money on more food; I like to eat my sushi while sober so I can enjoy it's goodness! ;)
name: Samurai Blue Sushi & Sake Bar
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Soup, Sushi Bars

text:
I've bought about 20 macarons from here by now. The flavors are always creative and the macarons always fresh and look carefully made. The people behind the counter are also friendly. At $1.50 a piece, this is actually a pretty good deal (for macarons). Macarons are expensive cookies for their size anyway, but from personal experience, they're not easy to make. I like the little jammy surprises in the center of each cookie. 

I also had the black sesame custard last time and it was good (if you like black sesame). But I shouldn't have eaten the whole thing in a few hours because all the sugar made me nauseous. Do share!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Holy WOW what a difference a few weeks made from my first visit!

One of the longest-running sushi bars in Reno recently closed, and I have to say it had seen better days. In its place is now a restaurant with food I would return for on a regular basis, Paradise Sushi.

Perhaps because they're new, the service was speedy and attentive. The chefs were quick with orders, and our server was fast on water refills; she even noticed--without being asked--that we needed more napkins. My order of hot sake turned out to be gratis, but it's possible this is because they're waiting on a license to sell the stuff. I certainly didn't mind free hooch.

We started with a plate of Paradise slaw, a varietal mix of shredded cabbage sprinkled with black sesame seeds, tossed in a lightly savory dressing. It reminded me of Vietnamese cabbage salad, but without the pungency of fish sauce. A serving of yakiton--cousin to crab rangoon--featured a single deep-fried, cream cheese and crab-stuffed wonton tube, cut on the bias and served with a sweet/spicy sauce. 

Our order of potstickers were unique (6 pieces). The meat filling was average, but the wrappers were completely fried to a deep golden brown, resembling little chimichangas more than gyoza. The miso soup was piping hot and had a lot more miso paste than most; very tasty. Best of all the starters, an order of baked mussels--also available grilled--were topped with Japanese mayo and chili sauce, served at just the right temp and in record time (6 pieces). Seriously, it felt like they arrived just moments after being ordered. Lunch AYCE includes one order of mussels, but they're unlimited for dinner diners. Mussel lovers rejoice.

The rice-to-fish ratio in both nigiri and rolls was good, and all the fish I tasted were great with a couple exceptions. The octopus was a bit tough and chewy, and the freshwater eel had an odd aftertaste I couldn't quite place. My wife said it tasted fishy, but for me it was just off enough I wouldn't order it again. Could be the sauce I didn't care for. I enjoyed all of the compound nigiri, with the "Spicy Upside Down Shrimp Fire" being of particular note. The flattened shrimp was topped with tuna, crab, avocado, and fire sauce. 

A Lulu roll with spicy crab, shrimp, salmon, ponzu sauce, lemon and cilantro was nice. The salmon tasted very fresh and the lemon really tied it all together. The Mt. Rose roll of salmon, spicy crab, lemon, cilantro, and tobiko was also enjoyable, though my wife noted the cilantro seemed dry rather than fresh. Cilantro loses a lot of aroma and flavor once it's dried, so using fresh herbs would be preferable.

The Wayne's hand roll was a high point of our meal. Perfect just-cooked scallop with tender, crunchy crystal shrimp and a decent mayo-based sauce. I can't recall when I've had one better. I followed this by requesting a more elaborate long roll--The Show--be converted to temaki with crystal shrimp, scallop, seared tuna, spicy crab, avocado and jalapeño. Complete mouthgasm in a crisp seaweed cone.

Similarly, a signature Paradise maki roll was rendered temaki on request, sans cream cheese as neither of us care for this ingredient in sushi. My wife loved it but wondered about the lack of jalapeño, until she found it in the bottom of the roll. It certainly added a bit of bang at the finish.

Typically a meal of AYCE sushi ends with a scoop of ice cream or mochi, but my wife wanted something more. Her tempura banana ice cream featured big slices of banana deep-fried in tempura batter, served with a whole strawberry, chocolate ice cream, strawberry cinnamon sauce, and whipped cream. A great finish for a very enjoyable dining experience.
name: Paradise Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text: A year and a half later after visiting your stand at the suburban station....BOOM...a storefront.  Congrats Audrey and team!  I knew your heavenly and delicious creations would someday be sold at a cool store.  I could not wait to visit the shop.  Sadly there was only tomorrow's batch left.  I was told to actually wait to munch on them tomorrow since they would taste better.  I couldn't remember the thee flavors i had except for the mango jasmine.  I  also indulged in the black sesame pudding.  Weirdly delicious but i prefer the salted caramel.  I can't wait to get my hands on more!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
If you want the BEST sandwich or Salad EVER come to South Coast Deli on Carrillo! I have gone to the other locations-and this one is by far the best one. 

Our favorite sandwich is the Chicken Chipotle Club (Chicken, turkey, bacon with jack cheese) and if you are courageous, add jalapeños to it! This three way sandwich is enough to share with a friend-or if you are super hungry, go for the thing all for yourself!

If salads are your thing, my favorite one is the Asian greens Salad (Napa and green cabbage, bok choy, onion, cilantro, black sesame seeds, crispy wontons, and sweet and spicy sesame dressing). Sometimes the dressing is spicier than other times, but it never bothers me. I love it.
name: South Coast Deli- Carrillo
categories: Salad, Sandwiches, Restaurants, Delis

text:
I pass by this shop quite often and never took the opportunity to walk in until today. Being the end of the day, most of her flavors were out (especially the ones I really wanted to try). However, the cashier (I assume Audrey the shop owner) was so outgoing and nice, I couldn't help but buy a few products.

I'm not a fan of sweets, but I have to say that the Black Sesame pudding was quite good! It was creamy and not quite sweet with a nice subtle black sesame taste. This place is definitely an Asian inspired bakery I would recommend!

I'm from New York, so I think I am quite fluent in the art of baked goods, so I have to say this place was quite good for the price. Never have I ever bought macarons at this price at this quality. Definitely a must try! 

Audrey, I hope this place becomes as famous as Laduree (overpriced, in my opinion).

Really recommend playing with some rose-water flavors. Makes a great new flavor profile.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Yes - the texture & temperature of the froyo is inconsistent.  Yes - Yogorino is much creamier.

BUT - Sweet Ending has tons of toppings (added cereals & syrups), friendly service & new flavors.  

AND - on my last trip they had **BLACK SESAME** frozen yogurt.  I mixed that in with some green tea & topped with mochi & mango.  The cup in the picture cost $3.50.  AMAZING... the black sesame is less tart, more earthy and reminds me of Japan.

My bf mixed up a messy concoction of strawberry, vanilla, green tea yogurt with strawberries, mangoes, mochi, sprinkles & raspberries - he called it the beauty of diy yogurt.  His overflowing disaster in a cup ran $5.50.

For location, price & the joy of experimentation, we'll definitely be back.

They also added frequent buyer cards - 11th yogurt is free.
name: Sweet Cafe
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Food

text: First of all, I dig Froyo shops. I do, I cant help it. Most of them at least. This one however is exceptional. The flavors are unique and interesting. Black sesame vanilla? Darn good. I think the toppings at most shops are the same (but for the love of god, please stop offering crushed granola bars as an option...just weird). The price is lower than most other stores, and its clean and friendly. I really liked this place. Nicely done Yogurtland.
name: Yogurtland
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: The best macaroons in philly with the best flavors. I love the sweet potato marshmallow which just reminds me of Thanksgiving and the coconut Thai tea which is quite possibly a combination of two of my favorite bubble tea flavors. The macaroons themselves are very well crafted with a light, crispy shell and creamy filling. They also have the capability to substitute other nuts like cashews and hazelnuts or seeds for a nut-free version, which is great!  I also love the black sesame pudding: sweet, creamy, and oh so aromatic. Of course the buttermilk panna cotta is still to die for. I am actually really really glad that I now live a good 12 blocks away because if I lived closer I would be horsing myself every single day. Unless they are closed of course.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Came in on a Saturday early evening during their soft opening and was welcomed by staff. It was our first time here and there were a lot of dessert options to pick from. They have waffle combos which have their dipped cone on top of a waffle garnished with variety of toppings. They also have their original dipped cones that you can pick from: Matcha, strawberry, black sesame, chocolate etc. As well as some drinks. They do serve brunch until 4pm, and after that it seems it's strictly the dessert menu.
We opted to try the Catcha Matcha waffle combo, and two Frappes - Praline and Matcha. You can substitute the milk in the frappes for soy milk or coconut milk for an extra charge. 
We were surprised when the waffle combo came out as they also gave us two dipped cones! I'm not sure if that was just a promo during their soft opening but it was a nice surprise :)
Service was excellent and the food was great. Lactose Intolerant people be warned! There'll be a lot of dairy and the waffle combo is already quite filling for two people. 

The cafe itself is really pretty - Instagram worthy cafe for sure!
Would definitely recommend trying the desserts here if you have quite a sweet tooth. Can't wait to try out their brunch menu next time.

P. S Everyone has different tastes, no need to be so passive aggressive towards other reviewers if you didn't enjoy your meal. If it wasn't tasty to you, then it wasn't.
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House
categories: Desserts, Chocolatiers & Shops, Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text: 3.5 stars. It's a cute place. A good location since there aren't many good bakeries in Chinatown, so it's nice to come here after grabbing dinner. A good/unique variety of flavors for the macarons and pudding. Main issue was packaging as I ordered 6 macarons that were placed in a little plastic bag. By the time I took them home to let my kids try, they crumbled/broke, so it wasn't as cute eating them. I got the black sesame pudding which wasn't too sweet- never had anything like it. I really liked the pudding a lot and want to try the other flavors other reviewers recommended. One HUGE perk to this place is it's safe for my peanut allergy kid! Tree nuts are used but not peanuts, so yay!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: This place is cozy but due to the prices only come here a few times with your rich friends so you can chat about who has the most diamonds on their engagement ring. We got the blackjack and catcha matcha waffles with salted caramel and mint chocolate frappés. The salted caramel didn't really taste like salted caramel but more like a normal frozen hot chocolate. The mint frappés mint flavor was pretty overwhelming and bitter it kinda tastes like medicine but idk I'm not fond of mint so that's probably just my opinion lol. This place is one of those cafes that look really good and the idea is amazing but the food is mediocre. Like it's kinda like an amusement park of food. The waffles are fairly sweet and I found it cute that they have cheesecake in top. These are pretty filling too. For the blackjack, the black sesame makes the waffles less sweet which I prefer and the mat ha was the one that was very sweet. Ok I hope I someone helped with my review!!!! The end
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House
categories: Desserts, Chocolatiers & Shops, Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Best fresh fruit smoothies in Chinatown for the lowest price, none of that powder stuff! 

Favorites:
- Ham and egg bread $0.80
- Rice roll $2.00 (can ask for beef and shrimp too! And their sweet soy sauce for it is the BEST, ask for extra if you get take out!) 
- Stir fried noodles $1.50 (runs out fast, don't forget to add Sriracha if you like spicy :))

Interesting Teas I've grown to love:
- Black Sesame Tea (use fresh ground up black sesame seeds) 
- Lavender Tea (never thought I'd like this, but their lavender is so aromatic and calming)
- MANGO SMOOTHIE :)
name: Greenland Tea House
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries

text:
My taste buds are still buzzing from my dinner at Vista Ramen last night...oh man...this place is special.

Right when you walk in, your cool points skyrocket.  The space is beautiful with a polished rustic interior.  The exposed kitchen is buzzing.  The music is interesting and upbeat, played at just the right volume.  And the people working there have style.

This isn't just a ramen spot, there's a bunch pan-Asian dishes with various influences like Korean, Japanese, Thai... Kicked off with a cocktail special made with gin, mint, yuzu syrup and machta green tea ($10).  Quite fantastic.

Then there's the food...the Korean fried chicken sliders ($10 for 2) are essential.  Everything about these was perfection.  The hot crispy chicken...the Korean spicy sauce that hits you with a punch, and then the sweet Hawaiian bun.  And the pickle. All in a nice little non-messy package. My god this was good.   

If you like beets, definitely get the beets w/ black sesame bread, burnt lemon, and popcorn ($7).  The plating was an absolute work of art, and the flavors & textures were on point.  Very cool and creative dish.

We went with the veggie ramen ($11) and were not disappointed.  The broth was rich, veggies were delicious, and the soft-boiled egg was just right.  The noodles were al-dente and cooked perfectly.  If I could make one suggestion, it would be to add some mushrooms to it, just because.  Along with the ramen we got a side of cucumber & tofu with lime, ginger, and chili ($6).  I highly recommend this!  The tofu was some of the best I've had, and the brightness of the dish was the perfect contrast to the savory veggie ramen.

I normally don't get dessert when eating out, but the thought of lemongrass-basil ice cream with ginger wafers ($5) was too good to pass up.   Yes, this is as amazing as it sounds, maybe even better.  It was beautifully plated, the ice cream was super creamy, and the taste almost brought tears to my eyes it was so good.  It's worth coming in just for this alone.

Creative and delicious food, great service and a lovely atmosphere to boot....Cherokee Street has definitely upped its game with Vista.  You need to eat here.
name: Vista
categories: Nightlife, Specialty Food, American (New), Japanese, Ramen, Bars, Food, Beer Bar, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants

text: My friend and I stopped by to share an order of the sweet black sesame soup with milk tea for dessert, and it was delicious! Spotted with the occasional whole sesame seed, it truly was as good as it gets!
name: Heung Fa Chun Sweet House
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Food, Desserts

text:
The Tap is a most beloved Indy brewery, and for good reason. Their on-tap beer selection is truly impressive, with flavor profiles across the board and enough to keep even a die-hard regular tasting something new each time. The servers know their beers really well and are so helpful in guiding you through the menu; they always take the time to learn your taste preferences and make their own recommendations. If you're on the fence, they're always quick to offer you the opportunity to taste test anything before officially making your selection. The service has also always been pretty fast.

YES, THEY SERVE HARD LIQUOR!: So while there's no question The Tap was made for beer people... how 'bout those non-beer people? I'd always assumed that cocktails and hard liquor were pretty much off the table here. I've never seen anyone even ask for one. So I'm not sure if it's a recent thing or not, but I can now confirm that yes, The Tap most definitely serves liquor! (The fact that most people do not goes to speak for the quality of their brews.)

NEED MORE GLUTEN-FREE BEERS/CIDERS!: Therein lies probably my only minor complaint: their pretty weak selection of gluten-free beers. They do have a few basic ciders and I think 1 or 2 pre-bottled (Omission) GF beers. Which is nice but for a brewery with such an impressive and expansive selection of beers on tap, I would've expected a littttle more. So my experience when I come to The Tap never really has anything to do with the beers themselves, ironically, and more to do with the experience alone. Because my beer options are pretty much the same here as they are anywhere else.

AWESOME ATMOSPHERE: The atmosphere is definitely enough to rile anyone up, beers or not. It's fun, loud and energetic. There's always a crowd, but never to the point where I've had to actually wait for a table. It's also a really fun spot to watch big sports games.

OUTDOOR SEATING AND DOG FRIENDLY!: There is outdoor seating in the summer, always a bonus! There are both tables and comfy couch areas out there, and it's dog-friendly. They also have this beautiful outdoor wall covered top to bottom with flower planters, creating a giant flower wall. Makes you happy just to look at! Psst, Insta babes, it's a perfect backdrop for a cute outdoor lunch pic. ;) 

--

YES, THEY SERVE DINNER, TOO!: I already went over my liquor revelaton, but did you know The Tap also offers a full menu of legit dinner options? I didn't!! Until last week, I thought they only had bar snacks and tap fries (which are fantastic, don't get me wrong.) But instead I discovered an entire menu of legit dinner options. I ordered the Ahi Tuna Salad. (I know I know, who goes to a brewery and orders a salad, but isn't the option nice?!) The salad consisted of seared black sesame tuna glazed in teriyaki sauce, on a romaine salad of onions, tomatoes, cheese, crunchy rice noodles, and a cucumber wasabi dressing on the side - which was so good and not spicy at all (trust me, I'd be the first to tell you). And the tuna, excellent.

The service was again quite fast, but I will say that the server was a little pushy in getting us to either drink more or leave... which I totally get, but we were eating dinner... and not for an overly long time? Overall though, great experience, great food, and all for just $20!
name: The Tap
categories: Restaurants, Breweries, American (Traditional), Beer Bar, Bars, American (New), Nightlife, Food

text:
It's been several years since my last review & my previous comments no longer apply; the price is about the only thing that hasn't changed.

The yogurt is often icy, there isn't much flavor turnover, and the less than fresh fruit toppings often look slimy.  I've been back frequently and not once have I seen the elusive black sesame yogurt.

The novelty has worn off.
name: Sweet Cafe
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Food

text:
While I do not frequent this establishment very often, when I do, it is a pure delight.  My parents are here almost once a week so I live vicariously through them in between visits.  I remember when I was in high school it was a greasy spoon diner known as Charcoal, Steak and Things.  Now it is the gem of Yardley borough serving classy food in creative ways.  

My review will be based upon the Kitchen Tasting I enjoyed this past December 2011, but I think it will give any reader some insight on the abilities and creativity of the chefs here.  I have posted pictures to accompany this review.  

First Course: Oyster: cherry, leek.  Before this tasting I had never had an oyster before.  I know, I know, it took me this long, but what a way to experience my first one!  We were presented with an oyster bathing in it's own juices, covered in thinly sliced leek and a cherry foam on top.  Unfortunately my experience was dominated by the flavor of the leek, but there was a subtle presence of the cherry foam and the oyster just melted away.  Impressive presentation.

Second Course: Scallop: lentil, grapefruit, frisee.  The scallop was cooked perfectly and paired well with the lentil.  I've never had lentil outside of soup so it was nice to experience it's true taste on it's own.  Paired with the scallop and frisee, there were many layers of textures ranging from soft and mushy to crisp crunch.  I should have asked the chef at the time, but I was left wondering what the purpose of the grapefruit was.  Possibly to cleanse the pallet after eating the scallop?

Third Course: Woodcock: polenta, cherry, sprout leaves.  Yes, I looked up a picture of a Woodcock right after I ate this course!  It looked like a cross between a woodpecker and a pigeon.  Found year round in the southeast, breeding in the northeast, this particular bird was from New York.  It's flavor was gamey, the breast not as gamey as the thigh.  Along with the creamy polenta and the bittersweet dried cherry, this was a unique course.  I preferred the flavor of the breast to the thigh greatly.  

Fourth Course: Trio of Duck.  I'm sorry to those that disapprove, but duck is GOOD!  We were presented with a thick cut of duck breast with a tasty layer of fat on top, a full duck heart and deep fried duck tongue.  I was surprised that the heart was pretty tender and almost tasted like a cut of filet mignon.  The tongue were like crispy little fried clams.  It was exotic without tasting as such.  I was really impressed with how it was presented as well.  

Fifth Course: Hanger Steak: turnip, red wine, broccoli rabe.  Hanger Steak, a.k.a. Butcher's Steak presents itself almost like a flank steak in it's look and texture but offers great flavor.  We were given a generous portion of steak atop turnip puree and red wine reduction.  Topped with broccoli rabe and pepper flakes, this was the course more familiar to my taste buds and eyes.  After the adventure of the first four courses, this was a treat to finish the savory dishes.

Sixth Course: Pliable Chocolate: black sesame, meringue.  First off, look at the picture I posted and how they presented this dish.  It was awesome!  I was never a big fan of sesame but when paired with chocolate, it really redefined the flavor for me.  There was this sesame 'dust' that just disappeared in your mouth, creamy toasted meringue, black sesame ice cream and chocolate ganache.  

If you can attend a tasting here, I highly recommend it as it really exposes you to things you may never order on your own.  You don't know what your going to eat until you arrive so there is a lot of excitement involved.  The chef presents each dish with a little explanation and will answer any questions you have.  The staff here is really friendly and the view overlooking the Delaware River just adds to the already pleasant ambiance.  Awesome job done by this place!
name: Charcoal
categories: American (New), Steakhouses, Restaurants

text:
Amazing macaroons. Amazing decor. Amazing service. Flavors are awesome and unique, and each macaroon is small enough for the perfect amount of satisfaction.

I absolutely enjoyed the apple pie macaroon (the apple sauce homemade in the center is just ridiculously good), but thought the black sesame pudding. I'm also a bit biased because I'm not a fan of pudding in general-- the texture throws me off. And cash only?!

Nonetheless, I'll definitely be back. For $1.50 per macaroon, I'd definitely come back to get a box of all flavors offered for the day. Incredible!
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
I enjoyed their ice cream way more then Ben & Jerry's just down the block.  The ice cream tasted better and was cheaper than B&Js plus it had 3 toppings added for free.  I ordered the black sesame vanilla with strawberry, lychee & mochi.  They also offer smoothies and bubble teas. 
 They looked great.
name: Snow Factory
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Cool unique place. Its a casual dining setting, coffee shop and ice cream all in one. Indoor seating only. 
Cant comment on food but the coffee was definitely great. We also tried the ice cream, that was delicious. Flavors such as black sesame, rice, etc it was really good, creamy and you get to add all your toppings in a Chinese food togo container. Not too sweet which was good.
name: Dart Coffee Co
categories: Food, Coffee Roasteries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I was so ecstatic that a Thai rolled ice cream style shop opened on the Loop in St. Louis. I never would have dreamed that this would happen. I don't even know of any in the area back home near my suburb of Los Angeles. Basically, this is BIG news. Everyone get excited please. 

I read an article online that a senior at UMSL recently opened this store with a vision for desserts from Asia. I think he pretty much hit the spot. When I first walked in, I was very impressed with the overall ambiance of the store, the Pintrest-like seating and lighting fixtures, all the white space, cool decorations, open glass ice cream stations to watch your creation being made in front of you, etc. The only thing I didn't like was the blasting of the music. It was a little absurdly loud, but that may change in the future. 

I looked at the array of ice cream flavors, and instantly my eyes lit up at matcha, taro, black sesame, etc. Flavors I love, but don't see done well in St. Louis very much. I ended up choosing the taro flavor with strawberries, pocky, and mochi. It was around $7 plus tax. A little pricey, but my wallet can handle this every once in awhile.

I was so happy when I got my creation. The taro was so real, with actual chunks of taro. It made me want to cry tears of happiness for my taste buds. Thank you Snow Factory for not giving me fake taro powdered flavoring. My ice cream rolls were pretty dense and filling, and I had a pretty good amount of toppings. Get the taro if you are a taro lover like me!! It's fantastic.

Overall, so happy about Snow Factory opening up. Great location, great set-up inside, super innovative in bringing this dessert trend to St. Louis already, and great execution so far. I am sure they will only get better with time and experience too.
name: Snow Factory
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
The group I was with spontaneously said let's grab sushi! We were in solvang at the time jumped in a taxi and went to Santa Barbara... We arrived here the decor AMAZING! seating a little tight but that brought us closer.

The food! Incredible I don't really venture off and try something I don't know. But I had 5 other friends with me so I got to try some different things, all amazing I'd definitely order what they got next time.

My dish was the black sesame scallops cooked to perfection and very flavorable. This spot is perfect for a date night or a girls night out! I'll be back!
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text: Guerrilla Street Food just opened another location inside 2nd Shift Brewery on The Hill. I know, it's a good thing. I hadn't had it in a while so I ordered The Wandering Pig (12 hour roasted pork shoulder, pulled and sauced with sriracha, hoisin, and calamansi, topped with fried garlic, black sesame seeds served over steamed local jasmine rice, and garnished with scallions.) As I'm sitting there eating the dish I can taste the bright flavors of the chiles, sriracha, and acidic notes from the calamansi. Best part might be the fried garlic!The pork is so tender I'm not even using my knife. I've never had Filipino food anywhere else but for whatever reason this food speaks to me. Probably because I'm a nice Jewish girl and I do really like pork. In all seriousness though go visit their new location and the beer is good too! P.S. The garlic peanuts are a nice bar snack.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Restaurants, Filipino, Street Vendors, Food Trucks, Food

text: Vegan doughnuts for, well, vegans or those allergic to eggs.  These are not your momma's doughnuts.  These are super huge and w designer flavours like blueberry lavender, black sesame mango, peach twist and an apple and cranberry fritter.  We made it ten minutes to closing and scored the last lavender doughnuts.  Totally worth the last minute dash!
name: Doughnut Party
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Donuts, Bakeries

text:
Two words: BRICK. TOAST.

I first went to Audabon to check out its selection of macarons and try its salted caramel pudding, but I made a very wise decision that day to also order a mini brick toast. The "mini" brick toast was anything but small: it was enough to feed me and my friend. That day it came with matcha ice cream, pastry cream, and pocky sticks with some blackberries on top.
