My friend and I loved it so much we had to go to Audabon again when we found out from Audabon's Facebook page that the brick toast flavor had changed to nutella pastry cream, salted caramel ice cream, and strawberries. I loved everything on this second toast and consequently fell head over heels for Audabon.

While so far I haven't had a macaron flavor that I dislike from Audabon, I must say the size of Audabon's macarons is smaller than Sugar Philly Truck. The salted caramel pudding was good, but it was so rich and sweet it became too much for me after eating only half of it. I have yet to try a black sesame panna cotta and matcha oreo mousse, so those two are my next conquests.

I like how cute the interior is and the free wifi, but there is one drawback to Audabon: it doesn't have a restroom for customers. One would assume that it would since Audabon serves coffee...
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: Cool new gourmet donut shop in YEG! Been wanting to try this place for a while.  The interior is nice, bright and modern.  Their mascot is this cute, what I presume to be a donut, character which will be a hit with the little ones. But the donuts are the star of the show of course. We had the cardamom rose apple fritter, passion fruit black sesame caramel, and breakfast smoothie. Deliciously unique.  The donut itself is soft and fluffy on the inside, and the icing had nice, bold flavouring. Be prepared to line up though...this place is popular. We paid $3.50 a donut, but they are quite large.
name: Doughnut Party
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Donuts, Bakeries

text: This is the best Chinese food in Nashville I've found - they have authentic and Chinese-American dishes. I ordered chow mein, egg custard buns, xiao long bao (my favorite of the meal), pea shoots, egg roll, black sesame buns, and sticky rice in lotus leaf. Definitely satisfied my craving for some good Chinese food.
name: Lucky Bamboo China Bistro
categories: Restaurants, Hot Pot, Dim Sum, Szechuan, Chinese

text:
One of the best dining experiences I've had in University city. Like mentioned in many of my reviews, I am very weary of restaurants in college towns, they tend to care less about quality and services. At Sang Kee however, the service was beyond excellent. I felt very welcomed since my first step into the door. I also noticed that the service kept up entire time, not only at my table but for everyone around us. We ordered half a Peking duck, shrimp wonton soup, steamed bass with ginger and scallion, mapo tofu and crunchy tofu in xo sauce.

The food came out pretty quickly. The wonton soup was great, it was light but had flavors, the wonton themselves were packed with shrimps and pork. The Peking duck came next. It was really amazing, the seasoning really penetrated through the meat. I did wanted the skin to be a tad crispier. The crunchy tofu was my favorite. It was stir fried with minced pork, adding a rich, salty taste to the tofu. The steamed ginger fish was also great, light and fresh. They had a special going on so it was 14 dollars instead of the usual 24! The only dish I had a small complaint with was the mapo tofu. While the tofu was really fresh and I love the chunks of minced pork in there, the sauce lacked salt, it was very light. 

I could've given this a four star with the food and service combined but the owner, Micheal came out to check on us. There is such care and attention he pays to his customers that really touched me. In this crazy business world, money seems to be the only thing that matters. It's rare to meet an individual who goes beyond that. He checked on us and gave us complementary deserts. The sweet rice soup with sesame was amazing. Micheal was nice enough to give us a small history behind the dish, which only made it better. The sweet soup had a really refreshing ginger after taste that clears up your throat. The rice balls were soft with this very decadent black sesame sweet filling. It's a very simple desert that was extremely satisfying. 

This, is how a business should be! Thanks to excellent customer service and attention to details, this place earn a 5 stars from me. I hope the business keeps up this level of excellence. If you're in university city, this is one of best spots to visit.
name: Sang Kee Noodle House
categories: Restaurants, Ethnic Food, Noodles, Food, Dim Sum, Specialty Food, Chinese

text:
I've been going to this bakery for years (about almost a decade long!!!) and the owners of the bakery are good friends of my parents and I've actually taught their kids in summer camp for a while so I've seen them grow up, which is crazy for me.  They are so sweet and kind to their customers and I just love that family-owned vibe that you don't get at these mainstream bubble tea places like Kung Fu or Tea Do. 

I love their traditional bakery goods (most under a $1!!!). I would recommend trying their: pineapple buns, hot dog buns, ham and egg buns, and roast pork buns--everything is super cheap so don't worry about breaking the bank for these treats.  

If you are in the mood for bubble tea or smoothies then you can never go wrong with their fruit smoothies, but I personally love their natural black sesame tea for $2.00 (can get it cold or warm), which is hard to find anywhere else so I always get it when I come back to Philly Chinatown.

***Note: This place is cash only!
name: Greenland Tea House
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries

text:
I'll give this place 5 stars. 

The facebook and philly asian community was buzzing about Audabon Bakeshop over the weekend. i was like "Audabon NJ???" Yeah...I didn't know who she was..

Made my way over on Sunday late afternoon (5pm'ish) Sold out. It's alright...i'll come back when they restock Wed. I actually came for the pull up contest but just had a big lunch, so I didn't attempt it. And 25 was a bit out of my range...lower it to 20 maybe? 

Came back Wed. night around 7pm, luckily there were some left. Ordered two of each (12 total) I was a little surprised there was no discount on anything over 5 macarons, but at $1.50...i think it's already cheap for something that can be rated "BEST IN PHILLY". After all, they have rent and utilities to pay for now at their physical bakery. I also got the new black sesame pudding thing too. At $5, i thought it was pricey. lol.

I think the location also messes with my perception of the products prices. Since it is located in Chinatown, I want to automatically assume its going to be "cheap" and filling. It isn't...it isn't expensive either. These are luxury items and the price reflects the quality and skill. At $1.50 for one (and no discount for large numbers purchased), I think they are reasonable. Are they an everyday treat like your morning coffee? I dont' think so...A quick stop after dim sum on Sundays? Sure.. perfect treat. The place is pretty spacious with some seating on the right. Not sure if they sell coffee or not, which i think Chinatown needs a coffee house since they are being overrun by tea-houses...

I can only rate the taste of the salted caramel macaron and the black sesame pudding. I'm not a big fan of macaron or sweet treats to begin with, but one bite of the salted caramel macaron was pretty good. There were layers of flavor that hit your taste buds..There was just enough sweet, just enough salt, just enough "MmMm". It was light, chewy, and  an enjoyable bite overall. The black sesame pudding was very decadent. I was full from dinner, but had 2 spoon fulls of the pudding and the flavor was pretty unique. Its not sweet, i'd even say bland (not in a bad way), but the nutty flavor and almost gritty texture from the sesame specs was nice. I don't see this being a big hit to non-Asians as the flavor is foreign to most people..I liked it. Reminded me of Mitsuwa's black sesame ice cream. (which is the reason i bought the pudding). 

I will update my review when i try the other flavors.

**UPDATE**

Tried the lemon and coffee flavors last night. They were pretty good too. The flavors aren't overwhelming and the texture and airiness of the macaron was great. Oh, the black sesame wasn't a pudding, i forgot it was a custard lol. After eating it some more, i do really like it. I still believe it won't be a big hit with non-asians bc of the flavor profile/texture. I think what sets these macarons apart from others are the consistency in the size/shape/flavor. The cream filling is really good, although it was on the border of "too sweet" for me.. but that's because i'm not a sweets person. But overall, these are pretty amazing luxury items.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: I went during weekday lunch time so I didn't experience other people's "out of food" incident. I ordered the garlic black sesame ramen and pork bun. If you have never had ramen before, Nami might be satisfactory. Unfortunately I've had better and Nami is a big disappointment. The soup is not thick enough and there's too much garlic oil which gave me a lasting acrid garlic burn in my digestive track. They need to use natural ingredients instead of artificial flavorings. Overall the ramen and the pork bun was bland in taste except for the garlic burn and lacking texture. Also the restaurant owners and staff need more experience in efficient management.
name: Nami Ramen
categories: Japanese, Ramen, Restaurants

text:
dear audrey,

it was like a year and a half ago.. my boyfriend came home and handed me some macarons b/c he knew i love that stuff~ and the first moment i popped your macarons in my mouth, i knew it was something amazing and i COULD NOT wait to try more flavors!! ( btw the goat cheese and popcorn ( i think) blew me out of the water!  probably b/c i didn't expect i would like it.. but i ended up LOVE LOVE LOVING IT!!!)

so after my first experience with your lovely treats, i had to go for more! conveniently, i work in center city so i could go explore and stop by your shop basically on any given day~  i followed your cute little cartoon map at the time and took my first trip to the suburban station looking for your spot~ ... couldn't find it.  went again the day after.. still couldn't find it.. i gave it another try-- going deeper into the station and looking at EVERY direction... still saw no sign of your shop.. i was sad.. it was almost like being told of a rabbit hole that i couldn't go down into the magical wonderland.. 

but just earlier this week, a friend told me about this new macaron shop that opened up in chinatown and as soon as my friend mentioned your name.  i was like THAT"S THE ONE!!! and i knew i had to pay you guys a visit a-sap! i grabbed every flavor you guys offered! kinda sad there weren't more.. but i'll be patient! nbd :)  also tried the black sesame pudding~ freakin' fabulous!! love the flavor with your own twist and recipe!!  i don't even have a sweet tooth and im contemplating about trying another one today :]

definitely looking forward to what else you guys have to offer!  so far, your macarons are THE BEST i've ever come across!!  i know i haven't tried too many kinds to give a fair judgement, but i am ecstatic that your new shop is easy to find in chinatown!! don't worry, i am spreading the word and i will be back very soon!

best,
kelly
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text:
Nathaniel Reid Bakery is so special! No wonder they've won so many awards! I stopped in for the first time and picked up a Smoked Ham & Gruyère Croissant, a Kouign-Amann (pronounced "queen" ah-mahn), and a spring seasonal delicacy: the Margo. Everything was absolutely incredible! It's clear that time, energy, and (most of all) skill goes into the creation of each and every one of these materpieces.

The ham and gruyère croissant was tender ham and melty gruyère cheese with tangy dijon encased in a buttery, flaky, freshly baked croissant (even a hint warm still from the oven!) The top of the croissant had a sprinkle of white and black sesame seeds, poppy seeds, and sunflower seeds. At $4.50, it tasted FAR better than any breakfast sandwich you could get anywhere else. The Kouign-Amann is a denser croissant dough covered in a sweet, crunchy, caramelized glaze that creates a perfect balance with the soft dough interior. Now for their true show of skill: the Margo pastry. The Margo is crafted with strawberry chantilly and raspberry-lemon verbena confit, garnished with fresh raspberries that are dusted with powdered sugar, and sandwiched between two fresh french macaron cookies. Delicate, fruity, and the epitome of spring. Not to mention, the staff is SO friendly! Nathaniel Reid is an experience that should not be missed!
name: Nathaniel Reid Bakery
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Restaurants, Bakeries

text:
I treat myself to South Coast once a week at minimum. It's definitely my favorite place to eat in IV if not all of Santa Barbara. I told myself I would try all the salads on their menu by the time I graduate because I'm convinced they're all incredible, but I always end up ordering one of my two favorites: Romaine & Gorgonzola and Asian Greens W/ Chicken. The salad portions are HUGE, the combinations unique, the ingredients fresh, and the prices beyond fair!

The Romaine & Gorgonzola was my first love. I ordered it simply because it was one of the few items on the 4/20 menu ($4.20 for select sammies and salads from 4:20-5pm every Thursday). It blew my taste buds away. The Romaine lettuce is chopped into wide strips that are crunchier than julienned greens. The thinly sliced turkey adds a smokiness, the crumbled gorgonzola adds a sharpness, and the walnuts and avocado add a butteriness. The tabasco vinaigrette is tangy and ever so slightly spicy, and ties everything together beautifully.

After studying abroad for a year, I revisited South Coast and was bummed to find that the 4/20 menu had changed. The Romaine & Gorgonzola no longer appeared on it, but I'd try the $4.20 Asian Greens W/ Chicken. It was another winner. The napa cabbage, green cabbage, and bok choy add a substantial bite to the salad. I ask for no shredded carrots, cilantro, or wonton strips, but I keep the chicken breast, green onions, black sesame seeds, and sweet & spicy sesame dressing. The staff is great about omissions and substitutions - just ask!

Even at regular price, both salads cost less than $9. Un. real. Here's to hoping that South Coast opens its doors in LA one day!
name: South Coast Deli- Isla Vista
categories: Restaurants, Food, Food Delivery Services, Sandwiches, Breakfast & Brunch, Delis, Salad

text:
We took a one day trip to Santa Barbara & after much Yelp research, decided to go to Arigato Sushi for dinner on a Thursday night.  This place is crowded all the time - we tried to go just when they opened (arriving about 15-20 minutes after dinner opening) but all the tables were taken.  We left our name & phone number and they will call you when a table is available.

The restaurant space is very crowded - tables inside, outside & upstairs and it is cramped!  After a 15-20 minute wait, we were seated - inside the restaurant is nicely decorated & there's tons of chefs in the kitchen (I like how you can see everything in the kitchen area).  We were hungry and ordered lots of food:

-Zippy roll (spicy tuna roll): standard I think
-Right Said Eel roll (freshwater eel roll): also pretty standard - the eel was good.
-Snake roll (eel on top of a CA roll): nicely presented but nothing we haven't seen before =)
-Dracula roll (albacore & blackened ahi inside with fresh tuna on top): I thought being called the Dracula roll there would be some garlic inside but alas no; tasted fine - fish was fresh but I was not blown away.
-Standing Room Only appetizer (baked avocado, eel, crab & tomatoes in eel sauce): Tasted fine but was hard to distinguish the different ingredients - think mashed avocado medley.
-Pan seared scallops w/lemon butter black sesame sauce: my favorite of the night; scallops were large and cooked perfectly with a nice acidic sauce to go with it.
-Godzilla dessert (tempura fried green tea ice cream): pretty good but we've had a better version
-Green tea creme brulee: very good green tea flavor & delicious!

There are some very creative items on the menu but unfortunately, we're not that adventurous.  I see they have oyster shooters & uni shooters too but I don't particularly care for that.  Thinking about it now, we probably should have chosen a less expensive restaurant based on our sushi order.  Nothing was bad...in fact, all of the fish was very tasty & fresh.  I just feel that it was a bit expensive for what it was, especially since we felt cramped and stuffed the entire time.
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text: We have been meaning to indulge in Amalour Revival Lounge for some time.  Revival is synonymous with improvement of a craft.  After eating here I have to agree with their concept of farm to table movement.  It screams out fresh food that is both "light" and delicious.  They have a great Happy Hour which we always enjoy going to  in many restaurants in Tucson. .To name a few of the small bites offered was Phyllo wrapped feta baked with black sesame and honey,  pulled pork phyllo in a sweet chili sauce, cauliflower, jalapeño and quinoa fritter with creamy sharp cheddar cheese. to name a few.  Each of these dishes had their own uniqueness to it.  Unfortunately Happy Hours ,you get smaller portions. But these were very small. When you come in with big appetites and fill up only a portion of your gut, you still crave for more.  To balance the craving we ordered some of their signature cocktails which had about 8 different choices.  Had the "Bee's Knees" and it was lightly flavored with honey.  Just hit the spot.  Love the chic ambiance with all the different kinds of seating such as sofas with pillows and coffee tables, regular tables and chairs,  cushy booths, nice bar area as well as outdoor seating.  I'll wait for cooler weather for that  The wait staff was great.  Taryn was so knowledgeable about each drink and gave us wanted advice, of course, she was professional.  As I always say,   WE WILL BE BACK. St. Phillips Plaza is a wonderful place to be situated.  Some of my favorite eating establishments are here.  Nice to walk around and if you are here on a Sunday so is the Farmer's Market.
name: Amalour Restaurant
categories: Lounges, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Food, Vegetarian, American (New), Italian, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Mediterranean, Restaurants, Nightlife

text:
I was gifted a Whole Body Wellness day package with additional credit added to use at Miraval. When I called to schedule the day and accompanying activities, I advised the experience planning concierge of the gift certificate. She confirmed via email, implying I was good to go. The day came and went, but lo and behold, I was charged the same amount (of the gift certificate) on my credit card. 

Therefore, I was none too pleased to spend unnecessary time out of my day to contact Miraval, communicate the situation, request they use their common sense and apply the funds on the already-paid-for gift certificate for my day package and additional services, and to please refund the amount charged to my card. This was completed in an expedient fashion, but I still had to expend extra energy on my end to watch my statement and ensure the refund posted. It was a frustrating and completely avoidable end to what was supposed to be a relaxing and decompressing day. 

Onto the day itself: I don't know how Miraval manages to have a "Tucson" address, because it's a ~30 min drive from Tucson proper, less if you're up north and more if you're coming from the south/east. The resort is actually in the town of Catalina.

The grounds are neatly manicured and tranquil. There are a few babbling brooks for ambiance, I suppose, if you like that sort of thing. I just feel the pools breed mosquitos. Customer service was generally excellent. I really enjoyed the variety of healthy smoothies offered at the Palm Court Cafe. 

The Cactus Flower Restaurant has indoor and outdoor seating; the tables are spaced out, I believe, for social distancing. However, I noted that the tables were kind of sticky, and there were flies I had to constantly shoo off my table and away from my food. I know it's difficult to keep the flies out, especially after the monsoon rains and the fact that the servers have to open doors to serve the folks seated outside, but the flies were a distraction from fully enjoying the meal. 

The meal itself at Cactus Flower left much to be desired. I had the soup du jour, or a tomato barley soup, which was very watery and lacking in much flavor. It felt "limp" and kind of like a can of Campbell's soup - all water, hardly any barley, and two token slices of mushroom. For the entree, I ordered the daily chef's creation, a barbecue pork with zucchini and cauliflower puree. There were 3-4 slices of pork (about the size of char siu pork) drizzled with bbq sauce. It was edible but hardly special. There was one okra-size zucchini, all atop a decent puree. Dessert consisted of 2 pistachio chocolate chip cookies. They were good, but it's a juvenile dessert for such an upscale (read: EXPENSIVE) resort. 

The saving grace was the Coyote Moon Bar & Lounge, whose food blew me away. For an afternoon snack, I ordered the black sesame somen, which was incredibly refreshing and tasted authentically and strongly of black sesame. I also got the house cured salmon, which I must say, is probably the best salmon I have ever had in my life. It was very fresh, the texture and flavor were perfect and went swimmingly with the quark creme fraiche. I think the food is all from the same kitchen, so I suppose it just depends on what you happen to order. 

I took a cardio drumming class and strength training class with Da Vinci body boards. The drumming class was fun and worked up a sweat; the body board class was intense and revealed conclusively how out of shape I am. The instructor of the Da Vinci body boards was funny and knows his stuff. My critique is that the room in which these classes take place, in the Body Mindfulness Center, is dated and it's a pretty small space. The locker room can also use a facelift. I don't think the bath towels should give off a light pink hue, but here we are. 

I squeezed in a deep desert massage and probiotic facial. The spa facilities are much better than the BMC - bigger and more updated. It also houses the spa amenities of a dry sauna, steam room (closed b/c of COVID), jacuzzi, and an enclosed outdoor space to lounge and relax. I especially liked the quiet room at the spa: a sitting room with large comfy lounge chairs that face a wall of windows showcasing a view of the mountains. 

My massage with Michael was mediocre. I like DEEP DEEP DEEEEEEP massages. I asked for more pressure, which he verbally acquiesced but didn't physically deliver. My facial was better, but I would've preferred more extractions, as upon inspecting my face afterwards, there could have been more extractions done.

My day's experience totaled $474, which is pricey, but I'd opt for a day package plus extras over staying overnight, which can average $2,000 PER NIGHT! Why pay 4x more for a dinner and roof over your head but access to the same facilities and activities? At that point, it's a situation of more dollars than sense.
name: Miraval Arizona Resort & Spa
categories: Hotels, Beauty & Spas, Event Planning & Services, Hotels & Travel, Venues & Event Spaces, Day Spas, Resorts

text:
The most aesthetically pleasing dessert cafe has just opened up in downtown Edmonton! Straight out of a perfect Instagram shot, Cacao 70 has brought its delicious dessert creations here. If you haven't heard of Cacao 70, it's a dessert chain based in Montreal that has expanded throughout Canada. Cacao 70 is well known for their decadent chocolate, such as fondues and hot chocolates. Since the chain has different concepts, the location I visited was their Sweet House concept which serves all-day brunch, dessert, and chocolate drinks. The dessert menu consists of waffles, fondues, crepes, dessert pizzas, and sharing plates. You can also get their signature dipped ice cream and chocolate drinks, available on the go.

This is their first Edmonton location, which is in the back of the Edmonton Tower in the Ice District. Two more locations are planned - one in West Edmonton Mall and the other on Whyte Ave.

My friend and I tried out their fondue and a classic waffle combo. Each of their fondue comes in two sizes and there are so many flavours to choose from! We settled on the smaller size of their matcha chocolate fondue, which was perfect for 2 people. Their other flavours are classic, black & white, triple, coffee, peanut butter, and Earl Grey. The fondue was served with fresh fruit, chocolate brownie pieces, and waffle bites. The matcha fondue itself was creamy and definitely did not lack the matcha taste. It wasn't bitter due to the balance of the chocolate but it was soooo good. I would definitely recommend trying this if you like matcha! They also have a classic waffle with their matcha chocolate called the Catcha Matcha which I'm probably gonna try on my next visit.

Their classic waffle combo definitely did not look like your average dessert waffle. We tried The Blackjack which had a Cacao 70 waffle hidden at the bottom, topped with black sesame chocolate, cheesecake creme brulee, soft serve ice cream, whipped cream, sesame seeds, and a waffle cone. Their Cacao 70 waffle had a slight crisp to it, which paired perfectly with the sesame chocolate and ice cream. I tried to get a bit of everything in each bite. Honestly, I couldn't tell where the cheesecake creme brulee was in this but I think I tasted it?? My friend and I both enjoyed The Blackjack even though it looked overwhelming at first!

Cacao 70 satisfied my sweet tooth for sure! I felt like I wasn't even in Edmonton when I was eating there.
name: Cacao 70 Sweet House
categories: Desserts, Chocolatiers & Shops, Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Red Bowl is a casual style Sichuan restaurant.  It is the only Sichuan restaurant in Tampa Bay.  Of course, there are other restaurants that have Sichuan dishes, but Red Bowl make the claim.  

This review will be quick, as I have tried almost here dish here.  I come here for very specific items;
1. Wonton/Dumpling in chili oil - mainly for the garlicy chili sauce.  The flavor has become more sweet over the years, sometimes a little too sweet.
2. Sweet Dumplings in soup - This is similar to Tang Yuan, minus the flavored tang.  The "dumplings" are chewy rice flour filled with sweet black sesame.  Addictive.
3. Peruvian Apple Herb Jelly - This is similar to Aiyu jelly and good for cooling your body down after eating spicy food.  For those that like the trendy brown sugar syrup flavor (in Tiger Sugar Bubble Drink), then you will like this flavor.  It also has chopped peanuts and raisins.
For the other dishes, I have had them and they are just ok.  There is another restaurant in this plaza that I go to for lamb and janbing.

I already wrote a review for this restaurant a few years ago that was more detailed, but it was deleted for some reason.
name: Red Bowl
categories: Szechuan, Restaurants, Hot Pot, Chinese, Noodles, Asian Fusion

text:
Many have tried and many have failed what Arigato Sushi is able to achieve - a true Californian style sushi restaurant that remains true to the root of Japanese culinary art. 

It is not hard to understand why this restaurant is crowded every night of the year. A two hours wait on the weekend is not uncommon if you arrive after 7. Arigato Sushi has what it takes to appeal to different clientele. Purists could sit in front of the sparkling clean sushi bar and receive full service from the chefs in the authentic style. Couples could enjoy a romantic dinner at the beautiful outdoor patio. The energetic ambiance made it an excellent place to socialize with your friends over a few glasses of cocktails or sake. 

The menu has fusion ingredients written all over. Arigato is not your typical Japanese sushi restaurant featuring some fusion maki. The food here is the child of a Japanese-Californian marriage. Different elements combined seamlessly to enhance the flavor of the fish without stealing any spotlight. Some might find their sauce and garnish on the mild side but I found the lack of distraction very comforting.

The most memorable thing I have ate there is actually the grilled portabella nigiri. A pure vegetarian creation and yet it is not shy in comparison to its seafood siblings. The texture actually resemble a good piece of anago. Quality of their fish is good although still far from what I would consider top tier. Dinner was overall very delightful. I have some complaints but the list is short. Serving sashimi platter on ice might look impressive but the cold temperature numbs the tongue too much and dumb down the tastebuds. Black sesame ice cream was slightly icy. 

It is really worth a 2 hours wait? Hard to say. If you are smart like me, you will get here super early to beat the crowd.
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
"Thank You Sushi"?  Ok, whatever.

SERVICE - EXCELLENT
Even though it was a Friday night and super busy, we somehow managed to get seated right away.  It was a table close to the door but far enough so that we didn't feel a draft and people couldn't hover over our table.  All night, the manager was very attentive to us.  He was actually our server.  Sometimes service was slow but that's cause the busyness really picked up.  The only negative for the night was that another server checked up on us, we asked for a dessert menu and it never came.

FOOD - VERY GOOD
I won't go into detail about all the things we ordered but here is a list of some:
-Seared Salmon
-Jalapeno Yellowtail
-Pacific Rim Roll
-Fiesta Roll (based on manager's recomendations)
-Sashimi Combo
All the fish was very fresh.  Nothing is as spicy as the menu makes it out to be, even if there is habanero involved.  The only roll that was unpleasant was the Fiesta Roll which contained tempura yellowtail, tomatoes, cucumber, avocado and rice in a soy wrap.  It tasted like a burrito and according to my friends, specifically like a fish burrito.  I think you all would completely agree.  The manager claimed that to be one of his ultimate favorites.  

AMBIANCE - GOOD
Trendy and hip.  There is an outdoor section, an indoor section and an upstairs section.  I love the blurry photographs all around the restaurant but I do not like the almost racist Asian caricature painting on the wall.  They might as well put up a picture of a Japanese guy eating sushi in an internment camp.

DESSERTS - BAD
-Black Sesame Ice Cream
-Tempura Red Bean Ice Cream
-Green Tea Creme Brulee
Do not order any of this.  The black sesame ice cream was probably the best of the three but didn't have enough black sesame flavor.  They probably lighten it up so that it's more likeable among the masses.  The tempura ice cream (red bean) was boring.  The tempura was not crisp and hard to break apart.  I've had better red bean ice cream.  The worst dish was the creme brulee.  I am not a fusion-food-hater but I do believe that people need to still adhere to certain basics of dishes while attempting to morph them.  You can try to break through the torched layer but you will most likely be unsuccessful since it's very bendy and chewy (made from brown sugar).  Once you do get through, the cream was curdling and resembled spinach dip.  Overall, it just didn't taste right.
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text: First time in had all you can eat with a friend. Service was fast except for when we waited for the check. Pretty lacklustre nothing very special on the menu most of the rolls came out kind of wet so they fell apart when I picked him up everything is covered in black sesame like another review stated. The fish was good quality but I don't think I would go out of my way to get on this part of town again.
name: Ohana Sushi
categories: Japanese, Food, Poke, Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text:
First, know this: macarons are not macaroons. Look up the difference if you are intrigued.

I discovered Audabon macarons a long time ago at a coffee shop near South street where I had the salted caramel and was floored by how good it was. Fast forward a year or so and I happen to walk by a new, nice looking bakery after lunch in Chinatown so I stopped in out of curiosity. Lo and behold the same macarons from that coffee shop were now being sold in their own store and I was super excited to try them out. I can't remember all the flavors but they're amazing. My friend and I got all 6 that they had and tried them all. I think they were something like thai tea, key lime pie, miso caramel, bananas foster, black sesame, and raspberry something. AMAZING I TELL YOU. Like heaven. In Chinatown.
name: Audabon Bakeshop
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Caterers, Event Planning & Services

text: Was on a business trip to Santa Barbara and had dinner here.  Great place, amazing food and terrific service.  Price to be expected for sushi but the sushi was among the best I have ever eaten.  The lobster tempura rolls were crazy delicious.  Not sure if the black sesame ice cream was made by them but it was very good.  Thanks, Arigato, for treating us so well!
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
Restaurant as part of (or connected) to the Best Western Hotel in Santa Barbara on Bath Street (which I hear is very nice, by the way).  You won't have any trouble finding parking here, so no hubbub or chaotic mess from State Street.  It's a cute place that features an enclosed patio setting.

It has a little of everything on the breakfast, lunch, and dinner menus.  But the uniqueness comes from the owner that brings a Polynesian/Hawaiian influence.  Want some Kahlua Pork?  Come here.  Want some Spam & Eggs?  Come here.  Want some Bacon Fried Rice?  Yep, come here.

PACIFIC RIM BACON FRIED RICE
============================
Made with mixed veggies, brown rice, avocado, green onion, black sesame seeds and a sunny side up egg for $10 -- this sounded really good.  Nice presentation for a very large portion, I ate half and took home the rest.  Execution?  Well, carrots, peas, and green beans from a bag out of the freezer took away from the healthy side of town, but the bacon was tasty.  (4.0 stars)

FINCHES
========
A very large bird aviary with about 100 Finches is directly connected to the restaurant.  So very cute, and not served on the menu.

OVERALL
========
The service is cordial, friendly, polite, and very accommodating.  It's a no-brainer if you are staying at the hotel to grab a convenient meal or two during your stay, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
name: Live Oak Cafe
categories: Farmers Market, Food, Fast Food, American (New), Bars, Wine Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Cafes, Restaurants, Nightlife

text:
The first thing we noticed about Arigato was the extensive menu and unique combinations of sashimi and sauces. Finding good sushi in Santa Barbara (that aren't just rolls or a limited sashimi menu) was a bit challenging, so we were happy to find Arigato.

Located in the heart of downtown SB, Arigato has nice ambiance with a relatively large wraparound sushi bar with 5 sushi chefs. We immediately ordered seared toro and made ourselves comfortable. The toro was a nice cut, although the sauce used overpowered the toro flavor. Next, we ordered hamachi with a black sesame sauce and were impressed by the creativity (we've only seen black sesame in ice cream, not on sushi!) and it was very flavorful. Excited to see Scottish salmon in the menu because it often has a salmon belly-like texture, and it didn't disappoint here either. 

We ordered a salmon skin and grilled lobstertail hand-roll next (yum!) and our sushi chef Demetrio made these beautifully. The salmon skin was more meaty than crispy, but had yummy, juicy flavor. The lobstertail handroll was really unique - with salmon roe, yellow tobiko, black sesame and enoki mushrooms (see pic for the beauty!) We tried the shrimp and halibut gyoza (have never seen these), ameobi shrimp and a soft shell crab handroll too. The gyozas were awesome - great flavor, juicy and a soft texture served with a classic ponzu. The fried shrimp heads were so good that we knew the soft shell crab would be prepared well too. The crab was creamy, salty and delicious.

For dessert, we ordered two more salmon skin handrolls (with sweet unagi sauce) and observant Demetrio made them without the veggies because he noticed we picked them out the first time (they're kind of filler to us!) 

A great choice in Santa Barbara for ambiance, good service (the staff seem to genuinely like each other which adds to the cheery atmosphere), and fun sushi options. It's hard to give this place 5 stars when you've had sushi in LA and the Bay area, but a good option if you're in the area.
name: Arigato Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
First try this hot dessert place with many different items...the guy was friendly but food was very disappointed to us. Unfortunately, store name sounds like a nice dessert place in HK to me..
We ordered togo with two red bean dessert..it's just translucent sugar water filled with half tub of red bean shells and no beans inside. Tofu fai was fresh from a hot stainless pot..ok but not smooth...Black sesame dessert was also watery too..it's a little better than the red bean dessert. Two orders of sticky rice rolls..its filling like nothing but a small strip of fried donut n a little pork sung rolled with lot of rice..two veggies/pork steam buns..each with small reddish meat filling and a large bun..just wonder how ppl rated 4 or 5 stars..unless some improvements, we will not go back again:(
name: Heung Fa Chun Sweet House
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Food, Desserts

text: Wow! We called for take-out last week and ordered a classic pizza. It was enjoyed by everyone (even picky teen)! This is now a favorite!!! But the bread with black sesame seeds and salt was amazing! We were transported to the streets of Jerusalem where they sell delicious bread like this on the street. You'll thank me for this!!! Headed back there tomorrow :)
name: La Pizzeria Metro
categories: Restaurants, Pizza

text:
After my boyfriend and I bowled at Getaway Entertainment Centre, we decided to visit this place. We arrived around 1 PM and this place was full. 

As usual we ordered 1 stew and 1 appetizer to share. We don't eat too much rice so 1 bowl of rice enough for us.

This time, we ordered spicy seafood,  beef brisket  and soft tofu soup (suk-uh sundubu) and haemul pajeon (seafood green onion pancake).

Soups from this Korean joint are always good  but I'm not a big fan of their toppoki (spicy rice cakes) as the sauce was too sweet to my liking so I usually go for the soups.

Gopchang Sundubu - Spicy stew with intestines, soft tofu and veggies.
Jangtuh Gukbap - Spicy beef bones stew
Seolleong-Tang - Beef bones soup with beef brisket and noodles

When you order soup or stew that is white which they usually are named tang or gukbap, make sure you request for condiments. The condiments will include chopped green chilies (no worry it's not spicy), gochujang (red chili paste), crushed black sesame seeds and salted shrimp. This salted shrimp is really good for the soup.

If you go here during lunch or dinner hour make sure you make a reservation so you don't need to wait.
name: Dookbaeki Hot Stone
categories: Restaurants, Korean

text:
Yummy Yummy Yume! Proximity to my office and delicious food, have me frequenting Yume often. I prefer to sit at the sushi bar and interact with their talented sushi chefs. Shout out to Chef Felix, my favorite, who takes the time to get to know his regulars and their palettes. He makes perfect recommendations based on my tastes and is up for creating custom rolls if guests are in the mood for something that is not on the menu. 

Since my original reviews, here are a few other menu items that I highly recommend:

Chili Poppers: Made to order Tempura Battered Jalapeños stuffed with Crab, Spicy Tuna and Cream Cheese, flash fried and finished with a Masago garnish and Cilantro Wasabi Crema. So good! Pro tip: Ask for a side of Eel Sauce for dipping. Sweet & Spicy is the perfect combo. 

Mike Dancing Pants Roll: Spicy crab meat, avocado, asparagus & shrimp topped with seared sea scallop & special house sauce (I recommend substituting the shrimp for tempura shrimp to add a little texture and crunch to the roll).

Popcorn Shrimp: deep fried shrimp tossed with spicy mayo sauce and garnished with black sesame seeds and green onion. Phenomenal!

Chips on Fire: tempura shiso leaf, topped with spicy tuna, green onion, masago, cilantro & wasabi sauce

Fish Mint Chip w/ Yellow Tail: tempura minced yellow tail & shiso leaf, served with ponzu sesame dressing, green onion & masago
name: Yume Sushi Japanese Restaurant
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Food, Desserts, Japanese

text:
So I was at a retreat and wanted a walk and lunch. A few blocks away was a Cafe - Live Oak. - Looked like a good choice, so I hoofed it over to Live Oak Cafe and am I glad I did. Even though my lunch was very simple, a hamburger (their Live Oak Burger) and a simple salad (cucumber and carrot and black sesame seeds), everything was flavorful, tasty, well presented, and just plain yummy. 
The facility is ultra clean. The floors simply shine, and everything is all so clean and inviting. 
The service was prompt, and delightful.
This is a wonderful place for lunch, and I now have it on my 'lets go back' list.
name: Live Oak Cafe
categories: Farmers Market, Food, Fast Food, American (New), Bars, Wine Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Cafes, Restaurants, Nightlife

text:
Thuy Café is an adorable little coffee and bubble tea shop that mixes up some sweet concoctions.  The interior is a shade of light jade with bamboo floors and futuristic lounge furniture, and Vietnamese music videos or live concerts on the flat screen television.  
They have two sizes of bubble tea Small (around $3.50) and Large ($4.50).  The owner is usually there to take your orders and is very nice and helpful if there are any questions.  Most of the bubble teas are blended (like a milkshake) and have a milk tea base.   However, unlike some other places that have bubble tea there are actual ingredients included aside from the mix.  For example: my Sesame Tea had ground black sesame seeds mixed in and my Avocado Smoothie had real Florida Avocado blended in with vanilla.  Delicious!  The teas here are referred to as "neutral," which means not too sweet, just right.  
They also make fresh squeezed Sugarcane Juice from canes that are in the glass case refrigerator by the counter.  
Their snacks are excellent and I recommend the Grilled Pork Bahn Mi ($3.50), crisp French bread filled with grilled marinated pork, picked radish and carrot, fresh cilantro, and garlic mayo wrapped up tight in wax paper with a green Thai chili pepper on the side.
This is the best place for bubble tea and Vietnamese snacks in St. Petersburg that I have found so far.  I think the only other place that has bubble tea is in Tyrone Mall, and it was pretty weak (tried it twice out of convenience).
name: Thuy Cafe
categories: Bubble Tea, Vietnamese, Restaurants, Food, Sandwiches

text:
I think I might have just found out how I'm going to carbo load for the Philly marathon. These might actually be the best bagels I've ever had in Philly. (I know. It's a strong assertion.)  I actually didn't get to go to the store itself, but my coworker brought a bunch in for a taste test. We got to try the Porcini, the Moroccan Spiced Apricot, the Black Sesame, and the Poppy. Seriously, these bagels are exactly what I look for - super soft and fluffy in the middle, with a nice tough exterior. (Fat kid alert.) The Moroccan Spiced Apricot was probably my favorite because it was so unique - sweet, but not too sweet (And I'm one of those people who hates sweet things mixed in with savory. So you know this was good!). I was honestly a little disappointed in the Porcini. I didn't get much of a Porcini flavor from it and we all thought it tasted more like Pumpernickel. I only got to try the plain cream cheese, but I can't wait to go back and try some of the flavored ones. (Kimchee cream cheese and Lemon Goat Cheese Spread? Yes please!) 

 So, in short, go to Knead. Now! Unless it's after 2 pm. Then go tomorrow.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Philly has overpriced Montreal-style bagels, chain bagel stores that always leave you wanting more cream cheese, and plenty of places that recommend toasting the bagel to ensure the best taste. I've been waiting for someone to bring good bagels to Center City and Knead Bagels leaves me waiting no longer. 

I came here on a Saturday morning around 10:30 and was surprised it wasn't a mob scene. I love that they offer both traditional and non-traditional bagels and cream cheese flavors. I tried the black sesame bagel with kimchee cream cheese and Dining Partner had an everything bagel with lox, onion, cucumber and plain cream cheese. The bagels were incredibly soft and fresh. After we devoured our bagels, we also both split another everything bagel with plain cream cheese. The bagels were a good size and they didn't even come close to skimping on the cream cheese. I ended up buying a half dozen to take home and they even included a freezer bag. Fast friendly service at the counter, reasonably priced, and now officially my go-to bagel spot in Philadelphia.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
I have a close place to my heart all foods Asian; be it Cantonese, Japanese fish, Thai, Malaysian and one of my favorites Korean.

What is there not to love about KOREAN food? When done well it tends to have all the perfect elements of the perfect meal.

Take KTown BBQ for instance, as soon as you walk into the door you know you are in for a treat. Your nostrils instantly pick up the aroma of grilled short ribs that have been marinating in special spices for over 24 hours.

Not trying to b racist or one of those other types but you know this the real deal with so many Korean families having lunch here. It is what it is. Its not Americanized and I luv that.

KTown is sort of a mini chain, Sammy Chon has become a pillar of the Korean Community in Philly and he has been able to spread his love across the Delaware into NJ.

He happens to be the creator of the famed Koagie (listed as one of the best sandwiches in America) http://www.endlesssimmer.com/2011/02/28/americas-best-new-sandwiches-part-2/

The take the hoagie tradition of Philly and stuff a bit of Korea into it, literally. Think bulgogi, sesame slaw. Amazing.

I was contemplating having one of those today (9-4-13) But after reviewing the menu and locking my eyes on LA Kalbi I knew instantly what I needed to order.

Shortly after I placed my order a complimentary set of ban-chan was brought to my table. For those that are wondering what that is, its basically small side dishes that complement the main course. Usually anywhere between 6 to 8 small dishes of various flavors that run the gamut from pickled to spicy to sweet all intended to compliment the flavors of the main course.

The LA Kalbi came out shortly after. And boy was it amazing. Some of the best I've had around.

Extremely tender and full of flavor which ranged from garlic, sesame, ginger, scallion and soy. Simply amazing esp the areas that had a bit of char close to the bone. Bliss!!!

The bento lunch also cam with a side of rice topped with black sesame. A sesame salad with various greens. Vermacelli noodles with beef and a side of radish.

Overall the meal was totally amazing and very generous. K cant wait to return. Please see pictures.
name: Dolsot House
categories: Tea Rooms, Korean, Asian Fusion, Chicken Wings, Food, Restaurants, Specialty Food

text:
Apparently, this restaurant has been opened as early as 2011, but it's a wonder how this gem stayed hidden! I had recently heard of this place and my friends were saying that it was hands-down the best ramen in town. Now don't be fooled...it is NOT a ramen restaurant. Disappointing...as they only serve ramen on Saturday mornings (11:30am to 2:00pm), but if you like ramen, you have got to give this place a try!

The portion is a little small compared to other ramen places in the Greater Edmonton Area and the price tag is the same at around $12. Taste-wise, it is the most flavourful broth currently available here. When you order, there are add-ons and I highly recommend adding the egg to your order. Those who don't like their eggs runny should skip this option. For those that love their meat, be warned that a bowl only comes with 1 slice of cha shu (pork), so adding meat may be something you would want to consider.

The noodles are cooked well and are slightly chewy, which is how I love it. One disappointing fact is that the noodles are not handmade by the restaurant. Traditional ramen is supposed to be handmade and paired with a rich pork broth. A plus is that this Japanese restaurant is actually owned by Japanese person, complete with a fluent, English-speaking Japanese waiter. While that doesn't guarantee authenticity or quality, Japanese foodies would know that is a rare occurrence now as most Japanese restaurants are Chinese owned/run.

Oh, I almost forgot to mention the delicious dessert. While most Japanese restaurants serve ice cream mochi, these were the best I have ever had! The rice dough outside layer was very thin and evenly distributed. They allow you to order any mix of flavours within an order. At $5 for 3 mochi, we ordered two orders (two of each flavour - chocolate, black sesame, and green tea). We were still contemplating how to split 6 mochi among 4 people as the order arrived. They had cut them into 12 perfect halves, ready for sharing. Talk about service! The ice cream was creamy smooth inside and were not at all runny from being cut open before serving. Also, the shape of them looks like they had been popped out of a mini muffin tray, which leads me to wonder if they had made it themselves.

All in all, I will definitely be paying Yuzen another visit sometime soon - both for their ramen and to try out the rest of their menu.
name: Yuzen Japanese Restaurant
categories: Ramen, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
I woke up yesterday and decided I needed some bagels.  This place was the closest.  It is definitely not for traditionalists.  The bagels are quite good though, as are the egg sandwiches etc.  One issue that almost lost them a star:  poppyseed bagels and not sesame bagels!!  I ordered my egg sandwich on a sesame bagel, and it came on a poppyseed bagel.  Ok, I thought, maybe I made a mistake or was misheard.  But then I opened the bagel bag this morning (I had ordered half-dozen), and in place of the two sesame bagels I ordered were two poppy.  I hate poppyseed bagels, so i know it wasn't me.  Have to edit this - my wife pointed out that they were black sesame seeds on the bagel.  This doesn't make things better - to me, a sesame bagel is a sesame bagel - no need to fix what works!
I'm editing this to give it five stars - I subtracted one because of the sesame seed issue.  The owner contacted me, was very nice and offered to give me free replacement bagels the next time I come in.  That is great customer relations.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Went here with the family including my sister and her boyfriend both whom are Bay Area foodies with solid palates. We ordered 9 dishes and all split them. 

The japchae was incredible! I mean incredible, the noodles were perfectly boiled and not too soft and soggy. There was a perfect blend of mixing a, finished well with black sesame seeds which made it taste great! 

The Korean fried chicken is awesome, the chicken is fresh, perfectly fried, the spices of the sauce we're great! The chicken managed to remain nice and crispy even at the end of our meal which is pretty rare usually it's soggy within 5 minutes so these guys got it down! Easily earns high marks for this dish alone. 

The bulgolgi was amazing! All agreed much better than Bay Area Korean restaurants... something about it you can tell it's fresh, it's well marinated, and man oh man is it tasty. Little to no fat or tendon, seriously try it! 

Kimchi Spam fried rice I felt was good,  but didn't blow me out of the water.

The tofu soup... we ordered two kinds. Definitely best in town. My sister thought better than most Korean restaurants in the bay. My wife agreed as well. 

The decor inside is very nice and trendy, the bathroom they did a great job at remodeling, fresh smelling with nice new subway tiles on the wall. 

For sure the best Korean restaurant in reno, for sure! I would say better than most if not all sacramento restaurants. Rivals several of the so callled best Korean restaurants in the Bay Area for the dishes I mentioned above. Again I think the comments from my sister and her boyfriend say a lot they eat out a lot in the Bay and live inside San Francisco.
name: Tofu House
categories: Korean, Restaurants

text: They have a large selection of flavors for macarons. It was my first time here today and I wanted to try half the flavors they offer. I ask for the recommendation of the staff but he was very blunt telling me that different people have different taste and that is true. He did recommend me the black sesame and peanut dark chocolate after asking me what types of food I like to eat. I got mostly dark chocolate related macarons because I'm a huge fan of chocolate. The black sesame macaron was the macaron that I saw on Yelp that made me decide to make a visit and I am glad I did. I recommend the black sesame for people to try and as well as lemon. Normally when I get lemon macarons it is either really sour or contains poppy seed, but the lemon macaron here is very refreshing
name: ICI Macarons & Cafe
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Coffee & Tea, Specialty Food, Macarons

text: Why have I only found out about this place now? Seriously the best bagel shop in the area. Ordered the sausage, egg and cheese with everything bagel and it is absolutely the best. It has an aioli spread that makes it so much better. One thing I like about this place is the different type of flavors they have here. Next time I visit, I want to try the kimchi cream cheese with black sesame bagel. Something unordinary but can totally rock your socks off.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Occupying the eastern portion of the former Seki Sui at Grand & Arsenal, Guerilla Street Food is a casual eatery with well crafted meat dishes.  While the space isn't particularly colorful, the flavors are.  I had the Flying Pig sans sriracha.  Slow roasted pork, calamansi, hoisin, fried garlic, toasted black sesame seeds, scallions, with a one hour egg on top.  I opted to have mine served over jasmine rice.  It can also be served as a burrito.  I really liked the way the flavors blended, reminded me of Korean barbecue.  There are three sauces on the tables; modified (kamayan?) soy sauce, fish sauce, and garlic sauce with a pepper in it.  I liked some of the modified soy sauce on the rice.
Also tried the Ube Fries on the side, purple sweet potato fries served with spicy banana ketchup.  I wasn't a big fan of these, the cut was really inconsistent on the fries so some were more cooked than others.
The woman at the counter was helpful in navigating the menu for spicy versus sweet or savory.  Overall I'm impressed with the quality of the main dish and look forward to trying other dishes on their menu.   
FYI, free soda with Yelp check in.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Food Trucks, Food, Filipino, Restaurants, Food Stands, Local Flavor, Asian Fusion

text:
The dining room is lovely and modern, mildly lit with fairy light-esque fixtures and soft hanging lights. The kitchen is open to the diner's view, separated off by a glass wall. An open kitchen concept is a nice touch for any restaurant and it's a fairly bold move, considering how the kitchen back line can be a place for heated discussions between servers, chefs, and expos. Earls managed this well, however, and it was nice to see both the servers and the chefs on display, since customers rarely get a glimpse of the back-of-house.

We ordered the Prawn Dynamite Rolls to start: maki made from panko breaded prawns, mango, avocado, cucumber, togarashi mayonnaise, maple soy reduction and sriracha mayonnaise, and toasted black sesame seeds. Earls is known for its Prawn Dynamite Rolls - apparently one of the best-selling appetizers on the menu - and it's easy to see why. They're delicious. The sauce reminds me of Mikado's Dragon Sauce (served with the Dragon Eye Rolls), and Earls' sushi fillings are fresh and tasty (the mango is a nice touch). They're perfect to share, as well, giving you a flavourful mouthful without being too filling.

Our entrées included the Cajun Blackened Chicken and the Peppercorn 9oz Certified Angus Beef Top Sirloin. The Cajun Blackened Chicken included a chicken breast cooked in blackening spices and garlic butter, and served with warm potato salad and coleslaw. The chicken, while slightly on the too-salty side, was moist and flavourful, and really exuded that smoky Cajun flavour. The potato salad was one of the best I've ever tasted - warm and rich - and the coleslaw was extremely tasty, even though the mayonnaise was a bit on the heavy side.

The Peppercorn Sirloin was cooked to an impeccable medium rare and was cooked with spicy peppercorns, fresh herbs, and demi-glace, and served with Yukon Gold garlic mashed potatoes and asparagus (the seasonal vegetable). While the peppercorn demi-glace was a bit too thick for my liking (resembling more of a North American-style gravy than a rich, French brown sauce), it complemented the steak nicely and went extremely well with the garlic mashed potatoes. I always love a bit of asparagus, and prefer them on the side of a nice steak, so the vegetables were an excellent pairing choice.

Top off an excellent meal with a couple of delicious gin caesars (served with a dill pickle and a beef jerky stick), and you've got yourself a very favourable dining experience.

One minor negative about our visit was that the service began quite slow, but picked up as soon as we'd received our appetizer. I think the main reason behind that was because two servers weren't sure if we were their table, which explains why our drink order was taken by a different girl than our food order and the rest of the service. This wasn't a problem, though - once the ball got rolling, the service was excellent and attentive for the rest of our meal.

Earls has definitely upped its game in the last several years and deserves to be recognized as in the same category as restaurants such as Joey's and Moxie's. Prices range from $15-25 per person, which is standard for a mid-range casual fine dining restaurant. If you're like me and boycotted Earls back in the early 2000s, I'd recommend giving it a retry - you might just be impressed.
name: Earls Kitchen + Bar
categories: American (New), Comfort Food, Cocktail Bars, Canadian (New), Asian Fusion, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants, Burgers, Sandwiches

text:
I didn't know about this place and just randomly was walking around looking for dinner.  Well turns out I stumbled upon a GEM!  Delicious, delicious, delicious!

It is BYOB but nevertheless I would recommend the 3 tartare in the cold appetizer menu.  Unbelievable!  Another recommendation is their waffle, whipped cream, chocolate with ice cream (recommend the black sesame flavor).... OMG this might be one of the best things I have ever had.  I went to bed dreaming about this dessert!!!
name: Doma
categories: Restaurants, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: I am a fan of simple, fresh sushi.  Not too crazy about rolls with heavy sauces, multiple ingredients and fanciful names.  Horinoya delivers.  I always start with the seafood salad, it's huge and I could probably just make that dinner if I were eating there on my own.  How are their avocados always the perfect degree of ripeness?  This week it included fresh crawfish tails and they were succulent and sweet and a very welcome addition to their standard.  The vegetable roll (I was so enamored with the pickled vegetables in the Tuna 911 roll at Kanno) was okay but I wouldn't order it again, kinda bland.  Everything else was fresh and wonderful.  I like to end with the black sesame ice cream, which makes me swoon, as does the little crumbly cookie they perch on top that my BF generously lets me eat every time.  As a sidebar, I saw some black sesame ice cream bars at Hong Kong Market and I got really excited but they were no good at all.  I can only get my fix at Horinoya.
name: Horinoya
categories: Restaurants, Japanese

text: Delicious Japanese flavors! Azuki bean, green tea, ginger, black sesame... So amazing! Thank you for bringing culture and new flavors to Reno! Suggestion: the crepe leaks thru the paper, would be nice if paper was reinforced with something like wax paper or foil? to prevent leaking.
name: Crepe N' Roll
categories: Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Food, Creperies, Restaurants

text: Amazing house made sausage egg and cheese on black sesame bagel with aoli spread. I would give a 5 star and visit at least once a week if it wasn't 7 and change for the sandwich. Maybe throw in a small coffee for that price point? Awesome place and staff overall!
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
So excited Clementine's came to my neighborhood! I have been to their Lafayette Square location as well. Same great quality came with them to this locale.

Fun flavors, cute interior, delicious cones. I would give five stars, but they were out of five flavors! All the ones I wanted. I was disappointed. Luckily, they have no shortage of goodness, and I ended up loving both the vanilla and black sesame. Highly recommend both, but hope next time I go they are better stocked.
name: Clementine's Naughty and Nice Creamery
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text: Went to Zama last night with my family for restaurant week, and it was one of the best restaurant week meals that I've had. I had the house salad, vegetable tempura, maki combo (spicy tuna, yellowtail, and salmon rolls), and for dessert the black sesame mochi and pumpkin bread pudding. Everything was excellent and went above my expectations, and the presentation was beautiful. Additionally, our waiter was great and our food came out at a normal pace (unlike other reviewers have mentioned). I was very pleased and will definitely be back!
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Knead Bagels is my favorite breakfast spot in the area. The bagels are better than any I've ever had, soft, flavorful, and unique. The cream cheese flavors are just a good and if you're vegan, they even have hummus for you! So far I've tried the black sesame bagel with scallion cream cheese and bacon, egg, & cheese on a togarashi. ALL DELICIOUS. 

I plan on coming back for a morning special with some coffee as often as my budget will allow. :)
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: I've only been living and working in Philly for about a month and am already addicted to Knead!!  My coworkers introduced me and I am hooked!!  So far I've tried the lavender with vanilla honey and the black sesame with poblano.  Both are tasty!  The lavender with vanilla honey is not too sweet, just the way I like.  I've also had the chicken salad sandwich, which was good.  Also, the salad is a must have!!  I was so sad today when my coworker reminded me that Knead is closed on Mondays--can't wait to get my fix!!
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: These bagel are so good and worth it! Everytime we went, they were sold out! We got the black sesame bagels with lime and pabalano cream cheese and the togarashi with scallion and lime cream cheese. This our new favorite bagel place.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Zama served one of the best meals I have eaten in a long time. I went with family for a birthday dinner so I wasn't paying, and I'd highly recommend dining on someone else's tab at this restaurant.

I tried: kaiso salad with octopus, house tofu (which is cooked tableside), wasabi truffle escargot, wasabi lobster and wasabi tuna sushi rolls, and the special which was soft shell crab. The appetizers were good but not incredible. The soft shell crab was out of this world delicious. The sushi rolls were good, but they had so much going on in them that you couldn't really appreciate the different ingredients. I don't know if they were worth the $19-$24 a roll. I'd say stick with the simpler rolls and just enjoy the incredible quality of fish. 

Then, the desserts. SAVE ROOM FOR DESSERT. It is rare for a place like this to have dessert that stacks up to the caliber of its dinner, but wow desserts were probably the best part of this meal. The desserts are all small and come three to an order for $12 so you can sample a few. This was a rare occasion where instead of splitting one or two desserts for the table everyone got their own and it was well worth it. My boyfriend and I shared so I was able to try six desserts and in order from good to greatest they were matcha green tea strawberry cake, bitter chocolate mousse with sea salt, tofu beignets, fluffernutter dumplings, black sesame cheesecake, and yuzu creme brulee. We were all full from dinner but the desserts were so good that we finished them off entirely. 

We also shared two bottles of wine, and the total for 5 people (more than enough food but no leftovers) was close to $500. It is definitely a place fit for a celebration. If you're looking for excellent Japanese food and are willing to pay for not just the excellent cuisine but very good service and ambience, I'd check Zama out. And if someone is offering to take you out for your birthday, it's an even better idea.
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Harmony Bakery is my #1 obsession of the moment for the fresh strawberry smoothie with yogurt bubbles in them. With the thick straw, I sucked up the first white bubble and bit into it. A tangy burst of thin yogurt coated my tongue, elevating this smoothie to something more than just a bakery beverage- it is entertainment, it is molecular gastronomy, it intrigues you until it is finish, and then it haunts you as you crave it.  Put this in a glass bowl over a black sesame brownie, call it Sunken Treasure Pearls, charge $14 and serve at Morimoto. Plus they use fresh fruit. 

Just make sure you get what you ask for, sometimes they get confused and don't add the bubbles. 

Skip the baked goods here and get the  $2  giant pile of rice noodle roll. It is plain, as it should be, so load on as much soy or hot sauce as you like.The shrimp filling was not the large juicy pieces you might find at dim sum, but it was still satisfying. And its a nice, non greasy option. Unlike the crispy salt pepper chicken wings. These guys are are crispy and aromatic with a lot of chicken on each wing.
name: Harmony Bakery
categories: Religious Organizations, Bakeries, Food

text:
To celebrate another personal orbit around the sun, my friends recently took me to Tofu House to check out Reno's newest Korean restaurant. To start, we ordered beer and soju to create a cocktail known as somaek, a popular combination in South Korea ($7, 633ml beer, $13, 360ml soju). The 18% ABV spirit is lightly sweet, and the end result is something like a weak boilermaker. Now properly warmed up, we moved on to appetizers.

Crispy pork and veggie pot stickers ($6.95, 8 pieces) were served with a pair of sauces and gone in seconds. A plate-sized scallion and seafood pancake ($14.95) had a crispy, almost hashbrown-like texture, full of long-cut green onion, white fish, octopus, shrimp, and other goodies. Packed with flavor, no sauce necessary.

Ddeokbokki ($12.95) is stir-fried Korean rice cake--something like a fat, spongey pasta--mixed with sweet fish cake, boiled egg, ramen noodle, onion, and cabbage swimming in a pool of sweet chili sauce. It's tasty, but huge. Definitely enough to share with friends. Speaking of huge, Korean fried chicken ($19.95) involves chopping, battering, and deep-frying an entire three pound bird to be served either plain, sweet and spicy, or half and half. It was good plain, but really something with the sauce.

Korean entrees are served with banchan, a series of small dishes intended to enhance the experience. Our lineup included kimchi, spicy daikon radish, sweet fish cake, pickled bean sprout, and a potato salad that was basically chunky mashed potatoes. All were fine, with the kimchi a standout. I do love me some good spicy, fermented cabbage.

A pair of diners ordered hot stone pot rice bowls, one beef bulgogi ($13.95) and the other beef bibimbap ($12.95). The former included marinated beef with mushroom, scallion, onion, carrot, cabbage, and pepper paste; it was quite good. The bibimbap was pretty much the same thing, but with a black sesame seeded fried egg on top, and considerably less beef. We asked why that bowl had just a couple pieces of meat and were told, "that's how it's served." I've been served bibimbap at other places with much more meat, so this was a little surprising. Without the meat the bowl was a bit bland and disappointing.

Japchae was next ($11.95), a plate of stir-fried Korean glass noodles with marinated beef, zucchini, mushroom, carrot, and bean sprout. When I've had this as part of banchan it's been very simple, lightly sweet with a lot of herb and fragrant spice. Adding those other ingredients made it something I'd order for lunch every week.

My friend's plate of spicy stir-fried squid ($18.95) included mushroom, scallion, onion, zucchini, and jalapeno, with noodles on the side. The thin strips of mollusc were just about as tender as I've tasted, and the combination of flavors made me wonder if I'd ordered the wrong entree. But I had eyes only for the sundubu soup.

Sundubu is silky soft tofu, and of the soups I chose "assorted" ($13.95), which mixed beef, seafood, mushroom, zucchini, and soft tofu, with a fresh raw egg on the side. The soup is served bubbling in a hot stone bowl, so you crack the egg over it and slowly stir as it cooks into the soup. Combined with the velvety tofu, the result is rich, creamy, and delicious. There is lot to like about Tofu House, but that soup is the reason I'll return.
name: Tofu House
categories: Korean, Restaurants

text:
Delicious Fishes!
Horinoya is one of the best places in town for sushi. It by far the best place to have a dinner party if you reserve one of the private rooms (in these rooms you sit on the floor, but get this, there is a hole for your legs, so you don't get all crunched up while stuffing your face with deliciousness). 

I highly recommend the Hijiki salad, the tuna tataki & the black sesame ice cream, although I haven't been disappointed with anything I've ordered. I have been here several times as part of a group and also as a part of a pair. In either instance the service has been very attentive and hospitable. 

The restaurant itself is small and clean. Street parking.
name: Horinoya
categories: Restaurants, Japanese

text: Love having the co-op in the neighborhood, beautiful building, good hours, and great staff. Though I am not a member, I shop here regularly (weekly, sometimes more than that). I can get some items cheaper elsewhere, but I like shopping locally and for the convenience. Here are the pluses of this store: bulk items, fresh baked breads, they carry Philly Muffins, seltzer goes on sale all the time!, Talenti gelato on sale a lot too!, and good quality produce and fruits. And they carry non-grocery items like greeting cards, candy, beauty products, candles, gifts, etc. Some of my favorite items that I exclusively get at Mariposa are: Raspberry Leaf Tea (loose leaf tea), green olives, granola mix, bulk olive oil, Fermented Foods sauerkraut, black sesame seed crackers, and the Guatemala coffee.
name: Mariposa Food Co-op
categories: Health Markets, Grocery, Specialty Food, Vegetarian, Restaurants, Food, Vegan

text: There aren't a ton of bagel shops in Philadelphia and I was excited to find this shop on my way to work. They aren't open Mondays which was weird to me since I feel more prone to buy breakfast on Mondays to make the best out of the beginning of the work week. They have different flavors of bagels that you wouldn't find in other shops, the only "traditional" flavors were plain and poppy seed. They serve drinks but nothing special - coffee, tea, iced tea, orange juice. I got the black sesame seed bacon egg and cheese sandwich. They put an aioli on the sandwich which is interesting...not sure if I like it, the flavor kind of overpowers the sandwich. My biggest issue is the price, it was $7 just for the sandwich. I can walk across the street and get a drink and breakfast sandwich for the same price at Starbucks. I regret getting black sesame seed and I wish it was traditional sesame seed since they already have poppy seed. The seeds get stuck easily in your teeth so bring floss! The sandwich was fine, just not worth the cost and will keep me from going back.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
We literally just left this cafe a minute ago. First off, the ambience is very homey. We got inside and was greeted right away who I believe may be the owner. They had a range of flavors and was $2 per macaron which is a reasonable price. Picked out 8 for to go and 4 to snack inside. 

I've had my fair share of macarons and ICI's were perfect for my liking. Not too sweet but was filled with so much flavor. My favorite was the Black Sesame. My boyfriend also had the ice coffee which was pretty good. On our way out, I couldn't resist but buy another box of 8 with different flavors from the first. 

Overall, I see myself visiting ICI whenever I'm back in Philly again.
name: ICI Macarons & Cafe
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Coffee & Tea, Specialty Food, Macarons

text:
It is tempting for me to give a scathing review and few stars to Adsum, but I will preface this review by saying that I ate at Adsum as part of a large group event with a set meal (you can't please everybody).

That said, even with the limited (and Kosher-style) menu choices, Adsum really needs to ADD SOME (Some food, maybe?) to their restaurant.

I will also qualify my review by saying that the chef is very talented and was so gracious in speaking with our group.  (Why did you give a bunch of pork, clam and sausage (Lamb Merguez) based recipes to a JEWISH group??? Weird.) He really knows his stuff, though.  The service was also good (save for our new - 3 weeks only - server - who made a few bumbles along the way.)

We started with a choice of soup or salad.  I chose the 100% butter (or is it Bibb?) lettuce salad (absolutely no crunch, kinda limp feeling) with delicious asian pears and honey/cayenne candied nuts.  Crumbled of Maytag Bleu cheese on top and a delicious dressing (Sweet) with black sesame seeds. (This is where our server said they were peppercorns.  Sorry, not true.)
The salad - while good in concept was really boring and unsatisfying to eat.   Salade Ennuis.

Now I am hungry.

The entree was sized like a large app.  3 ricotta filled "gnuddi" (Think Gnocchi crossed with ravioli) were delicious sitting atop a zesty lemony-cream.  But the 6 small bites (about 2 per gnocchi) were not enough.  There was also (5 star!) one - just one - fried green tomato presented with an olive oil powder on top.  I got tons of the powder, while my friend next to me had a light dusting.  I think because my tomato had so much powder I could detect a slight "chemical aftertaste" from it.  (The "top note - was great - a dry, green olive oil.)

I would have bet money that somehow liquid nitrogen was involved. I'd have lost money.  They make the Olive oil powder by centrifuging the Olive oil with a malto-dexttin aggregate or something. Maybe that accounts for the chemical aftertaste?

I am getting over the whole "molecular gastronomy" fad very quickly.
I am also not a big lover of sous-vide (so much of it is done poorly), but that is the subject for another review.

The other entree choice was a single (JUST ONE) deep-fried cod fritter.  Not my bag, baby.

Delicious gnuddi - just not enough food.

Now I am STARVING...

So dessert comes, and it is GINORMOUS.  (Nice salad, tiny entree, huge hunk of chocolate cake) and so dense and cold and rich you can barely eat it with a spoon. My friend wanted a knife - as did I.)

So I ate 2 bites of the chocolate cake, and felt my blood sugar spike almost instantly.

Not fun.  I boxed up the rest for my 6 year old to enjoy later.

For $46 per person??  I guess that's fair - if you had eaten an actual entree. (Salad, app, huge dessert.)

I literally had to eat a bowl of strawberries at 11:30 PM when I got home. I hate eating late at night but I was absolutely famished.

I am very, very disappointed with Adsum.
That said - the regular menu (Foie gras poutine?  The SUPER Poutine is like a platter of pure fat in many forms.) doesn't really do it for me either.

Sorry Adsum.

FAIL. The 3 stars is so you won't hate me.  I am so tempted to give only 2.
name: Adsum Restaurant
categories: Restaurants, American (New), French, Breakfast & Brunch, Brasseries

text:
Knead is the bomb. Plenty of vegetarian and some vegan options. Their cream cheese is so good that I've never actually gotten an egg sandwich - just a bagel with cream cheese :)

My favorites are the fennel and sea salt bagel with roasted tomato cream cheese and the black sesame bagel with sweet potato curry cream cheese. They also have some salads and bagel banh mi.

 Plus, the staff is so nice! Just be sure to get there early - they close at 2:00pm.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
This shop has a fun and adventurous variety of bagels and cream cheese spreads, such as black sesame with potato curry or lavender with vanilla honey. They also have a lot of different sandwiches if youre looking for something heavier. 
I went for the first time today and got a togarashi bagel with scallion lime cream cheese..it was so good! It wasn't spicy at all. Usually i scrape off a lot of cream cheese because i always feel it's too much, but today i had every bite! My friend got a coriander bagel with jalapeno cream cheese, which was also really good! Definitely will be going again.
name: Knead Bagels
