categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
so today, not only did i notice the new cone flavors (chocolate chip, rainbow cookie, chocolate, and pretzel) they had caramel bacon gelato... i tried the chai and it was pretty good, but the taste of caramel and the texture of tiny bits of bacon were too good to pass up.. so 5 stars for the caramel bacon on a pretzel cone... sweet n salty... they threw in a small tub of black sesame since it was one of the flavors i suggested.... 

my wife liked the honey almond, but she had the nutella affogato... affogato is just gelato with espresso served in a glass lined with caramel or chocolate topped with whipped cream...

there were about 4 other groups of ppl there.. other customers have also been suggesting their flavors... sounds like this place is doing well... in the near future, lunch options from SUP and extended hours...  

me + no iphone = 3 check ins here
name: Bijous Yogurt & Gelato Kafe
categories: Restaurants, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text: Down right amazing service - very hospitable. The sushi sashimi omakase is superb, and the truffle tuna nachos are the perfect appetizer. The black sesame ice cream is sprinkled with rice krispies that give it a perfect crunch.
name: Doma
categories: Restaurants, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
Very pricy Japanese food. If you are looking for a traditional experience, go somewhere else. If you are looking for a good ambience to take your business guests or a date to, you found it.


So why 3 stars? Well, 2 stars for the quality of fish and taste of rolls. 5 stars for dessert creativity and taste. I was more blown away by the dessert than the sushi. Minus a star for pricing that doesn't match up to expectations of fish quality. 

The sushi was alright. I have had better fish in California, but they do pay attention to details. Presentation was spectacular if that's what you're into. However, it seems more fusion than Japanese. (Hint: Japanese people don't ever use extra virgin olive oil on their rolls.) To give them credit, the special rolls were pretty creative. 

Dessert was amazing! The mochi was housemade and we got the black sesame and salted caramel mochis. Both were fantastic! I was really blown away by the salted caramel mochi! Yuzu creme brûlée was also superb! 

If I were to come back, it would be dessert only please. ;P
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
The food here is pretty good (I'd rate it 4-stars), but the service from the hostess and manager on duty were a bit off-putting when I came in for lunch recently. 

During Restaurant Week, we visited a number of restaurants near our offices during lunch. This was one of them. Restaurants in this area tend to be understandably busy during lunch, but this was the only place where we found absolutely no sense of urgency in taking care of customers. When we came in, a lot of tables were filled, but they were definitely not jam-packed the way other places were. There was no one at the host stand, which was fine for the first 5 minutes, but after that, we were confused as to whether we should just seat ourselves at the bar. It seemed staff working near the entrance were actively avoiding our glance. 

The restaurant is pretty small, so I could clearly see the hostess walking slowly back and forth between the tables. When she saw us, she continued to slowly walk back and forth between tables around the room. The manager, who was standing at the food window closer to the entrance, also saw us, but he stood perfectly still, looked away, and did not tell any member of his staff to go greet us. These folks really take the Zen concept to the next level!!!

Once we finally got seated at the sushi bar, the service was okay (it existed, but was not particularly remarkable). The RW lunch options were pretty decent, except for dessert. We got edamame, udon noodle soup (very tasty!), salads, and bento boxes containing shrimp/veggie tempura and simple selections of maki rolls and sashimi, which tasted very fresh. For dessert, we had a piece of black sesame mochi ice cream and 2 small pieces of rice crispy treat rolled up like sushi, which can either be found in the frozen section of an Asian supermarket or be created cheaply at home. 

I had been here before during HH, and I remember the food being tasty, but underwhelming when factoring in the price. In general, I like the concept, food quality, and atmosphere, but in order to justify the pricing, there has to be more than just good (but tiny) sushi and decent udon noodle soup.
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Delicious! Had a bacon egg and cheese on a plain bagel and it was one of the best bacon egg and cheese iv ever had! They put an aioli on it and it was amazzzzzzzing! Bagel was perfect- crispy soft doughy all at once. I do Wish the bacon was a touch crispier though. Also had black sesame and kimchee cream cheese, which was good but I'd probably skip the kimchee cc next time. Can't talk about wait times as I was there at 630am and no one else was there so it was relatively quick. The woman taking my order left a little to be desired- kind of stared at me like deer in headlights. The coffee she gave me had grounds in it so I just asked for a latte instead- more blank stares. Luckily another woman (manager? Owner?) came over and was extremely friendly and gave me the latte free of charge.

Can't wait to go back!! Maybe you guys should consider local delivery to Pennsylvania hospital ?!?
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
This place is great.  Best bagels and breakfast sandwiches to date. 

Definitely recommend the sausage egg and cheese on any bagel.  And they do have a good variety and healthy(er) bagels.  Note the sesame seed is black sesame.

People are great here as well.  Must try if you even semi-like bagels and eat breakfast.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
I have a meeting in center city this morning, so I figured that I would try this bagel shop/cafe. I am glad that I did. This shop has interesting bagel (black sesame seed- which is an unprocessed sesame seed, fennel seed, and lavender just to name a few) selection and a wide variety of toppings (flavored cream cheeses, many began options, eggs/meats, etc.). 

I went with the traditional choice of an everything bagel with roasted veggie cream cheese. The bagel is delicious, just the right consistency. The bagel was rolled in the sesame and poppy seeds, onion, garlic, etc., so the top and bottom of the bagel both have flavor (yay!). The roasted veggie cream cheese has a savory flavor but doesn't have a strong veggie flavor. The coffee is standard. Morning happy hour (until 8:30) gets you a coffee and bagel with cream cheese for $5 and change. 

The shop has a relaxed cafe ambience, with 4 high tops and 4 regular tables (each seating 2) inside plus a few outside tables. The kitchen and seating area is clean. The staff is pleasant, the service is fast, and the food is fresh. 

This is one of the best bagels that I have gotten outside of NY (and probably the best one that I've had in Philly). If I have another meeting in this area, I will be back to try one of their more eclectic recommended menu items.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: Wandering the countryside for a decent cheese monger in Phila is an adventure. I was spoiled when I lived back in Boston by great cheese and customer service. I digress. We walked in and everything had a place and was in it. Greeted cheerfully and I missed that ripe brie smell I have become so accustomed to from years of being a cheese shop. but the cheese and the knowledge did not disappoint. I gave them what we traditionally gravitate to and he introduced us to some variations on the theme and a few dark horses. PLUS they had my black sesame and soy rice crackers that I love oh so much not to mention other tasty treats. We left with a bag of goodies to make a small meal out of and will be back to test the waters further. Watch for updates to this review.
name: The Grand Fromage
categories: Honey, Meat Shops, Herbs & Spices, Cheese Shops, Specialty Food, Food, Olive Oil

text:
i'm not a vegan, or even vegetarian, but was blown away by this food. so delicious and not at all oily as i sometimes find vegan food to be. and everyone was super friendly. only downside was sitting in hi-ho lounge with some music that i did not like going on, but at least it wasn't loud. they said they will be moving soon, and i hope they find a nice spot. near me!
we had the scallion pancake appetizer which i loved. also had the vegetable dumpling which was good but maybe not quite my favorite.
shared two entrees: glass noodles where phenomenal! the braised tofu was very nice as well, but paled next to the noodles ;-)
for dessert we shared the black sesame sorbet, that was... amazing! and then came the dessert pancake... also amazing!
name: The Wandering Buddha
categories: Korean, Gluten-Free, Vegan, Vegetarian, Restaurants

text:
Great idea for St. Louis County to sponsor Food Truck Thursdays rotating through four of its parks for the summer and autumn.  We hit Faust Park night on September 27, with Soulard Blues Band providing great background music.  As our friends said, does that make us hipsters (in the Chesterhood)?

As we walked around checking out all the food trucks - there were about a dozen - the Flying Pig at Guerrilla Street Food jumped out at me.  I didn't know what all the ingredients were, but I know I like pig, and decided to live dangerously.  Good call.  Juicy slow roasted pork was piled over rice, with a generous covering of sauces (calamansi, hoising, sriracha - according to the menu board), fried garlic, and black sesame.  The sauces added savoriness with a gentle heat, the garlic & sesame pumped up the flavor, and a one hour egg along with the sauces & garlic & black sesame all gave it a real visual appeal and interest.  It was surprisingly filling, and only $7.

For a beverage, I ordered a tamarind soda.  Didn't know what to expect, but I was following the live dangerously credo.  It was pretty tasty.  Smooth, full flavor - kind of like a really mellow but tart tea, almost like thai tea with lemon.  The flavor stayed with you, but didn't change to anything unpleasant.  Give it a try.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Food Trucks, Food, Filipino, Restaurants, Food Stands, Local Flavor, Asian Fusion

text:
If you're in search of stand out and unique bagels and cream cheese, then you KNEAD to check this place out!

The bagels are baked fresh throughout the day, so they don't recommend  toasting the bagels (but will if you ask). 

The togarashi bagel had a hint of spice from the dried chili peppers and paired perfectly with the scallion lime cream cheese. They definitely didn't skimp on the herbs, and I loved the bright citrus note!

The black sesame bagel was a standout with its cherry pepper and prosciutto cream cheese. This is one of the most unique cream cheeses I've ever tasted, perfectly blending both savory and spicy ingredients!

I would order these two bagels again in a heartbeat and wish I lived closer to frequent this bagel shop more often!
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: Absolutely delicious. I ordered the Flying Pig and a fresh Lumpia. The fresh Lumpia was quite good. It has a slightly doughier texture than a fresh Vietnamese spring roll, but similar fillings. It comes with a wonderful peanut sauce. The Flying Pig was fabulous. It had very well balanced flavors and texture: savory braised pork, sweet umami hoisin sauce, spicy Sirracha (or similar) sauce, perfectly poached egg, slightly sticky rice, black sesame seeds, green onions, and a few other little items. Already looking forward to my next visit.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Food Trucks, Food, Filipino, Restaurants, Food Stands, Local Flavor, Asian Fusion

text:
Nestled right along the boat-lined Santa Barbara Harbor, Sushi GoGo delivers great-tasting sushi and prime vistas. This pocket-sized sushi spot (there is only outdoor seating) entices customers with fresh fish and fast and friendly service. I struck up a nice conversation with the sushi chef/owner..which really set the stage for a wonderful meal. 

We ordered a couple of the combo specials, which are well-priced at only $8.95. You can feast on teriyaki chicken, vegetable tempura, green salad, a California roll and a spicy tuna roll for a nominal fee. The tempura, California roll and the spicy tuna roll were all solid. For the low price, I thought the quality might suffer a little, but everything was right on point. The teriyaki sauce was a little lacking but still tasty and fulfilling.  The Philly Roll and the Jessica Roll (shrimp tempura and avocado topped with various fish) were both really good. Fresh crafted fish slices served over warm sushi rice with a light dusting of black sesame seeds made for a winsome combination. As people walked by, they keep admiring my sushi. I think I counted 12 comments on my sushi rolls. 

Nice Waterfront sushi gem on the marina with hard to beat prices. Since there is only outdoor seating, Sushigogo closes at 6:30 pm.
name: Sushi GoGo
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text: I always get the same thing here and it's always right on. The veggie bahn mi is where it's at (on a togarashi bagel, instead of the black sesame bagel). The place is always clean. The staff is super friendly and attentive.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: Amazing - high end, but well worth the splurge! Started with melt-in-your-mouth scallop-risotto appetizer, followed by delicious usuzukari tuna (incredibly thin and beautifully presented), specialty soft shell crab-shrimp and Kennett Square mushroom rolls. Just when we thought it couldn't get any better, we sampled an exquisite, heavenly mini dessert trio - black sesame cheesecake, yuzu creme brulee and fluffernutter dumplings. For a fleeting moment, I thought about licking the plate clean (but didn't). Excellent service by Pete was a bonus for our anniversary dinner!
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Amazing fresh bagels that are perfectly toasted yet soft and full of flavor: that's what Knead delivers. I came on a Saturday morning to pick up a dozen of bagels for a coworkers meeting for $13. I asked for a variety and we got black sesame, everything,  poppy seed, fennel seed & sea salt, flax & togarashi (which is actually spicy...yaass). I picked the garden vegetable cream cheese and the lady recommend the vanilla honey as well for a savory and sweet option. They were about  $6.50 / half pint, not $3.00 which was not written clearly on the blackboard (it threw me off guard when my total was $27).

The service was quick, 5 minutes and I was out. Everyone at the meeting loved the bagels and couldn't stop eating them. The cream cheese qas so delicious that I wish I wasn't so full so that I could continue eating.
Definitely try this place !!
I am going to give the lavender a try next time :)
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
so as a born and bred NY'er i am picky about 2 foods- bagels and pizza...

While the bread factor on Kneads bagels cannot beat NYs bagels, I have to give props to their creative spreads and bagels. 
I walked in there prepared to be wowed, because their choices are different! Sweet potato curry CC, lime bagels, togashri and black sesame... the varieties are intriguing.
the bagels and CCprice is pretty steep, at 3.50- but well worth a try..
Not as big as the NY bagel but the amount of CC they put on the bagel is filling.

Come for a bagel and sit out in the park across the street. They offer seating at Knead as well.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: What's not to like? Food is pretty and delicious. Chocolate croissant very good, not greasy at all, chicken salad sandwich, fresh, with cucumbers, great amount of greens on bread with black sesame seeds, good coffee, lovely assortment of baked goods, can't wait to try them all.
name: Paris Baguette
categories: Food, Bakeries, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea, Patisserie/Cake Shop, Cafes, Desserts

text: This is now one of my favorite sushi places in Philly! The menu is very extensive and has both japanese and korean options. I loved how unique some of the menu items and sushi rolls were! We started with the tuna nachos; these were SO good and I loved the asian fusion twist on nachos. All the rolls were fantastic as well. The tuna club was MASSIVE - very flavorful, extremely filling, and had generous chunks of avocado in it. We also got the chloe and triple spicy double tuna which I thoroughly enjoyed. If you extra room, treat yourself to the taiyaki dessert with black sesame ice cream!
name: Doma
categories: Restaurants, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
I'd been hearing a lot about this place and had been wanting to stop in and try it. 
We both liked the decor of the place. It almost had a steampunk-vibe. We both had appetizers (my fiancee had the cornbread; I had the deviled eggs.) While the eggs were tasty, I nabbed a couple fork-fulls of cornbread and wished I'd gotten that one like I started to. I absolutely love cornbread and the jalapeno butter they used was a nice flavorful touch. It also wasn't overly spicy, which I liked.

For entrees, she got the salmon and I opted for scallops. I can't really tell anymore if scallops are indicative of what a restaurant as a whole can do from a culinary standpoint because I feel like scallops are really hard to mess up. I always worry that the scallops won't be very filling but my concerns proved to be unfounded. The dish was filled with great vegetable choices and a smear of squash puree. I ate everything on my plate. So good. I tried a little bit of my fiancee's salmon dish and wasn't that impressed. If I remember correctly, it was seared with black sesame so one side looked like it had been dipped in tar. To be honest, it kind of tasted like it was a little on the burnt side. Glad I chose the scallops in this case because I think the salmon was in my top 3 choices when ordering. However, my fiancee LOVED the salmon totally, so different strokes on that one. 

Speaking of ordering, our server wasn't that great. When I was deliberating which one of two entrees I was considering, he was kind of flippant in his response and I could tell the last thing he wished to do was actually offer his opinion on a dish so I chose the scallops. But throughout the night, he hardly said anything. Never asked how we were doing. Didn't ask if we wanted dessert, just threw the menu down and strolled off. 

If there was a way we could have tipped the kitchen and not him, I would have done it. 

Overall, the food was fantastic and I would like to go back again and try a different entree this time. Hopefully we wouldn't get the same server because that guy was pretty crappy.
name: Polite Society
categories: American (New), Breakfast & Brunch, Tapas/Small Plates, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Cocktail Bars, Wine Bars, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants, Steakhouses, Food

text:
First off, if you can find a parking spot, that's an omen to go to Vegas or buy Lottery Tickets. Otherwise, your options are do the best you can and then wander for blocks through an interesting neighborhood until you arrive at a black box. Enter. Yes, it's like breaking into Al Capone's safe because the interior is all black but inside you are safe and welcome even though it feels like you put on your burqa backwards. 

The room is one dark, black cube with a small elliptical spirited Bar and a long Chef's Bar in front of a huge buzzin' kitchen. 

A background rock loop blends easily with the sound of communal dining. 

The Vibe: Philly's culinary adventurers. A congenial group who tried Monday through Thursday to get into Friday, Saturday and Sunday without success.  

The Staff: The Servers are overflowing with Brotherly love but although you are inches from the line cooks, they don't get out of line to chat. In fact they won't have anything to say to you unless you're related or they owe you money.

The Bar: It's as innovative as the food. 6 signature cocktails plus the usual suspects, (Wine and Beer) all on the wall along with dinner specials and thankfully all on the menu "B" side as the wall is too hard to see. Trump should be working on this wall. 

I had a My Session (could be my new obsession). This featured Dry Sherry, China in China, (Orange Bitters) and Passion Fruit about which I happen to be passionate. This was deep and delicious with rich notes of each of the 3 stars making it a 5 star libation. 

And just to test the system, I asked for a Whiskey Sour on the double which was double strength and finished double quick leaving me seeing me double in short order. Absolutely wonderful, it was. 

The Food: Wowser. It was positively sublime which is not easy to do in a town with Chef's as creative and daring as the Founding Fathers, all of whom would have bribed anyone to get a table here. 

I had no idea what to expect. Serpico? Basic Italian food for dirty cops? Non c'e modo. 

A wannabe Papadum (razor thin Rice Crackers) magically appeared and disappeared immediately. Studded with Black Sesame Seeds, you dip it into soft Cultured Butter with Cracked Pepper, or better, the Black Bean Dip with Cotija Cheese and Micro Cilantro. Get some under your nails for later. 

The Raw Diver Scallops were laid to rest in Buttermilk, Poppy Seeds, Green Yuzo Kosho, White Soy, and Chives when it arrives. It didn't stay long either. One bite and it was hoovered and savored. These silky smooth Scallops sported a unique presentation, were simply divine and gone as quick as a White House appointee.  

The Lettuce Salad is not a adequate name for such a beautiful composition of Micro Greens, Snow Peas, Smoked Lamb Bacon, Mint, Chervil, Lime and hand torn Nori dusted Croutons all judiciously bathed in a creamy Citrusy Dressing. A must. 

Fried Duck Leg riffed on a Hot Dog. Hoisin Sauce slathered on a mini Martin's Potato Bun with paper thin Cucumber coins, Scallions and a micro dot of Garlic Chili Sauce (Sriracha...I saw the bottle come out from under the counter). Everyone in the place had one for good reason. Party food rocks and this Duck rocked hard. 

The Chicken Snail Lasagna with Bechamel Sauce, Hazelnuts, Parsley, Pesto dots and Yuzu. Order this for sure if only because you won't find anything like this anywhere else. (Okay, Nightshade in LA does a Mapo Tofu Lasagna which compares favorably to this, except it's in LA). 

This dish was as brilliant as the idea to make it in the first place. 

Crisp Porchetta was a deconstructed version of a traditional belly beater. This was shredded Pork long braised to tenderness and then topped with a crown crackin' Cracklin' and treated to a few squirts of house made Pear Mustard. I had to rethink my devotion to a Stuffed Pork Sandwich as fat as a Whoopie Cushion on a crunchy Ciabatta Roll. 

Julienned Pickled Daikon replaced mundane Cole Slaw. Aw shucks the Porchetta was all so magnificently rich and satisfying, I defy any Vegan to resist it.

And now it's time for dessert. 

The Apple Cake was disguised Sticky Toffee Pudding. Dulce de Leche replaced melty Treacle. 
Burnt Apple Sauce pooled under the mound next to house made Vanilla Ice Cream topped with Shortbread Crumbles. Sweet!

The Vanilla Panna Cotta with fresh Berries, Candied Almonds and Yuzu will make you believe you are light. 

Serpico is a must go.
name: Serpico
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text: Got here around noon so there were not many bagels left. I tried the black sesame bagel. The black sesame gives a unique flavor but the bagel itself is dry and a little bit hard. Nothing special about it.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: Eh. Was expecting much more. The hana bento dinner was really bad... Should have known better and ordered some crazy rolls, so it was also partly my fault. The veggie bibim bap was decent and might have been the only vegetarian option on the menu. It was executed well since the place is Korean-run, but by the end of my meal there was a slight burning smell yet still not enough socarrat so maybe they should change the dolsot. Black sesame ice cream was really weak.
name: Doma
categories: Restaurants, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
I enjoyed Knead Bagels. Yes, the wait can be a bit long and yes they do run out of bagels by late afternoon.
There's a wide assortment of cream cheese that I have to try. I only had the plan so far and it was thick and creamy.
Everything bagel is awesome. So is garlic and black sesame. The bagels are dense and moist as they should be.
I had one of the breakfast sandwiches that had turkey sausage and egg, which I thought was very good.
Service was friendly. I would return.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Probably my new favorite place for tea time! This place is the newest place to check out and I highly recommend. It is decorated beautifully with elegant chandeliers and clean decor. They played soft music in the background, further adding to the soothing ambiance. 

The wait staff was very attentive so we were able to order quickly after we decided what we wanted.

We ordered a jasmine green tea, which was perfect since it was quite chilly that day. My mom has high standards for teas and this one passes the mark! We also ordered the Trio with Black Sesame Creme brûlée, Green tea fancier, and the Fruit Tart. 

The black sesame creme brûlée was DELISH. Not too sweet but strong black sesame flAvor - definitely interesting and unique.  

Green Tea Fancier was great! Reminiscent of a green tea muffin, which a slightly crisp muffin top but soft pillowy inside. 

Fruit tart wasn't too sweet. The cream didn't have too much flavor and acted more as a vessel to highlight the fruit. It was good but nothing to put in the books. 

We also ordered the purple yam soufflé, which was incredibly moist, making it taste like a yam but in muffin form. The ice cream added just the right amount of sweetness and added sharp juxtaposition between the soufflé in the hot ramekin and the cold ice cream.
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text:
Let's talk a bao the yummy food here! I got a dan tat (egg tart), the black sesame egg yolk pastry, Japanese cheesecake, and beef mini steamed buns. I'm usually a phone eats first kind of person, but I was very hungry and when I got home with my takeout and opened the bag holding the steamed buns - the smells that smacked me were so intoxicating I decided I eat first that day (so no picture, sorry!) The buns were super juicy! The wrapper got a bit soggy but I feel like they would be perfect if eaten fresh in the store. 

As for the desserts, the Japanese cheesecake was interesting. It didn't really have a strong cheesecake flavor - it was more like if a pound cake went on a diet. It had the richness and flavor profile of a pound cake but was somehow super airy and light - quite delicious! The egg tart was good, but unfortunately, the pastry got stuck to the holder so when I tried to pick it up it fell apart - this does not take away from the taste though which was classic and delicious. The egg yolk pastry was something that I've never tried! The black sesame flavor was strong and it was flaky AF. I definitely want to go back and try their cakes! Really awesome minority-owned business!
name: Wishing Town Bakery Cafe
categories: Bakeries, Food

text:
Knead bagels... what can I say about my favorite Philly spot? I'm leaving Philly and I will miss Knead Bagels every day I'm gone. Knead is known for their excellent quality bagels with interesting and unconventional flavor combinations and their wonderful staff. I started going to Knead back in 2014 and my favorite was the black sesame bagel with kimchi cream cheese. Since then I have discovered the beauty of their weekly specials which are simply put, special! The specials can be sweet, savory, or anything in between. It always fun to order the special bagel and cream cheese combo just to see how delicious it will be. I also love the togarashi with scallion lime cream cheese (which I've also started adding a pickled green tomato to at the suggestion of my friend). The spicy togarashi with the sharp but cooling cream cheese is too good. I will also deeply miss the chicken salad sandwhich and tuna salad sandwhich, both of which are so creative and flavorful. The chicken salad is so fresh and there are never any bites of gristle (I'm a big texture person). 

Finally, I would be remiss not to say that the staff are so wonderful and nice. It was such a nice place to visit and I will miss seeing everyone who made the experience so great.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
I would definitely come back again. 

Convenient parking: Mochi Ring is located within this plaza in Abington. That means I don't have to look for street parking if I want to go here for a quick snack/dessert. 

Clean: My first impression of this place is...it's clean. With Covid still being around, the two employees that I saw do have their masks on. However, there are no tables if you want to enjoy and eat their mochi donut or try out their drinks inside the store. 

Mochi Donuts: They taste fresh to me. There are a number of flavors to choose from. And from time to time, they will have new flavors out. The day I was there they had Ube and Mango as their new flavors. Their normal selections I believe are Strawberry, Matcha, Oreo, Nutella, Coffee, Brown Sugar Milk Tea, Black Sesame, Coconut, etc. I've tried all except Matcha. Personal preference that I would recommend is heat the mochi donut for a few seconds before eating so the texture of the mochi would be soft and chewy. 

Drinks: I ordered their Honey Citron Lemon Green Tea and their King of Oolong Milk Tea. Both drinks are yummy and delicious to me. Definitely recommend to give the drinks a try.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text:
Jane G's is a Szechuan restaurant in center city.  It's fairly large, with what seemed like about 75 or 100 seats, or so, no counting the al fresco seating which is another 20 or so.   Most of their options are spicy, so if you're not a fan of spicy Szechuan, this may not be the pace for you, though they do have options for the spice-averse among us...myself included.  I opted for their Hot Pot, which is similar to a Japanese Shabu Shabu or a fondue.  They have an interesting take on this, as you choose your broth (pork, chicken, veggie, or spicy chili) along with as many of about 30 veggie and protein options as you like.  For proteins they had pork, beef, lamb, fish, lobster (fake) balls, fish balls, "luncheon" meat (spam), as well as some items that had a surcharge like clams, oysters, head-on shrimp, and lobster.  They had several kinds of tofu, as well as napa cabbage, soy bean sprouts, spinach, mushrooms, etc., and three kinds of noodles:  vermicelli, udon, and a ramen/soba hybrid.  You can choose two kinds of broth if you like, but I opted for the basic chicken.  I ordered a chrysanthemum strawberry tea, which came iced, and was great if not just a bit on the sweet side.  

They brought a butane burner to the table, atop which was placed the simmering broth.  The chicken broth was simmering with some green onions, mushrooms, tomato, and goji berries.  They also bring three dipping sauces:  peanut (savory), barbecue (savory), and a garlic oil.  I got some chili oil on the side, as well.  

The proteins and veggies arrive on a large plate, the noodles on another, and you place the raw food in the simmering broth to your desired level of doneness.  They provide a small spider with which you retrieve the items once they're cooked to your liking.  It's nice, because you can cook everything just until it's done, then pull it out.  I especially liked the fact that the noodles came dry, so when you cooked them for six or seven minutes, they came out of the broth infused with the stock...very tasty. Overall, it's a fun dinner option and great for a group of people to dine together and try new foods.  

For dessert, I opted for an unusual dish called sesame dough soup.  It was, quite possibly, the strangest thing I've ever eaten...not so much for the ingredients, but more the presentation and taste.  The "soup" is a very watery base with very little taste, seemingly flavored with goji berries and I'm not sure what else.  The dough balls are glutinous rice balls stuffed with a black sesame paste.  The taste was ok, however as you eat the dish, especially if you cut the balls in half in the soup, it literally looks as if someone dumped an ashtray into the soup bowl; the sesame paste looks exactly as you'd think cigarette ashes would look if dumped in a bowl of water.  A very interesting dish that was visually horrible; the taste was not enough to my liking that I'd try it again, though it's a great dish to try with a bunch of people to see their reactions.  

I can't comment on the prepared dishes, since I only had the hot pot, but from what I could see, people seemed to be enjoying their dinners.  I'd definitely go back and try some other dishes, and I'd definitely re-visit for the hot pot.  This is no Susanna Foo's, but it's still very good.
name: Dim Sum House
categories: Shanghainese, Tapas Bars, Cantonese, Seafood, Dim Sum, Chinese, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Szechuan

text:
Lovely place for a quick bit and lot of chats. I wouldn't come if you're expecting a full meal but maybe a light bite. The do have some entrees but it's not very expansive. Their tea selection, however, is quite large.  

Tried the lavender oolong and loved it. It was light but aromatic. Quite excited to try other tea offerings. I split a teapot with my gal pal. Between us two, it was a decent amount. I think three to a pot might be a bit too little per person. Also got some fries and their dessert trio to share. The Goma (black sesame) Brulee is really good. Full of flavor, nutty and creamy. The Pâte à Choux were alright and the green tea financier is passable.

The service is quite nice. We didn't feel rushed and we enjoyed our tea time.
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text:
My dear friend suggested we go here December 20.

I read all the Yelp reviews, became skeptical, but was game, 'cause he'd been here before and liked it.

We were greeted by two guys behind the counter, and they were smiling. THAT is important.

Guerrilla Street Food serves Filipino-American food -- something of which I know nothing.

But I know a clean restaurant when I see it. It was immaculate, except for where we sat. More on that later.

Our order-taker helped us so much with explanations of the general Filipino food being not ridiculously hot of spice, as well as specifics about certain dishes and how they are arranged on the menu board. Most popular five dishes are first. He was incredibly helpful.

We ordered:
Shanghai Lumpia -- $3 -- Ground pork, onion, garlic, carrot, in a thin wrapper and fried. Served with chile sauce.

Flying Pig -- $8 for regular, $10 for large -- Pulled pork shoulder with hoisin, sriracha and calamansi over steamed jasmine rice. Topped with a slow-cooked egg, fried garlic, black sesame and green onion.

Wandering Pig -- $7 for regular, $9 for large -- Pulled pork shoulder with hoisin, sriracha and calamansi over steamed jasmine rice. Topped with fried garlic, black sesame and green onion.

We both ordered the large of our dishes and opted for water -- and virtually (and I'm using that word appropriately) when we got settled with our water on two bar seats facing Delmar, the food was delivered.

Both of our entrees were served in large bowls -- my bowl was on a tray, because that housed the Shanghai Lumpia and sauce in a container that we were sharing.

I was the Flying Pig and immediately pierced the runny yolk. And it ooozzzed beautifully throughout the dish along with some black sesame seeds.

He was the Wandering Pig -- same dish without the egg.

We ate, we talked, we shared the Lumpia. We ate, we talked.

The Shanghai Lumpia were tremendous. They were soooo hot and fresh out of the fryer when they came to the table, we had to let them cool down a bit, so we didn't burn our lips off. That's NOT a bad thing in my book.

Crunchy on the outside and NOT greasy, good innards. The chile sauce was sweet with a good back-heat, but not too much. I didn't count the pieces of lumpia, but I thing it was five or six. These are small rolls.

He was skeptical on the Lumpia, but he tasted one, dipped in the sauce. Then he tasted another one, dipped in the sauce, and he was sold.

Flying Pig and Wandering Pig -- only separated by a soft-cooked egg.

We both liked our dishes. I didn't taste his, and he didn't taste mine, so we didn't have comparisons.

I was amazed at the flavor and the lovely. A HUGE amount of shredded and flavorful pork in my Flying Pig. It was ridiculously wonderful. And the broken egg went down to flavor the other ingredients. The garlic wasn't overly present. The green onion was perfectly present.

I LOVE GARLIC, so I would have appreciated more. But that's my own personal preference.

BIGGEST problem: The bar on which we sat looking out to Delmar was sooooo sticky. His clothes and my clothes STUCK to the counter.

CLEAN and FIX that situation, please, Guerrilla Street Food. Your food is great, but clean the bartop.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Filipino, Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Food, Food Trucks

text:
food was great, service was a little slow because of the restaurant week rush.

i had the house salad, which was delicately dressed in a ginger vinaigrette. it was served as a very generous portion - it could have been an entree in itself. the fried pork dumplings (my second course) were served piping hot and had a great crunch and juicy filling.

i selected their maki combo as my third course, which included a spicy tuna roll, yellowtail jalapeño mango roll and a salmon avocado roll. the fish was fresh and i loved the deep bowl that it was served in - felt like i was plucking sushi out of the sea.

the best part of the meal however was... dessert! you were given a choice of two selections off the menu and my friend and i decided to get one of each (chocolate cake, black sesame mochi, apple crisp, and pumpkin bread pudding).

the pumpkin bread pudding was amazing - i would come back just to pick up some dessert if they still have this on the menu next time. it had a chewier texture than most bread puddings - i think they might have snuck some mochiko flour in it to give it that japanese edge.
name: Zama
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
A great spot for when you're looking for a solid ambiance and yummy desserts! 

I've tried a variety of their desserts, and haven't been disappointed so far. I think their trio set is particularly cute and flexible as you can choose from several options. I tried a goma (black sesame) crème brûlée here for the first time and really enjoyed it. 

For being a pricier place, they still have a credit card minimum of $15 or something, which can become cumbersome when you're just coming here to share a dessert. 

If you wanna let loose on your calorie count and your wallet for an occasional treat, would def recommend!
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text:
It was a very proud day, the day I whipped out my phone to check in to Lee Lee's and I was crowned the duchess on Yelp.  Yes, I am a dork, but I own it.  

This market it HUGE!!!!  It literally feels as if you are transported to another world.  Inside there is a jewelry store, a cell phone store, an Asian bbq (cash only), and a Vietnamese restaurant.  The pork and duck at that BBQ looks ah-mazing!  

It is brightly lit, with wide aisles and for an Asian market I think it smells just fine.  Each aisle is labeled Indian, Korean, Japanese, Hawaiian....they even have my coconut syrup- I have never seen it outside of Hawaii (well, its also at G and L market)

Make sure you get some coconut rolls, they are brought in from a Chinese bakery in Cali and they are super tasty.  You can also find unique items like grass jelly.  

They do have booze, but you can get wayyy better deals elsewhere.  What you do buy here is fresh herbs!  Cilantro, basil, mint, dill, bitter leaves for 20 cents to 50 cents for a large bag.  Also, check the discounted produce.  I got 2 pineapples for a buck, 4 guavas for a bucks....perfect for juicing!  No 10 percent discount on the already reduced items, but everything else in the store is 10 percent off.

I am almost afraid to type this, but the meat here is outstanding.  I do not want the cat out of the bag, but here it goes.  You can get the tastiest beef tenderloin for 7.99 a pound.  I am salivating just writing about it.  If you are adventurous they have the black silkie chicken too!  I had no idea that Tori Spelling's adorable fluffy pet chickens were black underneath....

The freezer section has some really cool stuff like mochi, Thai tea Popsicles, black sesame Popsicles, cheese kulcha and Medhu wada (lentil donuts with coconut chutney)...

Spices are a steal too!  Garam masala, fennel powder, kashmiri pepper powder and all under 4 bucks for about 3 cups worth of spice....fyi- you can turn these spices into the best Chicken Tikka Masala ever!  

I also stock up on my Thai supplies...trust me Chaokah is the BEST coconut milk and Maesri makes the best curry pastes...combine these with palm sugar and tamarind paste, you will have your significant other impressed and dazzled by your culinary craftiness.

My only beef is the Japanese candy section blows....I cannot seem to get my j-pop fix anywhere in this state.  

After you load your car up, make sure you pop over to Bings for some sweet boba!
name: Lee Lee International Supermarkets
categories: Ethnic Grocery, Food, Ethnic Food, Grocery, Specialty Food, Delis, Restaurants, Seafood Markets, International Grocery, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Meat Shops

text:
In order to be a successful eating establishment, one has to excel in at least one discipline or even one item.  If I were to correlate some to celebrities, ice cream shops would be like your sweet romantic comedy actors/actresses , steakhouses would be like your meaty action stars , and food trucks would be your Indie up and comers or niche actors/actresses.  

Once in a blue moon you come across a polymath, which wikipedia defines as "a person whose expertise spans a significant number of different subject areas--such a person is known to draw on complex bodies of knowledge to solve specific problems"  The first celebrity that comes to mind is Steve Martin.   Steve Martin is not only a comedic genius, but he holds his own as a reputable banjo player in his own band and a New York Times bestselling author and playwright. 

I would consider the baker behind the counter at ICI to be a polymath considering the fact she is not French, came into the business from an accounting background, but was able to use her exacting nature to devise some of the best macarons, croissants, as well as other pastries and coffee I have come across on the East coast, considering my top beloved joints mainly lie in San Francisco, Portland, and Seattle.  

While its namesake highlight the macarons and the coffee, the unspoken star as many others have pointed out are the croissants, the cream filled cruffins, and the kouign amann.  If there was a Richter scale for the degree of shatter between the laminations of butter and pastry biting into a croissant, the croissant at ICI would register a 7.4, well worth the caloric indulgence.  The fact that the baker is Asian carries an additional infusion of sophisticated flavors-twists such as green tea, peanut-black sesame,  and lychee/mancho/passionfruit in her other creations, but the technical mastery and blueprint behind every item is still indisputably French.

To paraphrase a compliment David Chang gave to one of his favorite  Tokyo yakitori joints in his Ugly Delicious series, "The greatest compliment that I can give is that when I am eating, I am already planning in my head my next trip returning for another meal".  That is how I feel whenever I come to Philly and have the opportunity to drop in since I am already planning the next pastry I want to try on my next visit as I eat the one I just purchased.
name: ICI Macarons & Cafe
categories: Desserts, Bakeries, Food, Coffee & Tea, Specialty Food, Macarons

text:
This place was so cute and definitely a charming and slightly fancy place for some great tea and dessert. 

Got the Montagne Bleue tea and it was floral and fragrant for a black tea, and you could definitely taste all the different notes in it. 

For dessert, I got the sampler trio with the Goma Crème brûlée, thé éclair, and the fruit tart. The fruit tart had a nice, light flavor, but was honestly not extraordinary , so it was my least favorite out of the three. Thé éclair was perfectly balanced between flaky pastry, and the cream was subtle and don't overpower the whole dessert. My favorite was the crème brûlée - the black Sesame added an amazingly unique taste and should honestly be a staple in crème brûlée from now on. Overall, all the desserts were light and not to sweet, so you don't feel guilty about loading up on sugar. 

Overall, a super cute place to go for dessert or another special occasion!
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text: I think their concept is so unique and cool. What a smart way to create your own fruit tea or milk tea flavors. The instructions are straight forward and there are a good amount of flavors to choose from. I think you can't go wrong with the fruit tea flavors. Any two flavors I picked, the finishing drink taste so good! I also enjoyed getting the black sesame and regular milk tea combined. The price is also decent. I like coming here if I am in the area! They also served some snack such as steamed buns, fries, and etc. A great place to hang out and grab a delicious fruit tea/ milk tea drink.
name: Bubblelicious Lab
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Coffee & Tea, Desserts

text:
Early gray milk tea was a great choice. We ordered it with 80% sugar which was still a bit sweet. Might have to do 
50% sugar next time. 
The durian Mille crepe pancake was very smooth and creamy. Strong durian flavor--tasted exactly like the fruit. 
We also ordered the Trio Combo.  The black sesame creme brûlée was the best dessert out of the trio. It was creamy with a perfect flavor of black sesame. The fruit tart filling was grainy and lacked flavor. The green tea fiancier wasn't anything memorable.  I would go back for the milk tea again.
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text:
One of the newest additions to Philadelphia, and it is good news. First class and top quality bagels that is still under the radar.

It was tough to choose, we were so tempted to buy a dozen of bagels, and so we did- a dozen of different varieties and we got an extra one for free.

Their bagels specialties includes black sesame, pastrami spiced, everything, poppy seed, and cardamom bagel, my favorite- that should be their calling card with the exotic flavor, absolute perfection!
Along with the insanely-good cream cheese spreads and schmears from the plain cream cheese, to the flavored ones i.e:  roasted tomato, cinnamon raisin and the scallion lime cream cheese, which was a vote-winner. If you're feeling adventurous, I suggests their smoked chopped liver cream cheese!

The bagels were rich, glossy with a golden glow, and always fresh out of the oven. Crispy and crunchy from the outside, dense and chewy from the inside- no need to be toasted and make one of the most perfect bites! What a delight! 

A swab of fresh cinnamon raisin cream cheese on a cardamom bagel bagel is hard to beat. Knead Bagels you nailed it!

Four and half Yelps!
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text: I was really pleased with my visit here recently. I came, got a nice cup of black sesame ice cream and lounged on the bench seating while I breastfed my baby and enjoyed it. This shop is tiny but it has some great ice cream and the staff member who worked here when I visited was great as well. I hope to enjoy the waffle cone in the future! I don't think there's a restroom here and there really isn't much seating (an outdoor wooden bench and an indoor booth bench by the window). Still, most are likely to leave with a pint in the winter or with a cone in the summer and enjoy the delicious treats!
name: Kind Ice Cream
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Food

text:
While visiting the city we stumbled upon this place; it was busy when we arrived so we opted to order to go vs waiting 20 minutes for a table for 2.  We got the B.E.C. breakfast sandwich & a butter croissant.  We still waited 20 minutes or so for our to go order; when we got our order we just sat at a table outside as there were a few open & no one waiting for the line - some places frown upon this but the staff did not mind. 
The B.E.C. was good sized for a breakfast sandwich & one of the best breakfast sandwiches we've had.  I think the black sesame seed roll is what put the B.E.C over the top. Everything on the menu sounded good - if we are back in the area we will visit again.
name: High Street Philadelphia
categories: Cafes, Pizza, American (New), Breakfast & Brunch, Sandwiches, Restaurants

text: Delicious bagels! I went with an everything bagel with roasted tomato cream cheese. I can't wait to go back and try some of their specialty combos like the black sesame bagel with kimchee cream cheese.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Got the Black Sesame bagel(supposedly with Kimchi? I may be wrong since I didn't taste any of it, and the website has not been updated..fail) with Kimchi cream cheese. Yes, I'm Korean.

The bagel, though, was a little disappointing. I didn't find anything distinct about it, and I can't even describe it. This place is not up to par with your neighborhood bagel shop in NYC (sorry if I sound like a snob...I LOVE bagels.) The Kimchi Cream Cheese was better, just enough Kimchi flavor (and actual kimchi in the spread!) with a tinge of heat.

A plus- Mighty Leaf teas!
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
Mochi Ring Donut just opened in Jenkintown. It's tucked away in a small plaza but when you walk in, it's cute and quaint. They offer a variety of flavors of mochi donuts from coconut, nutella, strawberry, coffee, black sesame, matcha, etc. From the few that I tried, my favorite is black sesame!

The donuts taste light and fluffy, and not overly sweet. Definitely a refreshing snack/dessert. There's a parking lot outside, so plenty of space. 

They're currently offering a soft/grand opening special where you can try a free mochi donut.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text:
Tucked away in the back of Chinatown, this place looks amazing inside. Aesthetically pleasing and welcoming atmosphere. The staff was nice and efficient. 

Since my friend and I was a little hungry we went with the Chicken Katsu Sandwich was delicious. The chicken was fried nicely and still juicy inside. Nicely seasoned as well. The flavoring was on point and the sauce on the chicken was delicious. Everything is held together by a delicious butter brioche bun.

The salad on the side was well a simple salad nothing special. Not too sure what kind of dressing they used, a little similar to honey mustard taste but very mild.

Onwards to the dessert. The Purple Yam Mille Crepe Cake was pretty good. This type of flavor is usually very mild, but I felt like this one was a bit too mild in flavor. The layers itself are very nicely done and soft, piled high, and easily cut through. Still a very delicious cake.

Trio Combo Mix and Match is a great sampler platter. Very aesthetically pleasing to the eyes and pictures. The green tea financier has a hint of green tea on a soft and warm cake. Very light and slightly moist. It definitely goes well with the tea they have.

The Pate a Choux Chocolate Ice Cream was just as delicious. Very crunch pastry on top that complements the rich chocolate ice cream.

Lastly the Goma Brûlée. It might not look the most appealing, but it was delicious. It still has the nice hard caramelization on top and underneath is the black sesame filling. Delicious and smooth as it enters your mouth and coats your tongue with the flavor of black sesame. The filling is a little thick but it isn't a big deal.

In conclusion an amazing place to try different desserts. Great place for a date and a must try. Definitely can't wait to go back again.
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text:
First time review at Guerrilla Street Food. 

First of all, this location is very easy to find and parking was plentiful. We were excited to find a Filipino food place in St. Louis. We walked inside through the ADA accessibility entrance ramp. Inside can fit up to 20 people. It is very clean and nicely decorated with a Filipino modern vibe. The menu is very straightforward and easy to read. 

We ordered the Large 800 Pound Guerrilla and the sinigang. The 800 Pound Guerrilla is a combination of their Flying Pig (12 hr braised pork shoulder, pulled and sauced with sriracha, hoisin, and calamansi, topped with a 63 degree egg, fried garlic, black sesame seeds) & Chicken Adobo (chicken thighs braised in sou sauce, cider vinegar, garlic, black peppercorn, bay leaves) served with jasmine rice and scallions. 

As we waited for our food, I viewed the other menu items and was excited to come back and try the other food items. However, when our food was brought to us, there was a hair in our sinigang. We sent it back and a new one was made for us and we were reimbursed for it. But, when we did send it back, the cook didn't even say sorry, he just said he'll reimburse us and make us another one. 

The 800 Pound Guerrilla was decent. In my opinion it was too much sriracha. I loved the Flying Pig side, especially the eggs. The chicken adobo was not what I was expecting. It was a lot sweeter than I was used to. I make adobo at home and have no idea which ingredient could have made it taste like that. Probably an unstated ingredient. 

The sinigang had radishes in it, which is different, but not in a good way. The soup was very sour/salty/spicy? The taste was not tolerable. 

The food portions are big. My husband and I shared and there is free water is available. The noise level when we got there was silent, no music, and then one of the workers turned on Country music... which is off from the Filipino decor and food. 

I love the idea of this restaurant but the food did not deliver. I probably won't be returning here and just cook these items on my own.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Food Trucks, Food, Filipino, Restaurants, Food Stands, Local Flavor, Asian Fusion

text: Really yummy, I tried the Nutella and black sesame mochi donuts so far. Nice spot for a quick snack!
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text:
This a nice place with both indoor and outdoor seating. Nice looking interior and has that cafe atmosphere to it.

I got the everything bagel with egg, cheese, and their house Knead Aioli. This was a pretty good bagel. Soft fluffy eggs and oozy cheese is on point. The aioli was delicious and can be a bit overpowering especially so depending on the bagel you get. It was a great bagel, but I think I would prefer a different bagel with this instead of the everything bagel.

My friend got the same thing, but with the Togarashi bagel. This was a Japanese chili powder kind of bagel with some seaweed and black sesame. It was delicious and complimented the egg, cheese, and Aioli. I would 100% recommend trying it with this bagel.

Overall they have tons of options to customize your bagel. It's not expensive for some good quality food with a variety of options. A word to the wise though, for those that like a softer kind of bagel this might not be up your alley, but I still recommend giving it a try. The bagels here are on the harder side of the scale.
name: Knead Bagels
categories: Restaurants, Bagels, Coffee & Tea, Sandwiches, Food, Soup, Salad

text:
I went to their soft opening, one of their first  customers! I am so excited about this place. 

Inside is sleek with tables and a couch. They have a few plants and decorations too. They have the clAssic  boba flavors with some unique in house drinks like the Sky Blue and Dream House Taro. The also have macaroons, cupcakes, and small cakes. Definitely a plus!!! The macaroon flavors I got were ube, green tea, black sesame and more I can't remember. The staff were really nice and helpful too. 

This is a family owned business and  I can't wait  for them to succeed and bring another boba place to the westbank!!!
name: Dream House Cafe
categories: Specialty Food, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Coffee & Tea, Macarons

text: I had the Morning Special which comes with bacon, egg, and cheese.  It was quite tasty and very affordable.  The dessert crepes looked fantastic and I'll have to go back for those soon.  I did try some of the ice cream and they had flavors that I had had never had before--both the Azuki (red bean) and Black Sesame were delicious.  I'll definitely be back!
name: Crepe N' Roll
categories: Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Food, Creperies, Restaurants

text:
Oh emmm gee, this place is delicious. I never had donuts quite like this before. The donuts had this chewy texture to it that can't quite be described in words. We ordered a half dozen of different flavors (matcha, strawberry, black sugar, black sesame, taro, and cookies n cream). I really enjoyed them all. My daughter loved the taro one and my sisters favorite was the strawberry. 

As for bubble teas - also wow! The Boba was cooked perfectly and the drinks varieties they had were plentiful. They had something for each of my parties liking. From fruit teas to milk teas, they have it!

If this place was closer to me, I'd definitely be going every weekend lol. .
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text: Pretty cute spot to just chill and grab some tea/dessert. We got the Trio Combo Mix and Match which was a good way to try several items. Our favorite was the black sesame creme brûlée. Usually I find black sesame to be a little strong of a flavor but it was made really well and had a more subtle taste.
name: Prince Tea House
categories: Sandwiches, Food, Desserts, Coffee & Tea, Restaurants, Tea Rooms

text: I love this place! Menu has a good mix of Korean and Japanese dishes and everything I've tried has been delicious. I highly recommend the tuna nachos- we were wowed by this. The tacos and the okonomiyaki are also good choices for starters. The appetizer options are honestly all so appealing that my mistake the first time here was filling up on apps before the main dishes even arrived. They have a good selection of sushi rolls, the tuna club was unique and tasty to boot. Definitely leave room for dessert. We opted for the taiyaki and it was the perfect ending to the meal. The taiyaki was stuffed with red bean paste, the black sesame ice cream was topped with Rice Krispies, and the whipped cream on the side had super soft pillowy mochi. The service is top notch and the staff is super friendly. I know I'll be back again soon.
name: Doma
categories: Restaurants, Korean, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
Prior to moving to St. Louis, I lived in NYC where I was introduced to Filipino food. When I moved to St. Louis several years ago and found out that there were no Filipino restaurants, I was super depressed. The Guerrilla Street Food Truck helped some, but now I can finally say that we have a Filipino restaurant in STL thanks to their new location in Tower Grove!!!! 

They have several items to choose from on their menu, including both traditional and newer Filipino dishes. Although I am sad that they do not serve Lechon Paksiw or Sinigang, I was super pleased to see both Pancit and Lumpia. 

For lunch, I ordered The Flying Pig, which you can get either as a bowl or as a burrito. I got it as a bowl and it comes with slow roasted pork asado, chilis, calamansi, sriracha served over rice, and is topped with a 1 hour egg. It was absolutely delicious. The best part is definitely the 1 hour egg. SO good! It was also a really good size and very filling. I tried the Fresh Lumpia, which was good with the sweet sauce. I think next time I'll have it fried. My friend ordered another favorite of this place, which was The 800 lb. Guerrilla. It also comes as a dish or as a burrito. It is a combination of chicken adobo and slow roasted pork, calamansi, sriracha, hoisin, fried garlic, paprika creme, greens and black sesame seeds, and was also topped with a 1 hour egg. 

To drink, my friend had the Calamansi Cooler. It is a house-made limeade with calamansi (an Asian lime), honey, fresh ginger, and mint. We both thought it was a little sweet. I ordered a drink that was made with coconut milk, pineapple juice, and black currant juice. It was OK (not my favorite), but I appreciated that it was free because I checked in on Yelp. 

The place itself is somewhat small, but located in a great spot on the corner of Grand and Arsenal. It is clean, simple, and there are some tables both inside and outside. The staff were really friendly, patient, and helpful. I most certainly will return.
name: Guerrilla Street Food
categories: Food Trucks, Food, Filipino, Restaurants, Food Stands, Local Flavor, Asian Fusion

text: The first Mochi Donuts place to open in Pa area and we arrived around noon , the Selection was good and I loved the strawberry, mango, coffee and black sesame Mochi donuts the most . , they were fresh and definitely worth the trip. I will be back and recommend. The donuts were soo good chewy and flavorful.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text:
I want everyone in the Philadelphia metropolitan area to descend on this place like suburban moms going to the strip mall on Black Friday morning. I want whoever is reading this to drop your phone right now, leave your house in whatever you're wearing, and hit the road. Because I want this place to become so popular that it never closes down. 

If you've never had a mochi ring donut, it's deep fried like a regular yeast donut, but made with tapioca/rice flour, which gives them a more springy consistency and slightly different flavor. (That description doesn't feel quite right... you just have to try them to understand). The icings are also better than average donut shops because they have things like yuzu, black sesame, and taro. They also have more traditional icings like strawberry or Nutella, but super-flavorful. 

To add icing to all of the icing you'll already have, they serve really great bubble tea. And corn dogs that are kind of hard to describe but you should eat them. And that's a full, balanced meal, folks.
name: Mochi Ring Donut And Bubble Tea
categories: Specialty Food, Donuts, Candy Stores, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Food, Asian Fusion

text:
Came here for hubby's birthday because he has an Iron Chef crush on Morimoto, even though chances were admittedly slim that there'd be a sighting.

Eating here is not just about the food, it's about the experience. Every dish was delicious and beautiful, and the atmosphere pulls it all together. My one big complaint about the decor is the big glowing phalice in the middle of the table... made arranging dishes on the table precarious and the celebratory birthday photo of us at the table took an unintended turn for the risque ;)

The tuna pizza was so good; I'm not usually big on the raw fish and almost stole some of hubby's slices after finishing my own. My curiosity to see tofu made table-side made me order the yosedofu; it was cool, very silky, not the most flavorful but good. He got the chef's selection sushi platter which was so much food. I got the ishi yaki buri bop; came in a beautiful presentation that involved more table-side prep, was ridiculously delicious, and still yummy the next day when I finished off the leftovers. 

The black sesame moussecake was again ordered partly out of curiosity, and was very good. They even had a candle on the plate for hubs to blow out =)

All in all an awesome meal. Portions were pretty huge, everything was tasty, and our server was attentive and helpful.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
So, I'm discriminating but not a prick and I rarely give out 5 stars because there is rarely perfection. I also like my food seasoned aggressively. In short this is a can't miss for price + food quality + service + ambiance. A lot of the restaurants in Seminole Heights come across as a bit "trendy snobby", not this place. It's unpretentious and comfortable. The menu didn't have a dish I wouldn't try.

We started with the cobia collar and the scallop crudot. Our favorite was the cobia but the scallop dish was really good. How can you go wrong with a fried collar? The pickled turnip and radish were nice and nouc man rounded out the dish. The spicy greens and black sesame seeds make the scallop dish. We moved on to the boar chop and the braised shank. Both dishes were very good. I will say that the star of both wasn't the proteins (although they were well done). I've always said you can tell the best restaurants by what they pair with the proteins and the care taken in preparation. These were spot on, damn delicious, and I wouldn't change a thing. We had a dessert and it rounded out the meal.

We left full but comfortable. I thought the portion sizes were perfect and priced well, especially given the quality. One of the things I really hate is leaving with a "doggie bag", leaving food on the plate, or being full before the main arrives. I completely disagree with reviews that the portions are too small or too expensive. 

For my palate, I would have tweaked a few things - but we were more than satisfied by the experience. 

Well done, keep it up, and I am looking forward to our next visit.
name: Rooster & the Till
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
I can't remember the last time I liked a restaurant so well that I've gone once a week since the first time I visited it. Enter Sushi Train. Here is the status of my relationship with them two months in.

I was poised to like it (I'd even had dreams about kaiten sushi places, being totally enchanted with the conveyor belt concept), but I had no idea I'd love it as much as I do.  There's always fresh sushi, reasonably priced, whirling around on the belt. As a small person who doesn't always get bang-for-buck at any kind of buffet, this place really suits me.You just eat as much as you want and only pay for what you take. I've stuffed myself for $25, and it was a damn sight better than any sushi buffet I've tried here before.

I prefer nigiri and sashimi, which are always fantastic here, but the rolls I've had are delicious too (I don't find them messy myself--most are bite-sized). The fish is always firm, so you won't have to struggle to take a bite of the larger nigiri and sashimi pieces, and the prepared rice is perfect. I like that I don't always recognize what I'm picking up, as it has caused me to be more adventurous in my sushi consumption. I've tried many things now that I never would have ordered off a menu, and I really appreciate that. I love that I can order all-yam tempura and not bother with those other inferior vegetables (and there's plenty of flavour in the tempura sauce--I don't know why the batter would need to be saltier). And get the black sesame ice cream. It's heavenly.

The service is lovely and the fish is of a high quality (at least for Edmonton), and it seems to me they're just figuring out a few kinks--like how many customers to expect on certain nights of the week. I've seen all kinds of things on the belt, and hardly anyone there to eat them. Give Sushi Train a try!
name: Sushi Train
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: Wow! I can't believe how many different and imaginative flavors of popsicles they have here!  Unless you're Asian or super into Asian desserts, you might've never tried black sesame sweets before. My friend was super confused about her black sesame popsicle but after one bit, she was hooked!  My favorite flavors were the earl grey, chocolate nibs and hibiscus pops.  So many flavors!!! How can you ever try all of them?? My tongue would freeze over and fall off first before I got through all the awesome flavors!!
name: Lil' Pop Shop
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
I stopped into Mr Ed's for the Crawfish Bread to go which I had read was "life-changing." Not exactly life-changing but I could see how if you were starving it would taste like you had died and gone to heaven. 

The cheese was velveeta-ish not real cheddary, but the onions and peppers were nice and crisp. The bread had 
black sesame seeds on it and had a good texture. A lot of the French bread in NOLA is completely flavorless...but I'm more a fan of Italian Bread. 

There could have been a few more crawfish but there were enough to say it was a decent portion. I waited at the bar for my order. The bartender gave me a bottle of water while I waited, which was super nice. I'd really like to try the broiled oysters here. It was a good, friendly atmosphere. I'd def go back.
name: Mr Ed's Oyster Bar - Bienville
categories: Cajun/Creole, Southern, French, Salad, Restaurants, Nightlife, Seafood, Fish & Chips, Bars

text:
Yogurtland has THE BEST plain tart and while you're at that..they also have the best pistachio flavor!  I'm so glad they finally opened up in Tucson!  

They are currently doing an "around the world" flavor fest featuring all kinds of different flavors from around the world like black sesame (a very popular ice cream flavor in east asian countries), pog juice flavor (from my original home in Hawaii), and other sorts that are worth checking out.
name: Yogurtland
categories: Chinese, Food, Restaurants, Desserts, Fast Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
The mango mille crepes is awesome. Definitely get this. It's served with chunks of fresh and sweet mango. Really refreshing. The matcha one is ok, you can pass on this one. We were around 2, I wanted the motchi but I was told it is available at 3. I also wanted the black sesame paste dessert but it's not available. Very disappointed .

The mango pocket is basically abig chunk of mango and whipped cream wrapped in a crepe. It's ok, nothing special.

Next time I want to try the shaved ice.
name: Mango Mango Dessert
categories: Food, Desserts, Shaved Ice, Waffles, Restaurants

text:
Fun ambiance, great entrees, and very attentive and excellent service.  The outside facade is actually nondescript so it's easy to walk past but the interior is hip and modern with neon lights and white tables on a wooden floor.  Very different from a traditional Japanese fusion restaurant.  

Some highlights:
1. Duck Duck Duck: Duck prepared 3 ways - fried rice, seared, and pan-fried.  The rice was excellent albeit greasy and the medium rare duck was tender and flavorful.  Very solid.
2. Sea bass in citrus vinaigrette: Very tender and flavorful with a slightly sweet and savory vinaigrette.
3. Seafood Toubayan: This was one of my favorites.  It came with fresh, HUGE pieces of king crab, shrimp, scallops, clams, and oyster mushrooms, topped with bok choy, all in a savory butter sauce.  It's served with sticky rice wrapped in a lotus leaf that pairs extremely well with the butter sauce.  Delicious!
 4. Black Sesame mousse cake: Amazing!  It's the perfect combination of fluffy mouse, sesame, and chocolate, capped off with a tiny macaroon.
6. Matcha Tres Leches cake: Delicous tres leches cake made with real matcha powder and served with a side of red bean ice cream.  The ice cream was okay but the soaked cake was amazing.

Service, as can be expected, was great and prices are reasonable for an Iron Chef restaurant.  It came to $150 including tax and tip for everything, which isn't bad.  Will be back for the Omakase shortly!
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Don't miss the Spring Menu at Marigold Kitchen

The setting: warm and welcoming. But what are we really here for, but the palate pleasing palette of delicious, diverse cuisine.  Ten courses, each uttelyr different and completely satisfying.

 Homemade rosemary bread with amazingly flavorful chanterelle butter to break the fast.  Then a panoply of starters - cool and refreshing Edamame Hummus studded with black sesame, brightened with a touch of chili oil and eaten with a light rice cracker; a lemon leek ricotta gnudi dressed with peeled tomato and fresh oregano; and a flavorful salad of lettuces in a puff pastry with sweet nubs of pineapple and crunchy hazelnut. 


The perfectly cooked Thai scallop with a fragrant and dizzyingly delicious curry-coconut sauce with mango, basil and mint was a showstopper, and I almost halted the meal right there since all I wanted was a full plate of this wonderful dish.  But more was still to come.  We moved to red wine when the tender wild boar was served with a braised mustard seed sauce, shiitake mushrooms and fava beans.   Again, my eyes closed with pleasure as I tasted the escargot in a 'good to the last drop' sauce of zinfandel, parmesan and basil.  We took a breath with the refreshing cantaloupe sorbet perfectly matched with cucumber water, a surprising, cool combination.  The perfectly cooked black pearl salmon with Bernaise sauce, a poached egg and Ossetra came next followed by tender free range Australian lamb with tabbouleh, pine nuts and white bean garnish. 


The cheese course was a melted base of Camembert de Normandie with a jellied strawberry and rhubarb flavored with balsamic and thyme.  The chef proved that he also masters chocolate with a rich square of dark chocolate ganache brightened with passionfruit, softened with buttermilk and garnished with edible wild flowers.  But my favorite was the 'finger likin' good' foie gras twix with a slight taste of dulce de leche and a white chocolate crunch candy.


Chef Keith Krajewski  has built on his foundation of training at the Culinary institute of America with flavors and a style that are all his own.  I cannot wait for my next meal at Marigold Kitchen, and following his culinary journey in the years ahead.
name: Marigold Kitchen
categories: Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, American (New), Sandwiches, Tapas/Small Plates, Salad

text: My heart weights heavy on this matter. I don't even like to talk about it when brought up by other locals and usually say it's like a bad breakup. I grew up in the riverbend area and have had a love affair with ninjas since it opened its doors at their first location on Jeannette street. I have loved it so much I HAD to go at least once a week for my fix. BUTTT unfortunately ever since the new ownership, it's declined. The place is ALWAYS empty even on a Saturday night when it used to be packed, so that's the first clue it's declined. Ever since the new ownership, some of my favorite rolls/ recipes have changed. Now I am all about the raw fish, as long as it's fresh it's hard to mess that up, but honestly one of my favs was just their crunchy  roll/special crunchy. I LOVED it, and I loved it wasn't the same old generic over mayo snow crab with crap tempura flakes pushed to the side instead of mixed together. . It used to be shredded imitation crab mixed all together with tempura flakes, smelt roe, and their awesome egg sauce, again, MXED ALL TOGETHER with asparagus! Perfection! No more . Also their snow crab and spicy snow crab WAS amazing not mayo filled, and had black sesame seeds mixed in. But they changed that too, and now it's mayo filled generic that you can get at every other sushi place. So needless to say since most rolls have crunchy filling or snow crab in them, they have ruined all my favorite rolls. I also used to love the ninjas salad, but last 2 times I ordered it, the mayo was rancid. I have started making my own version at home for my fix. The Cajun tuna tataki, and miso soup are still the same and very good. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE go back to the original recipes by the original owner, they even have the old owner making the original crunchy roll filling video on YOUTUBE! I want to love you guys again and would hate to see you close, but you have let me as a customer (and I came A LOT) unless you go back to original recipes.
name: Ninja Restaurant
categories: Tapas/Small Plates, Japanese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text:
Wait--I think I actually LOVE Mopho. We waited to try it out until Mopho worked out their routine. We had actually taken them off of our list because we got some ehh reviews. What brought us in was an appetizer we had at Drafts for Crafts at the museum, which was their blue cheese and some sort of chipotle mayo with a perfectly fried oyster. Obviously that was SOOOO GOOD that we just had to go to Mopho immediately after on the following night. 

We started with the chicken wings and shrimp and pork spring rolls. The chicken wings are to die for and are fun and messy, perfectly crispy, and tossed in a sauce I wanted to bathe in. The spring rolls are probably the best I've had at a restaurant, they're perfectly wrapped and filled with a delicious fresh combo of veggies, paired with a nice thick peanut sauce. After that we ordered our entrees. I got the tofu and cauliflower rice bowl with a fried egg and it was exactly what I wanted. It was light and filling at the same time and the tofu was crunchy without being dry. I definitely will have a hard time trying anything else because it was so good that I want to order it again and again. My dad got the oyster poboy (a take on Bahn mi) but did not share a single bite because he wasn't willing to part with it. That's a lot for a man who has never really liked Vietnamese food!
