My mom got the duck poboy. It was amazing, and delicious, and the (rice?) chips that they're served with was a refreshing take on basic chips. 

While I wish we could have gotten desert, we were honestly too stuffed...but I'll be coming back for something that our waiter mentioned there was house made black sesame ice cream in... However, this was probably because we started with drinks. I ordered the Guns-and-Roses + Mezcal boba tea, which was the most satisfying drink I've had at a restaurant recently. Who doesn't love boba tea, ESPECIALLY when there's alcohol added to it. I can't wait to come back and try the other flavors. 

I honestly see myself coming back to Mopho a million times. Easily one of my favorite spots in the city now.
name: Mopho
categories: Restaurants, Cocktail Bars, Vietnamese, American (New), Wine Bars, Gastropubs, Asian Fusion, Nightlife, Bubble Tea, Bars, Food

text:
For years I've watched Morimoto kick culinary butt on Iron Chef. So when I learned that his restaurant was based in Philly, I was super excited to make a reservation. So how was dinner you ask? Well, it freakin' kicked culinary butt.

I was a little hesitant about ordering the Omakase (the tasting menu) because I'm not a fan of raw fish, but I really wanted to order the Omakase because I wanted to experience Morimoto's talent and depth. When I asked the waiter if I could do the tasting menu sans sashimi, his answer was a confident, "Don't worry, I'll take care of you." And boy, did he ever. The lesson here: if you're going to be dining at an Iron Chef's restaurant, trust the Iron Chef and his staff completely.

The bf and I went with the $120 menu (there was also an $80 menu) because we wanted "the higher quality ingredients." Yes, the lobster and the kobe beef were worth the extra $40.

1st course
mine: a HUGE chunk of fresh snow crab mixed with crunchy fried scallions and topped with buttery avocado (you know how much work it takes to retrieve that much crab meat from a crab?)
the bf: tuna tartare + caviar (his favorite dish of the night)

2nd course
mine: kumamoto oyster tempura with 3 sauces: japanese salsa, ceviche (it was amazing - green, fresh, lime-intense - my favorite), and thai fish sauce
the bf: raw, kumamoto oysters with the above 3 sauces

3rd course: seared scallops for the both of us (definitely the highlight of the night - I can't stop thinking about this dish!! the scallops were sliced thin and were so delicate and fresh, but it was the sauce that blew us away ... the most perfect sauce that ever was made!!!!)

4th course:
mine: seared sashimi microgreen salad (least favorite dish of the night)
the bf: sashimi microgreen salad

home-made berry/vinegar soda to cleanse our palette ... this is where we learned that dinner was going to be 8 courses! We actually thought it was going to be 5 or 7 ... what a pleasant, belly-bustin' surprise!

5th course: Lobster 'Epice for the both of us - loved it, especially the chive creme fraiche

6th course: melt-in-your-mouth Kobe steak - really, really loved it, especially since I saved some of my lobster to eat with my Kobe ... can we say decadent??

7th course:
mine: the best, darn California rolls that ever existed (chock full of snow crab, avocado, cucumber, and black sesame seeds - Morimoto didn't even have the need to use any mayo)
the bf: nigiri that rivaled the nigiri he had in Japan

8th course: green tea tiramisu - at first, I was a little wary/disappointed because I don't like green tea BUT it didn't taste like green tea at all! It had a white chocolate bottom and a green tea caramel sauce and it was really light and refreshing and COMPLETELY cleansed our mouth - magic!

Drinks: I don't think you can go wrong with any of the cocktails - I ordered the lychee cosmo and it was really good! The bf ordered the Morimoto Rogue beer tasting and loved it.

Overall: We couldn't stop smiling. We smiled while we ate. We smiled while we chewed. We smiled while we swallowed and drank and before, after, and in-between courses. Everything was delicate.

ATMOSPHERE: Um ... this place is really, really cool. I love the hip, artsy, long, narrow, clean white+changing colors design of the restaurant. The ceiling is made of wood and is in the shape of a wave of water. The chairs ... they are the most comfortable restaurant chairs ever. Since you're going to spend at least 2 hours dining, comfy seats are a major plus. And the service is top-notch. *Applause*
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
For a special occasion, I highly recommend going with the omakase - the chef's tasting menu. Currently, there is a $120 and a $150 option. 

I usually get slightly anxious when I don't get to select my own food, but turns out anxiety is completely unwarranted at Morimoto. Every single course (of 8) was fantastic! There were many delicious items that were not on the regular menu, whether raw or cooked. We felt the $120 omakase was worth every dollar. 

Besides the ridiculously awesome tasting menus, Morimoto also has an a la carte menu, complemented by a beverage list consisting of signature cocktails, interesting Japanese beers, and various types of wine - though they also have a full bar available. While eating here is not cheap, Morimoto's a la carte prices are no greater than typical fine dining prices in Philly. 

Most recently, I had their duck duck duck dish, which consisted of the most tender and flavorful duck breast with the most amazing sauce, served with a side of duck confit fried rice, topped with a duck egg. The portioning was great: filling, but not overwhelming. It complemented well with my golden pear martini, which is very fruity and delicious. 

The tuna pizza appetizer was also a wonderful mixture of flavors and textures. It tasted so light and fresh. For dessert, I was torn between the black sesame mousse cake and the matcha tres leches. I ended up picking the matcha tres leches. It was very tasty, but once I left the restaurant, I began developing a strong craving for the black sesame mousse cake. 

Darn, I should have ordered both desserts. Looks like I will be here again soon to try the black sesame mousse cake.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
I finally went here for lunch during Japanese restaurant week to see if it lived up to the hype. Obviously as an avid fan of Iron Chef I hold such a place to the highest standard and expected perfection. While the overall meal was enjoyable, unfortunately nothing truly wow'ed me. Maybe there are menu items I missed out on but what I tasted seemed very standard to me.

We had the tuna pizza as an appetizer which was different. Tuna was obviously very fresh but the overall flavor was a bit on the bland side even though the anchovy sauce did complement it nicely. Our lunch sets came with house salad which was dressed nicely but nothing special and the miso soup was very flavorful, rarely do I enjoy tofu but this was super creamy.  The entrees included the Chirashi which had a nice assortment of fish, although I could have used some more and the sushi rice was perfectly sticky. I did enjoy the black sesame seeds which I had never had in Chirashi before. The other entrée was Tempura which was highlighted by the sweet potato. The trio of dipping sauces was also a nice addition although the red pepper one did not really go well with anything. 

Service was great, although I loathe the 8oz soda glasses that are filled to the brim with ice. Luckily it wasn't very busy so our waiter refilled mine promptly about 4 times. They have happy hour food deals so I will be back to check that out.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
We went to Morimoto for our second night's dinner. I've been to Morimoto in NYC, so I was expecting what to get and how good it would be, as I think it fit into the category, maybe slightly more than what I have expected. 

Compared to NYC one, it was much smaller, as it is only 1 floor (I guess), and it was much quieter. There was awkwardly located light in the middle of table, which made us little bit uncomfortable to share our dishes, but there was no way that we could remove it, so - whatever. 

As an appetizer, we got Toro Tartare and bone marrow spread (day's special) with ikura and shiso leaf pesto. The bone marrow was extremely delicious and the server was very attentive to get us extra baguette "before" we asked for - which we loved!

We ordered Uni Carbonara as our noodles dish, and we LOVED IT. Nowadays there are many places that have uni pastas, but this place had one of the best flavored dish - yet it was a little bit salty. 

As an entree, we had Duck Duck Duck, as it was highly recommended by the server. One of my party was a huge duck lover and she told me that their duck dish was better than one of NYC's upscale Michelin rated restaurant. 

We also ordered $60 of Chef's Combination of sushi, sashimi and rolls. It was "okay" I guess, but as Morimoto is not like a sushi-ya that only or highly focuses on classical sushi/sashimi, it was okay-leveled. But their tamago was exceptional delicious. Tamago that I've been looking for!

As desserts, because we didn't order too much of food (I GUESS HAHA), Yuzu Merigue Tart (which was too sweet for my guest - but she liked the freshness of yuzu and mango that brought), Matcha Tres Leches was extremely moist and deliciously sweet, and Black Sesame Moussecake, which was loved by all 3 of us and it had such a rich flavor in.

Overall, we loved the dinner as we were pretty much satisfied with most of our dishes and as the server reallyx100 friendly and approaching. I would visit this place again if I visit Philadelphia anytime soon but I will also often visit Morimoto in NYC.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
amazing sushi...absolutely the freshest ever.  the octopus appetizer was also melt in your mouth.  the oysters come with the sauce already on them which is my only negative.

drinks take FOREVER and it can be a little loud, but just go and relax - its worth it.  the changing lights really set the mood and the booths are super comfy.

and the desserts are delicious - they may sound a little crazy, but the chocolate pot d' creme and the black sesame chocolate cake rock.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Jumpin' Japanese junk food orgy are the first words that come to mind for this joint.

I have been meaning to catch one of these for months, but between kids, work, more work and kids, it just hadn't happened.  Until I caught up with them at Marathon Music Works for the "Extra Large" event.  Basically they had some guest chefs in from out of town, so I would say that this was not the standard Otaku South experience.

It couldn't have been a more beautiful day, and we tossed the kids in the car and headed on down to Germantown.  As we walked up around 4:45, they were still setting up the Yakitori grill outside, but good smells were already wafting out.  We asked the ironically mustachioed hipster bouncer how it all worked, and were guided to the ticket table.   For $36, we got tickets for myself, the wife and two kiddos, which isn't that bad, until you remember it is ramen.  

Things got a little zany when we got up to the ordering lines, partially because they had it set up so that you stood in line for the type of bowl you wanted,  Up for that night was:
-Smoked Duck Ramen w pickled duck tongue, cherry blossoms and slow egg
-Vegetarian Mazeman w black sesame, shiso, and salted pickled plum
-Spicy Tantanmen Ramen w chicken broth, sesame chili oil, ground pork and bean sprouts
-Tonkotsu Ramen w pork broth
-Kushiyaki skewers inc. chicken meatball, hanging tenderloin and pork belly

How could I not go for the duck?  I mean, it was right there!  Since the wife and kids are veg heads, they went for that option.  The lines were just a little confusing, just because after you ordered, you kind of had to stand off to the side, which made it seem as if you were standing in another line, and if you weren't assertive, people who ordered later could easily line jump.

Eventually we got it all together, and headed out to a table.  Lighting 100 was playing some great music, and there was plenty of seating.  Grabbed the wife and  a beer after waiting in line for 10 minutes behind some older butch chick who wanted to ask the MMW bartender what every fucking bottle booze was for her partner, who eventually just wanted a PBR.  Le sigh.  Another $10 for oat soda.

Then I dug in, only after noticing my kids had sesame ALL over their faces and were VERY happy - that's a win!  The wife was happy too!  As for mine, it was delicious!  The broth was like drinking confit and the cherry blossoms gave a great flavor.  And the tongues, oh the tongues.  Never had a duck tongue.  Kind of reminded me of a cross between an oyster and escargot with a delicious ducky flavor.  They will forever haunt my dreams.  Great bowl and perfect amount of noodles and WAIT!  No slow egg.  Bastards shorted me.

I couldn't stop there, I had to go back.  Since the previous bowl was from some NYC/Chicago folks, I decided I wanted to go back and try Ms Gavigan's offerings, the spicy ground pork bowl.  Had some trouble getting my bowl because of the line thing, and as I got it, I realized that you could customize it, as they were making them extra spicy for some - dammit, I love spicy.

I tucked in, and it was good!  The only bummer?  There were like a tablespoon of noodles for a ton of broth, and a crapload of sludgy sediment at the bottom of the bowl no matter how much I stirred.  Noodles were gone by bite three, leaving me to drink yummy broth.  Could have definitely used more noodles.  We packed it up after that, a happy and full family, just as it was starting to get crowded.  My only regret was missing the Yakitori offerings.

I would have given this a three star, but the great ambiance, cool venue, and happy family definitely bumped this up a notch.  Can't wait to try again and see how they are improving.
name: Otaku South Ramen
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Food, Ramen, Restaurants

text:
Life sucks when you realize that you start to count calories every time you look at your plate. I don't like to lose. The alternative for not crash at the dead end is to surrender my palate to someone who offers a better choice. I ceased my conflict at Rawk Star Cafe, a plant-based haven. 

Bring along your curiosity, this is not your average organic vegan cafe. This is rocket science. Their food is complicated, and believe it or not, it is also delicious. Very strange combination I tell yal. Let me enlighten you. 

Raw Burger Platter with Raw Slaw (9.95 +tax): quote, "Two seed burgers made with sunflower seeds, shitake mushroom, green cabbage, zucchini, carrots and select herbs - served between our dehydrated flat bread consisting of sunflower seeds, freshly ground flax seeds, black sesame seeds and coconut. Each burger is topped with house tahini mustard sauce along with organic baby lettuce, sliced tomato, cucumber and a dehydrated onion rings" end quote. 

Do you see what I mean, rocket science. No kidding. But don't worry, people who work there are good teachers! They let you try dressing samples, explain how they assemble their food and all these magical ingredients they add into the delightful energy smoothies. Portions are large and it worth every penny of yours. It is best to bring a friend with you. They do combo for everyone to sample the flavor. 

By the way, the word to describe that raw burger is, Crunchy.

Support the local business.
name: Rawk Star Cafe
categories: Vegan, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Food, Gluten-Free, Restaurants

text: Went in while there was a line, but got my order. The black sesame milk tea was amazing. I love that I could feel the little seeds so I know they put real sesame seeds.
name: Tea Do
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea, Food, Coffee & Tea

text:
Everyone at our table tried the $80 omakase (chef's selection, or a Japanese tasting menu) and every single dish was delicious. There was not a lot of sushi involved; so if you want to go the sushi route, you may want to order a la carte. There were some dishes where I felt the soy was a bit overpowering/too salty, but on the whole the meal was very satisfying. The second course was my favorite -- I loved the way the hamachi was marinated. For dessert, try to the black sesame mousse cake. Was it the best Japanese and sushi I've ever had? I'm not sure, but definitely worth a try.

Courses:
1. Toro tartare with caviar and fresh wasabi
2. Hamachi with ponzu and jalapeno
3. Sashimi salad with mixed greens, tuna tataki, shoyu dressing
4. Seared scallop with red miso glaze, marinated vegetables, rice, green tea dashi
5. Roasted duck breast with scallion pancake
6. Assortment of sushi
7. Cake with creme fraiche and peach compote

There was also a "course" that was more of an amuse bouche... it was in a shot glass and you were supposed to drink it, but it had more of a creamy texture than it was liquid.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text: Found a bug in my food and told them about it. They tried to convinced  me it's black sesame but black sesame don't have legs right? The bug I found and took a picture, clearly it had head and legs!
name: Kumo Asian Bistro
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants, Asian Fusion

text:
My significant other and I went to Morimoto on a Friday night (Oct. 30th) for a celebration dinner. We had a good - but not "blown away" - experience here. Let's talk first about the service: spot on, truly. Our server was a delight; very attentive (though not intrusive), knowledgeable and friendly. Kudos also goes to the bartender that night, as the drinks were FAB: I had the nashi blossom, and highly recommend this as it was ridiculously tasty. My partner had a gin-based drink that was mega strong, so he was very happy with the value! We also did the Morimoto tasting flights of beer - interesting, but a one-time thing just to see if you like any of the house brews. Of all 4, I wasn't so impressed and would really only order the soba ale again as a pint, perhaps. My advice: stick to the cocktails, they're great.

Now, the food. Our strategy was to order a bunch of small things to share, plus some sushi/sashimi/rolls. Here's an overview, in the order it arrived:

1 - Diver scallop ceviche: for me, this was a miss, and not a great way to open the experience. Definitely unlike any ceviche I've had, and not in a good way: the scallop was drowning in some sort of sauce that tasted like a watered-down thousand island dressing. Garnished with popped rice, which was interesting at least. Overall, I would say skip this.

2 - Whitefish carpaccio - HIT HIT HIT. Beautifully presented with an edible orchid garnish, the flavours, texture and colour of this dish were amazing. A bit heavy on the sesame oil, but I like it like that!

3 - Morimoto tempura - perfection, definitely get this. I was skeptical of the gorgonzola dipping sauce, but it ended up being the most delicious of the three. Perfectly crispy tempura coating tender-crisp veggies and juicy shrimp. Yum!

4 - Yose dofu - Interesting and fun, but needs improvement. It is served with a large quantity of a thick crab 'sauce' which is really more like a soup (actually, reminds me very strongly of chinese corn and crab egg-drop soup), so your dofu is swimming in this very milk soup-like sauce but you have NO spoon to enjoy it with. Also the quantity of the soup/sauce is enormous and it feels wasteful. I think this dish should be served with individual bowls and spoons for each diner to place some of the soup in the bottom, and then spoon the dofu over it. Fun for the novelty of being made at your table, but not a must-taste experience at all.

5 - Our selection of sushi/sashimi/rolls: we got the cucumber/shiso/ume roll (veggie), which was AMAZING. I love love love shiso and ume, and this combination with the juicy cucumber is so good. I wanted more!! We also got the otoro, which was fresh but so thinly sliced it seemed sort of stingy. Finally, a selection of seasonal fish served as sushi: greenling (THE BEST, very sweet and snappy, almost like a shrimp), barracuda (pretty good, strong fishy flavour like a mackerel almost, which i love), and grunt (just ok). All were very fresh and the rice was on point.

6 - Uni carbonara - SOOOOOOO GOOD. OMG. Definitely maxed out my sodium levels for the day (or possibly the week) but I don't even care!! Creamy and divine texture, with plenty of uni. Loved this, wanted more. It was like the ultimate version of a mentaiko pasta.

7 - For dessert: black sesame moussecake, and yuzu meringue: outstanding, both of them. The black sesame mousse was so richly flavourful without being too sweet, and the yuzu flavour was the perfect balance of sweet, tart and floral to end on.

Overall, I think that the food here is executed technically very well, but there are just some dishes that either don't work or don't really wow me - and so I can't give it a perfect score. Final verdict: will Morimoto take your tastes to new heights? Not quite. But is it delicious, and a good experience? Yes. You will have a *nice* dinner here. Recommended for a celebration splurge.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
I know I'm crazy, but if I was on death row, I'd want my last meal to be from here.
Sounds nutty from a guy who eats out practically every day at way-too-expensive to hole-in-the-wall joints in NYC, but I truly like the food here b/c it really reflects my 50/50 east/west personality in food form.

I've been here so many times to the point I've met Morimoto on several occasions and even have an autographed menu.  But it's not the star power that makes me like this place.  I really enjoy the fact the food here is tasty, well-balanced, well-priced and strikes that perfect mix of east and west.  

I've tried all versions of the omakase here and all of them have been more than satisfying.  But beyond that there are a couple of entrees that I've made a point of getting in my subsequent visits.  These are the seafood toban yaki and the steak.  The former is just a savory, satisfying seafood stew simmered in a sake based sauce.  The result is pure heaven (for me).  The broth is not overpowering and the quality of the seafood (as you would expect here) is absolutely top notch.  

As for the latter - the steak is honestly my favorite thing to eat.  Why would I love the steak here in favor of NYC icons like Peter Luger?  First off this is not the same kind of steak.  It would not be fair to compare a strip steak here with a porterhouse.  I just personally love the experience and the flavor of this dish, thanks to the perfectly charred and crusted meat, the subtle soy/wasabi dipping sauce that accompanies it.  The flavors blend so well, it almost tastes like you're eating a steak sushi.  It's just divine.  Add to that some tasty veggie tempura on the side and you have that rare, tasty fusion of east and west that so many other restaurants try hard to emulate, but fail in the execution.

The sushi here speaks for itself.  The fish is fresh and the specials are often excellent.  On our last visit, the Kazuo tuna was the featured fish (which really excited me since I don't often come across this type of tuna - usually it's your standard Maguro or Toro).  The texture of the fish was excellent - fresh with a hint of smokiness that gives this tuna its unique personality.  In addition I usually make a point of getting a few rolls - usually the eel, soft shell crab and conventional tuna (just so I can sample the freshness) - and they never disappoint.

I also make a point of ordering the Morimoto sashimi appetizer.  5 straightforward choices (Maguro, Tuna, Yellowtail, Salmon, Crab) with a side of 2 sauces.  Yes it's 25 bucks (which translates into 2.50 per tiny bite) but trust me, it's worth it.  The amazing textures and flavors at play here are worth the cost, which in the greater scheme of things isn't that much.  I can say the same food at inferior restaurants in NYC would often cost more than what you pay here.

As for dessert - I remember they used to have a TON of early issues due to the lack of a decent pastry chef.  In recent years that has changed and their desserts have improved infinitely.  I'm glad to see they have kept standards up - on our last visit we had the red bean/green tea tres leches which was one of the tastiest desserts I've had in a long time.  I also had the black sesame chocolate mousse cake which was excellent.  But the former is definitely a must try at your next visit (assuming it's still there).

All in all I love the place.  After eating there all these years, I"m glad to see they haven't lost a step.  In terms of the overall experience, price, quality and taste of the food, this place will remain my favorite place to eat until something else comes along.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Warning: my review and rating are for the Omakase experience. 

Drinks: Cilantro is a love/hate herb. If you love it like I do, order the Cilantro Gimlet and thank me later. The White Pear is a sweet drink for the ladies and was quite delicious. The Morimoto Hazelnut Ale brewed by Rogue Ales was also  good with a noticeable hazelnut aftertaste. For a really strong drink, go with the Morimoto Martini.

Food: Because it was a celebration, I decided to splurge on the $150pp Omakase. Overall, the food and quality were good but definitely not worth the price of admission.  At that price and for the $120pp price, I would much rather order 2 entrees, 1 cold appetizer and 1 hot appetizer because their regular menu has some delicious sound dishes. 

Now that you know how I feel about the Omakase. I'll give you a play by play of what I ate if you're still interested in trying it.
1) Toro (fatty tuna) Tartare with a light soy sauce and gold flakes
2) Three raw Japanese Oysters, each with a different topping
3) Hokkaido Scallop Carpaccio with Uni (sea urchin) on top
4) Five types of Sashimi (2 pieces for each type). Tuna, Amberjack, Yellowtail, Scallops, and I forgot the last one
5) Half of a Grilled Lobster
6) Wagyu Steak on a hot skillet (cook to your desired temperature by none other than you) served with a pesto sauce and a tomato puree
7) 5 pieces of Nigiri (sushi)
8) Goat Cheese Cake served with Peach Jelly and sprinkled with Black Sesame

I will definitely never order Omakase from Morimoto's again but I may someday return to order off the regular menu. I'm a sucker for Japanese inspired dishes and everything on the regular menu is making my mouth water right now.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
We decided to try the Japanese part of the restaurant for the first time in a few years. It was generally busy for the day prior to Thanksgiving. One of the owners seated us and was friendly and talkative. He recommended a few wines, but seemed put off when we opted for tea on the snowy eve. 

The tea was excellent and refilled. The steamed shrimp shumai were tasty and well prepared. The Grilled Chilean Sea Bass was cooked properly, but was a very undersized portion of fish which was disappointing. In comparison, the rare Black Sesame tuna was a large portion and literally out of this world good. 

To finish the meal we had Creme Brûlée and Berries, which again exceeded expectations. 

Overall, highly recommend for Japanese in Wayne now that Hana is no more.
name: Margaret Kuo's Wayne
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants, Chinese

text:
What's that ? Would I like quinioa in my veggie bowl ? this is a fast food restaurant , right ? 

DAMN straight! excellent veg  and non veg options to suit the entire family. 
If there was a CBW back east I'd probably eat there 3x a week. quick excellent service, plenty of choices , and actually healthy fast food. Whoda thunk it was possible in the sea of generica fast food choices. Try some of the black sesame seed and sea salt sprinkle on your favorite bowl!
name: Crazy Bowls & Wraps
categories: Vegetarian, American (New), Fast Food, Salad, Restaurants, Wraps

text:
My boyfriend and I came here he other night for my birthday. This was the first time i've ever eaten at a restaurant owner by a celebrity chef. Unfortunately he wasn't there but the service we top notch. I wish I remembered our server's name but right now i'm drawing a blank. He was very polite and answered all the questions I had about the menu. We started out with an appetizer and drinks. We order the dumplings and I got the Morimoto martini. My boyfriend ordered the signature beer flight. You got 5 dumplings in the order and they had a lot of flavor. The dumplings were a little slippery to pick up with chopsticks but i eventually got the hang of it. 

For entrees I ordered the Morimoto surf and turf (medium rare) and my boyfriend ordered the duck, duck, duck (medium rare). We were told the duck was a popular item on the menu. With our entrees our server recommended a white wine to pair with the duck. I was still sipping on my very strong martini so I didn't get a another drink. The wine my boyfriend got was tasty, I ended up stealing a sip. The surf and turf was delicious. A kobe sirloin cooked perfect, Hamachi ribbons on top of avocado salad, and herbed potatoes. I would've never thought to pair raw fish with essentially guacamole but it was good. At first I was reluctant to try the duck, i've had it other places and it was gross. After a few offers I took a small piece and it was not like the duck i've had before. It was tender and had great flavor, also not too fatty. It came with confit fried rice with a duck egg atop. 

For dessert we ordered a black sesame mousse cake. It was a flourless chocolate cake with goma mousse and dark chocolate ganache. It was very rich maybe too rich for one person but we split it. 
 
Parking is very limited on Chestnut street but there is a parking garage around the corner. Weekend parking was only $12. Its pricey but that's to be expected. The atmosphere is modern and i'd recommend not wearing your ripped jeans and tee shirts. They can get busy on a saturday night so make reservations. 

Next time I go I will be adventurous and try the sushi entrees.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
The authentic dim sum experience!!! The food is always seasoned well and service is above average for a dimsum place. We went there for the second time on Christmas Day with some family and they easily believed that this was one of the best dimsum they have ever had. 

Chicken Feet- a must if you're coming to a dimsum place. It is a YUM!

Congee with pork and preserved black egg- Sounds weird but is very common to eat at a Cantonese Dimsum Restaurant. Make sure to get the sliced green onions on top and ask for an extra little bowl or two to share.

Shrimp dumpling- yes yes and yes. 

Noodle stirfry- looks like ramen noodles stir fried but it is so addictive.

Fried Silver Fish (Ba Fan Yu?) -i am not sure what it is for sure but it is so good.

Black Sesame Roll- odd but worth a try once in your life.

Pork and Shrimp Shumai- It's not bad but far from my favorite.
name: Ocean Harbor
categories: Restaurants, Chinese, Dim Sum, Seafood

text: You enter, and Dana is there to assist with a huge smile and that wonderful personality.  You know the one, the personality that makes you feel at home and part of the family.  You can tell she runs a tight but friendly ship as everything just falls into place beautifully.  Lockeland Table is NOT a large place, quite the contrary, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in food and gracious staff.  Our plan was to sit at the bar, yet only one seat available and two of us.  No worries, there is a pizza bar in the back where you can sit and watch the pizzaiolo practice his craft.  If you can't take the heat get out of the kitchen...literally as the pizza oven is right next to the kitchen and it's a very warm place to sit.  Matt was our server and couldn't have been more helpful, considering he had almost half the restaurant he was also serving.  We tend to "graze" more than eat large meals, so we started with three cheeses, my favorite being the camembert, along with the dinosaur sized bone marrow (smoked certified Hereford bone marrow).   I will say that I wasn't terribly fond of the smokiness on the bone marrow or bread, but the marrow itself was incredibly unctuous and plentiful, hence the dinosaur reference.  My husband was drinking an IPA while I was drinking the lavender lemon drop, which was refreshing and very good.  Time for our next and last course, the pork and shrimp dumplings, with a sweet sauce they call Ninja sauce and black sesame seeds.  The dumplings were so tasty and while there are only four to an order, they are very rich and filling.  Next time I'll get the sauce on the side however as it was a tad too sweet for me.  My husband ordered the red Thai curry steamed PEI mussels, which were rich, creamy, spicy and damn good, lol.  Again, not so crazy about all the smokiness as it's just not our thing, so you may want to order non-toasted bread if the smoke isn't your thing too.  I finished our meal with a chocolate martini for dessert...not too sweet and not too alcoholly (is that a word? Lol).  Regardless of our dislike for the smoke in some of their dishes, the experience was pleasant, welcoming and we'll be back to try other dishes very soon.  Lastly, the parking is a bit of an issue as you need to park on the street, but we arrived early enough in the evening and didn't have a problem finding a spot. Call to make a reservation as again it's a quaint restaurant and fills up quickly!  Come visit the folks at Lockeland as they'll take great care of you as they did us!
name: Lockeland Table
categories: American (Traditional), Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Jay's is great. The selection is huge, the produce is decent and everything is surprisingly inexpensive. If you ever want to buy anything remotely foreign, go buy it here. Example: a tiny jar of sesame seeds sells for ~$4 at Schnucks while Jay's carries both white and black sesame seeds for 1/8 of the price. Same with olive oil. And their SPICES! You won't recognize 75% of what they sell, and the pricetag will be missing, and the label will absolutely not be in English, but they are cheap and good. I will never again buy any spice from Schnucks. (Maybe from the Soulard Spice Market.)

I would like Jays better if they had a more reasonable smell and better frozen food selection, but I'll take what I can get. Oh, and sometimes a girl just wants to buy enough rice for less than 100 meals. (Although I do think they have smaller bags in the back somewhere...) Overall thumbs up.
name: Jay International Food Co
categories: Specialty Food, Food, Ethnic Food, Wholesale Stores, Fruits & Veggies, Meat Shops, Shopping, Grocery, International Grocery

text: Whole foods is over priced, I went in to look for sesame seeds for my seared tuna recipe and they didn't have black sesame seeds for cheaper the $8! It's too fancy for me and there seems like they have no normal products, not a fan at all. I'm not a rich health freak so that might be the problem.
name: Whole Foods Market
categories: Organic Stores, Grocery, Food, Specialty Food, Health Markets

text: I found this new super cute & inviting clean, cutely decorated Pink & White place on the edge of the trendy, ever-growing Funk Zone thanks to Yelp!!  It was lunchtime on a Sunday & I to eat something I craved!  It seems like every time I go to Santa Barbara which is pretty often, there's one or two new places to eat!   By the looks of the pics on this site from my fellow Yelpers & the great reviews, I thought I found just the place annnnnd, it was brand new! Open for only 2 months.  Of course I hadn't eaten all day and I was starving!  The thing about me is I rather not eat anything at all if I can't eat something that I exactly CRAVE at the moment! And I craved Asian fusion!  Tyger Tyger, according to Yelp looked exactly like my respite & it is right off of the 101 FWY, even better! I was driving up the Central Coast food shopping every Farmers Market & Gourmet store from Hollywood through SB & SLO County for a Thanksgiving gig I'm catering in Big Sur from LA (my first hometown) back to my newest hometown, Cambria, I had to stop in Santa Barbara, my last hometown of 6 years, (also half way home).  I parked in the adjoining lot and saw some happy customers seated outside devouring & sharing their colorful & fresh looking Eats, I couldn't wait to get in the door!  Luckily I made it in between rushes.  I had anticipated ordering the Bahn Mi Sandwich at first- that's what I actually typed in Yelp Search , then according to the rave reviews on Yelp, couldn't decide between the Crispy Rice Salad w/seared albacore & the Weeping Brisket Salad...  I ended up ordering the the Northern Thai Pork Curried Noodle & a Hibiscus Iced Tea.  They serve great local wine & beer on tap too by the way!  The service was friendly & the entire staff was smiling!  The good Energy of this place made me happy and  I sat at the first stool next to the now, busy entrance.  While waiting for my food to arrive I went over to Monkey Shine, a super California & NY/Vegas FOOD (as in Momofuku's Milk Bar, etc.) trend soft-serve Asian ice cream bar (w/vegan options) This is in the opposite corner, all within the same space (room) that also includes a Coffee Roasting facility & a Tea  bar.  Monkey Shine serves flavors like Toasted Rice & Thai Spiced Chocolate, Ginger & Black Sesame, w/several choices of toppings served in a pressed lucky fish  shaped cone &/or Chinese little to-go box.  I tasted the toasted rice & the black sesame, both were delicious  and not at all too sweet, a lot like the stuff they serve at the new super trendy milk cake/"crack pie" etc., "Milk," on Melrose I had just sampled 2 days before. All in all Tyger Tyger I give a big !  Bravo  Chef Daniel Palaima! You hit it on point! I cannot wait to revisit this place w/friends & try everything!
name: Tyger Tyger
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion

text:
So glad I found another bubble tea shop in town because STL is so lacking... The decor inside is very cute and modern-looking and the staff was super friendly!Their milk teas were spot on in flavor and not sickeningly sweet. My friend got an Oreo milk tea at 50% sweetness with boba and I got black sesame milk tea at 75% with herb jelly and we were both very satisfied with them! Even though we went close to their closing time, a little after 8pm, their boba still tasted fresh. I've been to a lot of places where the boba tastes old and kind of hard close to closing. 

I also thought the price was good for the quality and quantity. I liked that they blended actual black sesame seeds in my drink instead of wimping out with a powder or something. It's one size and my drink was under $5 with no extra charge for boba, unless you want to add an additional topping for 0.50. It's not the best milk tea I've ever had, but it will be my go-to while I'm in the STL area.
name: Share Sweet
categories: Desserts, Food

text:
Started out the evening with a glass of sparkling ume (plum wine). It came in a cute flute and had a drop of actual ume on the bottom. The glass itself was insanely small, but I did manage to get slightly tipsy off it since I downed the whole thing before dinner started. It was happy hour, so it was a little cheaper than expected.

I started my meal with the appetizer-sized soba carbonara, which was quite delicious, though distinctly very non-Japanese. This is to be expected from Morimoto, whose specialty is Japanese-fusion. I really love the flavor and texture of soba noodles, and the sauce really sticks to it quite well. And you definitely can't go wrong with bacon. It could have done without the edamame, and perhaps they should have given me a fork for that dish to help eat them, but I can't complain. The entire bowl costs as much as a single piece of oh-toro.

My sushi selection was basically a dream team of expensive stuff I've been wanting to try for years now. The oh-toro costs twice as much as the others, but it was definitely the best. It's extremely fatty and gives the tuna a cloudy appearance compared to regular maguro. The taste is exquisitely buttery and had to be the best piece of sushi I've ever eaten in my life. The shima aji (striped jackfish) was also extremely good. It's not a fish you will find at most restaurants, but Morimoto claimed on Iron Chef it is one of the best types of fish for sushi, so I had to try it. I wasn't disappointed. The anago, I got on a friend's recommendation. It is sea eel (as opposed to unagi, which is fresh water) and possesses the same fatty characteristics of unagi. It was not as charred as unagi usually is and it lacked a sauce. It makes any comparison difficult to make, but it was tasty. I'm just not sure if I would order it again under the same circumstances. I'd be willing to try it one more time if it were prepared more closely to unagi because I really love that eel sauce. Lastly, the uni, I had to try since so many people hyped it. It was good, but nothing to write home about. It was slightly sweet with a kick of saltiness at the end. It was tasty, but I definitely prefer the taste and texture of raw fish.

For the entrees, I tried some of my cousin's angry chicken. It tasted extremely Indian, and we think the sauce is similar to tandoori. I didn't try the noodles or the giant red chili peppers that my cousin was munching on. I don't think I liked his entree much, but again, it might be better with the rice noodles and the chili peppers.

My entree was wild sea bass with black bean sauce. It was a bit disappointing for me. The black bean sauce was overwhelming on the sea bass. It was way saltier than the stuff I'm used to in Chinese cuisine. By contrast, the sake sauce was extraordinarily light and loaned itself quite well to the delicate flavors of the sea bass. The fish itself wasn't particularly special. I was hoping for some giant lumps of fish fat, but the entire filet was completely lean. What a disappointment. My friend completely cleaned off his plate and even eat up all the sauce with the leftover rice. He really loved it. Personally, I would skip the entrees here and just go for the sushi.

The desserts were both really awesome. My friend's dessert was a delicious sesame mousse cake. The mousse was made from black sesame and was quite silky smooth. Its relatively light flavor contrasted well with the thin layer of chocolate cake on the bottom and the soft chocolate ganache layer on the outside. The presentation of it was also beautiful. I didn't get to try the little cookie on the top, but oh well haha. The dessert I split with my cousin was fantastic. As good as the mousse cake was, the green tea trio (matcha tres leches) was even better. The little cracker on the top was infused with massive amounts of green tea flavor. The ice cream was really light and had the taste of honey. I've never had honey ice cream before, but now I will always crave some. The ice cream contrasted really well with the bit of green tea cake on the bottom. The cake was super moist and had the texture of a piece of bread soaked in way too much syrup. Green tea flavor was bursting out of every single bite. I am guessing that the cake must have been soaked in some kind of strong green tea syrup. It was amazing. 

All-in-all the food was pretty good. The sushi was top-notch and well-sized. The appetizer soba was excellent, though I think next time I go (if I ever go again) I will skip the entrees and either go straight sushi, or get a bigger bowl of noodles. The desserts were a nice finish. My meal cost me ~$90 (w/ tax and tip) even with the discount. I can't say it was worth it, but it was definitely an experience. Go big or go home. I doubt my cousin and my friend enjoyed themselves as much as I did, since they pretty much only had entrees... which to me was the least enjoyable portion of the meal. They said I should have gotten omakase, but meh. Maybe next time.

-C
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Having watched Morimoto cooked on Iron Chef years ago, I knew that going to Morimoto would be a delightful dining experience for me.  My friend enjoyed his experience at Morimoto in NYC, so we decided to check out the Philly 'branch.'

My dining experience was just as I have expected.  The restaurant is incredibly chic with minimalistic and modern decor (wavy ceilings with protruded walls and simple tables).  The hosts were welcoming, and our server was attentive.

The food, of course, was incredible!  Started with Shigoku oysters garnished with 3 different 'sauces' (Thai fish sauce, ceviche, and a Japanese-based sauce).  The oysters were meaty and fresh.  I got the lobster ceviche salad; the lobster was done two ways (poached and served ceviche-styled).  Every part of the salad from the seafood to the greens was savory.  Then got the soba carbonara.  While I am not too keen on fusion food, it was delicious.  The flavors all went well together, and it was just easy to eat it very fast because it was so good.  Finally, I got the black sesame (love love love it!) moussecake, and that was divine!

My friend had the dobin mushi (soup with chicken, shrimp, and mushroom), and he said it was great and simple.  Followed by the "Duck Duck Duck."  Duck breast, duck egg, and duck fried rice.  Not a big fan of duck, the duck was cooked soooo nicely that I asked for another piece of duck after trying it the first time.

I had the Lotus Blossom (gin, yuzu, and calpico), and my friend tried the Morimoto Soba Ale.  I like my drink, and my friend said his was quite easy to drink.

I only gave this place 4 stars because it is not a place that I can dine often (or even seldom) as it is a pricey place!  But if there is a special occasion and want to eat upscale fine Japanese food in Philly, then this is the place to go.  You won't be disappointed.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Super fresh, ultra hip, uniquely perfect!  I couldn't have dreamed up a better donut!

Check these guys out at both the downtown & 124 street Farmer's Markets!  Personally, I'm hoping to see them at the St. Albert Farmer's Market this summer!

Their strawberry wasabi with black sesame seeds sprinkled on top were a show stealer - sweet with a hint of spicy!  The raspberry hibiscus was simply divine and fit for a Princess tea party.  They use hibiscus tea and you may just find little flecks within the donut - heavenly!

And a little birdie told me they do a killer bacon one ;-)

I highly recommend you consider Moonshine Doughnuts for your next party or office meeting!  Can you imagine the surprise on your coworkers' faces when they get to choose between their uniquely and perfectly crafted creations?!?  I'm thinking baby showers, corporate events, birthday parties... it's endless!

I'm definitely looking forward to seeing Matt & Simon again soon to try out their latest culinary creation!
name: Moonshine Doughnuts
categories: Food Stands, Event Planning & Services, Donuts, Restaurants, Food

text:
Stopped by here after dinner at Aqua.  I'm a huge fan of the Iron Chef show and I've seen the food channel special when Chef Morimoto was building this place. After dinner, we figured we would get some sake and maybe some dessert.

But going to Morimoto and not trying the sushi didn't seem right. So we ordered the sashimi appetizer to share. It was the freshest and tasiest sushi I've had in a long time. I think I will have to come back here later in the week for dinner so I can pig out.
To accompany the sushi, I had one of the morimoto brand beers. It was ok, I didn't like it that much. 
Then I had dessert, I split the black sesame moussecake and morimoto brownies.  As you can see in the pictures, they looked too good to eat, but I had to eat them.  Good, but not great.
The ambiance was definitely 4 stars and the staff was definitely 5 stars!
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
To start our dinner we ordered Edamame. My husband ordered Rock Shrimp Tempura it was huge portion 4 ppl can it them.
My 3rd time dining here. I ordered 2 eel bbq sashimi and dragon roll.

for desert I had the Black sesame mousse cake- it was ok but not really a fan of it I wish I ordered the match tres leches.

But over all the menu stayed somewhat the same after they first opened.

I really want to try is their pork belly ramen which is only served for lunch. I called and asked if I can order it for dinner but they said NO. I thought they could accommodate but I guess I was wrong. If you are a constant customer I think it's ok if they kinda accommodate me! after all it's there in the kitchen with all the ingredients. I know it's full house but one pork belly ramen wouldn't throw their service off!!
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text:
Four of us had lunch here recently and it was quite good.

One friend and I had the "Black & Bleu" burger, described as:
"Cajun coated and topped with crumbled bleu cheese, lettuce, tomato and
red onion. $9.99." 

Patrons are given a few choices as a side-dish, soup, salad or "twigs" (their code for French fries). I had the sweet potato fries, which were tasty but, perhaps, a little dry. 

Alas, I did not specify how I wanted the burger cooked. So, it was served a teensy overcooked for my taste but, again, I did not order it as medium-rare as I do usually. That's "My bad."

Another friend had the "C.B.L.T.A.", which has the following description:
"It sounds like a government agency but it's actually a delicious sandwich made with
chipotle bacon, lettuce, fresh sliced tomato, chipotle mayonnaise, and sliced avocado
served on classic white bread. $9.49." 

She had her C.B.L.T.A. served on sourdough bread, enjoyed it very much, and also had a mix of the "regular" French fries and sweet potato fries -- one of the side-dish options.

The fourth dish served was from the "Raw Sushi" side of the house, a Maki roll, the "California Roll."
The description for that: "Chilean rock crab, avocado, and toasted black sesame seeds. $8.00."

The place was busy at lunchtime. We had to wait at the bar for a few minutes to get a table. Meanwhile, the waiter took our drink orders and we were quickly seated. The service was friendly and efficient.

Seating is a mix of traditional tables, bar seating and booths at the rear of the restaurant. There is also outdoor seating (too cold outside the day we were there).

The décor is simple but pleasant, complete with exposed air conditioning ducts overhead. (I'm kinda "done" with that look, but it works.)

For now, I'm giving Willowcreek Grill Four Stars and may "upgrade" my rating after another meal or two there, but it will probably never make it to a "full" Five Stars; it just misses the Five Star threshold. 

I'm certainly going to return; I kinda like the place.
name: Willowcreek Grill & Raw Sushi Restaurant
categories: American (New), Food, Restaurants, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, American (Traditional), Sports Bars, Coffee & Tea, Bars

text: Located next to Chifa, Morimoto is giving Jose Garces a run for his money. Unlike most restaurants, Morimoto is not dimly lit, and you can actually see the person sitting across from you. Although, there is an awkwardly placed artificial candle/light at the center of the table that can't be moved. As a result, shared dishes have to be put near the edge of the table and diners can't look at each other without being blinded by the light. The food, on the other hand, is enough reason to return. We started off with the 10 hour pork 'kakuni' - a braised pork belly served with hot rice porridge. The pork belly was cooked perfectly, with the meat flaky and the fat pure decadence. Next up was the angry chicken - a nicely marinated organic half chicken with roasted finger peppers and spiced chicken jus. The chicken was cooked just right, moist and tender without being overwhelmed by the sauce. Then there was the kobe beef ishi yaki bop - a rice dish prepared tableside in a hot river stone bowl. The kobe beef cooked evenly to medium-rare, and the flavors blended in a perfect fusion. Finally, the deserts. First came the black sesame moussecake - a silky smooth cake with layers of goma mousse, sea salt mousse, flourless chocolate cake, and dark chocolate ganache. Each bite was a bite of heaven. Then there was the irish coffee jelly parfait made up of coffee jelly, coconut sorbet, suntory 12 year yamazaki, and a dash of cinnamon. There really aren't that many words to describe this - you'll just have to go and find out.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text: Always a great choice when you're looking for a hybrid of fast food and a sit-down restaurant. The staff is incredibly friendly and the food puts Noodles and Company far ahead of their competition. I suggest the Japanese pan noodles with beef. On occasion, this particular dish can be heavy on the sprouts and black sesame. I suggest asking for light sprouts for a more balanced flavor. Overall, great food and service.
name: Noodles & Company
categories: Comfort Food, Italian, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Fast Food, Chinese

text:
Yelp gave me a notification to try this place and the photos looked really good so I went. 

Considering that I am Vietnamese I was pretty excited to learn of a new Vietnamese fusion food place. The location is pretty much in the heart of the funk zone. The pink lanterns are definitely an eye catcher. The restaurant was designed kind of the poorly. They were going for the communal feel which I appreciate but the use of space could have been a lot better. You order your food first and then you find a table. The line for the desert was also right in front of a door so that was strange. 

I went with a friend and we got the beef brisket, chicken something noodle soup (I forgot the name) and the chicken wings. It was about $55 for three dishes, which even for Santa Barbara was extremely expensive. The portions were super small as well. 

The beef brisket: the salad that comes with it is amazing! Most of the beef pieces we had were mostly fat and there was very few of it. The sticky rice was good and came in a fun little woven basket. 

The chicken noodle soup dish: I would definitely not recommend. The broth was really bland and the portion was that of a kids meal. It tasted more like a watered down pho and had two small chunks of meat. 

The chicken wings: of all the things we ate I would actually recommend this dish. The sauce was amazing and the chicken wings were large pieces fried to perfection. For the price it was worth it and I would recommend! 

For dessert we tried their ice cream and the black sesame ice cream in the cone was perfect to end the meal. The only problem I had here was the sanitary concern of the cashier handling money and touching tons of things and then using her bare hands to grab my ice cream cone to fill it. 

All in all I think this place will do well but for any Asian native you will probably be disappointed. The price is really High so if you're on a budget I would not recommend unless you can splurge on a meal. I also saw my neighbor order the banh xeo and it was quite comical that the menu said it was meant for 2-4 people to share ONE banh xeo. It also cost $22?!! That is just absurd. In any normal Vietnamese restaurant a single person consumes 2-3 of those alone and they only cost about $8 for multiple banh xeo. 


Things I saw that looked good: the banh mi sandwich looked really hearty and I might come back just to try that.
name: Tyger Tyger
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion

text:
Really delicious. Clean, tasteful atmosphere with a great smooth vibe! 

Super friendly staff! We were seated promptly and ordered pork belly and sheimp spring rolls to share. Then my friends ordered pho and pork belly vermicelli. I had the special. It was an incredibly spicy chicken over cd vermicelli. Lots of fresh herbs, cucumber, and pepper. So delicious! 

We ended the meal with three desserts. Ginger ice cream sammys (deeeeeelish), a sponge cake with ice cream and fresh strawberries (nice and fresh), and salted caramel chocolate torte, topped with chocolate ice. Ream and cashews with black sesame seeds. All tjree were amazing!

Prompt, friendly service, delicious food, wonderful experience! Highly recommended!
name: Mopho
categories: Restaurants, Cocktail Bars, Vietnamese, American (New), Wine Bars, Gastropubs, Asian Fusion, Nightlife, Bubble Tea, Bars, Food

text:
I've come here a few times and this is my official fav place in Chinatown for bubble tea.  It has more of a clean tea taste compared to Kung Fu or Vivi.  I like the jasmine milk tea.  You can tailor the ice and sweetness to your preference.  The black sesame is good too but I recommend less sweet.  Bubbles are included.

They also serve some snacks that are reasonably priced.  Jenga is also around so groups can distract themselves.  The only negative about this place is no loyalty card and sometimes the lines are a bit outta control and disorderly.
name: Tea Do
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea, Food, Coffee & Tea

text:
I tried Bar Otaku last night with a friend for snacks/light dinner after we'd done happy hour at Gertie's Bar. My friend got a beer, and I had a 4.5 oz serving of an unfiltered sake. (I also ordered a green tea, which I assumed would be hot green tea, but was Ito En bottled unsweetened green tea. Maybe I just didn't read the menu clearly, but it wasn't what I was expecting!) The sake was very good. 

For food, we tried a few things. My friend got the tuna handroll (with cucumber and yuzu shallot), and I got the hamachi handroll (yellowtail, jalapeno, shiso, and ginger). My friend liked her handroll (I didn't try it), and I really did like the hamachi handroll. It was among the best things we tried, but at $6 for three bites, it's a little pricey. I also ordered the okonomiyaki (a cabbage pancake with mayo, "bulldog sauce," and bonito flakes), which I wasn't really a fan of. While the pancake was seared, it was MUSH. I'm used to being able to pick up a slice of the pancake with chopsticks, but this okonomiyaki fell apart when you touched it. The flavor was fine, but the texture wasn't what I was expecting and it wasn't very pleasant. My friend ordered the sweet potatoes (with shoyu honey and black sesame), which were well cooked but a little too sweet for my taste.  Our waitress brought us an order of chicken (boneless thigh, kewpie mayo, and lemon wedge) on the house, which was so nice, and it was one of the highlights of the night for us! Well cooked, salty fried chicken bites with a delicious mayo! I'd order that again for sure! 

The service was great, and the restaurant is pretty cool looking (it's definitely extremely dark given the black walls, and I did miss the Little Octopus decor a bit). But I just wasn't wowed by the food enough that I'll rush back. Definitely not a bad meal or experience though.
name: Bar Otaku
categories: Izakaya, Tapas/Small Plates, Japanese, Sushi Bars, Bars, Beer Bar, Nightlife, Restaurants

text:
This store has great selection of veggies , fish and many noodles for all the Thai cooking
The store also has an aloe drink we all like that is natural from Vietnam , stocked up on that.
Huge selection of fish that comes in fresh on Friday.
I get all my vegetables here because they are fresher in the plastic bags and stay well in home fridge.
Bags of sweet rolled jackfruit with black sesame cookies area weakness , and here I find lots of other flavors.
The separate section has a good selection of cooking and serving bowls and spoons.
I got a beautiful floor mat for the lanai.
name: Lien Hoa Oriental Market
categories: Vietnamese, Home Services, Grocery, Restaurants, Real Estate, Food, Homeowner Association, International Grocery

text:
Literally a hole in the wall that needs some extra loving as it is ranked as one of Indy's best Chinese restaurant on MSN. My husband comes home like a town crier with the news. It left me a bit surprised that this nook made it onto the list. Asian Snack is as close to street side dining in China right smack dab inside Saraga. There's a small booth rental with a very small sit down area to eat. Afterwards, you can go treasure hunting in the supermarket full of ethnic finds.

We were lucky to trudge into a big crowd, and it was almost impossible to push a shopping cart in, let alone stand there without being bumped. I'm sure you'd get trampled if you fell over....Then again, I always go there on a weekend and it's packed, literally feeling like a can of sardines. So be brave and fight the Saraga crowd to try this place out.

History lesson 101: Where this "Asian Cuisine's stall" specializes in is from this port city in northeastern China (Tianjin), which is very well known for making flaky pastries, scallion pancake pockets, and noodles for their meal instead of rice being their primary staple like in other regions of China and Asia altogether. I could smell the fragrant aroma as I was at the counter looking at the menu.cThe lady at the counter speaks minimal English but they have a picture menu board as well as a menu with English translations. Just point to what you want and she'll write down the order.
 
A man at the opposite corner was making a crispy egg crepe-like pancake (aka Jian Bing Guo Zi) stuffed with fried dough sticks, slathered with spicy sauce, topped with scallions and sesame seeds. I HAD TO TRY THIS AT LEAST ONCE. It's quite entertaining to watch him make it (as I was filming). That Jian Bing was so enormous that we had to take it home to reheat as a snack. I must say, it was crunchy and had a very unique texture and flavor. They also made flaky cake like pastries stuffed with taro, black sesame, or red bean from scratch. We bought a black sesame and red bean filled mini cake and a Chinese hamburger "Rou ma jio" to-go. The mini cakes remind me of a "moon cake" since it's dense, but it has a wonderful flaky dough. They don't have mutton hamburgers, but the pork as amazingly juicy with the perfect amount of spice. I saw a couple of young college students get a bowl of the beef noodles, which looked spectacular. Next time we come back, we'll be dining in and trying something new.
name: Asian Snack
categories: Asian Fusion, Seafood, Fast Food, Restaurants, Chinese

text: First time dining here.. It was one of the last beautiful days in October,so I chose to dine outside. A nice patio dining space enclosed by planter boxes. I was greeted by the owner, very nice, both her and the wait person. I looked though the menu and spotted the Tuna Tartare. I had overheard a nearby table raving about it ,so it was a must try. I had been craving Fish and Chips so I ordered that as my entree. The tuna Tartare arrived, a round molded piece of art topped with a quail egg, black sesame seeds and a wonderful wasabi sauce on the plate served with fried wontons for piling on the tuna. It was so, so delicious. I don't know all the ingredients mixed within the Tartare, but I could have had just that and a cocktail and been very happy.. The Fish and Chips arrived crispy with thin cut fries which were crispy and nicely seasoned. The Fish was Cod and with two generous pieces . Two comments: I love steak fries with fish and chips and the raw quail looked nice on the Tartare but didn't appeal to me. But that's personal taste.. However it was a lovely meal on a lovely day.. Much success to Finbar.
name: Finbar
categories: Nightlife, Wine Bars, Bars, Seafood, Restaurants

text:
About 2 weeks ago, we stopped by the Rooster & the Till for dinner. It was my first time there and it did not disappoint. 

We started with the tofu dumplings for our appetizer. They had great flavor, texture, and the flavor combos worked well. For our main dishes we went with the birria lamb neck quesadilla and the short rib gnocchi. The lamb neck quesadilla was very good. It had a nice rich flavor and was not gamey in the least. The short rib gnocchi were phenomenal. The pickled peppers worked so well with the richness of the short rib. The gnocchi literally melted in our mouth. It was incredible. For dessert I decided to go with the mochi donuts over coconut custard, strawberry yuzu, and five spice caramel. My girlfriend decided to get the black sesame ice cream with pineapple coconut jam, Thai tea caramel, and toasted milk. Both of the desserts were outstanding, but we both loved the mochi donut dish a bit more. 

Overall, we enjoyed our meal. The food was on point as was the service.  We will definitely be back in the near future to check out the ever changing menu.
name: Rooster & the Till
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Very sad that I did not try this place sooner. It has instantly engraved itself into a piece of my Heart. I must say there are about a handful of tampa restaurants I can truly say is unique, flavorful and something you would be unable to get anywhere else and rooster and the till fits that bill.

The restaurant itself is very small and intimate with an open kitchen in the middle of the dining area. Thus as soon as you walk in - you will immediately smell all the goodness coming from that kitchen. The menu had both small and large plates but they are all share able and def recommend getting 2 small and 2 larges to split with two people! For the small plates - the scallop crudo stood out over the others. It is raw scallop over a cashew milk gremolata with black sesame and fried chive flowers - amazing ! Another favorite was the schezuan shrimp - head on shrimp with fried oats and green beans. Pasta was also very fresh and delicious! Lastly the highlight of my meal was the rendition of the banana pudding - thai basil, macadamia butterscotch crunch, tapioca and topped with matcha foam! My favorite 

Thank you rooster and the till for reminding me what Tampas food scene should be about! Delicious meal with great flavors!
name: Rooster & the Till
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Not sure where to begin: with the five plates we tried, the killer service, or the ambience and beauty of the restaurant. 


1. Food 

For starters, the oysters on special were St. James and Blue Point from the Atlantic northeast. I am already biased toward oysters, but my esteemed dining companion -- and overall favorite person ("FP") is an admittedly "inexperienced" oyster-eater and ate them with me: very high praise. They were prepared with diced green apple, black sesame, and wasabi; we both wished for more of a spicy kick, but they were delicious nonetheless. 

Next we tried the peel and eat shrimp appetizer with hot sauce and lime juice. These shrimp were the largest I had ever seen, and they were prepared simply with a Cajun-ish spice. Says FP, "They were prepared simply and were not trying to be anything besides what they were." Agreed! We also got our hands very messy eating these giant sssssseashrimp, which is where I'd like to mention our impressively attentive server, Angel. He commended our peeling skills and brought extra napkins without prompting. 

We continued to get our hands dirty later in the meal, but the next course was the gnocchi with pickled pepperoncini, smoked ricotta, and short ribs. According to Angel, this is a staple on the menu and a must-try for any visit. The RtT gnocchi is not made of potato, but of cloud. (Just kidding.) It is lighter than most gnocchi and in an extremely flavorful sauce. It can be made vegetarian as well. FP says, "The pickled peppers were pleasantly prepared" (alliteration mine) "and the ricotta created a [expletive] deliciously creamy sauce."

Let's talk about the five-spiced quail now. FP's going to take over because this was his favorite part: the base was like Tom Yum soup, a glorious mix of coconut milk and droplets of some fat (quail? Butter? Don't know, don't care); compressed kohlrabi; lime leaves; and banjo* string chili strands rounded out some perfectly cooked quail wings. They were crispy, spicy, coco nutty. We *may* have drank the broth. 

*mandoline, probably, but banjo actually works better here!

Finally, our last dish was something vegetarian of which I cannot remember the name, but it contained tender and cubed butternut squash, chewy onion pakora, crunchy puffed rice, and creamy tahini yogurt sauce. These textures were varied and complementary, and easily the best of any Indian food or vegetarian food I have ever eaten. FP agrees the texture here was just as important as the flavor, and both were on-point. We are still talking about this dish a day later. We don't know how a vegetarian dish could ever taste better than this. 


2. Service

We had made reservations for a time admittedly a bit early in the night, and were a little late due to rush hour traffic. The hostess was understanding when we called and we had zero issue with our table. Angel, our server, rattled off the beer selections for us with recommendations and tips for our taste. He also helped us choose entrees and starters to share, and seemed to truly care about our experience. No sooner did he clear a plate from our table than someone was taking it from him to wash it. The kitchen staff seemed to be a tight crew and we could see it in the presentation of the food. 


3. Music & Atmosphere

FP brought this up immediately when we were seated: "This sounds like a playlist that I would make," which maybe sounds silly to read but trust me when I say FP crushes it with music so this was a big deal. Anderson Paak, Hieroglyphics, and any other chill indie music you wish you could hear more of on the radio. Is this a "hipster" spot? It is hip in the best way, with its reclaimed wood, exposed bulbs and beams, and fresh farm to table food. Rooster & the Till seems to succeed in being trendy while also seeming timeless, which may be more inviting to the non-self proclaimed hipster crowd. 

Sitting at the kitchen bar vs the dining room may be an even more enhanced experience if you want to see more of how the food comes together, but we give it a combined 5/5 and will be returning next time we are in town.
name: Rooster & the Till
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
First let me say that at first glance the menu was not to my liking. I only went because my millennial son had heard "good things" about it and he wanted to try it. He's wrapping up his masters so I took him as a graduation present of sorts. 
Service was absolutely first rate. If I have had better I don't recall it. We sat outside and enjoyed a nice Friday night in Tampa. 
He couldn't decide between two items, as usual. I told him we would order both and share. We had the eggplant ravioli and the wheat based gnocchi. I wouldn't have ordered either of my own volition. I would have been so wrong. Both were done in a style that was stunning in presentation and with simply amazing flavors. Not overpowering, but firmly there. You tasted the balance, not just the spice. We were so pleased we tried two desserts the donut holes with miso five spice butterscotch and the black sesame ice cream. I took pictures and attached them here. I've never had better dessert. You really need to check them out. They more than live up to their reputation.
name: Rooster & the Till
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
I'm not much of a sweet tooth, but these popsicles are just the right amount of sweet. They have a variety of flavors that rotate I believe. I've only been here twice and saw different flavors both times. The first time I went, I got the sweet corn pop and it was THE BEST. My girlfriend wanted to trade her lychee pop for my corn, so I shared most of mine.

The second time we went, I was hoping to see the sweet corn, but :(

The black sesame pop was decent, I just had sesame seeds in between my teeth for the next hour. These pops are a refreshing dessert after a nice meal at the nearby restaurants.
name: Lil' Pop Shop
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
I really wanted to like this place but... it fell short. Starting with beverages, my cousin ordered the Thai iced tea and it was pretty watered down. My ginger lemonade was quite tasty though. We decided to split a few dishes; papaya salad, curry pork noodles, chicken street noodles, and the pork banh mi.

Papaya salad and curry noodles came out first, both were tasty but definitely over-salted. Then came the chicken street noodles. I thought that maybe because we had two strong flavors prior to this dish... we weren't able to taste the broth. But that was just benefit of the doubt. It was terribly bland. Even after adding chili and garlic sauce... still couldn't taste a thing. I dipped some of the noodles into the left over curry we had hoping to retrieve some type of flavor but alas... the noodles already absorbed the previous broth and just watered down the taste of the curry. The bread of the banh mi was great, soft and crispy at the same time. Wasn't a fan of the pate, dripped everywhere and was... oily? But it wasn't terrible.

It was kind of strange to see an East Asian inspired restaurant... with no Asian people on the staff or even as customers while we were there. Not saying that other cultures can't draw inspiration and creativity. Food is food, doesn't matter who is creating what as long as it's delicious, right? Given it was opening day... but the food just wasn't consistent and didn't leave enough of an impression for me or my cousin to have the desire to return. Especially regarding how expensive the meal was compared to the portion size we received.

Lastly. We were curious about the soft serve ice cream flavors. We tried the toasted rice, which was actually good. But it was the way the sample was presented to us. The server had gotten ice cream all over her hand. We saw her hesitate to throw it away and make another one. But then she still decided to hand my cousin the sample cup... with ice cream covering and dripping from her entire hand. She then handed me the black sesame flavor I asked for which... when she saw my reaction, said "it's more like peanut butter." And she was right.

They started strong. I actually really liked my beverage and the papaya salad. Curry was enjoyable too but was definitely too salty. The rest of the meal wasn't impressive and neither was the the ice cream. But the place was cute, and pretty packed. I hope they become more consistent with their flavors, there's room for growth and improvement.
name: Tyger Tyger
categories: Restaurants, Asian Fusion

text: When you arrive at this restaurant you immediately know you are in for a unique dining experience.  We had a drink at the bar upstairs which is very nice then proceeded downstairs to the dining room.  We started with the toro carpaccio that was small but tasty.  The uni carbonara was the best thing we are all night and the wagyu dumplings were also very nice.  We then ordered the $90 chefs selection sushi and sashimi which was pretty basic but very fresh and delicious.  There are so many sashimi options, some of which you rarely see even in Tokyo that I thought the chefs selection would be a little more adventurous.  We also added some sashimi to the order that we had never had (the barracuda, big eye snapper and uni stood out).  Everything was fresh and light and so fun to try such unique sushi/sashimi.  We also ordered a couple of desserts we didn't need but wanted to try.  The black sesame was good but the blood orange raspberry sorbet was better.  All in all great meal, although with a hefty price tag.
name: Morimoto
categories: Japanese, American (Traditional), American (New), Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Asian Fusion

text: Outstanding food, good drinks, and some of the best ice cream in Tucson! Favorite flavors include black sesame and bourbon almond brittle. I have gone here with smaller groups with no reservations, a big group with a reservation, and just for ice cream and service has been good but not great (hence 4 not 5 stars). It is a little chaotic with the large numbers of customers and staff navigating a small space, but tables are spacious. You can come in and just order ice cream and sit at open tables and staff gives water and napkins, very classy. Glad to see improvements in downtown!
name: HUB Restaurant & Ice Creamery
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, American (New), Nightlife, Sandwiches, Bars, Restaurants, Salad, American (Traditional), Desserts, Food

text:
Fast becoming one of my favorite sushi joints in the area. 

Conveniently moved and sharing space with a great Thai spot with a renowned Thai chef who is the proprietor of both establishments, but let's talk about sushi.

This is not typical run of the mill tuna salmon and yellowtail. It's much more than that. Always an interesting selection of more exciting fish, and even more importantly, ALWAYS prepared with a lot of skill. 

Eddie knows his craft and wields his yanagiba with precision. Simple swift cuts, a minimum of movement and 4 motion preparation of his nigiri. Quite a treat to watch and enjoy and savor. 

Also one of the only places where I am comfortable walking in, sitting down at the bar, and saying surprise me...make me some stuff I'll like. And I always do. Always. From a surprise couple slices of torched and oiled salmon belly, to delicately folded fluke...always something special on my plate in addition to the standards. And the standards, again, a step above. Cut properly so there is a delicacy to every bite. You just don't get this in many places. 

Wonderful apps like their spicy tuna rice crisps with black sesame, roasted shallots and micro greens...the delicate usuzukuri Fluke carpaccio with shreds of spicy radish, scallions and citrus soy vinaigrette...and some tasty kitchen treats too!  Can't go wrong with yummy pork belly buns or tasty and savory takoyaki.  

Top it off with sweet servers and attentive hosts and you have the complete package.

No reason to venture into downtown if you are in the burbs. Stop short of 76 and just head down Main St in Manayunk and satisfy your craving for excellent fish. 

You'll be glad you did.
name: Yanako
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
Love this place - in part because mango is my favorite fruit and I would happily eat fresh mango every day. I even love eating around the pit and getting the fibers all stuck in my teeth. 

So a whole dessert shop centered around the magnificent mango? Yes please. 

- Mango juice with mango chunks and lychee jelly. Perfect for a blistering summer day. (And every day.)
