- Snow white juice with green tea ice cream, red bean, and rice balls. Is there a more Asian dessert? Possibly not. Really nice blend of textures - my favorites were the chewy rice balls. By the way, each of these desserts is around $8-9 so by no means cheap but they do fill up the plates to heaping. 

- Also ordered the hot black sesame paste soup with peanut mochi. Brought me immediately back to childhood. Mango mango's version is probably a little less "authentic" than other places in Chinatown - it's a lot thicker and sweeter, which is to say, exactly how I like it. I think "chun" sesame paste soup is runnier and more bitter, with more of the sesame flavor, but I absolutely loved this. 

Plenty of seating with both upstairs and downstairs tables. The waiters were all really friendly. Just wished they could use less plastic everything.
name: Mango Mango Dessert
categories: Food, Desserts, Shaved Ice, Waffles, Restaurants

text: I had a fantastic first experience at Tredici. The complimentary olives were some of the best I've ever had - a great way to start a meal. We ordered a number of plates from each section of the menu. The bacon wrapped dates could be one of the best dishes in the city! Broccoli and Avocado with black sesame seeds were an inventive way to dress up a simple combination of vegetables. Can't wait to go back and try it again. The space is warm and inviting for any occasion with any group.
name: Tredici Enoteca
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Bars, Nightlife, Italian

text:
A table for 3 outside during a sunny Sunday afternoon.  I liked the decorum and the feeling that I was siting in a vibrant garden just outside a farm. You can listen to the soft breeze that passes through this alley and the dripping water fountain from multiple outdoor pipe faucets.  The waiter was attentive and easily approachable.  He explained recommendations and the local, organic ingredients that were featured.  

I ordered the Plancha Searerd Shrimp, sweet bicolor corn, Bulgar, nectarines, Arugula pesto, and wild Purslane.  The Shrimp was smokey from the grill and complimented well with the sweetness of the corn/necterines.  The Purslane also added a hint of freshness and bitterness.  Amazing!

I tried a bit of the hand torn pasta ribbons, squash, and ricotta.  However, my group and I didn't enjoy it and we didn't see much of the summer truffle.  I thought the flavors could have been developed more by adding porchinos, chanterelles, or chrimini mushrooms to the sauce.  

Main dish for me was the local bluefish with black sesame crust, charred eggplant, sweet and sour kale, tangy raisins, and tahini sauce.  I thought the eggplant and tahini sauce reminded me of an Indian dish.  The fish was moist and the crust wasn't burnt.  Overall, I thought my experience was great.  I'd come here again.
name: Talula's Garden
categories: American (New), Restaurants

text:
As promised, my review is being updated. 
Just left Boca after coming for brunch to try their new fall menu. My friend and I had Eric as our server, who was AMAZING!!!!!! Apparently it was his first shift and he knocked it out of the park! This was the best service to date at Boca and truly left a great impression! Their new fall menu makes it difficult to choose but my friend and I decided on the sweet potato pancakes and the general Tao chicken and waffles. The flavor for both dishes were impeccable but their were some execution issues. As this was their initial roll-out it was to be expected, and I can't wait to go back and try these again! 
As my dish was the general Tao chicken and waffles I will review that- the waffles are speckled with black sesame which was really excited about but the flavor did not come through enough, the plum glaze on the chicken gave the dish a great overall tang to counter the rich creamy peanut butter (addicting) sauce, I'm not sure where the cowboy candy (jalapeños) were because I didn't have any on my plate but it was mentioned on the menu and I think that heat would have really brought the dish together. Overall, would try again if these issues get fixed.
name: Boca - Brandon
categories: Bars, Restaurants, American (New), Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
I've been here twice and the first time I didn't care for it as much but this time was much better. The tab was $190 including one cocktail drink

There were two small plates that were exceptional, but the rest was just okay (okay by my standards anyway, you'll probably think it was the best thing you ate in your life). We ended up having two more small plates (one was spaghetti with crab) and two large plates. The smores brownie at the end was pretty tasty as well. 

The gnocchi with figs and the shrimp with corn were outstanding. I was literally in culinary heaven on those two dishes which was a problem because it was my GF who ordered them. If they are still on the menu, you'll want to check them out.


=================================
OUTSTANDING:
Plancha-Seared Fresh Dixie Shrimp, Salad of Sweet Bi-Color Corn, Bulgur, and Nectarines, Arugula Pesto, and Wild Purslane 
Pan-Fried Gold Potato Gnocchi, Roasted Black Mission Figs, Speck Ham, and Gooey Cheese Fondue Sauce
=================================
OKAY:
Chilled Tuna Crudo, Raw Line-Caught Albacore, Lime Salt, Summer Melons; Pickled, Fresh and Sauced, Mint and Basil Blossoms 
'Spaghetti and Crab'...Maryland Blue Crab Gravy, Guitar Cut Pasta, Braised Fennel, and Garlic Breadcrumb

Seared Day Boat Scallops, Sweet Corn and Curry Sauce, Garden Squash & Zucchini 'Succotash,' Spiced Cashews, and Kaffir Lime
Fresh Caught Local Bluefish, Black Sesame Crust, Charred Eggplant, Sweet and Sour Kale, Tangy Raisins, and Tahini Sauce
name: Talula's Garden
categories: American (New), Restaurants

text:
I'm slightly hesitant to award the fifth star at this time. Not because of anything on the restaurant's part, but because it is only the third spot I've been to in this area. And I only sampled 3 rolls.

That is partly my fault, I had to order the lunch bento box. Overall it was good, but maybe my choice of red curry chicken was a stretch. The chicken and fresh veggies were perfectly cooked, but the curry was thin. Tricia selected chicken udon noodles, nicely done version of this staple. And we shared a 2 roll lunch special, shrimp tempura and spicy tuna. These were perfectly constructed and artfully plated. I appreciated the attention to detail that the chef employed by adding a bit of white and black sesame seeds to the rice.

I really liked the decor too. Hip and modern would be a good way to describe this tiny shop. With a long bar where patrons can engage with the very friendly chef. Our server was excellent too. And as a last and very nice impression, really good Japanese candies are offered as you exit. I need to come back and concentrate on sushi and sashimi only, and not be swayed by the Asian fusion part of the menu. Let's go with 4.5 WASABI Yelps
name: Naruto Sushi
categories: Restaurants, Japanese

text:
Had our first dinner in NOLA and it remained our favorite meal for the entire trip. We started with the face bacon and the CBD with pickled fruits, all of which were eaten with, "omg, this is so good!" For the entree, we stuck to the popular dishes - the smoked scallops, duck, and the curry vegetables. Smoked scallops was the clear star amongst the three. For dessert, we had the black sesame ice cream and I've been craving it every day since we got back. 

4 stars for the meal, 5 stars for the service, which also topped our other restaurant experiences in NOLA. Would highly recommend.
name: Root
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Southern

text:
It's hard to believe there's only one 2010 review of this place, and that was back in January.  So I'm going to change that right now.  :)

Me and the wife ate here, about 8 years or so ago.  We remember enjoying it then, and it's been too long getting back.  Wifey had to bowl Monday evening, so we decided to make lunch of it Monday, June 14th.  We arrived at about 1pm.  It was not crowded and we got a nice window seat overlooking the strip.  I have to say, I had forgotten how cozy the chairs are and how nice the table tops look. Like granite, probably faux, but nice looking.  

Wifey has a new kick and started with a Tom Collins.  I opted for a white Zin.  It's so nice we can order from the sushi bar.  My wife loves cali roll, but only if made with real crab.  Ok, so she's spoiled, lol.  We asked our server and he was honest enough to tell us theirs was not made of the real thing.  In that case, the wifey ordered fried calamari for her starter.

Soon we were greeted by a basket of warm breads, and I do mean breads.  There were several different types in the basket with plenty of creamy butter.  You can be sure we saved most of those for later.  

I had to be greedy and ordered two starters.  I always have to try clam chowder wherever I go, so I ordered a cup of that.  I also ordered my fave sushi, spicy tuna hand roll and salmon skin hand roll.  I think the chowder came first, with oyster crackers on the side. 

Of the whole trip this was the best clam chowder I've had.  The one from the salad bar in the Parrot was watery and skimpy on the clams and potatoes.  The one at Jax in Truckee was good, but a bit heavy on the nutmeg.  Though I thought I ordered a cup, it came in a nice big bowl, see pic.

Then I polished off my spicy tuna hand roll.  Stuffed full of tuna, all the way to the end, I love that.  I hate it when I get a spicy tuna hand roll, and all of the meat is at the top, only rice in the middle, and only a mouthful of nori at the very bottom.  No skimping here.  Nice touch was the real orchid flower on the plate.  See the pics.  I saved the salmon skin for snacking later.  Unfortunately the heat of the tuna roll came from wasabi embeded inside.  Not the usual red pepper and black sesame seed spice I am used to.  Minus a point there.  They did serve both regular soy, and low sodium soy without me having to ask.  Plus a point there.

I munched on some of my wifes fried calamari.  They came in fish stick fashion, not what she is used to, but still very good and tender. I do have a pic of it, I will have to upload it later.  The batter actually stuck to the fish, and the cocktail sauce actually had some bite to it.  No wimpy sauce here.  She loved them.  Better than the Delta Kings.  Her only complaint there were no tentacles.  She loves those, lol.  Take a hint, Sky, fry up some of those wiggly legs, lol.

At last the object of our desire arrived at the table.  The oysters were nestled on the bottom in lovely radicchio cups.  Then piles of fresh crab legs surrounded the tall glass holding the shrimp. On top of legs were a good portion of lobster claws, and the whole thing crowned with jumbo shrimp cocktail.  A set up was presented for each of us along with a large bowl for the shells.  We dug in, cracking and shucking and eating to our hearts content.  

Wifey doesn't do raw food, so the oysters were all mine.  A total of 5 came on the tower of fun.  Each one ice cold and very fresh, and each one seemed like a different species.  

Unfortunately I don't recall our server checking on us once our entree was delivered.  We had to get his attention to ask for more drawn butter and a napkin.  Unfortunately he brought us more wetnaps, when what we really needed was another linen one.  Oh well, we didn't make that clear, not even when he presented the wet ones.  In all, we both got our seafood fix that day, and it was way too much food.  Gladly they brought us a box to take back to our room the two sets of crab legs we just could not finish, and a plastic bag to make carrying it easier.  Good thing I had an excuse for a fridge in our room.  

This spot is always a must go place whenever we are in Reno, and probably will be for years to come.
name: Atlantis Sky Terrace Sushi Bar
address: Atlantis Casino Resort Spa, 3800 S Virginia St
categories: Japanese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Seafood

text:
I was on a second date with an awesome man today. He suggested Yoshimatsu because I'm vegatarian (he won street cred for being considerate!).
We had such a great time! The food was perfect, lunch special with vegatarian gyoza, choice of white or brown rice (I chose brown), the most adorable server ever...I can't remember her name, which is embarrassing because I told her I liked it and shook her hand!
It wasn't busy, we arrived a bit after 1pm on a Thursday. But that was fine because we were able to feel unrushed on our date.
Oh, and the moshi dessert special? AWESOME!! The black sesame flavor was our favorite!!

Thanks so much folks for being the best restaurant for a 2nd date EVER !!
name: Yoshimatsu Japanese Eatery
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese, Seafood, Noodles

text:
Earth Fare is a health food store in Oldsmar, right between the Beall's and AMC Movie Theatre. The parking is ample, and it's easy to get to from both directions. 

Overall, I like Earth Fare. It's very similar to Whole Foods to me, in price for sure. They have a good selection of bulk foods, grains, nuts, honey, etc and it is easy to stock up on your staple items or just get a tiny amount of something. I appreciate this when I need a small amount of an expensive ingredient, like black sesame seeds. 

The selection of 'aisle' and frozen foods is very good, very good indeed. They have almond flour pasta in the freezer for the Keto folks, and some really good options for all healthy lifestyles. 

My favorite area is the cheese section. The meat section is OK, but the cheese is where they shine. A good selection and the prices are pretty good for the gourmet-ness that you get. I looooooove the olive bar and hope they keep it there forever, because Earth Fare is my first stop when I'm having a cheese party. I also enjoy the soup and salad bar, it's nice to have healthy fresh options on the go.
name: Earth Fare
categories: Grocery, Organic Stores, Meat Shops, Food, Specialty Food, Health Markets

text:
This is my third time getting the AYCE sushi here but tonight is the first time I ever had AYCE sushi by myself. It actually turned out pretty good. I decided to get hand rolls since I got no one to share the long rolls with and I'm glad the sushi chef was able to make my favorite rolls in this form (half the size but more meat and less rice). By the way, I came in 45 mins before closing so it's not busy and I feel like I have my own personal sushi chef :) So I started with mussels and miso soup for appetizers. The mussels are good, a bit dry so I suggest putting ponzu sauce for every shell. Then I ordered the GSR hand roll, wow I was blown away!!! The temperature of the fish is perfectly cold, so it tastes fresh. The flavor was amazing, a must try!!! Coz of this I got excited and ordered Rim Special. Wow, I would say getting it in hand roll is the way to go! Lots of meat plus, the mango just sealed the flavor. I like the fact that they keep the mangoes cold too. The combination of this roll was so good coz you would get different layers of flavor and they all end up tasting great and delightfully fresh. I could eat this roll without dipping it to soy sauce. Then I asked for the Buddha hand roll and thought it's just ok. Maybe there's too much sweet sauce in it and the kiwi was just too tart. So I would prefer getting this in long roll. At this point, I wanted to order another rim special hand roll but I wanted to make room for my favorite nigiri, which is the ikura with quail egg. Not disappointed coz I like quail eggs :) needless to mention that I ordered a quail egg shooter which is yummy too. Then I thought I should get one more roll, so I challenged the chef to make a Donald hand roll. I'm surprised that he had to ask me what's in it or maybe he just wanted to make sure. So I told him it got salmon, avocado and lemon. I was kinda unsure of the outcome coz I didn't know the sauce in it or that he might skip the sauce but nope, he knew what's in Donald roll and added the sauce, kani, and black sesame seeds which I missed. Wow that was pretty amazing, now I would only eat Donald in hand rolls. Loved it! At this moment, I got so full and thought to wrap it up. So they gave me my green tea ice cream. While eating, I looked at the time and thought hmmm I still got 5 mins till they close so I asked the chef if he can make a dessert roll and he did! He mixed kani, mango, cream cheese, rolled in soy paper then topped with kiwi and macadamia nuts. It's actually good but I would go for strawberries instead of kiwi then top it with whip cream and chocolate syrup :) 

I would love to give 5 stars but the price is a little higher and thought I could get the same service and quality rolls at a less expensive AYCE sushi in Reno.
name: Rim Asian Bistro
categories: Nightlife, Diners, Specialty Food, Chinese, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars, Food

text:
Really dig this hole in the wall spot in the funk zone !

I got the "black sesame" with captain crunch 

Great vibes
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
So glad that Shake Shack has finally landed in Metairie!! Very cute patio seating with string lights outside and a good amount of tables inside. My go-to order is the ShackBurger and cheese fries +/- a vanilla malt. They do have seasonal shakes that change every so often too! Right now they have a pie flavor and black sesame. Service is very quick and friendly. Someone saw us walking toward a table and came to wipe it down for us without us even asking! The line also moves quickly despite how long it has been recently.

Only downside to this location is the limited parking. You can always park across the street at the mall and walk over though. Lines have been out the door because it's so new, so if you are not about the crowd life ... wait it out a few weeks! Alternatively, you can download the online Shake Shack app and order for pickup. They let you choose a time slot and are pretty prompt with the order. Only downside is you can only order a max of two items per category via the app. For example... 2 Shackburgers, 2 fries, 2 shakes. Try to add that third shake in and it will give you an error message sadly. Good for diet control I guess!
name: Shake Shack
categories: Fast Food, Restaurants, Burgers, American (Traditional)

text:
My writing buddy and I finished a meeting close to City Hall and realized we were both quite hungry. Of course, this was at that odd time of day when most restaurants are just about finished serving lunch and not yet serving dinner. We wanted to sit, have a drink (too early for happy hour), eat and catch up on non-business chat. We found ourselves at 13th & Chestnut and started walking up the block, suddenly confronted with a lot of prospective places to eat-many with outdoor seating.

Tredici Enoteca has a corner location with a nice brass plaque outside. We had no idea what to expect, other than something probably Italian, and we had reached the too damn hungry to keep walking level of low blood sugar so we headed inside. 

First impression-light, airy, blonde woods, clean, welcoming. It was a hot day and the restaurant has outdoor seating (all full) but they open all their side doors so you still get the feeling of being outside but with reduced noise. Our waiter, Frank, came over to greet us right away and take drink orders. They make an excellent Negroni.

I love seafood so I immediately knew I wanted the raw bar sampler. Henry and I decided on some small plates and when Frank returned with our drinks, we were ready to order. What we had not realized is that Tredici has a sweet lunch deal where you can order 3 items from a list of about 8 to 10 items for $14. Frank pointed that out and told us the lunch items would just be smaller than if they were regular menu items. 3 of the things we wanted were on that list so we chose the bacon wrapped dates, chicken meatballs and the ribs. We got a regular sized order of the broccoli and avocado salad along with the raw bar sampler.

Henry and I both love food and we have very healthy appetites. When we are not dining out, we cook clean food in our homes and make a point to use healthy saturated fats in our diet. This place was avocado heaven for us! As basic as the broccoli avocado dish sounds, it was scrumptious and I was glad we ordered a full size. It was lightly dressed and garnished with black sesame seeds. 

The raw sampler comes with 3 oysters, 3 jumbo shrimp and a small bowl of raw tuna ribbons over more avocado presented on a bed of ice with seafood forks and 2 sauces, cocktail and mignonette. It's a bit pricey at $39 but I could not fault the quality of the seafood.

Henry went nuts over the bacon wrapped dates. 3 come in an order. They are hot and crisp on the outside with a touch of a savory sauce and one bites into a soft, sweet, luscious hot seedless date. We both would have been thrilled with 20 more of these. 

The meatballs were fine, nothing remarkable and the ribs were tender with meat falling off the bone. The sauce was not the usual sweet barbecue stuff; it was more savoury and subtle. I let Henry have the bulk of these as ribs are not one of my favorite foods. 

We ordered a second round of drinks and service throughout the meal was superb. Efficient, friendly and well timed. The place is noisy but still allows non-screamed conversation between table mates. We were not rushed and when we finally paid our check, we were both chuffed as hell with having found a great new place for that weird not lunch/not happy hour/not dinner time of day. We will definitely be back!
name: Tredici Enoteca
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Bars, Nightlife, Italian

text: In my quest to work my way through the menu, tonight I had the Aloha Classic bowl which has beautiful fresh ahi tuna, spring mix, edamame, Persian cucumbers, furikake, sweet onion & scallions and I added a little rice. This was a very large portion and the flavors were fresh and bright. It's so healthy and I loved it. I saved some for later though because I wanted to try one of their many side dishes. I have got to clue you in on their tofu "fries!" OMG, they were amazing! They were made fresh to order and coated in a thin, crispy, crunchy (panko?) breading studded with black sesame seeds. It takes a lot of skill to fry something with black sesame seeds because the oil in the seeds burns quickly. Not a problem here! These tofu fries were fried to perfection while keeping the generous wand of tofu creamy and soft on the inside. Hands down the BEST tofu fries ever.  Served with unagi sauce & Poke Munch sauce for dipping, I couldn't stop eating them! Looking forward to my next bowl or burrito, but I already know I'm ordering the tofu fries again.
name: Poké Munch
categories: Sushi Bars, Japanese, Poke, Specialty Food, Food, Hawaiian, Restaurants

text:
Guide of the Best that the Rama has to offer
Another visit means another update!  Solid 3 star experience, I am doing this review a bit differently than the other.  I tried pretty much EVERYTHING they had that was worth trying, just so I could make you the guide of all the best food. Though it seems like an oxymoron this buffet does has some good HOMEMADE food that is worth a taste.

  First the salad bar is very green and yada yada, but let's be real your not paying $10-15 a person to eat salad.  

**1st plate (as pictured) 
Ham- salty and pretty dry 
Garlic Bread- Cold, wet, and hard edges
Sour cream potatoes- Top was rubbery and overcooked, tasted of heavy sourcream
Mashed pot- Real redskin mashed made fresh AWESOME! 
Mac n cheese- Must use KFC'S left overs, have that same pasty liquid cheese from a bag, soo bland
Fried Chicken- Juicy, crunchy, and tasted better than KFC. it's meh at its finest

2nd plate

BBQ chicken- Light bbq sauce glaze, flavorful, tender, sauce builds with spice and sweetness. Great
Rotisserie Chick- Slow roasted, juicy, crispy skin well flavored, Great 
Grilled cod- Seasoned well with paprika and black sesame seeds, overcooked and super dry.  
Beef Stroganoff- Salty beef sauce, with very tough cuts of beef, super bland. 

3rd Plate (Super Flavor Plate) If you don't want to play games get these items! 

Roll w cinnamon butter- fresh baked, light, airy, hot and taste amazing with the creamy butter. 
Mash- Once again fresh homade REAL potatoes 
Turkey Breast- fresh cooked, lean, succulent, turkey Breast carved right in front of you. 
Rotisserie Chick- All about slow roasted flavor
Kettle Roasted Turkey- Truly a signature dish filled with flavor and hearty pieces of carrots and potatoes.
Ham- Depending on if they are cutting it hot, this is really hit and miss. I like the roast beef but tends to have lots of gristle. (Fat) 

Desserts- I tried the best looking ones 
Oreo Cake! - Light sponge, Oreo crunch, chocolate and all around a winner. 
Brownie Lava-  This was hot, chocolatey, and a bit overcooked. 
Rice pudding- It was bland with no taste 
bread pudding- Meh 
Cookie- Hard and burnt, look out for the lemon icing cookies they are the best.  
triple berry cream cheese cake- This had a light frosting, dense sponge, and not much flavor.  

 Their you have an extensive run down of my experience plate by plate, yes I ate a lot all in the name of Yelping lol.
name: Chuck-A-Rama Buffet
categories: Buffets, Restaurants

text:
A few months back, the GF and I were in the mood for Asian noodles, but not exactly itching for the prototypical mushy noodles that accompany an order of Americanized Chinese takeout. Hearing good things about Wokworks, we decided to hop on DiningIn and see what all the fuss was about.

Spicy Asian Pickles [$1.95]
Pickles, chili 

We started off with the spicy pickles. While a pittance of a portion, they were crisp and sweet, with spice that came through on the finish.

Jalapeno Brussels Sprouts [$4]
Brussels sprouts, gluten-free soy, jalapeno

I'm a brussels sprouts fiend so naturally, we had to order these. While I missed the touted heat from the jalapenos, the sprouts had nice bite and were well seasoned. Thankfully, they weren't overly salty from the soy.

Crispy Edamame Dumplings [$4.95]
Peanut sauce

The edamame dumplings were nice - incredibly crispy with a creamy essence within. They were topped with some green onions and sweet black sesame seeds.

BBQ Pork Belly Sliders [$5.95]
Steamed buns, pork belly, pineapple salsa, cilantro

Regular readers know that the pork belly buns were a must order for me. The gluttonous pork was well-braised and had a lightly sweet glaze. The dish itself could have used more texture, with the soft, pliant buns rendering each bite soft on soft. I could have used more pork as well - perhaps double pork a la Momofuku? Still, the accompanying pineapple salsa and cilantro brought some bright balance to the heft of the pork.

Build Your Own Tall Wok [$10.95]
Lo mein, chicken, snow peas, mushrooms, bok choy, crispy shallots, roasted almonds, Blackgold teriyaki sauce 

But what is Wokworks really known for? Their stir-fried noodles! We elected to build our own, with chicken, lo mein noodles, and a melange of various veggies.
These noodles weren't mushy at all and thankfully had life to each bite. They were well-coated with the requested Blackgold teriyaki sauce and the multitude of accompanying additions helped to create a hearty dish.

Overall, Wokworks delivered an experience that was well above the standard Chinese takeout you might order on a random night. Do try their stir-fried noodles. I also wouldn't hesitate to order the pork belly buns again!
name: Wokworks
categories: Restaurants, Food, Specialty Food, Fast Food, Asian Fusion, Chinese

text:
We started by ordering a bottle of wine and a couple of appetizers and a salad.  The waiter then took our menus without us ordering entrees at the time which seemed strange, but we figured he would come back to take our entree orders.  The appetizers came out and the bacon wrapped shrimp was okay and the calamari was sub-par in that it was not crunchy and somewhat rubbery, but still edible. If this in itself were the only issue we could easily have gotten over it.  Once we finished the appetizers the waiter asked if we were ready for dessert.  We explained we wanted to order entrees and he apologized and said he misunderstood and thought we were just ordering apps.  No big deal. 

I ordered a bone in strip steak and my girlfriend ordered the black sesame tuna.  I had ordered my steak medium, which they said would have a pink middle, which is what i wanted.  When i cut into the steak it was completely raw in what i would describe as tartare at best. It barely had a seer on the outside. On top of that the one bite I did take had zero seasoning and literally just tasted like they took the piece of meat and put it straight on the grill.  No salt, no pepper, not even a true seer on the outside to provide the crunchy texture one would expect from a steak.  My girlfriend's tuna she immediately said tasted "off" after her first bite.  I tried it and it did have a strange almost sour off putting taste.  Im not sure if it was the fish itself or the seasoning, but it was not pleasant. 

The manager came over and asked us how our meal was and we explained to him the above.  He apologized and asked us if we wanted new entrees brought out.  We said no as we had both lost our appetite at that point and he said he would "take care of it", which was fine.  He then brought back the bill and offered us free dessert which was nice, but at that point we really just wanted to leave.  

In looking at the bill when he "took care of it" he discounted each entree less than half of the purchase price!  I had a gift card that covered the entire cost of the meal so I did not complain further, but he did not know that at the time and the reality is the full entree cost should have been removed as neither of us actually ate the entree and immediately brought our concerns to the attention of the manager. 

The final dagger was that after we got our bill neither the manager nor our waiter would come back over to run the gift card or my credit card so i could leave a tip.  (Despite the terrible food i know that this was not the fault of the server).  Unfortunately we literally sat for over 20 minutes before we could finally flag down another waiter who ended up running the cards for us. It ended up taking us almost 3 hours to get through a meal where we didn't even eat the entrees.  

Overall a terrible experience not only from the food perspective, but also subsequently very poorly handled by the wait staff and management.
name: Copia
categories: Restaurants, American (Traditional)

text:
Visited: July 7 2019

My companions and I stumbled upon TSUJIRI and we decided to make a pit stop for some matcha goodness.

There were street parking but they were all taken and metered so we decided to park across the street at Save On Foods (we shopped there first to make our parking legit).

The inside of the restaurant was very zen; peaceful and serene.  (It was a Sunday afternoon but the shop wasn't busy)  Since it was a rainy day,  I quickly decided on a hot beverage.  I ordered the black sesame matcha latte and it was indeed satisfying.  Not a whole lot of black sesame taste but the matcha was intense.  At first glance, I thought the drink was well worth the price of admission (almost $7) as it came in a large tumbler.  Upon closer look, the tumbler was double walled (presumably to keep drinks hot longer) so the drink wasn't as large it seems to be.
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Bakeries

text: Found this local sushi/Thai restaurant on yelp and went based off the reviews. Walked in and was shortly greeted by a friendly waitress who asked if we wanted a booth or a table. We requested a booth and were seated promptly. Took a few minutes to get somebody to come take our initial drink order but once they acknowledged us as patrons at the table the service was very very good. A series of three different waitresses helped to take our order clear our plates and make sure our drinks were filled. We ordered the spring rolls for an appetizer which were light crispy and quite delicious. For our main course we ordered three sushi rolls. The neck, the rock 'n' roll and the samurai. They were all good but we agreed we enjoyed the rock 'n' roll the best. We decided to indulge ourselves in some unnecessary dessert. We were happily surprised, and enjoyed their offering of coconut ice cream and fried bananas. The bananas were fried light and crispy and the coconut ice cream was creamy and delicious. They adorned the desert with a drizzle of honey and black sesame seeds. My only small critique on this is the amount of fried bananas is small in comparison to the amount of ice cream they provide. There is only four small slices of bananas put into little pockets of fried yummness. Totally wish I could've had twice that amount. All in all it was a very good experience and we will definitely be back. Happy to find this close to home.
name: Thai Samurai
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Thai, Sushi Bars

text: This place is delicious! I stopped by today to  grab a menu and they offered me samples and all their signature sauces. All 3 were great but the black sesame was My favorite. I ordered them for delivery a few hours later. So good and a great addition to the neighborhood.
name: Big Catch Poke
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Poke, Japanese, Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea

text: This place was really delicious! I had the mushroom burger and it's a portabello stuffed with cheese put on a bun with lettuce and tomato and it was very good. The cheese fries were hot with a delicious blend of cheese on them and the black sesame mil shake was delicious. Others in my party got burgers and said the burgers were very good. The restaurant was clean and comfortable. A little cold but it was a hot day! Shake shack is the best new place I've tried in quiet a while and I'm so glad I did.
name: Shake Shack
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, American (Traditional), Food, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants

text:
Holy moly! We had such a stellar meal here. They have a great looking cocktail menu. I went with the Suburban Birdcage- very tropical and suuuper good. For appetizers, we had the Spicy Tuna TarTare sushi and Bao Buns. The Bao Buns were out of this world and the sushi was also delicious. I had the Umami Noodles and really enjoyed the salty pork and edamame. My husband had the Tamarind Noodles and liked it but thought the sauce was a little too sweet. We finished with the Black Sesame Ice Cream that came with chocolate ganache. It was very unique. It tasted a lot like mint ice cream and the ganache was rich. The perfect ending to our meal. 
Next time we come, I plan on ordering more of the appetizers and sushi. The entire menu looks so good. Our service was friendly and quick. Can't wait to come back!
name: Modita
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Dim Sum, Asian Fusion, Noodles, Chinese, Pan Asian

text: I am so glad stopped by last night. Excellent service and food is delicious! I love their special sauces specially the Jalapeño base whixh is what they call the mind eraser ... another good one is secret weapon and vinegar black sesame.... will be back again definitely!!!
name: Big Catch Poke
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Poke, Japanese, Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea

text:
Upscale gastropub I wanted to love and had quality food, but place didn't click with me. 3.25 stars 

Food: 3.5, Service: 3, Atmosphere: 2
Cost to worth it rating: 2 (chicken was $29 pretty spendy)
Return worthiness: probably not

Highlights:
- Critically acclaimed chef: always interests nerdy foodie me ;-)
- High quality ingredients
- Poutine: stacked up high, excellent stewed pork cheek and cheese, and solid pure potato fries. 4.5 stars
- Cucumbers: refreshingly chilled with black sesame, fresh strings of ginger, and whipped tofu. 4.5 stars
- Chicken: well cooked and on top of a gravy with more tender meat in it. 3.5 stars
- Cocktails: definition of craft with specialty ingredients and elegant presentation 

Midlights:
- Sticky toffee pudding: their specialty was just ok for me. 3 stars

Lowlights:
- Cold: vibe didn't feel welcoming and was actually temperature actually matched being cold in there as well. So many places in Nola are full of life that this seemed out of place and almost too formal for a casual gastropub setting.

Food was fine and reviewing this realize the menu sounded promising, but the atmosphere made me sad.
name: Balise Tavern
categories: French, Restaurants, American (New), Southern

text:
Can you say "YUM"?!?!

I have the pleasure of working right across the street from Fabrica, and I can confidently say that after one visit, that this is going to get me into trouble!

I am usually a plane Jane when it comes to my pizzas, and am very picky.  So I decided to venture off and get the Favorita pizza.  This included:  mozzarella, provolone, chicken scallions and drizzled with red pepper sriracha sauce and black sesame seeds.  O-M-G.  I was in heaven.  Someone else ordered the Funghi pizza which is mozzarella, provolone, sweet and sour onions, oven roasted mushrooms and rosemary.  I am not a mushroom fan, but she was a huge fan of it and it looked mighty pretty!  Two others ordered the Vendura which is broccolini, whipped ricotta, mozzarella, garlic chili flakes, EVOO and baby spinach.  I kept eyeballing it the entire time as well!  The pizzas are presented very well and the ingredients are very good quality.  For a personal pizza, the prices vary from 13-17, so it can be on the pricey end depending on what you get.  But knowing I can have this for two days for lunch with leftovers isn't a bad deal!!!
name: Fabrica Pizza
categories: Restaurants, Salad, Pizza, Italian

text:
I am so happy I discovered this little frozen yogurt joint! It's located inside the same building as Tyger Tyger, and although I've never tried the food I think I might now! 

I got the ube flavored frozen yogurt with fruity pebbles. It was really yummy and not too sweet. This frozen yogurt seems to be better quality than other chain frozen yogurts, so the higher price makes sense. They had other flavors including thai tea and black sesame. 

Super nice staff and lovely aesthetic inside.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
This place is located in the Funk Zone, which is a quaint little open market style place that hosts a few other establishments. The interior is very trendy with a bunch of aesthetic decorations, including the famous pink lanterns that line the ceiling and help cultivate the super cute vibe inside.

Opted for ice cream in a taiyaki fish cone. Keep in mind that these cones are significantly smaller than the ones that are often seen in popular chains throughout LA/socal. Couldn't tell if the worker who was swirling my ice cream was being stingy but my ice cream came out looking very sad and lopsided. Paid an additional 50 cents for fruity pebbles on top. In photo attached you can see that my hand is way bigger than the cone itself and that the serving of ice cream is quite small as well. Overall the presentation was quite disappointing and looked very different from the photos advertised online. 

In terms of the actual taste..
Taiyaki fish cones: I saw that there were multiple already premade and on display, you could tell that it wasn't fresh and had been sitting out for a while. The best part of taiyaki cones is the contrasting crunchy exterior to the soft inside breading after it is first made, it could have been a lot better if their cones were made-to-order. The bread was, as expected, hard from having been set out for a while and also was quite bland, there was nothing memorable about it. 

Ice cream: They had four flavors available, chocolate, vanilla, black sesame, and mango sticky rice. Opted for the latter two in hopes of finally having some type of Asian-inspired dessert in this city which has very mediocre Asian cuisine overall. First of all, the cone was so small that there was very little ice cream that came with it. Black sesame did not have that mellow nutty flavor and strangely tasted more sour and lemon-y. The mango sticky rice did not taste even remotely of mango and had a very potent aftertaste that I could not get off my tongue. To be honest I didn't want to be too critical given that it is probably impossible to measure up to actual Asian ice cream shops back in the bay or LA but it's hard to describe what exactly they tasted like - I just know for sure that they did NOT taste anything like what I was expecting. 

For a place to specifically pride itself in serving Asian ingredients and spices in their ice cream, this place was really far off the mark. I really wanted to like it but both flavors were extremely disappointing - neither of them tasted anything like what they were labeled and I honestly have to question if it is because the establishment is run by people who do not have an in-depth understanding of Asian flavors. Disappointed, but I shouldn't be surprised given that this is Santa Barbara. Considering the price point for what you get, including paying an additional 50 cents for each topping, I have to give this place a solid no. Overall, I encourage you all to save your money or spend a little more and go to McConnell's instead for some actual high quality ice cream.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Honestly this is probably a 2 star (wouldn't go there again, unless someone else was paying), but it wasn't horrible, so I'll do a three.

There are things about this place that could be really good, If they just tweaked it a bit.

What we had: Koran corn dog, soup dumpling, hamachi, Wagyu nigiri, Chilean sea bass, short ribs, black sesame ice cream, cheese cake. (Total $170 before tip)

There were no real stand outs here, not for the pricing. If we're being real, pay a little more and go to Hinata. That's worth the money. 

Anyway, the worst part of the meal was the sushi rice. How can it be mushy and hard at the same time? How can you open a higher end restaurant that serves sushi and then not try to attempt to make good sushi rice? Here's some advice to the chef, take a trip to Asaka or even one world market, and taste their rice's flavor and texture... then try to replicate it. If they did that, then they would have something good going on, because the sushi flavors are there, the rice just ruins it all.

The soup dumpling doesn't really have soup in it. So that was unfortunate. The flavor was on point, but I don't think they have enough congealed liquid to meat ratio for it to be really soupy, and their skin is too thick. 

I can't speak to the Chilean sea bass, as that was more my husbands deal, it was cooked fine, but the charred (korean bbq-esque flavor) was a bit odd putting. 

My short ribs were good, I though it was cooked nicely. If I were them, I'd do a pickled daikon or maybe a chayote, instead of a red radish, but the slices of Asian pear were a good accompaniment.

The deserts were alright, our favorite was the black sesame. 

Nothing to write home about here folks. Don't let the ambiance (it's really nice in there) fool you. The food is not as good as the location. Cool vibes doesn't equal good food.
name: Modita
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Dim Sum, Asian Fusion, Noodles, Chinese, Pan Asian

text: Excellent service. The soft had a wonderful texture but not a lot of flavor, unfortunately. I tried black sesame and it did nothing for me. I got coconut and it just tasted like cream with a mild essence of coconut. I appreciate it wasn't super sweet, though. My wife got a berry basil popsicle, there was no vegan soft serve option. It was very flavorful but too tart. She couldn't finish it. Ambience is the best. Really cool with the pink lights.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
Finally! Mochi donuts in STL Thank you Pokedoke for bringing these amazing chewy donuts to us

Mochi donuts were originated from from Japan and is one of the star product at Mister Donut in Taiwan. It was super popular since about at least 10 years ago in Taiwan. I never seen these being sold here in the US until recent years. It's becoming a new hit in cities with more Asian populations. I am so super excited that we can finally get them here in St. Louis! 

If you never tried, they are a hybrid of cake donuts and mochi, with a dense and chewy texture. Usually a sugar/flavored glazed will be applied on one side of it. This week, they have Strawberry and Black Sesame and I love them both!!! Not quite as chewy as I would hope but it definitely meets my standard and every bite is so joyful

They have had Matcha, Taro, Cookies and Cream and powdered sugar flavors before. I think only the Delmar and Kirkwood locations have it right now. And they said you can contacted them with few days notice to customize the flavor you like for your event! I will definitely try to get all the flavors in the future
name: PokeDoke
categories: Food, Poke, Bubble Tea, Korean, Restaurants

text:
Monkeyshine has finally opened! A cute little ice cream place that shares a sliver of the new hot spot restaurant Tyger Tyger located in the Funk Zone. 

I came here with my son to check it out and we were kindly greeted by the two employees working. Sorry didn't get their names but they were both helpful and offered us samples to try of their unique soft serve ice cream flavors. Toasted rice, Thai chili chocolate, black sesame, and ginger. The toasted rice was the winner so we chose that flavor. 

I wanted to try the cool looking fish cone despite them looking dry, burnt, and not too pretty but I was very surprised at how yummy they were! It's comparable to a waffle cone with a hint of cinnamon flavor. Definitely recommend trying it! 

Like most of the new hot spots popping up around town the prices aren't cheap! After ordering two fish cones, and five toppings later the price came out to $14. Not cheap by any means but it was still a nice treat and fun to try! 

Overall a cute little place to check out with the best exterior in the Funk Zone! Love the pretty pink lanterns outside.
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text: Amazing food! We came here for our 11th anniversary dinner. We ordered the arugula salad with honey whipped ricotta. Amazing! Then the broccoli and avocado side with black sesame seeds, sooo good! For our mains we had the papardelle veal osso bucco, and the pork chop with a crispy sweet potato risotto. Truly the meal was amazing all around. The desserts we tried were the bread pudding and the butterscotch and creme fraiche, such a good ending to an amazing meal. Would recommend this to anyone!
name: Tredici Enoteca
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Wine Bars, Bars, Nightlife, Italian

text:
Matcha Black Sesame Latte ($6.75+tax) tasted more like black sesame with milk. There was a hint of matcha flavour though. Edmonton was getting cold, so this warm drink was gooooodd!! However, I think I would prefer just the Matcha Latte drinks instead.

Matcha Rare Cheesecake ($5.75+tax) was creamy and had strong matcha flavour! Super delicious! Lovedddd it! My fave dessert!

Yuzu Tart ($5.25+tax) was nommy as well! Personally, I don't really like sour desserts, but this was actually pretty good! Normally, the yuzu flavour desserts don't have much of the "yuzu" taste, but this tart had quite a strong yuzu flavour! Not bad!

Overall, I love anything that has matcha in it! I can't wait for Vancouver location to open. Is it still "opening soon"? What's taking them so long to open in Vancouver? I feel like it's been 6 yrs since they announced it..... Highly recommend this place for the matcha lovers.
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Bakeries

text:
Monkeyshine is located in the Funk Zone in the same building as Tyger Tyger and Dart Coffee! This cute new little ice cream place is delicious.

They have a few different flavors that you can choose from. They have a toasted rice, thai chili chocolate, black sesame, and a ginger flavor. They were all really good! I ended up going with the toasted rice flavor which was my favorite. I got it with one of their fish cones which was also super tasty and it tasted just like a waffle cone. 

They also have tons of toppings to choose from as well. I didn't end up getting any this time but I plan to in the future. They even have vegan options here too! I'm not vegan but my friend is so I'll be sure to tell her!

Overall the atmosphere of this place, the ice cream, and the cone make me want to come back here soon! Thanks for the awesome first experience Monkeyshine, I'll be back soon to try your toppings!
name: Monkeyshine
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food

text:
I love coming here for desserts and drinks! It's one of the regular places that I frequent. There aren't many places that offer traditional japanese desserts and authentic matcha drinks and desserts. 

One of my favorite things is the parfaits! There are couple varieties. My favorite has a few layers of the mix soft serve, toasted rice, sweet azuki bean (red bean) paste + mochi balls. Mmm so good!

My go to drink is the Black Sesame Matcha latte. Such a great combo! They have soy milk for their lattes if you are lactose intolerant. 

The staff are very friendly and always helpful to explain anything from the menu.

If you are new to matcha and want their soft serve, start with the vanilla/matcha mix, all matcha may be too strong to start with off the bat. 

They have a cute little tatami room for bigger groups where you need to take off your shoes to sit inside.

Earlier this year, they opened their patio so you can enjoy the sun!
name: TSUJIRI Japanese Tea House
categories: Food, Coffee & Tea, Desserts, Bakeries

text:
Stopped by finally for Devour Indy. Some hits, some misses.


Bao bun 5/5 - the slaw is a perfect balance to the softness of the bun. The grilled pork had a great smoky taste. Oof yes loved it.

Hamachi Sushi 4.5/5 - the garlic chili crunch really came out in this one, and it balanced surprisingly well with the asian pear slivers. I could definitely have a bottle of the garlic chili crunch. Only complaint was the sushi rice, a little too hard in parts.

Edamame 4/5 - simple and tasty with a kick from that garlic chili sauce. The spice from the garlic chili sauce was a little overwhelming at times making it hard to distinguish the soy sauce and lime. Did we finish it all though? Absolutely. 

Tikka masala 4/5 - so creamy but with a great balance of lightness, especially with the cauliflower. It could use a slight twist of freshness. The dish is also vegan and gluten free!

Tamarind noodles 4.5/5 - hefty serving of jumbo shrimp just slightly overcooked. The bean sprouts offer so much textural contrast, and there's a little spice but isn't overwhelming.

Center cut sirloin 2.5/5 - most of this fell flat, the broccolini was super dry, the sirloin was also tough to cut into. The mash potatoes flavor was great but the texture could have been creamier. 

Mango sorbet with plantains 4/5 - loved the sorbet, loved the plantains, didn't love them together. One of my plantains was a little hard but the rest were fantastic with the dulce de leche. The sorbet was great with coconut flakes. 

Sesame icecream with chocolate mint ganache 3.5/5 - I didn't love this pairing, couldn't put my finger on what exactly wasn't working here. Black sesame was overpowered by the chocolate mint. 

Ambiance 8/10 - the music was a little too hype for the rest of the place and it was quite loud. It's VERY chilly so bring a jacket if you get cold easily. Signal is spotty but they have wifi. 

Service 10/10 - came in without a reservation and they told us a wait time and texted us when the place was ready. Our server was very kind and attentive.
name: Modita
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Dim Sum, Asian Fusion, Noodles, Chinese, Pan Asian

text:
I've been quite pleased with the food that I've gotten from the Chop Chop Shop.  A big portion of the menu consists of bowls that you pick and choose ingredients from.  You choose a meat, a sauce, and sides.  The Chop Chop Chimichurri sauce is absolutely delicious.  The "mean greens" side is something I haven't had before.  The menu says it's Asian greens with black sesame sauce.  It complements the meat in the bowl really well.  There are several items on the menu I'm looking forward to trying.

The parking situation is baffling to me.  This restaurant and the dead pizza place next to it share three parking spots.  If you go at night you can park at some of the nearby businesses that are closed.  I have no idea what you would do during the day.
name: Chop Chop Shop
categories: Asian Fusion, Korean, Comfort Food, American (New), Restaurants, Chicken Shop, Japanese

text: Hot take but when you live in Manzi, you see the reality that Carrillo is...well. She has her good days and she certainly had her bad days. I will give them this though, their brunch on the weekends was top tier. During my CHI-5 freshman year my friends and I would commute to Carrillo for Sunday brunch (we were very late risers so it was that serious). Nothing in all of the UCSB dining halls outbeats the egg station. Chefs kiss. Anyway I appreciated their multicultural days once a quarter. Furthermore, their fruit selection was always better than Ortega and DLG. The froyo is either a hit or miss. Once they had red bean and black sesame and me and all the intl girls were here for it, but sometimes they had REDBULL flavor during midterm season...yikes...but all said, Carrillo is pretty standard.
name: Carrillo Dining Commons
categories: Restaurants, Italian, Asian Fusion, Breakfast & Brunch, Delis, American (New), American (Traditional)

text:
I came here with a friend for her birthday dinner. The vibe and atmosphere of the place was great. We started with cocktails, Topaz and Hyacinth, both were nice. The Hyacinth had a nice little kick to it from the jalapenos.

My friend loves soup dumplings so we ordered those, great taste, but not as soupy as we were hoping. Then we split the Crab Roll, not your typical sushi roll, had some mint in it with a strawberry-jalapeno jam on top, very refreshing taste. We were still a little hungry so we tried the most popular item on the menu, the Bao Buns. Those were delicious. For dessert my friend ordered the Black Sesame Ice Cream, highly recommend. 

Great service and a fun, new place to earn those CRG points.
name: Modita
categories: Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Dim Sum, Asian Fusion, Noodles, Chinese, Pan Asian

text:
Cute little poke spot on Passyunk. The staff was super friendly even though she was the only one working and there was a line of people waiting to be served, her energy was  great. She even offered me samples of her 3 special sauce - black sesame was my favorite. 

I customized my own poke  bowl and she was really generous with the serving size. I even got a free sirarcha sauce because we spent over $20. The bowl was delicious, however, mid way through my meal, my stomach was not feeling the greatest. My boyfriend also felt the same. It's most likely the salmon and tuna that was not very fresh. 

Love the service  but I'm not sure if I will be returning just based off of my experience.
name: Big Catch Poke
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Poke, Japanese, Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Bubble Tea

text:
I contacted Bellefonte Cafe through their facebook, last week, looking to make reservations for my birthday. Dave, whom I think might be the owner, responded promptly. For my first visit, it was just a friend and I. This restaurant seems to have once been a home and has since be converted. So, be mindful when parking, it's street parking and there are houses nearby. 

There is a painted sign out front and there is a sphere water fountain in front of the stairs. When stepping onto the porch there are two entrances; a door to your left and a door if you keep walking straight. I think it is seat yourself, because I've never seen anyone waiting at the door to seat people and I've seen other customers just walk in and seat themselves. Both times I've made reservations they have a little paper placeholder with your name and reservation time on it. I like that they use both sides of it; they seem environmentally conscious. They don't automatically put straws (or lemons) in your complimentary glass of water and their take-out containers are recyclable, if not biodegradable. I would describe Bellefonte Cafe's style as eclectic. I like that none of the tables, chairs match, and it is boldy colored with complementary artwork.

My 1st visit: As we were sitting down, I told the waiter I was communicating with someone running their facebook and asked to speak with them. Dave, the owner (I think), came over to our table to introduce himself. I like face-to-face communication after corresponding online in a situation like that; good owners care about their customers. He was nice to give me a complimentary dessert for my birthday. 

The waiter seemed to be, I don't know if distracted was the word to describe it, but something was off. One thing I wasn't a fan of was that he never came to ask how things were. They weren't that busy either so I don't know if there was something happening behind the scenes.  He was prompt with refilling our water glasses though. 

I ordered their Thai Chicken Salad (slided chicken breast, orange lime ginger sauce, black sesame seeds, scallions, seasonal greens, grape tomato, cucumber.) The greens and other veggies were super fresh. But the chicken was dry and the sauce was overpoweringly tangy. Also, I didn't taste any ginger. I think maybe that would have balanced out the sauce a little more.

My 2nd visit today was much better. Our waiter was a curly haired bearded guy named Dave. My mom and I weren't really interested in any of their apps so we shared an order of their Hummus Stuffed Avocado (half avocado stuffed with homemade hummus, topped with grape tomato, red onion, Kalamata olives, extra virgin olive oil, chopped herbs, served with crostinis.) It was really good. Their hummus was delicious! Also, the Kalamata olives were the best I've ever had. The ingredients go really well together, and I think it's perfect portion for two.

For my entree I ordered their Pine Nut Salad (roasted pine nuts, blue cheese, scallions, seasonal greens, grape tomatoes, cucumber, honey mustard vinaigrette) with chicken for an extra $2. Again, their veggies were very fresh. Their tomatoes and cucumber were my favorites. I asked for my dressing on the side. Dave dropped off our food and a waitress came over with the dressing a couple secs later. I tasted it and my mom tasted it and it tasted like regular vinaigrette. When we saw Dave, I asked about the honey mustard vinaigrette that was supposed to be with the salad. He went and got it but I don't know if there was confusion happening or what, but he said it was the same one that the waitress brought. But the one he brought, you could taste the honey mustard, with the other one, you could taste the vinegar. Regardless, they were both yummy. I just wanted to make sure I tasted both of them.

Also, they seem to have a musician every night around like 6:30ish. It's a fun atmosphere with good food. I'm sure I will be back and am looking forward to trying other things. The town of Bellefonte has it's own local flavor (they also have arts festival too). Check them out.
name: Bellefonte Cafe
categories: Breakfast & Brunch, Food, Tapas Bars, Restaurants, Antiques, American (Traditional), Coffee & Tea, Venues & Event Spaces, American (New), Vegetarian, Shopping, Comfort Food, Event Planning & Services

text:
On our hunt for new restaurants to try, the hubby and I went here for an early dinner last night.

Here's the run down:

We shared a few small plates, three of which were on the regular menu and one special for the night.  The special was beef bone marrow with roasted poblano peppers and parmasean cheese with onion pancakes.  I don't think you can ever go wrong ordering bone marrow... it's the best butter substitute ever!  The onion pancakes were nice and dense.  We also got the shrimp and green papaya salad, the okonomiyaki fries and the kimchi katsu don bowl.  The standout were the fries... those bonito flakes were a fun and delicious treat.  We liked the kimchi bowl the least.  The pork was too fried and I felt like the kimchi wasn't spicy enough... although it had great acidity.  

We also shared a small bowl of the house ramen.  No added shennanigans.  The broth was ok... needed more seasoning I felt.  We kept adding the spice and black sesame salt that they have on the side as condiments.  The noodles were well done, so that's a plus.

For dessert, we had the chocolate pecan chocolate pie.  That was scrumptious!  It was chewy and had the right balance of everything.  Although, at $6.50, we thought it was overpriced for a slice of pie.  

Overall, I would give it try if you're looking for something new and interesting.
name: Noodle & Pie
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion, Noodles

text:
I had dinner at Double Knot last night with a group of 6 and it was spectacular! I had heard good things about this restaurant, but it exceeded my expectations.  We got the chef's tasting menu for 5 people and thoroughly enjoyed it. There are two options: pick your own dishes (roughly one from each section of the menu) or just let the chef choose. We did the former - pick our own - but the waitress helped guide us towards some of her favorite and/or most popular dishes. After that delicious dish after delicious dish came out as they were ready. (The 6th guest was gluten free and the waitress helped her select allergy-friendly items separately that she said she enjoyed).

We ended up with:
Yellowtail sashimi - everyone loved this - the flavors were great and fish so tender
Tuna with avocado - also a big hit and great quality fish and sauce very tasty
Japanese fried chicken - I think the restaurant is known for this - it was very good
Edamame dumpling - also one of the most popular dishes. Some thought this was a standout, others thought good, but not as thrilled
Salmon sushi roll - great quality, but less exciting than some other dishes
Octopus robatayaki - deliciously tender and well-seasoned
Rib-eye robatayaki - this was absolutely fantastic. You wouldn't think you could make a piece of rib-eye on a stick that much of a standout, but this dish melted in my mouth
Beef short rib - good sauce and flavor, but the robatayaki was better
Broiled sea bass - delicious, melts in your mouth - definitely a favorite
Crispy brussel sprouts - also got high marks from the table
Dessert: black sesame "cheesecake" tart - everyone seemed to like it and it had nice flavor, but the savory items definitely outshined the dessert

Overall, I think we all agreed there wasn't a bad dish. They were all great, with some standing out more than others, but really exceptional start to finish. We were also all impressed with the portion size.  For $55 they really give you your money's worth and portion out the items well.  We ended up taking home a few leftovers because we simply couldn't eat it all and were very full by the end.  Though, at the same time everyone did sample everything so it wasn't completely overwhelming. The chef's tasting was nice because everything came out such that we could split it equally and you get enough items that you're still feeling like you get to taste a lot of dishes.  I could see ordering a la carte being fun too, though, if everyone picks a few dishes they are excited about - not sure how it would price out if you did it that way. The cocktail menu also has a number of exciting options and we all enjoyed sampling with some advice from the waitress. 

The ambience of the restaurant is also very cool.  The top floor is more of a bar/lounge area, whereas the downstairs (where we ate) is setup like a speakeasy with a separate unmarked door and very cool vibe. We were also seated at probably the best table in the restaurant, a plush circle booth that is a few steps up from the main dining floor and overlooks the whole restaurant. It was more private and special (and comfortable) for our group, but we still got to enjoy the ambience of the downstairs restaurant.  Just lucked into this table, but would definitely request if possible in the future with an appropriate size group. Though the other tables I'm sure are fine and the food is the worth sitting at any table.

I will definitely be back to Double Knot!
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
This may be the best sushi I have ever eaten anywhere.  I'm no connoisseur, but I love the food at Kuramoto in Pleasant View.

This has become my favorite restaurant!  The seafood is always fresh and while I have my preferences, everything I've ever tried has been good.  My kids love the fried rice and yum-yum sauce.  The stone bowl meals are very good.  The Steak Udon soup is delicious.  The salmon teriyaki is great.  Tempura soft-shelled crab is good, Chicken bon bon, Gyoza and Butter Scallops and tempura squid are favorite appetizers for my family. My favorites are the seafood fried rice, avocado salad and my favorite is their Tiger Roll. I eat here as often as I reasonably (or unreasonably) can.

The staff is always friendly.  Oh and the ice cream (green tea, black bean, and black sesame) are a wonderful sweet ending to a meal. Dishes still tend to come out not all at the same time, but everything else makes up for that.
name: Kuramoto
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: Can't say enough about how great Itri is. They partner with Stateside Vodka, which is my favorite vodka brand, so the cocktails were fantastic. Their wood fired wings might be the best wings I've had. Seriously. The perfect amount of crispiness with the right amount of sauce with black sesame seeds and green scallions. As for the pizza, we got the margarita and N' duja and both were delicious! I look forward to going back and recommend you give them a visit!
name: Itri Wood Fired Pizza Bar
categories: Cocktail Bars, Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, Pizza

text:
I had their tasting menu ($60) with 10 selections + mochi. I let the chef choose my dishes, and here's what I got:


From specialty sashimi, the salmon with spicy ponzu and soy ginger. The salmon was nice, but the ponzu completely overpowered the fish.


From cold, the ceviche with kampachi, mango, and yuzu kosho ponzu. Also not my favorite, something about the flavors didn't sit right with me. It was pretty zingy.


From sushi/sashimi, the toro nigiri. It was really good toro and melted in my mouth.


From crispy, the shrimp taco with radish, chili, and avocado. The shrimp could've been crispier, but I really liked the creamy avocado at the bottom, and the flavors all balanced nicely.


From small, the edamame dumplings. This dish was my favorite of the evening. Edamame dumplings don't sound like much but these were creamy and delicious, and the accompanying broth tasted a lot like shiitake mushrooms.


From the robatayaki, the octopus and the rib eye scallion. The octopus was a bit overcooked and had too much sauce. The rib eye scallion was juicy, but I felt like the scallions could have had so much more flavor. I'm not sure how they managed to make scallions so tasteless, but they succeeded.


From the fish, the broiled seabass with truffle soy and pea shoots. I was pleasantly surprised by this dish, since the fish was very flaky but fatty enough to maintain its juiciness. My only complaint was that it was on the salty side.


From the sides, the black cod fried rice with miso caramel. The rice itself was prepared well, but I'm not a huge fan of sweeter dishes. Miso has a great depth of flavor, and I felt like this dish was missing some of that.


For ice cream mochi I got orange creamsicle, Belgian chocolate, and vanilla chocolate chip. They weren't anything special, and at this point I just sat there thinking really? After giving me all the least adventurous dishes you could've picked, these are the flavors you give me. I was expecting flavors much more interesting than this (like black sesame perhaps?).


That was all I got. At this point, you might be thinking, but wait. You said there were 10 selections + mochi, I only see 9 selections + mochi. Where in the world is the tenth dish? Trust me, I was wondering the same thing. Apparently because I was a solo diner, I only got 9 selections. This fact was not made apparent to me at the start of my meal, and as a result, I was pretty annoyed when I found out I would only get 9 dishes at the same price of 10. In case any of you decide to go solo at the restaurant, just keep this in mind.


All in all, this meal was incredibly ordinary. None of the dishes besides the edamame dumplings stood out to me. The chef's choices of dishes were also really boring. If you're looking for something more adventurous, I would recommend choosing your own meal.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
I came here to grab some dessert after a dinner of hand drawn noodles. There is no better way to end off the day! 

Having never had shaved ice cream or rolled ice cream before, I didn't know what to expect. We ordered the pink cosmos and matcha rolled icecream with unlimited toppings (given the small size of the cup, there really is a limit to the number of toppings you can put on. I keep imagining myself dousing the rolls with mountains of mochi and fruit pieces, but the workers are much more conservative with their serving sizes). 

BTW.. the pink spoons turn blue/purple when exposed to cold! That was really neat. 

[Food] 
I was really looking forward to seeing them shave a huge block of ice in persion, but a cup of pink appeared out of nowhere. I decided that they may have already pre-shaved and then had it in the freezer for convenience.  The texture was heavenly.. melt off the tongue... very cotton candy like. However, there was something very artificial tasting, almost medicinal, about the pink cosmos. I could not decide whether it was the ice cream base or the syrup. I would probably try the cheesecake or black sesame flavor next time

The person who made our rolled icecream was quite skilled. He produced 5 perfect rolls which were coated with our choice of toppings.The matcha rolled icecream stole the show with it's very heavy and distinctive flavor. There was a little bitterness to balance the sweetness, making the dessert quite delectable. The mochi and red beans were the perfect toppings. Unfortunately, the spoons were not quite strong enough to break through the rolls  - you definitely needed to work at it. That being said, the presentation, performance, and taste was worth 5 stars. 

We unfortunately ate all of the icecream before any photos were taken.
name: Ice Land
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Shaved Ice, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text: Excellet food my husband and I are regulars and are there at least twice a month. I always order sushi and he always orders steak. We love the food and staff feels little dinner with friends and we can't get enough of the home made specialty ice cream. We recommend the green tea and black sesame mmmm so delicious.
name: Kuramoto
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: Best coffee shop in Philly, hands down. Inventive lattes (cardamom rose!) to activated charcoal bagels, it's a really unique place. Great customer service. I would recommend the vegan lox with cream cheese on a black sesame bagel. AMAZING.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
We walked 3 miles out of our way to come here while spending the weekend in Philly, and it was completely worth it.

Fresh, hand drawn noodles in a delicious broth. I got the egg and vegetable, husband got the duck. I'm pretty sure he had a spiritual awakening over the whole thing. It was aromatic and so yummy. Not to mention the huge portions for the reasonable price. Cannot go wrong.

We also had the peanut noodles, which were equally plentiful and cheap, along with the marinated beef. Everything was so wonderful. I really had to struggle to make myself stop eating. There's soy and rooster sauce on the table along with a delicious black sesame and chili oil. I'm legit salivating just thinking about it.

The restaurant is small with no frills, and busy - we popped in a little before 3pm and we got the last table available. I don't even want to think about how it must be during actual meal times. The staff was friendly and the food came out quick.

I know this will become a must-go place every time we visit the city from now on.
name: Nan Zhou Hand Drawn Noodle House
categories: Specialty Food, Noodles, Ethnic Food, Chinese, Comfort Food, Restaurants, Food

text:
This was by far our favorite restaurant of the trip.  I know when you think of New Orleans, you immediately think of Israeli food - NOT - but I guess we just like what we like.

There were six of us and we made our lunch reservation a little over a week in advance.  However, it was already slim pickings for time slots since we were visiting over a very popular weekend.  Luckily, you have the option to try for outdoor seating the day of.  You can call Shaya at 10am when they first open to make a same-day patio reservation, but we instead just showed up at the restaurant when we wanted to eat and were very lucky they had a patio table available for 6 immediately.

Aside from being able to eat our lunch at a normal hour, eating outside was even more of a blessing because the A/C inside the restaurant was FREEZING.  While I am sure that wood-burning oven makes the staff toasty warm, I am just as sure the indoor guests were most uncomfortable.  Other reviews even mentioned teeth chattering!

Once we were seated in the lovely and comfortable patio area, our epic meal began.  The service was quick and friendly.  The drinks were tasty.  The food was amazing.  The portions are pretty small, as you might expect, so order a bunch of things to share, and maybe some duplicate dishes too to make sure there is enough for everyone.  I wouldn't come here planning to stick to a modest budget.  This is the perfect restaurant to go nuts and end a nice vacation with a bang.

They brought out only one or two fluffy pitas at a time for our table of six to share.  We tore into each pita like animals, scalding our hands in the process every. single. time.  Meanwhile, the table beside us used a fork and knife to cut up their pita, like civilized people.  

I'm pretty sure we enjoyed our meal more.

Normally when a restaurant offers me a dessert menu I take a hard pass.  In this case, I *demanded* to see the dessert menu and, though we had eaten plenty already, ordered three dessert items.

There you have it.  I will compile a list of what we ordered below.  Everything was good.  If I were to skip something, it might be the labneh - but even that was good.  If you are a fan of Mediterranean food, you can't go wrong here.

Salatim:
Lutenitsa (x2)
Bulgarian purée of roasted pepper, eggplant, garlic and tomato

Tabouleh
parsley and bulgar wheat salad, red onion, toasted almonds, preserved lemon

Labneh
Progress Farm's yogurt, wax peppers, radishes

Wood Roasted Brussel Sprouts
black harissa, tahini, pickled onions

Some kind of delicious seasoned olive oil also came with the pita for dipping.

Hummus:
Curried Cauliflower
caramelized onions and cilantro

Lamb Ragú
with crispy chickpeas

Small Plates:
Falafel
cabbage salad and cucumber tzatziki (the cabbage salad had some kind of floral vinaigrette - I think orange blossom - that we were captivated by)

Crispy Halloumi
strawberries, mint, pistachio

Salad:
Baby Kale
golden beets, black garlic-verjus vinaigrette, pumpkin seeds, satsumas

Israeli Salad
cherry tomatoes, cucumbers, parsley, za'atar and Bulgarian feta

Drinks:
Some sort of pomegranate/lemon soda... there might have been other stuff in it I don't remember, but most importantly, it was tasty.

Some kind of white wine.

THEY WERE OUT OF COFFEE  :-O

Desserts:
Malabi
vanilla bean custard, pomegranate, kumquat, coconut, black sesame

Orange Blossom Kanafeh
crispy filo, sweet cream, passionfruit, pistachio

Milk and Honey
cheesecake, mixed nut granola, burnt honey gelato
name: Shaya
categories: Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Restaurants, Desserts, Food, Kosher, American (New)

text:
I stumbled upon Will BYOB from the fact that I've passed through this little dainty restaurant at East Passyunk and decided to go on a Sunday evening with my gf. 

Will has fixed tasting menu every Sundays and ala carte on the rest of the days. 
Overall, we had really fantastic experience dining at Will. The nuances were romantic and fitting dim lighting, service was attentive but not overbearing. Good space between the tables. 

Okay, here is the most important part : foods were awesome. We had the entire tasting menu with additional rabbit terrine+ foei gras with pistachio tuile/blood orange. It was worth the money. 

Appetizer : 
Sweet Potato+ Apple Potage - Banyuls | Pecans & Pumpernickel | Asian Pears --amazing!! I should say this was my favorite part.
White Miso Cavatelli - Black Olive| Mussels | Piperade - really enjoyed the piperade with enough hints of the mussels.
Duck Confit Royale - Lentils Du Puy | Potato Mousseline | Alliums -- A little too heavy but great taste.

Entree :
Rhode Island Skate Wing with Fennel Moutarde | Yuzu | Chickpea Panisse --beautifully well balanced entree, pretty dish too! 
72 Hour Beef Rib Steak with Parsnip Creme | Glazed Salsify | Pumpkin -- very soft and tender, nicely cooked to rare medium - servers didn't ask our preferences but it worked just fine for us.

Dessert :
Almond Financier with Pineapple | Black Sesame Buttercream | Roasted Banana -- Not too sweet! which suits me, love the dessert especially the black sesame buttercream.
Bergamot Creme Brulee with Szechuan Biscuit -- the creme brulee has very lemony taste. I didn't care that much for the szechuan biscuit. 

Overall , I feel as if the tasting menu were built based on Light vs. Heavy!
I'd definitely come back to Will BYOB without any doubt.
name: Will BYOB
categories: Restaurants, French, American (New)

text:
Finally they open!!! Have been waiting this for couple months. I think they supposed to open on July, but they open on August 1st. 
The first day I got Matcha Chocolate Truffles & Angus Short Ribs. Both of them so delicious!!
If they put matcha ice cream it will great!!! I like the crepes, not too sweet, and enough crisps for me. 
And the Angus Beef is yummy!!! 
And I also got Black Sesame Shake. For me, I don't really like it. I feel like it bit bitter. I don't know maybe I just eat the crepes or the shake is not sweet at all.

And the second day I got Chocolate Nut Party. It so chocolate! Not too much sweet but too much chocolate for me. If you are chocolate lover you should try this! And I got Dark Chocolate Shake. And it still so chocolate so thick!
 
The line was so crazy! But not too long to wait. When I came it was number 50 something and mine was 67. Then I got my crepes 30 minutes later.
