Not bad, some bubble tea store longer than that and that's only drink. But this is freshly made. They make the skin after you order it then put all the toppings. 

Very recommended! First in Philadelphia (I think) Japanese Crepes!
name: T-Swirl Crêpe
categories: Salad, Coffee & Tea, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Creperies, Gluten-Free, Restaurants, Japanese

text:
I visited Bubble House on a whim, during a quick two-day trip to Philly. I happened to read a mention of the joint online the day I was there, and I am a fan of bubble tea so I couldn't resist. It must be said, though, that I am no bubble tea afficionado. It has been awhile since I have had anything but the super sugary, frozen bubble teas at a local chain, which I still enjoy.

We arrived at Bubble House with the kind of appetite where anything you stuff in your mouth is going to taste gourmet. Additionally, we were on vacation and in love, so maybe my review is biased, but I loved the place.

The wife and I split a veggie hoagie and salad, which were both great but not especially memorable. I have a real fondness for spicy potatoes, and predictably loved the wasabi mashed potatoes. The sweet potato fries and the orange ginger dipping sauce were the real winners, though. If I lived nearby, I could see myself swinging by for bubble tea and fries pretty regularly.

The bubble tea was so good we ordered a gigantic, Big Gulp sized one to go after each enjoying the ones we got during our meal. Probably my favorite was one I'd never order: black sesame. Good thing I have my better half around to order the right thing. I wish I had bubble tea like this in my town; you can actually taste the tea while still feeling like you got dessert in a cup.
name: The Bubble House
categories: American (Traditional), Sandwiches, Tea Rooms, Coffee & Tea, Food, Asian Fusion, Restaurants

text: Tried the lychee and strawberry one and it was super delicious. I really like how the crepes here are a little crunchy around the edges - I was afraid they would be soft and soggy but these had a great texture. This place has a credit card minimum though so we also ended up having to get a blended black sesame smoothie to reach it.
name: T-Swirl Crêpe
categories: Salad, Coffee & Tea, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Creperies, Gluten-Free, Restaurants, Japanese

text:
Absolutely LOVED double Knot!

Our Japanese grill favorites in order: 
1) Kobe beef
2) chicken breast
3) short rib
4) lobster - which was still amazing!

Other loves:
-king salmon sashimi
-yellowtail scallion roll-so simple yet so good!
-duck "scrapple" bao which was more confit than scrapple
-black sesame mochi ice cream! The perfect ending to an amazing dinner 

Likes:
Bacon yakisoba

Did NOT like the Tofu-it was heavily fried and mostly consisted of breading! Avoid!

The service was friendly and we will be back soon!
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
Our first foray to shanghai grill was led by recommendations from friends.  We ordered the traditional Shanghai dishes to see if Edmonton has finally found it's very own truly authentic Shanghai eats.  Nope.  While I must admit the drunken chicken was a tasty appetizer, the rest of the meal was quite oily and pedestrian.  You may expect the same quality from any "pick 3 combo" Chinese take away from a mall.  
The xiao long bao WERE quite nice the first time we went, but subsequent visits when we went with other friends were met with poorer and poorer quality of food.
During our last visit, the "XLB" ,as they liked to coin it in the Edmonton Journal (I would regard this as a marketing "branding" scheme on behalf of the owner's Journal advertisement), were not freshly steamed, cold, and quite possibly microwaved? The wrapper lacked it's much desired chewy/stretchiness and the signature "jus" from a xiao long bao was missing.  
For dessert, we ordered the "tong yuan", which is akin to a Japanese mochi.  Tong yuan, if you wiki it, are glutinous rice dumplings, inour case, filled with black sesame paste in a sweet soup.  They should be delectably chewy and a burst of intense flavour when the filling erupts from your bite.  Our tong yuan however...
Well first, there were bits of carrot, mushrooms, and napa cabbage in our tong yuan's sweet soup (we had earlier ordered a savoury soup as part of our meal which had these peculiarly same ingredients).  When inquired about this, our server merely said, and I paraphrase but do not exaggerate, "well we reheat the sweet soup in our woks, so maybe some of other bits of food found its way in", as if everything was perfectly normal and that we were silly in thinking otherwise.  Next, the soup was speckled with bits of black sesame paste that broke out of our tong yuan.  Then the tong yuan itself. They were overboiled, sludgy, not chewy at all.  Some because of premature eruptions, were empty of their black sesame innards.  As one who buys and eats tong yuan from the frozen section of T&T, it is easy to see and taste that Shanghai Grill's tong yuan were not homemade (as they sheepishly try to deny) but bought out.  In addition, they couldn't even reheat and prepare them properly in accord to the manufacturer's instructions.

Well, keep waiting Edmonton, hopefully we will be blessed with a true Shanghai restaurant in our near future.
name: Shanghai Grill
categories: Specialty Food, Chinese, Restaurants, Food, Ethnic Food

text:
I'm amazed at just how disappointed I am by today's lunch. Why don't I just toss it up as rubbish and move on with my day? Mainly because I only had $10 in cash at the NoLibs 2nd Street Fair to spend on food and $6 of that $10 was, basically, wasted leaving me feeling unsatisfied.

I thought that the Dan Dan Noodles sounded really good because I adore those noodles at Han Dynasty. Well, not all Dan Dan Noodles are created equal. DumpnRoll's version was made with Raman Noodles (the packaged kind you get for 50 cents with the flavor packet- and they could have benefited, greatly from the flavor packet). Do you know those tiny, foil packets are like silver dollars in jail? Learned that from OITNB. Anyway, the Raman were topped with shredded carrot, mini cucumber batons, slivered scallions, black sesame seeds and served with a small container of mildly spicy peanut sauce. I asked for hot sauce, but they did not have any which dumbfounded me as Asian food is always offered with Sriracha or chili oil.

The Raman Noodles were cooked to, almost, mush. The veggies atop were fresh & crisp. The sauce, although it offered some heat, was extraordinarily bland and not quite enough for all the noodles. I thought that the amount of sauce was the cause of its tastelessness, so I returned to the truck, now ravenous, and requested another container of sauce which I enthusiastically emptied onto the noodles.

I was so voracious, I ate half of them, flavorless, in all their squishy splendor. Now here I am with a belly fully of Raman and $4..
name: Dump-N-Roll
categories: Food, Food Trucks, Caterers, Chinese, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Japanese, Event Planning & Services, Italian, Steakhouses, Dim Sum, Street Vendors

text:
A friend of mine reccomended this place to me. I was a little distressed when I heard that they put mango, macadamia nuts, cilantro, and asparagus in some of their rolls. 

I'm not a sushi snob; it doesn't matter to me how "Western" or "Eastern" or authentic my sushi is, so long as the fish is fresh and it tastes good. But I am rather picky about what goes into my food, and for some reason those mentioned ingredients just didn't sound appetizing as part of my sushi. That being said, it took me a while to work up the guts to try this place out.

I went on a Saturday afternoon/early evening with my boyfriend. We wanted to make sure that we were there for the dinner menu, so we could try the full assortment of what they had to offer. 

When we came in, the hostess/waitress asked if we'd prefer to sit at the bar. Since this was our first time to Sushi Moto, we wanted a chance to peruse the menu at leisure with no pressure to order right away. I requested a table instead, and the lady seemed somewhat miffed by that, but brought us to a two-seater anyway. I mentioned that this was our first time, hoping to get some reccomendations, but after our drink order, she left us with the menus and no real explanation of what we were supposed to do next.

I've only ever been to Sushi Pier, where they leave a checklist of what sushi they offer. After you make your selections, they go off to make them. We had no such offering, but there --was-- a little call button on the edge of our table. We weren't sure if we were supposed to ring the bell when we were ready to make an order, or what. So we just waited until the waitress came back with our drinks. She pulled out a pen (which she kept dropping and having to pick up from under our table) and asked us what we wanted to eat.

My boyfriend and I had ordered the "All-you-can-eat" dinner special, of course, which is about $21.95 per person. I had heard that you could also get endless appetizers from the dinner menu, too, but that wasn't really the reason why we were checking this place out. (I did break down and tried the shrimp tempura appetizer towards the end, though. It wasn't anything exceptional, just the standard fried fare; if you've had one tempura shrimp, you've had them all, I guess. Not even the dipping sauce was very memorable. All I can recall was that it was some sweet soy sauce blend, but not very noteworthy.)

Let me say right now that Sushi Moto specializes in different long rolls and not much else. Sure, you have the typical Japanese cuisine, too, like terriyaki or udon, but when there is "sushi" in the restaurant name, you kind of expect that to be the prize winner. They have about 40 different long rolls, but when I say "different" I mean that they change up the ingredients here and there to make a "new" roll.

For example, I started with the Blast Roll (made with smoked salmon, cream cheese, cucumber and green onion). The smoked salmon was definately a change from typical sake/salmon that you find in most sushi. My boyfriend hates anything that tastes even remotely fishy, so I was sure he'd hate the smoked salmon, too. He managed to ingest it, though, much to my surprise, but I do have to say that smoked salmon does have a strong flavor, so buyer beware if you prefer a more subtle taste to your sushi.

Now, about four rolls down I found the Cilantro Roll, which is pretty much just the Blast Roll, only without the cream cheese and with cilantro instead.  And even further down, was the Steady Wild Ride, wich was, again, like the Blast Roll, only without the cucumber and now they fried it, tempura-style. 

Aside from the recycled ingredients, almost all of the long rolls are cooked in some way. I was hard pressed to find a single piece of raw fish in any of them. Sure, you can order the nigiri--and I did, to test the tobiko (flying fish roe) and the ebi (shrimp), both of which turned out to be just okay--but like I said earlier, Sushi Moto specializes in long rolls. For all the "diversity" of the menu, there really wasn't any.

We also tried the California Roll, the Cabin Fever (one of the ones with mango and macadamia nuts), the Friday Night (it had some sort of secret sauce on it that tasted suspiciously like plain mayonaise), the Maui Wowie (another one with mango and nuts), and the Spider Roll (the flavor of the smoked salmon killed everything else). We also ordered a Pandora's Box (with grilled asparagus, mushrooms, carrots, roasted garlic, carmalized red onions) and a Treading Lightly (with artichoke hearts, carrots, avocado, macadamia nuts, and black sesame seeds). 

By this point, I was rather sick of eating warm rolls. Everything had been served at room temperature or above, even the nigiri, which I assumed would have been cooler since it wasn't cooked like everything else. I was dying for some cold fish.

Since this review is out of room, let me summarize: Sushi Moto = just okay.
name: Sushi Moto
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text:
Wow -- so delicious. I loved that there are so many options and each dish is small, so you can try a lot!

The only downside is that the waiters were almost too attentive, taking away our dishes nearly seconds after we finished. Additionally, I felt like most of our dishes were on the sweeter side. A bit more salt would be preferred.

For more details on why I loved my meal...

Small hot dishes:
-short rib: really delicious flavor. Super tender!
-rib eye with scallions: similar flavor to the short rib. Also very good, but I preferred the short rib as I thought it was more flavorful.
-tuna with rice cracker: the cracker (basically a block of rice with a fried outside) was a bit tough. Overall liked it, but wouldn't recommend ordering it.
-pastrami bao bun: super unique dish. I love pastrami and thought the meat and slaw had good flavor, but there was way too much mustard on my piece. Would give this a try if you're looking for a fun, tasty bite.
-fried chicken with onions: hearty serving for $7. Not the best chicken I've had, but a good filler if you're not looking to completely blow your bank account.

Main:
-sea bass with pea shoots: Pretty decent hunk of fish. Had a great bright and crispy outside, and a nice sweet sauce on the plate. Our dish was a little cold, though. And I wish it was saltier. 
-black cod fried rice: ***this was probably my favorite dish! There were so many different elements to the rice which made it really delicious -- the saltiness of the cod (although honestly I would have preferred just a pinch of salt in the dish itself), sweetness of the caramel, spiciness of the peppers, and the pop of the edamame. 

Dessert:
-black sesame mocha: I like sesame so I enjoyed this dessert. Nothing super special, though.
-strawberry shortcake with sesame: would highly recommend this. Was a pretty big dessert so would be good for sharing. So delicious!
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
My relatives said we were getting dim sum, so naturally I thought we'd be going to China Town in Philly, but instead we ended up going here, which was just amazing! Street parking here is way easier to find than in China Town, doesn't say much about the place but it's a hell of a lot easier to get to! It's a bit unsuspecting of a place, but when you see the fish tank, you know you're at a real Chinese place.
The decor and ambience was on par with most Chinese dim sum places, casual in the afternoon, but easily could suffice for a banquet at night. The service was good as well, always bringing us more water and giving us teapots with tea.
The food itself was incredible for most the part. They have the standard dim sum fare: shrimp and pork dumplings, chicken feet, shrimp with fun noodles, taro dumplings etc. The dim sum was great, and unless they mess it up, it's usually always great. The highlight was the adorable custard buns! The buns looked like little pigs, they're seriously the cutest buns ever! If the custard buns aren't your thing, they offer the same sort of buns that look like pigs, but they're filled instead with black sesame paste. I even tried their beef chow fun and I'll say it wasn't the greatest beef chow fun I've had. It wasn't bottom of the barrel, but it wasn't the greatest one I've had either. It was tasty but it definitely needed more "wok hay" which is wok heat/flavor. That being said, the beef was tasty and the fun noodles were super fresh, so they get points for that.
As a Chinese person, I'd recommend this place for when you're trying to get your dim sum fix. Tasty food and a convenient location!
name: China Gourmet
categories: Restaurants, Chinese, Cantonese, Dim Sum

text: I usually write my reviews on OpenTable (mostly really good ones!) but Tredici isn't on it. I've been here twice. Its a "scene" place, with Maserati's out front. Which is fun, if the food were great. It really wasn't.  The white truffle flatbread pizza was really dry and almost flavorless. The cheese board - honestly - my husband and I were pissed off we paid for it  -  it had mustard and an apple type spread, the cheese cut in big hunks like someone was in a hurry and absolutely nothing about it paired well. I felt like if I went to Trader Joe's I could've done better and no one wants to feel that way when they eat out. They were busy that night, so I don't know if that affected it, but the $20+ you pay should get you a little more thoughtfulness. The broccoli salad with black sesame and avocado, which I had high hopes for, was flavorless, and I felt like I was eating cold, plain, previously steamed broccoli, avocado nearly absent and while there was a lot of black sesame, it didn't carry any flavor. The cocktail I had was really good! But my wine pour on the second visit was so cheap - I understand we're all supposed to be fine paying $15 for 4oz these days but I still think that's the biggest con & a way for a restaurant to nickel and dime its customers.   So - this is a pretty place, I wish I enjoyed my visits because the main line always needs great and fun restaurants, but I'll leave it to the others that want to get all dressed up to eat subpar offerings and drink tiny amounts of wine for lots of cash.
name: Enoteca Tredici
categories: Mediterranean, Wine Bars, Italian, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants

text:
Yet another promising mainline restaurant that disappoints with mediocre food. 

Beautifully decorated albeit a bit loud with a  enticing menu and sweet service staff. We were excited to start our dinner when the ever cute server brought out excellent complimentary olives to start. However, the food that followed was very meh. 

The ricotta with honey and olive oil was a gigantic slab of ricotta accompanied by honey and little olive oil. This dish was too sweet and lacked any complexity. We didn't finish half of it. The broccoli with avocado was a joke of a dish that I could of made at home. Blanched broccoli sprinkled with black sesame and cubed avocado. We didn't finish either. Our entrées were mushroom cream lasagne and squid ink pasta. The lasagna was dry and overly salty lacking in any cream. The squid ink pasta had peppercini peppers that were chopped at one inch width, completely overwhelming the dish, and all the clams were out of their shells. We didn't finish any of our dishes. 

Even though the prices were reasonable, I still would not come back.
name: Enoteca Tredici
categories: Mediterranean, Wine Bars, Italian, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants

text: I've been wanting to try out The Kettle Black for a while and finally got to try it! I got there at around 1pm on a Saturday and only the Everything bagel and 2 pastries were left. I was so sad because I wanted to try the Black Sesame bagel! I ended up getting the Everything bagel (toasted) with cream cheese, onions and tomato. It was warm, chewy and delicious! I also got a latte and it was also delicious. To have more bagel and pastry options, would suggest getting there at least before 11am.. it seemed like a lot of the pastries had sold out even by noon that day. If you are driving, there are 2 hour street parking spots around. (Note: Right around the corner of The Kettle Black, do NOT turn onto Green Street and then N Hancock Street looking for parking.. N Hancock Street is super super narrow and I was scared that I was going to damage my car while driving through that street!) I can't wait to go back (earlier during the day) to try the Black Sesame bagel and to get another latte! If I lived right around there, I would definitely pop in often.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Doth my eyes deceive me? Is there an honest to goodness boulangerie in my neighborhood? Can it be true? Is there an adorable little place where I can get the most delightful, airy pastries and breads a plenty? 

There is indeed! Oh joy! Oh adoration. There is nothing that makes me happier than a business that opens and fills a desperate neighborhood need. Thank you Kettle Black.

Come early for the first bake and snag yourself a baguette or two. Perfection. Black sesame bagels are a revelation. If you're feeling fancy, get some trimmings on it. Coffee on point and lastly, three words for you: Pain au chocolat. Perfect amount of flakiness with each buttery bite and a perfect chocolate ratio. Have mercy!

P.S. kitchen closes at 2 pm but stays open until closing or until they sell out!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
We were seated pretty quickly and the food was good. We ordered the spicy ramen, tonkatsu ramen, chicken dumplings, pork buns (amazing!) and the black sesame/green tea mochi for dessert. The pork buns were huge and delicious and we wish that we had about 7 more orders. 

The ambience was casual but comfortable, although I wasn't the one sitting on the stool.
name: @Ramen
categories: Japanese, Restaurants, Ramen

text:
Philly is home to quite a few steakhouses. You've got Barclay Prime and Butcher and Singer from Stephen Starr. The chains also have you set with Ruth's Chris and Smith & Wollensky, of which the latter is one of my favorites in NYC. And of course, you've also got Del Frisco's, a "chain" steakhouse that embodies all things power lunch or expense accounts. And regular readers know that, at least in my opinion, higher-end chains like Ruth's Chris and Del Frisco's are nothing to scoff at. If anything they have consistent execution and service down pat.

Philly's outpost for Del Frisco's is cavernous. It all starts with the iron-clad gates that welcome you in. You can venture downstairs and have your meal in a bank vault. 

Or enter straight ahead and enjoy a drink at the bar, with the vaulted ceilings providing a grand atmosphere. 

Or do as the GF and I did and reserve a table upstairs to overlook it all, right next to a spiral staircase filled with hundreds, if not thousands of bottles of wine.

Old Fashioned [$14]
Knob Creek bourbon, muddled cherry, orange, sugar, bitters

I started the meal with an oft-enjoyed cocktail. Can't go wrong with Knob Creek - the orange helped to add some lightness to this well-made drink.

Diet Coke [$4]

The GF wasn't feeling a drink that night, so went with a Diet Coke. FYI - this is the type of place that won't invest in fountain soda, for reasons that are financially obvious. Interestingly though, the soda was initially completely flat. No carbonation whatsoever. The server was a bit flummoxed as well, but once we offered her a taste to dispel any disbelief (which she declined), she brought us another which was just fine. Weird.

Bread Service

The meal starts off with bread service - crusty, yeasty, and salty sesame bread. Whipped butter was served at room temp, which is always appreciated. The server stopped by to ask if we wanted some more bread, but we decided to save room for what was to come.

Del's Salad [$10]

The GF ordered the house salad, which the servers graciously split for us, much to the chagrin of the GF. A thick-cut, crispy piece of bacon sat atop Romaine and field greens, in addition to a melange of cherry tomatoes, carrots, avocado, green onions, and croutons. Ranch dressing was provided as well.

Fried Calamari [$17]
Shanghai style 

This was our second time at Del Frisco's in Philly and we had to order the calamari again. Sweet and crispy, the calamari had a nice bit of head on the end. The mung bean sprouts and pickled jalapeno offered some texture and tang, with the sweetness of the black sesame accenting the delicious sauce. Highly recommended.

8 oz. Filet Mignon [$39]

The GF went with the 8 ounce filet, cooked nicely medium-rare. This is USDA prime beef, though not aged. It had great flavor with a tenderness that's prototypical of the filet. The crust was nicely seasoned and accentuated the beef. Unfortunately, here, they cut into the steak before bringing it to your table. Understandably, they want to get the temperature correct before their patrons dig in, but in my mind, it brings down the experience a bit, especially at these prices.

16 oz. Ribeye [$45]

As expected, I went with the ribeye which was beautifully seasoned on the outside. This USDA prime beef is wet-aged for 16 to 18 days. While I give the nod to Ruth's Chris's ribeye for their superlative crust, this was still quite delicious. The deckle or cap of the steak was gorgeously marbled - clearly my favorite cut on the steak.

Onion Rings [$10]

Knowing the belly of this pig, you'd expect me to order a few sides as well. For me, a steakhouse's sides are often measured by their onions rings. Though not as crispy as other steakhouses, these were huge and had a creamy batter - reminiscent of a malt/vinegar fish n chips batter.

Lobster Mac n Cheese [$18]

When I see lobster mac n cheese on the menu, it will be ordered. This was creamy and the briny essence of the lobster comes through nicely, with a few chunks of lobster interspersed throughout. The top of the mac n cheese was nicely crispy, offering some texture to each bite. 

And with that, our meal was over, with plenty of leftovers for the next day. Other than the flat soda ($4!!), the meal was on point and service was excellent. Though Barclay Prime and Ruth's Chris remain my favorites in Philly, Del Frisco's offers a great meal as well. Not that Kanye West and Kim Kardashian's choices for fine dining are anything to consider (they're not), but they did enjoy a meal here when they were last in town.

And about a week later, we received a thank you card from Del Frisco's. Certainly a nice touch and definitely appreciated!
name: Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steakhouse
categories: Food, Restaurants, Seafood, Specialty Food, Steakhouses, American (Traditional)

text: I have been searching for a good bagel place near old city who doesn't skimp on their everything seasoning. These bagels are well seasoned and are beautifully baked - soft on the inside with a slight crisp on the outside. We had a black sesame bagel with scallion cream cheese, tomato, and cucumber and a cheddar everything bagel, which were both scrumptious. We also ordered a dozen bagels to take home and freeze. I am excited to make this place part of my weekend ritual.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text: What an amazing experience! The service was on point, and the server was extremely detailed. She recommended ordering 4 dishes (to share) between my friend and I. I ordered lovers knot as my cocktail drink and it was so refreshing. My overall favourite dish was the duck bao. For dessert I got moji - assortment of flavours (I liked coconut and black sesame) 5/5 would recommend, especially if you love asian fusion.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text: Had this place bookmarked since moving to Philly last summer and finally crawled out of bed early this Sunday morning to catch them before they sold out. An early morning stroll, a black sesame bagel with lox and fixings, and an earl grey crème latte made me ~slightly~ consider becoming a morning person. Staff is super friendly, the food and coffee are delicious; would definitely make the trek to buy a loaf of bread (no bread today because of Labor Day weekend) during the weekday; it's that good!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I've been craving a bagel for 3 months to be exact but can never find a place that has vegan cream cheese. After an extensive Yelp research session I found this place and decided to venture out on a Saturday morning. This place opens and closes very early so I suggest coming in early. 

 I've been on this street before since I love getting the vegan pizza right across the street.

I woke up at 9 AM on a Saturday and I was a bit mad about it because I love getting sleep on the weekends. I drove all the way to Fishtown which is about a 20 minute drive. I parked my car kind of far and took a longer than expected walk however it seems like there are many businesses opening in Fishtown because there were so many places I have been meaning to try and they all turned out to be in close proximity to each other.

I walked into Black Kettle and it was packed! I mean I did not expect there to be so many people. I got the black sesame bagel and their seasonal special vegan cream cheese. After taking a bite of this the drive, the walk, the cold weather and having to wake up early did not matter because I was so content with the bagel. I also got the vegan chocolate pastry I think and it was very good. You can honestly taste that it's freshly baked and not frozen and then reheated. I love and support businesses that bake their goodies everyday. It is a lot of man labor and stress so I don't even mind paying more money for that.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Etch exceeded all expectations. We sat at the bar, facing the open kitchen. The wine list is expansive and as said hundreds of times before, the food was incredible. 

We ordered a bottle of the Yangarra Shiraz and it paired well with everything we ate. We had the bread to start (the butters were black sesame garlic and chili mango - trust me, order it!). Then we split the Etch salad - would highly recommend. I would order that for lunch everyday if I lived in town. For entrees, we had the tempura tofu and the special fish, which was corvina on top of brown butter kale farro (kind of like risotto) with roasted carrots, shallots and topped with carrot top pesto. Honestly one of the best fish dishes I have had in months. We ended our meal with the ice cream sundae and the blonde cookie chunks were cooked perfectly. 

What made this experience amazing was the service from our waiter Mathieu S. He was very knowledgeable about the menu and had great recommendations. We were also impressed by his knowledge of the wine menu and suggestions on pairing. 

Any one of these factors would have brought us back, but the combination of thoughtful food, nice ambience, and superb service will have us highly recommending Etch to any and all visiting Nashville.
name: Etch
categories: Desserts, Wine Bars, Restaurants, Event Planning & Services, Seafood, Food, Nightlife, Bars, Middle Eastern, Venues & Event Spaces, Asian Fusion, Mediterranean, American (New), Salad

text: Stopped by this little store in the morning during the weekday. It was around 8am, the store had a  short line already. The cashier was super friendly. We ordered black salt and black sesame with janapeno cream cheese! Omg, the bagels were so good, we really enjoyed them! The coffee was ok, but we were here for the bagel anyway. Only wish the store was a little bigger so people can actually sit down and enjoy the bites. Will definitely come back for more!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
Came in on a Tuesday around 6:30PM for a single reservation at the chef'a counter - great option eating solo and watching your food being made. The space overall is big and the chef's counter is quieter than the main bar area.

I opted for the chef's tasting and actually went blind- I let the chef choose and he did not disappoint. You get 10 dishes and a dessert. The notable items I got:
-yellowtail toro sushi: the bite left such a tender citrusy burst, a great start
-kobe beef yakitori: so juicy and tender, seared to perfection - must drizzle the mustard sauce on the side 
-scallop yakitori: my favorite- somehow the chef magically knew I loved scallops? Just slightly charred and each bite was just perfect, miso glaze added a nice touch - if you love seafood, need to put dibs on this! 
- broiled sea bass: served with some garnished veggies and drizzled in miso/teriyaki sauce, the filet was not over cooked and the flavor was just great 
- black sesame ice cream mochi: soft mochi with cold black sesame ice cream filling - the best sweet note and treat to end your night

The deal being $60 pretax was amazing for the amount of food you get (there was more than listed, I just put down the ones I loved). The whole 10 courses took around 1.5 hours at my slow pace though I wished they waited for me to finish each one before the next one came out. I definitely would come back again and maybe see what the chef can surprise me with again! Come with a friend or go alone, great foodie spot.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text: Love the cassia (cinnamon), cardamom, zatar, spearmint, garlic, cocoa, black sesame seeds, anise.... well, lots of stuff here!  Check it out for yourself, then head over to Vom Fass for more good stuff.  Maplewood is another cool area of town!
name: Penzeys Spices
categories: Specialty Food, Food

text:
So excited to have such a great bagel place near me!

A little sad there are no breakfast sandwiches but maybe one day they will. I got the black sesame bagel with dill cream cheese and pickled fennel and it was BOMB DOT COM. It wasn't even toasted and I enjoyed it! I can't wait to try out their other goodies but would definitely recommend they get more items on their menu!
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I really wanted to love this place because the decor and atmosphere is adorable but the food left a lot to be desired.

- Japancake [ SHREDDED SAVORY CABBAGE, AIOLI, JALAPENO, MB HOT SAUCE ] Added a fried egg: Tasted like straight up pickled cabbage. The fried egg made it less vinegar-y but there weren't any other flavors.

- What's Kraken? [ TOAST, BLACK SESAME SPREAD, CHORIZO, OCTOPUS, GIARDINIERA ]: Octopus was over cooked and chewy. The black sesame spread looked like a poop smear on the plate and you couldn't even scrap any of it off the plate because it had hardened. There was barely any chorizo. Not good at all.

- Southern Livin' [ FRIED PICKLED OKRA, CORN CHOW CHOW, HEIRLOOM TOMATO REMOULADE ]:  Not bad. My second best dish of the night. Doesn't mean much though. It was just fried okra.

- Tatchos [ TATER TOTS, LAMB CHILI, BEER CHEDDAR, SCALLION ]: Best dish of the night. The lamb chili had a game-y taste that's to be expected and it was still edible.

We also got a few cocktails that were really well made.

Overall, the atmosphere and drinks were good. The bar was bustling as we were leaving! However the food was just a NO THANKS for me. Service was friendly.
name: The Mockingbird Nashville
categories: Diners, American (New), Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars

text:
I've gone back and forth in my mind on this one, finally had to round up to 5. We came here for a belated bday celebration  and the first good omen was its location, in the former spot that I enjoyed many meals at when it was Indeblue. Then it dawned on me that with "Z" being so close, the chef(s) must have some cojones to set down roots here. 

From that start most of the food that followed affirmed the rating. We both did the $75 tasting and selected different dishes so most of the menu could be sampled. I won't list everything but top dishes for me were both "snacks" crispy asparagus and the beets and radishes were both simple concepts, but they both showcased and elevated those ingredients in unique ways. Next,  the 3 tomato salad was one of my top salads ever( I am an admitted tomato-phile) it contained fried, fresh and oven dried specimens, but the addition of green chick peas and the incredible thick oven dried bacon made this very special. All courses that contained seafood were perfect, the soft shell crab was one of the plumpest I've seen, and it was pan sautéed to perfection, my red snapper main and cotaster's scallops were equally well done. The standout dessert of this trip was the deconstructed black sesame cheesecake, WOW! 

When I mulled this one over I considered many things, price to portion and quality ratio was perhaps the biggest. My complaint and something I notice other Yelpers comment on when reviewing tasting menus is portion size. This had to be the most food I've ever had during a meal like this. Usually the portion size of each dish is reduced, if so it was not noticeable except in one of the desserts and the scallop main. Another factor is how many dishes fell short, in my opinion there was only 1 in 10 that I would not reorder, and one dessert that while very tasty, was minuscule( chocolate mouse) Lastly there is the service component. Our waiter Jordan was possibly the best I've encountered in several years. Not only was he able to explain each ingredient of all courses, he gave great recommendations and was very passionate and excited about all of it. He was attentive, funny and helped us enjoy the experience more. 

There are a few other restaurants of this caliber nearby, and although I haven't gotten to(all of)them yet I feel pretty confident that this one stands up. While I still would love to try them, my experience here will make that a tough decision.
name: Porch & Proper
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Stopped by for lunch (yes they do lunch from 11:30 - 2:30) and asked if they could do  a "cup" of the daily special tomato soup.  They accommodated me by just bringing me half their usual small bowl so I could try it out.  It was extremely good!  Then I ordered the "Chicago" dog (hot dog) off the regular lunch menu.  Why a hot dog at an upscale place you ask?  Well usually they can get quite messy when you add lots of condiments so I prefer to eat them sitting down at a table vs. in the car from a truck or a pit stop.  Now this dog beat all others because it had the best relish I've ever tasted.  The relish was "home-made" and complimented the dog perfectly.  But there were other things too, like a black sesame seed bun, and an extremely tasty dog, that made this far superior than your usual dog.  The dressing on the greens that came with it was unique and very tasty as well.

But the thing that struck me the most, was the service.  It was faster than a fast food joint.  And the server opened the door for us to leave.  Yeah some chains use a hostess for that but I think its nicer when the server does it to complete the dining experience.  Also, there were several "check-ins" at our table to make sure everything was A-Ok, which is always a major reward for the server.

Yeah its a little bit more pricey for a lunch but then hey, you can't get unique taste, fast service, something new you've never had before (the home-made relish), without laying down a few extra dollars.
name: Jax Kitchen
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
Incredibly disappointed.  The service was really good and the glassware was pretty cool, but we left disappointed with the meal.  Will definitely not go back.

Started with a few apps:
The Japancake which was smothered in MB Hot Sauce.  It was the blandest cabbage cake swimming in a tangy yet flavorless thin "hot sauce".

What's Kraken? TOAST, BLACK SESAME SPREAD, CHORIZO, OCTOPUS, GIARDINIERA.
The octopus was served on Texas Toast, virtually no chorizo, no giardiniera, the octopus was cooked nicely, and the black sesame spread was tasty.

Unbeetable
BEET SALAD, FIG MOSTRADA, GOAT FETA, CACAO NIBS, ORANGE SHERRY VINEGAR
Beets yes, Salad no.  Their beets were almost delicious but they overdressed with the mostrada and vinegar.  No leafy greens just sweet upon sweet with no textural components.

Entrees:
Three's Company
MB BACON-SIRLOIN-CHORIZO MEATLOAF, FRIED EGG, TEXAS TOAST, ADOBO GRAVY
was served on top of yet another piece of Texas Toast.  It was a good textural component because the meatloaf needed it.  The meatloaf tasted pretty good, but was cheapened by the Texas Toast.  This dish definitely was not worth $20.

Poultry in Motion
CARAMEL CHICKEN, BREAST AND LEG, SPICY UMAMI SAUCE
was fried chicken & mashed potatoes.  Definitely not worth $21.

Oooooh Barbacoa
BEEF SHORT RIB, ANSON MILLS RED FIELD PEAS, PORK BITS, ESCABECHE CARROTS
Probably the best entree we had.  Very well balanced dish in terms of flavor and texture.
name: The Mockingbird Nashville
categories: Diners, American (New), Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars

text:
I've been walking by this place for a few weeks, and the other day the door opened and I got a whiff of something that smelled amazing. I decided to stop in today on my way to work. 

The interior is super cute with a laid back, relaxed feel. I didn't even realize the place was a bakery, I assumed it was a coffee shop that sold baked goods but not a place that bakes things themselves. 

I ordered a black sesame bagel with butter and a cappuccino. It was really, really good. 

I'm excited to try more of their stuff, but this experience was fantastic.
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text: It's hard to go wrong here- drinks, happy hour, sushi, grilled meats- all of it is fantastic. I'm a big fan of Japanese food which is why I prefer it slightly more to Sampan (asian fusion)- nevertheless both are great. The upstairs is definitely more casual/tightly packed-modern lounge vibes- and the downstairs is dimly lit and intimate- my favorite spot to sit is at the sushi bar but there's also cozy seating near the downstairs bar. I've been here several times over the years and love doing the happy hour or chef's tasting for special occasions. The staff is really nice and accommodating of food restrictions and the food always comes out really fast. My favorites are definitely the lover's knot cocktail, big eye tuna roll, edamame dumplings, miso eggplant, black cod fried rice, and the brussels sprouts. Also for dessert the seasonal mochi is really good- it was black sesame one time which I loved. Overall you can spend a good amount of time here and the food is consistently great.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
Our family had such a great time and awesome meal at Yaikatori Boy! I actually never knew what a solid  place to dine it was! I always thought it was strictly a karaoke bar! The downstairs restaurant is family friendly! Sorry I didn't know this all along! 

The menu is really extensive! There's definitely something for everyone, kids included!

We started with some "Japas" aka Japanese tapas!! We enjoyed agedaahi tofu and edamame, then moved on to "Yaikatori" aka skewers. We had they shrimp and shishito, and both were wonderful! The starter that really stole the show however, were the brussels! They were INSANE! Hands down, the bet I've ever had!! My husband and youngest who aren't fans normally, LOVED these!! 

The kiddos had simple avocado and green rolls, while hubs and I dove into some specialty rolls that were outrageous! The 'He Roll' has scorched scallops that gave it an unexpected smokey flavor. The 'Rocket Roll' featured cold lobster salad atop salmon with sweet apple that balanced the wasabi tobiko so well! It was wrapped with black sesame soy paper. So neat!  

We also split the whole grilled bronzini, which is actually a pike fish, and was a steal at just $18! 

We finished, or shall I say, the kids finished the meal with tempura ice cream. They devoured it before we could grab a bite! The mochi flight is what's up for us next time, oh, and the lobster two ways!! Yaaaassss! 

Service from Aaron was stellar and the cocktails and imported Japanese beer were the perfect accompaniment. Shirley Temples for the kids! 

I now know you can order any of this food upstairs for a night out with some singing! Yep, definitely coming back for that!
name: Yakitori Boy
categories: Japanese, Sushi Bars, Karaoke, Nightlife, Restaurants

text: I don't know why this place has such high ratings. I've tried it twice to give it a fair shot. The first time I got the Black Sesame Cream Milk Tea Boba and it was just... average. I do like the texture and size of the tapioca pearls, but they taste so plain. The black sesame cream was the best part of the drink. I also ordered with 100% sugar and it tasted like 50%. The next time I ordered the brown sugar matcha boba in hopes that the boba would be sweeter, and it was, but it didn't taste that good to me. The matcha was pretty decent though. Definitely not comparable to any LA boba shop. To be honest, Phresh Teas and Mojo's beat Hochaya any day. Maybe I'll go again and try the fruit teas or the pudding tea?
name: Hochaya
categories: Restaurants, Food, Bubble Tea

text:
I really, really, really want to give this place 4.5 stars; 4 just doesn't seem right, but they don't quiiite deserve 5 stars. Anywho...

I came here for dinner with my brother on Friday night, and we left extremely satisfied. The Mockingbird elevates classic comfort food dishes, and incorporates multiple food cultures to create unique experiences. 

SERVICE: Our waitress was DIVINE. She was passionate about the opening of the restaurant, extremely knowledgeable of the menu, and was very attentive - our drink glasses were NEVER empty!

FOOD: The food was SOOOO good. Here's what we ate: 

Don't Worry Brie Happy: 4 mini brie grilled cheeses, with jalapeno jam and topped with a chimicurri. These were outstanding mini grilled cheeses, and perfect for sharing! They were the perfect combination of sweet and salty, and super crispy on the outside. I personally would have liked more cheese, because who wouldn't, but my brother says "I'm a cheese guy, and I think they're perfect the way they are".  

What's Kraken: Pieces of toast with black sesame spread, octopus, and chorizo. We were unsure what to expect of this dish, and while it was tasty, it still is a bit confusing. The octopus and chorizo were good, but the spread was hard to taste, and the toast was a ~~different~~ way to serve this food. I'm not sure I would order this again. 

Seoul Purpose: Slices of bulgogi style hangar steak, served with a waffled latke topped with a fried egg, and some greens. I don't even like steak, but this was SO. SO. GOOD. The meat was super flavorful, and it was an interesting new flavor I have never had before. The latke and waffle were also a great side, as well as the greens. The steak was cooked perfectly. Definitely order this!!

Sea Signore: Housemade spaghetti with crab, corn, some peppers, and a spicy chili sauce. HANDS DOWN the best part of the meal. The pasta was so creamy, and was the perfect combination of spicy and sweet. It was melt in your mouth good and no other words can do it justice. 

Definitely come and give the Mockingbird a try! There's tons on the menu to choose from. I plan on coming back soon to try more!
name: The Mockingbird Nashville
categories: Diners, American (New), Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, Nightlife, Restaurants, Cocktail Bars

text: We started off with a monkeys fist cocktail which was great because it had subtleties that reminded me of a pina colada, but was so refreshing and light and not very sweet at all (which I like). And then we had a Kobe beef skewer which was I kid you not the best bite of cooked red meat I've ever had in my entire life...... I was DEAD after trying it it was incredible. Got another one of those because of how good it was. The two sushi rolls we got were the one named after the place and some other roll I forget the name, loved both but the rolls weren't what stood out to me about this meal. Edamame dumplings that were sooo good and like a hug. The sea bass which was..... phenomenal. My other favorite thing we ate was a DUCK SCRAPPLE bao bun, UNREALLLLL good. And then least favorite thing was a wild mushroom gyoza, which I feel like had the potential to be good but it came in like a vinaigrette broth kinda thing and I wish they had a more creamy element because I thought it would complement the mushrooms better, I didn't like the acidity and bitterness of the broth. And then also a salmon skewer which was also amazing. OH and the best mochi ice cream I've ever had for desert, flavors were matcha, black sesame, and salted caramel. Server was ASTOUNDING best server I've ever had. Food came out almost immediately after ordering (free-flowing kitchen was quick!!!).
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
Stopped by here for dinner after work and it just happened to be $55 for the 5 course menu. They were out of soft shelled crab as it is the end of summer and they are no longer in season but the rest of the menu did not disappoint.

Fried asparagus comes with a nice dip that adds welcomed spice. Got the tomato salad for the next course they had fresh tomatoes, fried tomatoes and dried tomatoes each with a different flavor and larger than I expected. I would pass on the sunchoke agnolotti pasta if I every came back. Finally the bavette steak was enjoyable and cooked perfectly for me although it might be a bit rare for others. Ended with a deconstructed black sesame cheesecake which tasted good combined but each component tasted alone was either too tart or sweet.

Service was quick and friendly but lacking grace. The server would often tilt the plate heavily to one side and when placing the plates down the food would often slide around on the plate.
name: Porch & Proper
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text: Really great coffee shop/patisserie/bakery. Wouldn't necessarily call it French. It's a place for bread and coffee - as advertised on the door - but it definitely takes it up a notch in quality and creativity. On one hand, they've perfected the traditional croissant and pain au chocolat. On the other, they offer golden milk, sesame tahini bread, black sesame bagels, and chocolate chip miso sea salt cookies. I'd only ask them to kick up the ambiance and offer a few more cream cheese flavors and they'd be hedging a 5. Voted the bakery in northern liberties Most Worth a Visit. By me. :)
name: The Kettle Black
categories: Bagels, Food, Bakeries, Coffee & Tea

text:
I can see why this is a favorite of my sis and best friend. But I was skeptical walking down the dim alley. My heart calmed then swelled when I was the happy cloud over the bar.  
Their wine selection is interesting with many that I don't recognize. One friend had to try a couple before settling into one. 
To start, we had the anchovies drenched in olive oil, kale salad with shaved veggies and a black sesame cream. We shared the angry pizza with jalapeños. This pizza came with a warning when we ordered it and I was concerned that I'd burn up while waiting for it.  It was amazing and I found it to be medium spicy.
name: Pizzeria Beddia
categories: Italian, Specialty Food, Pizza, Food, Restaurants, Nightlife, Bars, Juice Bars & Smoothies

text: Hello NE Philly eating scene! Before you had to drive to chinatown to get amazing dim sum, not the case anymore! I've been searching for a replacement since my absolute fave place, imperial inn (RIP) closed recently. The place is huge, clean and the servers are all quite nice and efficient. They wear headsets here to communicate your needs quicker. water, clean plates, etc always made it out to our table in decent time. But the most important part? The food! I have taken my family here too and they all agreed it was excellent, comparable to the ocean harbor in Chinatown. In my opinion, China gourmet does some dishes better and the service is great. I also love their unique dishes that I haven't found anywhere else like the adorable dessert ones. Little pig buns, durian rolls  and a black sesame filled ball that was sooo good! Do yourself a favor and check it out! Bonus, free and widely available parking!! Just be careful on the weekends, especially Sunday when lines can get long and parking lot can be full!!
name: China Gourmet
categories: Restaurants, Chinese, Cantonese, Dim Sum

text:
My second visit is pleasant. This time I am sit down have snack at dinner. I believe they are 4.5 stars restaurant not full 5 stars. Although I didn't try their ninja chicken nuggets again, but we do try fried calamari and the the black garlic ramen. They finally have the token ramen with newest ramen dish. Black garlic is one of the kind. It has the black sesame oil with black garlic on it. It is delicious. The calamari was fried very good with good coating. 

The reason they are upgraded is I make a challenge to their boba team. I ask a drink that partial in the menu but not totally in the menu. They have winter Mellon milk tea. I ask if they can do the slush. They said they have not done that before. But they will try. End up it is good drink.
name: Kung Fu Tea
categories: Ramen, Japanese, Restaurants, Food, Bubble Tea

text:
Double Knot is another fantastic concept by the wonderful chef Michael Schulson. Connected to Sampan, the top floor was crowded at the few tables and around the bar on a Friday night. Luckily, we had a reservation, and we were evaded the bustling upstairs and were seated at an table in the intimate basement level. Downstairs, it was equally as crowded, with patrons filling every table, and a very "weekend" vibe with the dim lighting and close quarters. 

Our server, Dustin, was a wonderful server! He suggested a wine for us, which we absolutely loved. He talked us through the menu, and let us mull over our options. We opted to do the tasting menu. For $60 a person, the table chooses ten dishes - 1 from each section of the menu, but 2 from the robatayaki - to share. While tasting dishes typically leave you hungry, this was the complete opposite. While some dishes were small, others came out in grandiose portions, and by the end of the meal, we were STUFFED. We didn't even finish the last few dishes, although everything was incredible!

TUNA RICE CRACKER - cold // This dish was full of flavor, but the textural contrast is what takes it to the next level. A brick of crispy rice, which is chewy on the inside, is topped with a cool dollop of spicy tuna, with a sweet glaze. The bite ranges from soft to crispy to chewy all at once, and is a textural party in your mouth!

SALMON - specialty sashimi // Thinly sliced pieces of fresh salmon, in a spicy ponzu sauce and topped with soy ginger + scallions. This dish lets the fresh salmon do the talking!

TOFU - crispy // Normally tofu goes unnoticed while on the table, if people even order it at all. But not this tofu! This tofu is fried until it is extremely crispy on the outside, but with a pillowy interior that disintegrates in your mouth. The tofu has two sauces: a pesto and a miso caramel, which both stand out against the mild tofu. Even those who were opposed to ordering tofu helped scarf down this crispy delicacy! 

EDAMAME DUMPLING - small // These little dumps were adorable! The dumplings had a smooth, mild filling made with ground edamame. The flavor was very mellow, yet intriguing. Apparently these are one of the best sellers at Double Knot.

CHICKEN BREAST - robatayaki // Probably the least impressive dish in the meal. The chicken was cooked well, but lacked an explosive flavor compared to the other dishes. 

RIB EYE SCALLION - robatayaki // This was INCREDIBLE, and this is coming from someone who doesn't even like steak. The rib eye was so incredibly tender and juicy, it just melted in the mouth after the first bite. It was topped with a green scallion sauce that was so dynamite, it could have bene paired with cardboard and I'd eat it. Definitely the robatayaki to get!

BEEF SHORT RIB - meat // This was MASSIVE. And so DELICIOUS. The short rib comes to the table whole, and is shredded in front of you. The meat is succulent in the flavorful miso sauce. It's served with lettuce cups and white rice to make lettuce wraps, or you can just jab it with your fork and shovel as much as you possibly can into your mouth.

BROILED SEABASS - fish // By the time this dish came, we were filling up, and I don't think it got the attention it deserved. The seabass was cooked to just past the point of being raw (aka perfect), with glistening insides and a truffle soy glaze on the plate. A simple, understated, perfectly cooked fish. 

CRISPY BRUSSEL SPROUTS - sides // These were good, but not great. The brussels are super crispy, which I loved, and served in a salty fish sauce. While I typically love brussels served like this, I felt the sauce was a bit too pungent or salty, and it made it hard to eat a lot of these.

SPICY TUNA ROLL - sushi // Standard, spicy tuna roll. Fresh fish. 

MOCHI // The tasing menu comes with complimentary mochi. We had two flavors: black sesame and strawberry. These mochi were on the bigger side, with a chewy exterior. The strawberry was a little too sweet for me, but the black sesame tasted like a more mild peanut butter. So delicious and unexpected!!

Double Knot is definitely a spot I will be back to. Will I need to do the tasting menu again? Perhaps, but it was a lot of food. If I were to do it again, I would let the chef choose the menu so I could try some dishes I wouldn't normally. There's tons to chose from the expansive menu, and it's perfect for a weekend dinner or a date night.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
Porch and Proper has a nice rustic feel to it. During the warmer months, outdoor seating is available. The menu changes seasonally and everything is farm to fork. I came here on a Wednesday night around 8PM, and there were three other tables occupied. The staff was very attentive and professional.

We chose the five course tasting menu - usually $75, but the night we went, they had a promotion and it was only $55 for the tasting menu. 

First they started us off with complimentary sourdough fococcia.

For the snacks, we ordered the crispy asparagus and shrimp. I loved the sauces for both dishes, I even dipped the sourdough in the sauces. I liked that the smoked aioli (that came with the asparagus) had a nice kick to it. 

For the small plates we ordered the tomato salad and steak tartare. The tomato salad portion was huge! The tomatoes were very sweet. The dressing went perfect with the tomatoes. The steak tartare was delicious. It was nicely seasoned and I loved the flavors from the sautéed onions and pepper relish. I was disappointed they did not have the soft shell crab (my favorite), but it was no longer in season.

For grains and pasta, we ordered the black chittara and sunchoce agnolotti. The butter flavor in the black chittara dish was perfect. The lobster tasted very fresh. The sunchoce agnolotti dish was a bit too sour for me - not sure if they squeezed too much lemon on top, but it was very sour.

For large plates, we ordered the market fish (forget what fish we had) and bavette-steak. I loved the grain that was served with the fish- super flavorful. The fish was cooked perfectly. I must say, the steak was my favor. The black garlic sauce along with the charred flavor of the steak was perfect.

For dessert, we had the chocolate mousse and black sesame cheesecake. The chocolate mousse tasted good, but it was more of a firm jello texture than mousse. The deconstructed black sesame cheesecake was interesting. I did not like the flavor of black sesame cheesecake by itself. When it was mixed with the black sesame cracker and whipped cream, it tasted better.

Overall, a very good first experience at P&P.
name: Porch & Proper
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text:
With so much sushi to choose from in Reno, service and flavor have got to be present in equal measure in order to compete. I can cope with waiting on food if the meal is outstanding, and a middle of the road meal can be improved by quick and attentive service. Unfortunately, neither side of the equation made me want a repeat visit to Sushi? OK, located in a building that has housed a variety of eateries over the years.

The place was packed with families having dinner, so perhaps they were short on supplies; we were provided a single menu for the table to share. However, the order slip included half the items listed on the extensive menu, and some others that weren't listed at all. We wrote a few selections in the margins and hoped for the best.

Receiving anything other than drinks took a very long time. Appetizers took about 30 minutes, and there were long pauses between plates after that. From the sizeable list of appetizers we kept it simple with potstickers, miso soup, and baked mussels. The soup and potstickers were tasty, but served at lukewarm temperature. More disappointing were nicely seasoned, spicy mussels that were served stone cold. At least my sake was served a bit warmer, though not really hot. Last and oddest, we were presented with napkins, utensils, and condiment dishes, but had to ask for pickled ginger and wasabi after our first dishes arrived.

Although I appreciate hand and long rolls, nigiri sushi is my favorite. The rice-to-fish ratio and freshness of fish were adequate. I sampled tuna, yellowtail, salmon, snapper, and mackerel--which was about as fresh-tasting as any mackerel I've had in Reno--but my orders of fresh water eel and octopus were missing in action.

Moving on to complex nigiri, the upside down shrimp was topped with rice, raw bay scallop, scallion, black sesame seed, and Japanese mayo, followed by the Volcano, a big piece of yellowtail rolled around a ball of rice, topped with raw bay scallop, scallion, black sesame seed, and Japanese mayo. The Hollywood featured rice topped with sliced, raw jumbo scallop topped with cooked sea scallop, sesame seeds, and toasted sesame oil. Finally, the Sexy Dory upside down shrimp topped with rice, sea scallop, scallion, and toasted sesame oil. Overall, the flavors of the two variations on upside down shrimp and the Volcano were quite sweet and mostly indistinguishable from one another. The Hollywood stood out on flavor and texture, most definitely something I would order again.

Our first long roll was the Sancho, a mix of jalapeno, crystal shrimp, salmon, avocado, spicy crab, cilantro, lemon, and teriyaki sauce. Mostly I tasted rice, sweet with a bit of heat. A Show roll of crystal shrimp, jalapeno, spicy crab, and seared tuna had quite a bit of spice, cut by crab salad with a lot of mayo, while the Guerra Fire roll's mix of salmon, crystal shrimp, lemon, and sesame seed was a bit overpowered by a seriously fiery habanero sauce. We used bites of deep-fried Jumbo roll--shrimp, crab, cream cheese, sweet teriyaki--to cut the heat, though I really couldn't taste any fish flavors through the cream cheese, batter, and sauce.

Three other rolls had been ordered but apparently forgotten, so we decided to just skip them and move on. Sitting for two hours for a partial order is about my limit for adequate-to-mediocre food.
name: Sushi? Ok
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text:
I'm a fan of this place, minus the long wait. We have had similar ice cream in Thailand and it's really good. Our favorites were the Thai Iced Tea Ice Rolls and Black Sesame Snow Ice. They were delicious and the toppings were great too. Each was about $6.

The thing is, it took a while. I understand that they are going to add more stations or automate it (machine) in the future, but it's tough to make your customers loyal when it takes 20 minutes or more. 

We came this past Sunday after lunch and there wasn't a huge wait. I can't imagine if there is a line out the door. You could wait 45 min for an ice cream.

To be one of the first places in this market space its a huge step. I just wish that they would have put more into the execution because 20 min is way too long.
name: Ice Land
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Shaved Ice, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
This is definitely my favorite Thai restaurant in Santa Barbara. I'll be honest- I have really high expectations when it comes to Asian food because 1) I'm Asian!! When I moved to Santa Barbara for college, all I ever craved was Asian food. I tried Pattaya and TAP thai but they were both just okay and never fully satisfied my thai food cravings. THANK GOODNESS that I discovered this place!!! This place serves AUTHENTIC thai food! Everything I've tried here is delicious- pad thai, panang curry, pad see ew and the mongolian beef. My favorite dish here though is the panang curry. They have lunch specials where certain dishes come with an eggroll and soup or salad. 
Also, the ice cream here is AMAZING! I've tried the cookies and thai tea ice cream and the vietnamese coffee mudpie. Their ice cream is made right on the spot (homemade ice cream!!!) They have other unique flavors such as roasted black sesame ice cream and basil mint chip.
Your Choice Resturant is a must-try!!
name: Your Choice
categories: Restaurants, Thai, Food, Chicken Wings, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts

text:
All I can say is WOW!! I was not expecting such great Asian fusion in Nashville, especially when most of the popular restaurants in town have the same type of foods - hot chicken or BBQ meats. I was really impressed with the uniqueness of the items we ordered, as well as my unexpected enjoyment of items that I was sure I would not like. 

We tried almost all of the dumplings since we were a party of eight. Most of the table enjoyed the Shrimp Stuffed Eggplant the most, but my favorite was the Fire Cracker Wontons. 

For the entree, we ordered several items to share family style: Hong Kong Style Cumin Short Rib, Dry Fry Sichuan Beef, Kung Pao Cauliflower, and Hangzhou Late Night Noodles. I thought the short ribs and noodles would be my favorites, but the dry fry beef and cauliflower were the winners according to my taste buds. This really surprised me as I typically avoid fried food (don't like a lot of grease) and cauliflower has never been a favorite. I still enjoyed the short ribs and noodles as both of those were good, but the beef and cauliflower were the items I kept eating long after I should have cut myself off.

I should mention that we also ordered a few sides: General Tso's Brussel Sprouts, Crispy Togarashi Potatoes, and Szechuan Dry Fry Okra. All three were very good. 

We figured we should get dessert since everything else had been so great so far. We ordered the Black Sesame Creme Brûlée and the White Chocolate Cake with passion fruit caramel to share.  Both were so, so unique. I wasn't in love with the matcha-flavored creme brûlée, but I'm still glad we tried it.  The cake was good, but I don't know if it was that memorable. 

Overall I wasn't amazed with the desserts, but I'm still giving this place 5 stars as everything other than dessert had been exceptionally good!
name: Tànsuŏ
categories: Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Chinese

text:
If you're looking for a great place to celebrate a special occasion in philly, this is it. Make a reservation and you'll get seated downstairs. The ambience down there is darker/dim lit with candles and was really romantic.

I would highly recommend the chefs tasting, for 60 a person. I really feel like it's the best deal and the way to get the true experience of the restaurant. 

We did a good mix of seafood and meat dishes and all were delicious. In the chefs tasting you pick one item from each section and two from the robatayaki grill section, for this we did the Kobe beef and shrimp, both were delicious and the Kobe beef was cooked perfectly and was so tender.

Some of our favorites from the tasting menu were the hanger steak, the miso sea bass, and the Kobe beef robatayaki. The one dish I felt could use more flavor was the crab udon. They did serve them in a small bowl for each person which was nice to not share (which would probably be messy). It was still really good but I think more spice/kick to it would have made it better.

The cocktails were great as well, the double knot is smoky flavored though so only get it if that's your thing! Overall wonderful experience finished off the meal with Black sesame Mochi.
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text:
Four of us stopped in to dinner at Porch and Proper and it was a great experience all around.  Our server Jordan was perfect, great service and we would definitely ask for him on our return.

We chose to go a la carte as opposed to the $75 tasting menu and even so, we managed to try 2/3 of the menu.  Overall the food was 5-star good in taste and presentation.  Here's what we had:

The entire 'snacks' section of crispy asparagus (phenomenal), beets & radishes (very good), three proper shrimp (very good) & tiger cucumbers (very good).

From the 'grains & pasta' section we tried the Black Chittara with Maine lobster, truffle butter and chilies - outstanding dish, very good.
Two of the 'small plates' section items of Steak Tartare (very, very good) and the Tuna in the raw (very good).

From the 'Large Plates' section, we ordered the Market Fish which happened to be cod and it was excellent.  The Sea Scallops were also very good, well-cooked and two of us had the Bavette which was delicious and perfectly cooked as well.  

For 'dessert', we had all four of the offerings: Wood Smoked Chocolate Mousse (very good, but a bit too smoky for two of us), Baby Chouxs (sounded great, tasted ok but the choux were a bit soggy), Cheese Plate (great cheeses but very similar in taste and the accoutrements of granola and fennel jam were not good for any of us, unfortunately.  The macerated cherries with the cheesecake, though were delicious with the cheese) and finally the best dessert for all of us was the Black Sesame Cheesecake.  Visually interesting, great taste and texture combinations - a dessert home run.  The coffee was also very good.

We had a great dinner in a great space with great service and I think we all agreed that we'd rate Porch & Proper a solid 4 or 4.5.  We definitely would be back, possibly frequently as the food and service were that good.  

Here are the plusses:

Great service by Jordan from beginning to end and kudos for getting the cork out of a 1989 Vouvray perfectly.  We would definitely request Jordan on any return visit.

Beautifully presented plates and delicious food - very good.

Great ambiance

Here are the minuses:

The only bread available was the focaccia, and while good; it seemed to have been made for the accompanying ricotta spread (which was very good) but it did not go well with the cheese plate and for my preference; there should have been some baguette, toasts or crackers for the cheese plate.

Two of us ordered the Bavette and my dining partner had a nice swath of demi sauce on his plate while I had practically none, so the plating consistency was just a bit off.

The cheese plate was just not up to the standard of all of the other dishes.  The cheeses were very similar in taste, the granola and the fennel jam were just not very good accompaniments (in the opinion of two of us who order and prepare cheese plates often) which left the cheese plate very one-note.

Finally, the choux were ok but not up to the level of the mousse and the black sesame cheesecake - again, just our opinion and we know tastes vary.  Also - not trying to be obnoxious at all - choux is already the plural of chou so no need for the 's' at the end of choux.  Chouxs is not a word.

Overall, Porch & Proper more than delivered on the promise and on the past reviews by other - a very, very good restaurant with very, very good food and service.  We will definitely be back and I'm sure it will be often.  

A great gem of a restaurant in South Jersey and a BYOB as well.  Win-Win.
name: Porch & Proper
categories: Restaurants, American (New)

text: We started off with a monkeys fist cocktail which was great because it had subtleties that reminded me of a pina colada, but was so refreshing and light and not very sweet at all (which I like). And then we had a Kobe beef skewer which was I kid you not the best bite of cooked red meat I've ever had in my entire life...... I was DEAD after trying it it was incredible. Got another one of those because of how good it was. The two sushi rolls we got were the one named after the place and some other roll I forget the name, loved both but the rolls weren't what stood out to me about this meal. Edamame dumplings that were sooo good and like a hug. The sea bass which was..... phenomenal. My other favorite thing we ate was a DUCK SCRAPPLE bao bun, UNREALLLLL good. And then least favorite thing was a wild mushroom gyoza, which I feel like had the potential to be good but it came in like a vinaigrette broth kinda thing and I wish they had a more creamy element because I thought it would complement the mushrooms better, I didn't like the acidity and bitterness of the broth. And then also a salmon skewer which was also amazing. OH and the best mochi ice cream I've ever had for desert, flavors were matcha, black sesame, and salted caramel. Server was ASTOUNDING best server I've ever had. Food came out almost immediately after ordering (free-flowing kitchen was quick!!!).
name: Double Knot
categories: Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Cafes, Japanese, Bars, Restaurants

text: I went to the soft opening of this much anticipated soft serve place, 100% have to try the matcha, black sesame twist on a chocolate cone, with chocolate powder sprinkled on top! The $7 cone price is a little steep, I agree, but with the unlimited toppings it all adds up, so I'm not angry about the price!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Amazing soft serve ice cream with unlimited toppings. My favorite is black sesame and matcha! The employees are friendly and service is great. I can't wait to go back and eat more black sesame!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: I was in Philly for a quick weekend trip and was lucky to find Kuriimii close to where I was staying. It was their soft opening, but their grand opening will be on 9/15-6. Their space is clean and bright. I tried the honeydew soft serve and it was perfect! Good texture, not too sweet. The workers were really nice and helpful even if there was such a large crowd. Since I'm not in Philly often, I'm definitely going to try to make it out when I come. Their matcha black sesame is next on my list!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: finally, black sesame ice cream in South Philly!! Price is decent and size are a lot too.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Simply amazing. Staff welcomed is and were ready to give us samples of every flavor. My greatest advice would be to sample the flavors! When you see something like "charcoal vanilla" or "black sesame" you might be a little shaken. But try them. I'm sure at least 2-3 things in that menu will stand out for sure. Will definitely come back in hopes for a new seasonal flavor.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Kuriimii is the only soft serve in the Philadelphia area serving exotic Asian flavors such as matcha, taro, and black sesame. Best of all, they deliver on quality! The space itself is very modern from the beautiful while tiles to ample recess lighting throughout. The flavors are rich yet not too sweet. The combo swirls are definitely reccomended if you're trying to try all if the flavors.. which you will want to do. Best of all, the portions are very sizeable! Definitely big enough to share with your jawn, you know what I'm saying? The unlimited toppings were also a plus. Overall, very pleased with this establishment, won't have to travel up to NY for similar soft serve selections. I will be back!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
There's not many places I'll go for Chinese food. I make an exception for Shanghainese food. I've been to Shanghai 456 many times now having taken friends, family and co-workers and they've all loved it. If you want a more in-depth review, take a look here.

Took J and L out for an early Friday dinner. They've never had XLB's before or Shanghai food for that matter. My mind was blown and clearly I had to do my duty and show them the ropes. That and try a couple new dishes obviously.

- Fun see ($16.95) - this one is on their special menu but if you want something different and absolutely delicious, order it! Just point to the picture on the menu. These noodles have the perfect, chewy bite. I'd order this again in a heartbeat.

- Bok choy (E16) ($11.95) - Shanghai bok choy stir fried with garlic sauce. They were out of their green beans with x.o. sauce - HOW is that even possible - so we went with something simple. Sometimes simple is best.

- Xiao long bao (A2) ($6.95) - obviously, we ordered two baskets of XLB's because one is never enough. Each basket contains six of the most plump, juicy, delicious soup filled dumplings you will find in the city. Hands down. Give it a little bath in the vinegar soy sauce and be prepared to be blown away. Always a must order.

- House special hot pot (C7) ($21.95 medium) - hot pot with homemade fish balls, salty pork belly slices, meat, vegetables and glass noodles. I've had this before on another occasion but we wanted something warm to fill our stomachs. This hit the spot with a good variety of vegetables inside (enoki mushrooms, bok choy, tofu, cabbage). The meat itself is meh - too salty but that's to be expected for this type of dish. However, the broth is flavourful and the glass noodles add that chewy, comforting texture to bring things together.

- Wor tip (A3) ($7.50) - pan fried beef dumplings. These came out last but holy crap, it was piping hot. Seriously, Jman burnt his tongue because he couldn't wait. Excellent crispy dumplings and with a bit of soup inside them as well, watch out.

- Sesame balls - they always bring something at the end for dessert and this time it was sesame balls with black sesame paste inside. Fresh, hot and gooey. I think L fell in love with this one - she wanted a couple more to take home.

What more is there to say? Each time that I hit up the 456, I'm always happy and get my fill of XLB's. Order a couple of their staples and then branch out a bit with a new dish or two that you've never had before.
name: Shanghai 456
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Dim Sum

text:
Came here for the soft opening and I already can't wait to come back. Walking into this ice cream shop I immediately felt welcomed by the friendly staff and the bright modern atmosphere. 
For the flavors I tried honeydew, avocado, & matcha. The flavors were so good and creamy, and the chocolate cone was the perfect touch. 
I can't wait to try the other flavors like black sesame & Taro. I highly suggest visiting Kuriimii if you haven't yet.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Anyone else feeling that rolled ice cream is rather underwhelming in Chinatown now? 

Which is exactly why Kuriimii is bringing a much needed addition to Chinatown - SOFT SERVE ice cream! ... which is also why I am a big fan, not to mention the Asian inspired flavors to choose from.

Pros:
- Flavors (changes regularly) 
* Black Sesame: nutty, perfect for a black sesame fan but could be stronger in flavor 
* Matcha: no one can agree against green tea, good but typical  
* Black Sesame & Matcha swirl -- perfect balance of the two
*Avocado: rich, creamy, just like an avocado smoothie but in ice cream form. (warning: acquired taste)
- Taro: like taro. 

Tips & Improvements:
