- Because it is soft serve, be mindful of it melting like the polar ice caps. That being said, be smart whether you want a cone or a cup. I had a friend who got a cone, and she would be slurping her ice cream mid-sentence every 5 second. 
- Don't forget about the swirls -- a mixture of two flavors!
- Viet Coffee flavor: unfortunately not creamy and rich like the other flavors, slightly more watery. 
- Interior: clean, modern, but the space is slightly odd like a long tunnel and music can be very loud.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
This place seems like a bit of a hub for asian-americas on campus, which is cool and a welcoming atmosphere in that sense, so I appreciate what they are trying to do. They have a cool vibe and a TV playing music videos from the 80s/90s for some reason, but hey its cool.

The actual shaved ice, I was less impressed with. I got the taro and it was really flavorless, my friend got the black sesame which was better but def not the best taiwanese shaved ice I've had. The texture of the ice is really well done, but I think they need to add more flavor. Very instragrammable (if that's a word) since it looks very aesthetically pleasing but the taste doesn't match the looks. 

Overall, I may possibly recommend this place if you are in the neighborhood and are just really craving shaved ice, but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to seek it!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: I am a huge fan of soft serve ice cream and the only time I was ever able to get my hands on some was from the ice cream trucks. With all the hand roll ice cream spots in Chinatown, kuriimii definitely brings a new cold twist to town. Kuriimii specializes in soft serve ice cream with exotic flavors such as: matcha, avocado, black sesame, charcoal vanilla and taro. I can absolutely see myself coming back here many times. One cone is never enough because I'm still debating whether which flavor is my most favorite.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Group of 6 of us, we ordered one of everything on the menu. Favorites were: Signature wings, duck salad, Brussels sprouts, mia goreng, chicken sausage fried rice and hands down the fried branzino was the winner! They were out of ribeye and bao. Our favorite of the desserts was definitely banana doughnuts. Tres leches with black sesame was unique, less sweet than everything else. Great service, loud atmosphere. Not good for kids. Would definitely recommend!
name: Sama Sama Kitchen
categories: Cocktail Bars, Farmers Market, Tapas Bars, Food, Desserts, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Indonesian

text: Sooo good! Must try: cheese ddukbokgi, stone bowl bibimbap, soft tofu soup. All the ingredients are so fresh and delicious. Also got the house salad with black sesame dressing, bibim naengmyun and don katsu. All very good! Highly recommend this place and prices are very reasonable.
name: Miga Korean Cuisine Restaurant
categories: Barbeque, Korean, Restaurants

text: Friendly servers and deliciously creamy soft serve! Would 10/10 recommend to all people who love soft serve or any ice cream-especially for these perfectly unique flavors. My favorites are the taro and black sesame! They give you a good portion and they even make it look picture perfect for those of you wanting to take a photo that makes ur friends wish they were eating with u:) love this new addition to chinatowns list of dessert joints!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
It's always safe to stick with the classic, creamy (kuriimii), soft serve. Enter, Kuriimii, a soft serve jawn. I stumbled upon their soft opening on the way to Bonchon. Wondering what the long line was about, I walked inside to discover a beautiful ice cream shop with plenty of artwork, seats, and lighting (for the 'gram). 

Avocado and black sesame were recommended to me. Of course, my curious palate went for both. I opted for the chocolate waffle cone with the black sesame and avocado in a cup. Toppings were unlimited and extensive, including fruity pebbles, freshly torched marshmallow, chocolate powder, coconut shavings, etc! Each ice cream was twisted to perfection and the toppings added even more goodness. The flavors were on point and texture was smooth and creamy. Not too sweet, not overly rich - just right. I was told that the up and coming flavor, Ube, will be offered soon. Drool.

I'm not even mad that they're opening after summer (less drippy mess on your hands).
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Black sesame and condensed milk here are out of this world. Two of the most delicious things I've had and they go so well together. 

The "small" is enough volume to entertain an adult with a sweet tooth for the proper amount of ice-cream eating time, or to split with your friend without either feeling too underwhelmed. Since it's a lovely fluffy type of shaved ice, it's really fun without making you physically feel the guilt one feels after ice cream sometimes. 

I've also heard that their boba is better than average (though I can't attest to this myself)!

It's always full of big groups of people hanging out and playing Jenga. I wouldn't come here for a date over somewhere quieter in the city, but a fun place to spend time with friends.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: I love this place! They have a good selection and I was super happy to be able to find the things I wanted. I was pretty impressed with this place since it is in Boise but I plan to return many many times from now on. I bought a grass jelly drink, ramune, agar powder (I love making coffee jelly), inarizushi, mochi, nori, ochazuke mix, several jelly pudding mixes and prolly would have bought a lot more if I could. I think their prices are fair and the kid who works the register is nice and friendly. Wish he was my age, lol. Everything I tried tasted delicious! I got a mochi sampler and the black sesame mochi is so wonderful! I think they do a good job of being a general Asian store and that you can find almost anything.
name: Asia Market
categories: Food, International Grocery, Grocery

text:
Lunch at Zento was the highlight of my day on 1/5/12. Granted, it is only 2:30 and there's a chance things could perk up from here, but I'm not sure what could top this flawlessly executed meal.

For a mere $10, you can enjoy miso soup (savory and rich, not watery at all), a green salad (sprinkled with black sesame seeds and a light ginger dressing) and two rolls from the list provided. I ordered my favorites: spicy tuna and salmoncado (this roll was not on the list, and had a $1 upcharge, but whatever). Michelle C ordered green tea for the both of us, which was served in a fancy handle-less mug, and had hints of an earthy rice flavor.

The rolls aren't massive, but I liked it that way. The rice:fish ratio is on point. No globs of rice falling off any piece. Both the tuna and salmon tasted fresher than any other sushi I've tasted in Philadelphia. 

Service was, if anything, too good. There are only so many times a two-top happily eating their sushi needs to be checked up on. 

I'll have to dine-in while they're still BYOB before their location changes to a "sexy and trendy establishment with a premium sake bar." Liquor licenses are the worst. 

Regardless, every bite was delicious. I'll be back, BYO or not.
name: Zento Contemporary Japanese Cuisine
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion, Event Planning & Services, Caterers

text:
I went to the soft opening about a week or so ago. I got the Black Sesame and GreenTea mix and I thought it was very good! It wasn't too sweet or flavorless. 

Because it was a soft opening, I got a discount; I believe 20 or 25% off. I wouldn't get it for the full price. The ice cream wasn't THAT good. 

To be honest, I only went because of their black ice cream cones. It's the first place I've found in Philadelphia that had black cones! Great for pictures and the 'gram! 

The store itself was spacious. When I went, there were almost no decorations. All the furniture is white. I didn't like how they positioned their tables; they were so close together that it was hard to move without asking the other people sitting at other tables to move their chairs. 

Also, they seemed a bit unprepared. They didn't have change for my friend who was trying to pay with a $20 (but they ended up just giving it to her for free).

4/5!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Quick, friendly service! So delicious, very authentic, fresh ingredients. They make their salad dressing in house, definitely recommend the black sesame. The cheese toppokki has glass noodles as well, dip the mandu in the spicy sauce and eat it with with the cheese, it's to die for!
name: Miga Korean Cuisine Restaurant
categories: Barbeque, Korean, Restaurants

text:
I don't really believe in $6/$7 for soft serve ice-cream, even if it has Asian-inspired flavors (which happen to be my favorite type of flavors). Perhaps it was only my personal experience there but both the taste and service wasn't up to par with the price. And yeah, they say "limitless toppings", but it feels just a bit misleading in that they only put a minimum amount of each type of topping and the toppings available are very inconsistent (i.e. no teddy bears even when it was advertised on the board). 

I had the taro and the black sesame when I visited, and the taro was okay but nothing to rave about. Black sesame was actually rather unpalatable, with an oddly spicy and bitter flavor. I wasn't the only person who thought so; 4 out of the 5 people who were there didn't even want a second bite of the black sesame. To be fair, some of them had tried the black sesame flavor there before and said that it had tasted different/better previously. I generally like black sesame flavors, but perhaps they wanted it to be stronger given previous reviews and it happened to backfire. 

Sure, sometimes it's nice to shell out for dessert, but there are many other options that are far more worthwhile within a few block radius. Plus, soft serve is not a new concept - swing by Micky Ds anytime for the same type of deliciousness for just a happy $1.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
This was my first time at Winterfell Dessert. I'm a huge Game of Thrones fan so I was a little sad that the room didn't live up to the name (though the house word/ice puns were pretty good!). The decor reminds me of places in China, with the addition of some comic book vinyl figures and board games. 

They have many flavors and toppings to choose from, as well as their pre-created specials menu. I shared the JS (black sesame ice, mochi, white sprinkles, vanilla cookies and cream, condensed milk) because I wanted to try sesame as a sweet flavor (as opposed to the usual savory). The cup looks huge when it first comes out, but the ice is super fluffy. I wasn't entirely wowed by my selection when I tried it - the combination of the type of ice and toppings didn't really fit with what I wanted in a dessert at that moment. It has the potential to be really good though, and I think I'll create my own next time.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: It's really cool that there's a soft serve place in Chinatown that serves Chinese flavors like taro, black sesame, green tea, etc. The flavors are not as strong I was expecting. But overall it's good ice cream but it melts super fast.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I'm torn here between 3 and 4 stars.  

Atmosphere - I loved the furniture, which was made by someone locally (Fernley maybe?) from reclaimed woods, and we sat at a long, hightop, that could have sat maybe 8 or 10?

We stopped in on Friday night, for their tapas menu.  Here's what we ordered:

Crispy friend monkfish, soy sake broth, wasabi creme - $11

Pernod Steamed PEI mussles, grape tomatoes, jalapeno bacon - $13

Smoke pork enchiladas, machego and oaxaca - $9

Russian ghost cone, espresso ice cream, and chocolate souffle - $11

I really liked the monkfish, and though the presentation was great, with julienne veggies and seaweed for accents, black sesame atop the wasabi creme, etc.  Flavors blended well too.

The mussels were fine - no wow factor here, but just solid mussels.

Enchiladas were a bit of a miss - they were closer to lukewarm than warm, and were just kind of there.

The dessert was great - delicous souffle, and the ghost cone was this thin, gelatinous film, that complimented the espresso ice cream well.  The ice cream was maybe a bit too smooth, but overall a good dessert.

The reason I'm torn is mainly since I expected a tapas menu to be a bit more affordable.  The price point was definitely higher than expected.  Menu was rad and innovative, but considering that 2 of the 4 items we had were a bit of a miss, I don't think the GF and I had a $45 meal.  For now, I'm going to stick with 3 stars, as they didn't wow me, but there's definitely potential there.
name: Composition Cafe
categories: Wine Bars, Nightlife, Tapas Bars, Food, Tapas/Small Plates, Burgers, Cafes, Restaurants, Bars

text: Pretty good soft serve. The top flavors for me were matcha, taro, and charcoal vanilla. They didn't have black sesame when we visited. They let you sample before you chose which helps in making a choice. They also have WiFi!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Yay for a soft serve place in Philly! My ice cream prayers have finally been answered! If you frequent NYC, this place is comparable to Soft Swerve. I assume they're going for a similar vibe. The flavors lean towards pleasing the Asian palette (being based in Chinatown, that's pretty appropriate), so you'll see flavors like Matcha, Taro, Black Sesame and more. The ice cream is super creamy and thick. I got the Taro, which could have been more flavorful (using Soft Swerve as a standard), but I did visit on the soft opening so maybe they're still working out some kinks. I will say that the price is definitely on the steeper side. $7 for a cone, and $6 for a cup. So if you're not into the exotic flavors, then a $1 McDonald's cone will probably satisfy your soft serve hankerings. But if you are into some out-of-the-box flavors, then Kuriimii is your place.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Yummy variety of snow ice and toppings! Our group got the black sesame ice, mango ice, lychee ice, and matcha ice with a variety of toppings. Delicious! They have a variety of toppings but I wish they had more traditional snow ice/shaved ice toppings.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
BANGIN SHAVED ICE

I ordered black sesame with red bean, pocky sticks, coconut shavings, and mochi.
Solid selection of flavors - mango, strawberry, sesame, lychee, green tea, taro and honeydew!
Friendly and goofy staff. Will definitely be back to try all flavors/toppings!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: Fluffy shaved ice cream, not too sweet. I had King of North (if I remembered correctly), really loved the black sesame flavor, reminds me of some snack I used to eat growing up. Will be back to try more other flavors.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: This place just opened. And I freaking love it ! The taro and black sesame flavors are bomb. Also your social media / marketing is on point. Keep up the good work ^___^ PLEASE BRING TOFU FLAVOR PLEASE PLEASE
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I've been here twice for lunch, and even if there is a line, service is quick. This might be a little pricier that other sandwich shops, but the quality is so far beyond what you would get elsewhere.  

I've had the pleasure of sampling the following:
Rook: Vietnamese pork roll, chicken liver terrine --  A little more on hearty side. If you love liver, you will appreciate this one!

Magpie: Marinated ground chicken -- Clean. Fresh. Excellent on a hot day.

Pork Cracklings: Salty fried goodness

MACARONS: Black Sesame,  Green Tea, and Wasabi -- These were ok.... wasabi was the best. Cindy's traditional flavors are the best. 

Can't wait to see what Chef Carlos brings to the table here!
name: Rook
categories: Asian Fusion, Vietnamese, Restaurants, Sandwiches, Filipino

text:
This IceBurg has two poke stops within the area.
Sitting and eating ice cream all while getting poke balls, definitely worth it .

Thai ice cream is definitely worth it with coconut and condensed milk syrup + mochi.
Thanks Kevin for awesome service. 
Definitely want to try black sesame ice cream next time
name: IceBurg
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cafes, Acai Bowls, Restaurants, Desserts

text: We were here to satisfy an ice cream craving on a super hot day during our trip to Philly. The place blasted the typical club/party music you may find in other trendy dessert spots, but the lack of decor made it feel mostly barren inside. The taro was decent, but black sesame tasted unusually grainy compared to other soft serve places, and it didn't taste much like black sesame... The toppings were less than impressive and I would just skip any extras that weren't included. This was the first soft serve place we happened upon, but next time, I'd hit a different dessert spot instead.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Drunken Fish on 10/29 the Saturday night of the 2016 Halloween festivities. 

My boyfriend and I must have wandered in here just after 9pm. We had been hanging on the street and were ready to sit down and get a drink and a bite to eat. Turns out the guy at the gate entrance says there's a $5 cover charge. Just to walk in and have dinner? Yes. Ok fine. We get to the hostess stand and ask if we can get a table outside which honestly didn't look very crowded. She says she can only seat the first 4 tables and they've been occupied all night. Oh, wait a minute. One is empty. If you give us a couple of minutes to get it cleared it's yours. Thanks! We'll take it. So we got to sit on the patio both facing the street to watch all of the people and costumes from the comfort of a table on the patio! Yay! Now that's worth a $5 cover. When we sat down the BF ordered a fancy martini. I pulled out my phone and checked into Yelp and there was a check in offer for a free order of Edamame Hummus which wasn't even on the menu. I showed this to the server and she said she'd bring it right out. We looked over the menu and ordered some sushi. Out came the hummus and it was delicious! It had white and black sesame seeds on top and there was a slightly sweet taste but not overdone. The accompanying chips were fried wonton strips. I loved it! The sushi was adequate but nothing special. I felt the fish wasn't particularly stellar and it certainly wasn't plentiful. I realize this was a super busy day for them but the ladies room needed a lot of attention by this time of night. Not good. The stars of this show were the location, view, and Edamame Hummus!
name: Drunken Fish - Central West End
categories: Japanese, Restaurants, Lounges, Nightlife, Bars, Sushi Bars

text: This place is great! Charcoal vanilla, black sesame, and taro were all capital D-lish!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
The workers/owner are very nice and also gave out complementary ice cream because they were a few minutes late opening up their store. They really didn't have to - so def service is great! 

I got the charcoal vanilla ice cream and black sesame. My friend got the charcoal vanilla and the taro ice cream. I was hoping they'd have the hot cheeto topping but they didn't. :( This was my first time trying the charcoal vanilla ice cream. It tasted just like vanilla and the fun part was that it made our mouths black. I didn't really enjoy the black sesame like I thought I would but the taro was really goooooood and dense(?) - it wasn't liquidy either. I think I'd go back for the taro if I were to go back. Also, you gotta eat fast or else your ice cream will melt - might be cause we went on a really hot day.....

Also, even if we were to have paid for the ice cream, the price was not bad at all. You also get 2 free toppings(?), which I thought was pretty nice!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
healthy fast food - ditch the fries & 'burgers and go for japanese pan noodles with broccoli, carrots, shitake mushrooms, asian sprouts with black sesame seeds & cilantro garnish. yuuuum!

you can pick a plate, or a salad - mix & match - asian, mediterranean, american. add a protein serving, including tiger shrimp or organic tofu as well as chicken or beef - and you've got a balanced meal on the run for $6.95. 

try the wisconsin mac & cheese, thai curry soup, pasta fresca, potstickers - and oh yeah - the flatbread or rustic rolls 

regular & small sizes, or choose a trio - any small noodles or soup, a protein, & a side salad - green or ceasar.

for a chain, this one stacks up well.
name: Noodles & Company
categories: Restaurants, Italian, American (New), Noodles, Pasta Shops, Food, Specialty Food, Comfort Food, Asian Fusion, Salad, Mediterranean

text:
Went on grand opening, a lot of people as expected but lines were quick! I got the black sesame matcha swirl with green tea toppings which are my fave.. super soft, perfect amount of sweetness, and def satisfied my soft swerve cravings  
 
Can't wait to try all of the other flavors. Will def come back!! #softswerve #phillylove
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Upon walking in Ciccio's, I instantly knew we would be in for a treat. The unique thing about Ciccio's is that it is technically two restaurants in one. Ciccio's California Cuisine and Ciccio's Water. The menu is vast, offering everything from California noodle bowls to gourmet sushi and everything in between. The specialty menu switches monthly and they keep it non hectic by having two kitchens, one for the Sushi and one for everything else. Also, Ciccio's gets the majority of their products local.

We started off by sampling the famous Slam-Gria. A giant glass of homemade sangria, offered in red, champagne and white. Our table tried one of each. My personal favorite was the red. 

Out first item off the menu was Tuna Bruschetta: Pistachio Wasabi Crusted Seared Tuna with edamame hummus, seaweed salad and soy ginger vinaigrette. It was amazing. The Tuna was perfectly seared to have the pistachio crust. The flavors really complemented one another.

Up next was Filet Mignon Quesadilla's: Strips of filet mignon, black beans, roasted poblanos, cilantro, spicy corn guacamole, jack cheese and sour cream. My boyfriend really enjoyed this dish and has asked me to make it at home.

One of my favorite dishes of the night was Lobster Mac and Cheese with Truffle Oil Drizzle. Ermahgerd....This dish was beyond. Rich, savory, delicious, creamy, cheesy, truffle, lobster goodness. I told Ciccio's Manager Steve that they should put this in a New England Style Hot Dog Roll and make a Lobster Mac and Cheese roll out of it. 

After savoring those three items, out came three rolls of sushi. Up first was the Spicy Diablo Roll which was amazing: Ahi tuna, tempura onions, topped with spicy tuna, beet tobbikko, daikon sprouts, and sriracha aioli and sesame seeds. We also had one of the monthly specials, Sleepy Hallow: Spicy ahi tuna, cucumber, mango, avocado, topped with zesty spicy aioli marinated Maine lobster meat, black sesame seeds, beet tobbiko and tempura spinach. 

Next came out two pizza's. The Chicken Marsala Pizza, which was delicious. I need the recipe for Ciccio's homemade marsala sauce. Along with the "Almost Gluten Free Thin Crusted Pizza". 8 inch single serving with fresh tomato sauce, basil and mozzarella. You can include a variety of toppings and there are only traces of gluten (22 carbs include fiber). This pizza was simple and delicious.

Time for more cocktails, I tried the Cucumber - Muddled cucumber and sugar, Absolut Vodka, St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur, fresh lime and a splash of club soda. Katie tried the Zen Cosmopolitan - Gekkeikan Sake, Triple Sec, Lime, Cranberry Juice. The cucumber was very refreshing and I could probably drink  too many of them. My friend Katie ordered the Zen Cosmo was made with Sake so it had a different twist to the classic cosmo. It was great!

I have heard wonderful things about Ciccio's California bowls. They are known for the variety of options, everyone will find something on the menu that they would love. You choose to have your bowl served with steamed yellow, sticky rice, brown rice, farro (add $1) or chilled Asian noodles (add $2). We tried the Thai Chicken Bowl,  napa cabbage, scallions, cilantro, carrots, mango, crispy wontons and peanut aioli (with steamed rice). As this included all of my favorite flavors, I was a very happy (and full) girl.

We also tried the fish of the day which was local caught Tile Fish served with spaghetti squash, grilled broccolini and lemon almond sauce. I could eat an entire bowl of the spaghetti squash. When I make it at home, it is never this good. I have never had Tile fish before and really enjoyed it.It's a light white fish.

Next thing I know, dessert came out. I can never say no to Smores, no matter how much room is left in my belly. Toasted marshmallow and Chocolate bar with vanilla ice cream and caramel. Need I say more?

Everything we had was delicious. I will absolutely be back again. If you have yet to dine there, I urge you to go give them a try! They offer a weekend brunch and a daily Happy Hour.
name: Water + Flour
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Pizza, Gluten-Free, Tapas/Small Plates, Cocktail Bars, Bars, Nightlife, American (New), Italian

text: Went to the grand opening because of their BOGO promo. Tried 5/6 flavours (no taro for me). Was a bit disappointed that they didn't have ube like they did at their soft opening but the black sesame made up for it ! It's hard to find black sesame ice cream in this city, so I'm glad Kuriimii has it. Whoever said the ice cream was too sweet is crazy. Knocked off a star due to pricing since it's just soft serve.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
5 stars for hole in the wall Shanghai style soup dumplings

The steamed soup dumplings are heaven in a steamed basket!  The service was quite friendly.  The siu mai was fresh and had great flavor and textures.  The chive and pork dumplings were right on the money and pan fried to perfection.  They also had a new menu item of pan fried soup dumpling with black sesame seeds on top.  This was a party in your mouth.

There are 3 sauces at the table which mixed together are sublime on all the dumplings.  The vinegar is perfect on the soup dumplings.  

If you've never had soup dumplings remember to eat them while they're hot and put it on the soup spoon and add your favorite sauce on top.  Eat it one bite and make sure you don't burn yourself. 

As for the roast duck over rice.... reminded me of eating in Hong Kong at night time with some greens on the side a little roast duck nicely seasoned with 5 spice powder on the bottom which gets into the white rice that the duck sits on.  

This place lacks atmosphere and may be considered a hole in the wall by some.  I call it a hidden gem and can't wait to go back.  

The prices at this restaurant are very reasonable and it's BYOB.
name: Dim Sum Garden
categories: Restaurants, Chinese, Dim Sum

text:
a ton of instagrammable ice cream locations popping up in chinatown, like a liquid nitrogen one next door or rolled up ice cream. must have a ton of competition, but I think this place is worth it out of all. it's cheaper than I thought and they give a huge amount of ice cream.

ordered the matcha and black sesame swirl soft serve in a cup (the combination of these two flavors are amazing. bitter and nutty combined. i think the matcha flavor is great but i dont think the black sesame is as good as other places ive been too, could be more flavorful or taste less grainy. they give a huge amount I couldn't finish it. I topped mine off with some fruity pebbles and 2 green tea pocky) and the matcha soft serve in a cone (I highly recommend the matcha only compared to the swirl. the cones are all waffle cones only).

you get 2 free toppings of any choice. they didn't have the charcoal vanilla when I went and had hazelnut instead which sucked. also, maybe it's because we went late at night, it looked like they were sparse in ingredients, and the place didn't seem as clean or tidy. maybe also the all white interior and empty walls, except the menu board, in this huge place doesn't really make it seem cozy or make you want to stay, looks too cheap and plastic. other than that, I would recommend coming here for the matcha ice cream for cheap after eating some greasy Chinese food
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
This building is the space that Christian's and Redemption formerly occupied. I didn't have the opportunity to go to either on of those restaurants, so actually eating dinner in what was a former church was a whole new experience for me.

From top to bottom, this place is just divine. I love the fact that the restaurant is situated in a "reworked" church, and still has the feel with the stained glass windows and high ceilings. The atmosphere is cozy, yet elegant and everything is just beautiful. The staff here might be the friendliest staff in town. I know that some of you might say it's because the place is so new, but I was greeted by multiple people when I arrived, a few staff members stopped by during dinner to inquire about the meal and I got a friendly goodbye on my way out the door.

I started off with the #gooddecisions cocktail as I looked over the menu. Everything here sounds so amazing, and I like that they have a nice selection of options from seafood and pork to chicken and vegetable dishes. For my appetizers I got the 3 cheese plate which came with the chef's choice of cheeses as well as the rabbit rillette, which is basically a pâté, The cheese was delicious- I wish I could remember exactly what the cheeses were, but I really enjoyed them. The rabbit rillette was out of this world. It was full of flavor and a biscuit came on the side so it could be spread. It was really rich, and if I was just getting a drink and an appetizer here, this is exactly what I would order.

For my entree, I got the whole smoked fish, charred eggplant, house yogurt, eggplant & black sesame seed purée. The fish is indeed a whole fish which comes with the bones in and head on. It was delicious! The fish had enough meat on it that the bones being in it wasn't a problem at all and they were fairly easy to "pick out". The fish had a smoky flavor that was good without being overwhelming. The eggplant was perfectly roasted and the yogurt was a nice touch and mellowed out the flavor of the fish a bit- it was a nice balance of flavors.

I loved my experience here and I am excited to return. On the night I was here the crowd was pretty thin, but I am sure that this place will definitely "take off" once word gets out about how good it is.
name: Vessel NOLA
categories: Desserts, Cocktail Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Bars, Food, Tapas/Small Plates, American (New), Restaurants

text:
I actually didn't even know this place served dinner.  I figured with all the not so stellar early reviews including how limited the menu is, how could they spread it over to dinner?  But we passed by while in Fountain Square and saw their chalkboard out front with a dinner special listed, so we stopped in before a show at Radio Radio.  This is a cool looking spot-- narrow, industrial, minimalistic. Counter service but food is brought out to you. Drink options--bottles in the fridge. The dinner menu was written on a large spool of brown paper hanging behind the counter.  Agree that prices seem pretty high for what's offered. $6 for 4 thin dumplings. $8 for 2 hand-sized Vietnamese pancakes. and the dinner special---congee? really? you can make a dinner entree out of that?  I didn't actually see it, but when I think congee, i think of garlicky/bland soupy white rice that you eat when you're sick or hung-over (or very pregnant like the lady in front of us). 
The wild mushroom dumplings were quite good--obviously handmade with what looked like only mushrooms inside, but pretty flimsy. The sauce had a tad too much vinegar for my taste.  We shared the non-vegetarian Vietnamese pancakes. At first I wondered why they were not just called Korean pancakes since most of the ingredients were Korean (bulbogi beef and sauce, kimchi), but they were definitely not Korean pancakes (juhn)--they were more like tacos on a little crepe (and topped with pickled shredded cabbage and fresh cucumber slices, not really kimchi). I guess the sauce was bulgogi inspired, not quite the same. It also had a little spicy kick. Husband quite enjoyed them. We also shared the Korean noodles ($12). Surprise! It's cold. And more like a noodle salad or maybe a cold noodle bibimbop--short udon noodles tossed with chili paste sauce and topped with pickled Asian pear (I thought they were radishes), fresh cucumbers slices, soft boiled eggs, and sprinkled with green onions, black sesame seeds ( I don't even think I noticed the baby bok choy or Thai basil).  Over all the food was more like 3.5 stars, but we left still kinda hungry.  Don't think I'll be back for dinner anytime soon, but I'll almost certainly return to try the bahn mi and see what specials show up on the menu for dinner.
name: Rook
categories: Asian Fusion, Vietnamese, Restaurants, Sandwiches, Filipino

text:
Nestled right in the middle of philly Chinatown, Kuriimii is the perfect place for your mid-night sweet tooth cravings (they're open until 12am on the weekends)  They offer a variety of interesting soft serve flavors that is new to philly, and include an unlimited amount of toppings. The staff are very friendly and the ambiance is very chill. It definitely feels like a philly-take on soft serve! Whether it be after your afternoon lunch, or after a couple drinks at the local bars, I highly recommend the soft serve here as a means of satisfying your sweet tooth. I personally love the black sesame soft serve on a chocolate waffle cone! 

(Attached is the honeydew cone - also recommended if you love melona bar ice cream. I ate my black sesame cone too quick to snap a pic)
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I came here for my birthday dessert with my family. I knew this will be sweet overload, so after my birthday brunch in center city we decided to walk here from 13th and Walnut. Arctic Scoop is on E. Passyunk near 13th St. It is a small store with very limited seating. Fortunately, when we went we were the only customers so we grabbed the only table that will seat four people. Soon after that more people came in. 

On their menu board you can see the ice cream flavours, toppings, etc. When we went they only had about 6 flavours, but I thought that was enough. I really wanted to try their lychee lavender ice cream, but I didn't see it. Workers will happily let you taste different flavours, so after tasting pandan I knew I wanted that. My daughter ordered black sesame, and I thought it tasted good, but for me the flavour was a bit too intense. I think from few years ago Philly has caught onto selling egg waffles, but all the egg waffles I have seen sold around here are kind of expensive. I am used to paying $1 - $2 in SE Asia, so definitely a sticker shock. However, if you like egg waffles Arctic Scoop does a good job. 

I think Arctic Scoop truly serves good ice cream with great customer service. All the workers are really friendly and helpful. This is a place to splurge trying out different and unique ice cream flavours and toppings. Just remember the limited seating, and also, if you get too many toppings it's really difficult to eat because toppings keep on spilling.
name: Arctic Scoop
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Desserts

text:
My review will be biased from one drink

Service:4/5
Decor: 4/5
Drink: 0/5

Friendly service. Neat decor with sofas. This place was crowded and the line gets long.
I got the Black sesame boba had gooey boba and I wasn't a fan of that. The black sesame tasted watered down.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
My first experience with snow cream! Winterfell is a good dessert option if you want something unique and relatively light. Happy I got a chance to try it before the school year starts and it's overrun by students. With multiple exciting flavors and toppings, a GoT theme, board games galore, and late night hours, I am sure business will explode once Penn is back in session. 

Flavors are hit or miss - go for the Taro or the Black Sesame. I was most excited to try their Matcha flavor and was disappointed to find it bland and chalky. Mochi and condensed milk drizzle are a must, as well as the variety of fresh fruits. A bit pricey, but portions are generous. You can easily share a small with a friend. Be warned: your grass jelly topping will harden and freeze into a weird sludgy version of what it once was.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text: Def my favorite soft serve spot! There are a lot of flavors and toppings to choose from but my favorite flavor is definitely the honeydew & black sesame. The interior is also very nice and roomy. Would definitely recommend
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
A casual bar atmosphere with Japanese izakaya fare. Great sake and whiskey selection. The raw fish tasted extremely fresh. On two occasions, I tried the sashimi platter on special, grilled shishito peppers, shrimp tempura and avocado roll, spicy salmon roll, vegetable and pork gyoza, and the mochi. The black sesame and strawberry mochi worked well together. 

Service was attentive. Take a lyft/uber/cab as parking can be difficult.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
The staff was very friendly and offered samples along with suggestions on their most popular flavors. They probably have to explain the flavors a lot but they did not seem tired or annoyed of answering question.

I got the original egg waffle with pandan ice cream. I don't usually get toppings but with free unlimited toppings, how could I not? I got regular and black sesame mochi and a condensed milk drizzle. I was a bit surprised when it came with a chocolate and matcha Pocky. But no complaints here.

I haven't had egg waffle since I was a kid visiting Hong Kong, which was about 15 years ago. So I was pretty excited and this did not disappoint. I've had pandan before but the flavor wasn't subtle like I thought it would be. It went well with the egg waffle. I'll probably be back to try the coconut bowl and other flavors!
name: Arctic Scoop
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Desserts

text:
I am SO excited a Asian soft serve place opened up in Philly. I somehow stumbled across this place on Instagram and knew I had to try it immediately. When I went in the cold, rainy weather, there were still a few other customers inside. The staff was really helpful in helping us pick out flavors. They also give samples, which is a huge plus. I ended up getting a green tea + black sesame swirl with condensed milk and fruity pebbles. It was so good! The ice cream was super creamy, and the serving size was HUGE. The cone presentation itself was very aesthetically pleasing, and we weren't the only ones taking pictures of our food. 

Overall,  I would definitely come back here again. I originally wanted to try the charcoal vanilla because it looked interesting, but they were sold out of that flavor for the night. Next time!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: First time there and was very impressed with the Sake list and the variety of small, well prepared and very tasty dishes.  The sushi was fresh, and the warm dishes were well done, and not too small.  We especially like the eggplant, the spinach in black sesame Sauce and the curry crusted Tofu.  Will definitely be back!
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
Came here for the soft opening and can I just say this place is absolutely adorable. The workers were so friendly despite me asking to try basically every flavor! I ended up sticking to my all time favorite black sesame. I haven't found any other places in the area with the same kinds of flavors, which definitely makes this place stand out. However, the flavors were a bit weak for me. Some of the flavors I tried just tasted like cream to me... but the black sesame was still pretty good. They have unlimited toppings and cinnamon, chocolate, and vanilla cones. I must say I really did enjoy that cinnamon cone-- maybe more than the actual ice cream. 
I will probably end up returning to this place since I haven't found another place in the area with the same flavors.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Really chic and modern store selling really good soft serve. My personal fave is the green tea and black sesame!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Very nice restaurant in downtown Santa Barbara.  Modern decor, great food, excellent service.  Happy hours are 5PM - 7PM on weeknights and offer discounted prices on some drinks and food.

What we ordered:
- Crispy duck salad - excellent, very tasty and great texture
- Crispy rice salad - excellent
- Signature wings* - excellent, unusual taste but delicious
- Egg noodles* - good
- Crispy brussels sprouts* - excellent
- Black pepper tofu and broccolini - good
- Black sesame tres leche - looks ugly but tastes prety good
- Blue ginger marguerita* - good
- Mule kick* - good

* denote that item is available on happy hour menu at a discounted price
name: Sama Sama Kitchen
categories: Cocktail Bars, Farmers Market, Tapas Bars, Food, Desserts, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Indonesian

text: The spot is cute and modern. Seems like a great place to hang out while enjoying a dessert! I was so excited to finally have a soft serve ice cream spot in the city but was a bit disappointed. We got the matcha soft serve with pocky, green tea kit kats, and condensed milk. The texture of the ice cream was strange since there were little tiny bubbles or powder or something that made it gritty. The little particles were quite unpleasant and I actually did not finish the ice cream because of that. There are, however, lots of choices of flavors (today they also had black sesame, charcoal vanilla, Vietnamese coffee, taro, and honeydew) and unlimited toppings so maybe there's a better flavor. For $6 though I might as well get ice cream elsewhere.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Parking can be a hassle here if it's busy, so keep that in mind. We've only come on weekdays for lunch, so it's not super busy when we're there. Service is prompt and the food comes out really quickly. 

The soup dumplings are delicious. 6 to an order, there are regular pork ones or pork & crab ones. Personally, I don't think it's worth it for the upcharge since you don't get much crab. 

We've also tried the garlic baby bok choy and it's normally very good, but the last time we ordered it there were a couple pieces that looked questionable - but they were the last few pieces on the dish so we just left it. Something to be mindful of though.

Was also told to try the Dan Dan noodles but I found it kind of bland. Others have tried the lunch special (fried rice, ginger beef and a spring roll) and they also said it was pretty flavourless.

I like the soup dumplings a lot, but haven't found anything else to be super mind blowing. I do love that they give you free dessert! The last few visits we've received sesame balls filled with black sesame and they were delicious. 

Credit card only seems to be accepted over $40, otherwise it's cash/debit.
name: Shanghai 456
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Dim Sum

text: My group of 12 women did the Saba Table for Sunday lunch, and I can't say enough what a wonderful experience it was. We had a pre-set menu that included tabouleh, lutenitsa (roasted eggplant and tomato) and Bulgarian feta; tahini hummus; falafel sandwich with seasoned fries;  carob fudge cake with black sesame molasses; and of course all the pita we wanted. The meal was served family style and there was more than enough food for everyone. In fact, we gave all the leftovers to our guest of honor to bring home to her family. Everything was delicious and the service was impeccable. If you have a group of 10-12 people, I highly recommend dining at the big table.
name: Saba
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Middle Eastern

text:
Tried my first Kuriimii cone during their soft opening and regardless of soft opening or not, they did really well, ran smoothly and had really good flavors. I had their Honeydew and charcoal vanilla which were both really good. i also tasted Taro, Black Sesame, Matcha which i liked too. Ice cream is super creamy and a large serving so it would be best to share if you can't eat a lot of ice cream. I love their unique flavors and cannot wait to try their featured monthly flavors. I really wanted to try their vietnamese iced coffee, but not sure if it's still available. 
they have such friendly staff, a bright, clean, and welcoming store with a really cute 'Selfie' wall. 
can't wait to make another visit.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Super instagrammable photos of the soft serve here caught my eye, and having just come from a trip to China awash in awesome treats, I found this place irresistible. 

I ordered 1/2 matcha and 1/2 taro soft serve in a cup, topped with oreo crumbs and condensed milk ($5, large enough to share for 2 people). They also had a smaller cup option for $3.50. Pretty reasonable $ - maybe in response to earlier feedback that this place was too expensive.

The perfect presentation practically had me drooling, but as I tried the first few bites, it was just...okay? Not overly sweet, but not as creamy, flavorful, or dense as I've had before. I was also sad not to see black sesame, a flavor that's popped up in a lot of Yelp reviews/photos and part of the reason I was drawn here. The topping bar also looked surprisingly sparse. 

Although the treats here lend themselves to super cool, drool-worthy photos, there's some cost-cutting corners that don't make this place a hit in my book. Sparse topping and flavor selection/quality compared to other places (plus, I barely received a few drizzles of condensed milk on my $5 ice cream), donuts advertised on the chalk board that weren't there, something off about the interior design and location in Chinatown that makes it difficult to want to linger (if you can, given the limited seating), understaffed service (only 1 employee making soft serve 1 at a time on a Friday afternoon). Maybe I came at a bad time, but this was right before the weekend crowds are supposed to roll in. 

Kuriimii is a unique soft serve spot in Chinatown with lots of potential. The beautiful Insta-worthy photos already draw first-timers like me in, but it'll need to set the bar higher to bring me back. Hopefully they do, because I would return WAY more often in that case!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I have to admit that I loved Rolf and his children much more than I thought I would. When I perused the menu online before we made reservations, it seemed kind of a hoity-toity-fancy-schmancy foodie restaurant. Esp. when it came up on literally *every* "cool places to eat in Nashville" list.

But, well, it was extremely good, and the food was really great. We shared a number of dishes, including chicken liver with a jam; it didn't taste at all like chicken liver, so everybody really liked it except me. We also had some kind of pasta which was very good. The beer was excellent and the service, especially our server, (I can't remember his name, but he had a shaved head, a lumberjack beard, and tatts LOL--does that help?) made the meal extra special. He was just a nice guy and very professional and never steered us wrong on anything. 

We weren't crazy about the desserts,  they just didn't do it for me. Way too  foodie, weird food like black sesame ice cream, whatever. But highly recommend this restaurant for the ambience, food, and service.
name: Rolf and Daughters
categories: Italian, American (New), Restaurants, Mediterranean

text:
I live in NYC and love the food in Chinatown.  Recently I was visiting my folks in Edmonton, and was surprised when my dad insisted that we go to this new place close to the Municipal Airport.  It's a small cafeteria-style place next to the Edmonton Flying Club, serving Chinese food along with standard Western food like burgers and fries.

The dan dan noodle soup was delicious, the green beans were crunchy and succulent, and the beef brisket with tofu skins was better than anything I've eaten in NYC's Chinatown over the past 15 years.

We were so full after all that, we had to take home our dessert: sticky rice balls covered with crushed peanuts and filled with black sesame.

Definitely try this place if you like Chinese noodle shops and inexpensive, delicious food.  There is a one-page menu with English on one side and Chinese on the other side.
name: Shanghai 456
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Dim Sum

text: This new gem has Asian inspired ice cream flavors. There aren't many flavors but they let you sample whatever you want first. My least favorite was the black sesame seed one but by far taro was the best out of the ones I tried. Cute spot would go again. The best part is it's soft serve ice cream and not rolled like everything else in Chinatown.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Taking on the challenge of replacing a previous, well-regarded eatery, recently opened Washoe Public House is forging its own identity with a new chef/owner and menu, while managing to retain quite a bit of the charm and style that made its predecessor so popular.

We started with the "Lost in Translation" and "How We Mule" cocktails. The former's blend of mescal, agave, absinthe, and both Angostura and grapefruit bitters was good, but the absinthe could be dropped. Its strong, single note is mostly a distraction ($12). However, the mule is one of the best cocktails I've ever tasted. The familiar mix of vodka, lime juice, and ginger beer was dramatically elevated with a muddle of housemade blackberry-jalapeno jam ($10). Sweet, tart, zesty, and pleasantly spicy.

We followed drinks with an order of coconut prawns ($10). The coconut and panko-encrusted shrimp were served with housemade orange marmalade and pickled radish on the side. Overall a bit too sweet for me, but the shrimp were tender and the radish provided a nice contrast.

Next, a serving of pork belly spring rolls stuffed with cilantro, pickled carrot, jalapeno, kimchi, hot and sweet mustard, and above-average peanut sauce ($8). Every bite was was a delight. Equally good, a plate of bibb lettuce poke wraps filled with fresh hamachi, housemade green sriracha, black sesame seed, bean sprout, cilantro, and lime ($12). Fresh and tasty.

Classic arancini are small balls of risotto stuffed with ragu, peas, and mozzarella, deep-fried in Italian bread crumbs. This chef's take is a simpler mix of risotto and peas, deep-fried in panko and served with a creamy gouda sauce ($4). The bacon-enhanced sauce was a must, as the rice seemed a tad overcooked and the seasoning was mild-to-missing. I'm thinking perhaps the chef purposely went bland with the morsels in order to showcase a knockout sauce.

Still unsated, we ordered a pair of memorable entrees. First, a sizeable bowl of fancy mac and cheese made with cavatappi pasta, jack, cheddar, and smoked gouda cheeses, bacon, and golden cherry tomato ($14). I've tried a lot of classy takes on this favorite--and I've made a few at home--but this is something else. The spiral pasta is fun, the blend of cheeses work well together, but the savoriness of bacon combined with sweet tomato is what pushes it above and beyond. A side order of house-pickled vegetables turned out to be an excellent counterpoint ($4).

Finally, a dish of the sort that makes you wonder where it's been all your life. I've grilled and smoked elk, made sauces and stews with it, enjoyed elk sausage, and am generally a fan of the large cervine. I don't often write in flowery tones, so strap in. On this occasion, I was served one of the best prepared, best tasting examples of wild game I've experienced to date.

A double on-the-bone elk chop was cooked to a perfect medium rare, drizzled in a luxardo cherry demi-glace and set astride what was described as, "lemon, fork-crushed potatoes," dressed with grilled chunks of asparagus and fresh sprouts ($28). The potato bites had a nice crusty exterior and pillowy interior, the hint of lemon adding an air of mystery. I can't remember when I've had asparagus done so expertly. The sauce was a perfect complement to a perfectly cooked piece of high quality meat. I took my time and savored every bite.
name: Washoe Public House
categories: Bars, Beer Bar, Cocktail Bars, American (New), Nightlife, Restaurants

text:
Ciccio's/Water in SoHo is one of the many restaurants in the Ciccio Restaurant Group found on Howard Avenue in South Tampa. they serve fresh California cuisine (salads, bowls, stir frys, etc.) as well as a unique selection of sushi. I'd heard great things about the dining experience at Ciccio's/Water, and knew my group was in for a treat as soon as we sat down.

We had to start off the night by trying out one of their signature drinks: Slamgrias! They are enormous fishbowl glasses filled with white or red sangria...as well as a miniature bottle of red wine, white wine, or champagne. We ended up sampling one of each between the four of us...you know...for scientific purposes...All three varieties were fruity and tasty - they're definitely a party in a glass, and the presentation is very fun! Definitely order one up if you're dining at Ciccio's/Water!

Meanwhile, a few appetizers were arriving at our table! We sampled the tuna bruschetta, which was not only beautiful in color, but delicious in taste! It contained pistachio crusted seared tuna on a crisp crostini with edamame hummus. If you know me, you know that I am VERY new to the idea of eating sushi/raw fish. I have to say: this appetizer was absolutely delicious!!!! The balance of flavors and textures worked wonderfully together in the perfect bite. Yum! We followed that with a sampling of filet quesadillas, their Almost Gluten Free thin crust pizza (the crust is craker thin and crunchy - I was personally a fan), the chicken marsala pizza, and a big bowl of lobster baked macaroni and cheese with truffle oil. Now there's a taste treat! Not only was the mac n cheese rich and creamy, but you could definitely taste the tangy kick of truffle oil in each and every bite. It's definitely an indulgence...so I'm glad we were all sharing! An enormous plate of sushi was also presented on our table, and I was SO excited to try everything! Yep - two experiences with raw fish in this meal...and I LIKED IT! Can someone pat me on the back? On the top of the plate was the Diablo roll (which I am pretty sure was the favorite around the ENTIRE table); it contained Ahi tuna, tempura onions, and was topped with spicy tuna, beet tobbikko, daikon sprouts, sriracha aioli, and sesame seeds. To the left was the Sleepy Hallow: it contained spicy Ahi tuna, cucumber, mango, avocado, and was topped with zesty spicy aioli marinated Maine lobster meat, black sesame seeds, beet tobbiko and tempura spinach. If you like sushi, the selection at Ciccio's/Water is so unique! There were quite a few rolls on the menu that I would have also liked to try, but I guess there's always next time...right?

We weren't done yet, though! My friend Megan and I decided to sample a few of the martinis on the menu. I ordered the Zen cosmopolitan (made with sake instead of vodka) and Megan opted for the cucumber martini (refreshing!).

Then, we soldiered on to taste two entrees: first was the Thai chicken bowl. This was my personal favorite dish of the evening, and I wouldn't be surprised if I ordered it on a return trip. It contains chicken, napa cabbage, scallions, cilantro, carrots, mango, crispy wontons, and peanut aioli, with a scoop of sticky rice. It was crisp and fresh, and not at all heavy. I loved the balance! We also tried the fish special, which happened to be tile fish on that day. The tile fish was served on top of a bed of spaghetti squash and broccolini, with a lemon almond sauce. Again, the flavors and ingredients were fresh and flavorful. And it featured spaghetti squash...one of my favorites!

We thought we were done at this point in the meal, but we were wrong! A bucket arrived at our table...with a huge sparkler spewing fire from it! It was a shot bucket...sent for special occasions. Talk about presentation! And dessert was absolutely necessary, right? That evening, we could not resist a s'mores inspired option. Be still, my heart. I didn't want to share...I wanted one of these bad boys all to myself. It featured a toasted marshmallow and chocolate bar with vanilla ice cream and caramel. I don't think you can go wrong with any of these ingredients, and I'm quite sure that the dessert was devoured by our table in about 10 seconds flat.

All in all, I could not have been happier with our experience at Ciccio's/Water. If you're in the South Tampa area, definitely make sure to head in and give them a try - they are open for weekday lunch, dinner every night, and feature a brunch on Saturdays - so many options!

For more details/photos, see my blog
name: Water + Flour
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Pizza, Gluten-Free, Tapas/Small Plates, Cocktail Bars, Bars, Nightlife, American (New), Italian

text: We went to Fond for a date night and had an incredible meal. The olive bread with salted butter was delicious, and thankfully, they only give you one piece, or I would have spoiled my whole appetite eating bread. Fond also provided us with a complimentary amuse bouche-a cold and spicy watermelon soup in a small shot glass prior to the arrival of our appetizer. We ordered the Tuna Crudo appetizer and it was amazing. The pineapple and black sesame seeds were an especially nice touch. Our entrees were also very well prepared. We got the Hanger Steak (the special that night) and the Pork Belly, and they were both excellent. We would definitely go back.
name: Fond
categories: American (New), Bars, Seafood, Restaurants, Nightlife

text: Flavors seem to rotate in and out.  I was hoping to try black sesame when we came, but it wasn't one of the choices so we went with matcha and mango.  Both pretty good, but I wasn't a fan of the flecks in the matcha flavor - gave it a gritty mouth feel.  If you're familiar with the infamous Dole Whip made popular by Disney, Kuriimii has a non-dairy pineapple soft serve version that is pretty reminiscent if you ever need to get your fix.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Just waking up on a lazy Sunday morning and already missing my meal from last night. 

It was that impressive.

We showed up around 8:45 and put my name down for our party of 4 since it was a full house (including a full bar without much standing space). The hostess kindly suggested that we could go to this other bar a block away and she'd call us when the table is ready. We took her advice and had a few drinks at New Wave (a nice neighborhood spot), and about an hour later got the call our table was ready (they reserve it for you for the next 10 min).

We were so hungry we ordered up a storm. Unfortunately I got lazy with picture taking so didn't capture all the food we ordered.

Ordered:
-Tuna mentaiko (tuna, fluke, spicy cod roe, sesame seeds, sesame oil, soy, scallions)
-Spinach gomaae (spinach, black sesame sauce, sesame seeds)
-Chashu buns (pork belly, scallions, cucumbers, some combo of mayo/soy ginger glaze)
-Hamachi Kama (grilled yellowtail collar)
-Saba shioyaki (grilled mackerel)
-Grilled squid
-Salmon/avocado sushi roll 
-Chirashi 
-Some yakitori plate with shishito peppers, ginkgo nuts, bacon scallop, chicken and something else I'm forgetting. I'm angry at my friend for not sharing the scallop w/ me.
-Takoyaki 
-Eggplant (I think glazed with sweet miso per the menu I found online)

Everything was tasty and well executed. Some of my favorites were the tuna mentaiko, chashu buns, and the yellowtail collar. The other grilled options and both our sushi orders were excellent as well.

I loved the decor, a mix of fun Japanese touches with the anime playing on the wall and cute candles lining the wall behind the seats, with the wooden bar that has more of a mature look.

Pricing is reasonable, especially considering we ordered 4 carafes of sake (menu also boosts a respectable sake collection). 

In the past when I craved izakaya food I ended up in NYC because of slim pickings here. I'm glad that's no longer the case!
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text: Great new addition to the Philly Chinatown scene. The ice cream is creamy and flavorful. It's proven to be a solid choice for dessert when in the area. Recommend: black sesame (my favorite) and match green tea. Don't forget to ask for samples, if it's your first time!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Shanghai 456 is one of Edmonton's few restaurants offering xiao long bao (XLB), a soup filled dumpling and specialty of Shanghai cuisine. Previously located on Airport Road, it closed last November with a promise of a return in the new year. The new year has come and their new location was next on my long list of eats.

You'll find Shanghai 456 at 14456 - 118 Ave, just further north of Telus World of Science. Whether or not they intentionally looked for an address that included "456″, I found it pretty amusing. Don't bother trying to find a sign that actually says "144 St" though because there isn't if you're heading westbound on 118 Ave. It's right on the southwest corner, intersection of 145 St and 118 Ave. It didn't help at all that the sign was a measly unlit square overshadowed by the banner. Perhaps too soon to say, but if that's all the signs that are going up, I suggest you just spot the blank red store front banner to locate it. Parking available on the west side of the building, as well as in front of the restaurant alongside the smaller road.

Compared to their location before, the number of seating seems to be the same, with the only improvement being that it actually looks like a restaurant now instead of an old cafeteria of Edmonton's city airport! Fair warning: something is up with their floors. Just that particular tile, or perhaps just a coincidence that both Sharon's and my boots were sliding along with no grip. Slick! Be careful, especially if you have wet shoes or heels!

Of course, we ordered the xiao long bao. Glad to say that the quality have remained as they were! Nicely wrapped by a thin dough and lots of soup! Prices have increased though to $7.50 per basket of 6, from their $6.95 fare. A small cost when you consider their new location must have higher rent.

A new dish that I haven't tried before at Shanghai 456: the house special hot and sour soup, as per Sharon's request. Normally I'm not a fan as most that I've tried are too sour for my liking, but this version was a good balance of spicy and sour. A really good portion if you ask me, with lots of tofu, chicken, and vegetables. I would definitely order it again!

Not wanting to order just regular xiao long bao, we ordered the ones with crab meat to change it up. I prefer the traditional dumplings, but these would be a great option for any seafood or crab lovers. Packed with real crab, the flavor definitely overpowers the pork, which could be a good thing if that's what you were looking for.

Complimentary dessert is standard at Shanghai 456, or at least it's always been every time I've been there. This time it was freshly made black sesame pastry. The pastry was crisp and flaky, with the black sesame filling being not too sweet. Absolutely loved it! You can order it if they're offering a different dessert for the meal as well, Lotus Blossom, $3.50.

Verdict: It's the same place as it was at its previous location. So for those who have sat in the old cafeteria and experienced the original Shanghai 456, expect the same but with slippery floors, and a more restaurant-like feel. For those who have never tried, you're missing out on some great Asian comfort foods. My only qualm about this place is the service. When it gets busy, it literally becomes a standstill. I understand that the dumplings need to be freshly made and steamed, which could take a while especially if each table is ordering most likely more than one basket, but there must be a better way to get those bad boys out! We arrived for lunch on a Monday at 12:30pm. Our first order of xiao long bao didn't come to our table until 1:20pm (that's almost an hour folks!), as did our hot and sour soup. Last to come was the crab version and by the time we finished, it was already 2pm. My apologies to Sharon for such an extended lunch hour although we both knew what we were in for. It was a consolation that the owner did come out to apologize to each and every table and thanked them for waiting, but dining experience would drastically improve if they could find a way to bang those little dumplings out. Great visit and highly recommended, just bring your delicate chopstick skills and patience.
name: Shanghai 456
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Dim Sum

text:
This place just opened about 1-2 weeks ago. There are many flavors, some exotic and some more common Asian flavors, including taro, charcoal vanilla, black sesame, and matcha. You can get it in a cup or add $1 for a waffle cone, then you can choose UNLIMITED toppings!!! I got the charcoal and Vietnamese coffee swirl in a cinnamon cone. 

The coffee soft serve is really good. Very strong coffee flavor. I personally am not a fan of the charcoal flavor. Besides adding grainy texture and black color, it doesn't taste like anything and the vanilla base flavor is less milky and more sugary than my tasting. Next time I want to try the other flavors!

I have to give credit to the owner. He came over as I was about to throw away the rest of the waffle cone to inquire my feedback. I was honest about the cone being stale and not crispy. He then insisted to refund me the $1...even though I really didn't need him to. I do appreciate and want to recognize his effort to provide high-quality products to his customers. Just for that, I will recommend you to try this place!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I have been craving some XLB's for the longest time and to make up for the lack of Shanghainese food I have had, I ended up going to Shanghai 456 twice this weekend.  Both times (Friday night and Sunday afternoon) were busy with most of the tables filled. The new place is a slight upgrade from their previous digs but I personally miss the old hole in the wall vibe (not that the new place is bad, I am just nostalgic for the old).

Anyways, for food this is what we tried:

Trip #1
- Xiao long bao ($7.50) - you get 6 delicious, juicy soup filled dumplings. Dip it in the sauce, take a nibble and suck up that juicy fillings. Nice and tender. So good!  Definitely try them if you've never had them before.
- Steamed vegetarian dumplings ($8) - these were tasty as well. Nice amount of filling and you get 6 plump dumplings.
- Golden chinese baguette with condensed milk ($3.50) - first time I've had this. Basically, a small baguette and you dip the bread into the condensed milk. Sweet but don't think I would get this again.
- Lotus blossom ($3.50) - a pastry filled with black sesame paste. You get three. Not overly sweet which i liked. Nice as a small dessert.
- Shredded pork and cabbage noodle soup ($8.50) - we didn't even finish this (shocker!) but it's your typical noodle soup with some meat and veggies. 
- Complimentary dessert - mango pudding. Perfect way to end the meal.

Trip #2
- XLB's ($7.50) - excellent as always
- Wor tip ($8) - beef fried dumplings. This one has soup in it too! Didn't try it but my friends devoured it. Ask for the chili sauce if they don't give it to you.
- Minced pork with spicy sauce on noodles (jar jiang lo mein) ($9.50) - a bit on the salty side (my friend had this before and it was even more salty) but is pretty tasty.
- Green beans with X.O. sauce ($12) - so simple and yet so delicious. Garlic, salt, and a bit of dried shrimp over green beans. Awesome! Could eat a whole plate of this myself.
- Salt and pepper boneless ribs ($12) - came out piping hot along with some stir fried onions and green peppers (watch out for the red chili peppers). I liked it but one of my friends thought it wasn't crunchy/deep fried enough. I agree it was a bit on the greasy side.
- Complimentary desert - mango pudding again!

Overall, both my trips were excellent and will definitely be back! Service is a bit spotty (that's probably being nice) but don't let that stop you from trying Shanghai 456! Definitely a great spot to cure your Shanghainese cravings.
name: Shanghai 456
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Dim Sum

text: We stumbled upon this place after leaving a delicious Chinese food restaurant and decided to give this a try. We tried the J.S. which consist of shaved ice, mochi, black sesame seeds, sprinkles, cookies and cream. The mochi was chewy but it was sweet so I ate it because I'm a sugar addict. The shaved ice tasted like peanut butter. I was pleasantly surprised and highly recommend trying it. The owner is very friendly.
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
Wowwwww just went here again last night for a private event and the food was TO DIE FOR. 
Pinot noir: Grade A
Hamachi: A
Goat cheese with strawberries and black sesame granola: A
Wild arugula and peaches: A
Grilled CA asparagus w/ burrata: A+ 
Spring orecchiette pasta: A. Unique and tasty!
Roasted Ocean Trout: A+ WOWOWOWOW
I don't eat meat, but had the brown butter cornbread that came with the lamb and the black pepper grits that came with the short rib and they were fantastic!!!
For dessert, even though I was stuffed, I had a few bites of the Valrhona chocolate cake and Meyer lemon mousse- not surprisingly they were both incredible tasting and unique!
Would come again and hopefully ASAP!
name: The Lark
categories: Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Food, American (New), Desserts, Restaurants

text:
58hundred is a tiny restaurant doing some really neat food.  Having taken over an old neighborhood bar, it is right on the corner.  It has a full bar and then a small dining room.  Because of the size, they do not take reservations.  I understand but it can be tough for a crowd.

The restaurant is casual but refined.  They have white walls and lacquered wood tables, so there is no distraction from the food.  The staff is very friendly but the service is a little uneven.  Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long for things.

The food, with the exception of dessert, is exceptional.  It was surprising that the dessert was such a letdown, but I recommend skipping that and ordering something wonderful like a Manhattan from the bar.  The food is truly worth the trip.

We started with the Braunschweiger, which was a perfectly seasoned pate of pig liver made in house and served with dill pickles, pickled red onions, aioli, brown mustard and grilled bread.  It was the best that I have ever had - it was best simply with the brown mustard but the pickled red onions were also a clever pairing.

The marinated flank steak and charred broccoli were the two dishes that were the most "as expected" of the evening.  The charred broccoli had a bit of grilled lemon but could have used a bit of salt.  I appreciated that it was crisp and served warm.  The marinated flank steak was well seasoned and finished with excellent blue cheese and housemade onion rings.  How could you go wrong with such a combination?

The 3 cheese sandwich with tomato soup blows your mind.  It is the most incredible tomato bisque that is finished with blue cheese crumbles and slivers of scallion greens and black sesame.  This is supposedly a mere accompaniment to the sandwich, but it is the reason that the sandwich is worth ordering.  Not that the grilled sourdough sandwich with sharp, white cheddar and blue cheeses, chopped portabellas and roasted peppers, and marinated artichoke hummus is not incredible - it is.  But it is other worldly after it is dipped in that soup.

The smoked pork belly with a sesame soy glaze over cauliflower puree with crunchy green beans is also impressive.  The pork belly is moist and tender, and the cauliflower puree is perfectly smooth and creamy.  The green beans add a sweet crunch and the sesame soy glaze adds a little nutty sweetness.

The smoked mushroom risotto is OUT OF THIS WORLD!!!  Order this dish!!!  Incredibly creamy risotto with just the right toothsomeness is loaded with smoky, meaty mushrooms and lots of herbs.  It oozes richness.  The crisp broccolini on top are also al dente and add a nice freshness to the whole dish.  I was blown away.

We knew we needed to order dessert, because the food was so incredible.  Alas, the train derailed.  The butter poundcake was on the dry side, even if I liked the housemade strawberry sauce or the fact that it would have crunchy edges from the cast iron dish.  The apple cobbler was just boring apple mush without a lot of imagination.  The rich chocolate brownie was just this side of dry so it was saved by the wonderful cream cheese frosting and the drizzle of chocolate sauce.

We had a great time at 58hundred and expect that it is among the best that St. Louis has to offer.  I am rounding up from 4.5 stars, but that 3 cheese sandwich and soup is WORTH THE TRIP and the round up.
name: 58hundred
categories: Bars, Cocktail Bars, Restaurants, Nightlife, American (New), American (Traditional)

text: Great service and delicious sushi and appetizers!  We always drove by this place and wanted to try it.  I read the Yelp reviews and saw photos which spurred our decision to finally try it.  I loved the New Orleans Roll with Smoked Oysters and Louisiana Roll with Crawfish, Crab, Cooked Shrimp and Spicy Mayo.  The Sunonomo Salad aka Cucumber/Pickled Salad with Black Sesame was full of flavor.  Shrimp Shu Mai with Ponzu sauce snd green onion was our son's favorite.  It is a small sushi place with 8 tables across from Jefferson Feed.  It reminds me of a typical neighborhood Sushi place in Los Angeles, our former hometown.  The chef is quite generous with portions of fish.  You won't be disappointed!
name: Sake Don Sushi Bar
categories: Restaurants, Food, Japanese, Sushi Bars, Beer, Wine & Spirits

text: Not all Chinese eatery's are created equal and this place is a cut above the rest for the tasty cuisine they serve up!  I'm very partial to the Gen. Tso chicken either  as a black sesame serving or the traditional type and both are available.   Not really comparable to PF's in any sense but to each her own. I have been dining here for the past 7 years and found every dish to be full, meaty and the the vegetables crisp. My litmus test is the chicken dishes fat content which if you eat out for Chinese you will  Inevitably get those fatty pieces, but not here for some reason...and that's a good thing.  I recommend lunch for the best prices as the dinner menu can giddy up and go without too much effort.  Ohh and it's BYOB.  FYI: the wine store is across the street, down through a little alley way which leads to a parking lot....which is actually a good place to park as the lot at the Duck Sauce is a bit tight.  Beer store also there as well.
name: Duck Sauce
categories: Salad, Chinese, Seafood, Restaurants

text:
Was so excited this place opened up in Philly, since I felt like I'd been missing out on the soft serve scene for quite a while. To be honest, my experience was a bit meh.

My boyfriend wanted to order the Pumpkin Spice swirled with Charcoal Vanilla. However, we were informed they did not have Charcoal Vanilla that day - a huge disappointment, given that this is one of their biggest selling points. Also, it was about 1-2pm on a weekend, not the end of the day or anything. My boyfriend ended up ordering the Pumpkin Spice and Taro instead - surprisingly, not a bad combination. We got condensed milk and oreo crumbles on top. Taro is great, it's light and not overly sweet, without an overwhelming taro flavor, would recommend. Hard pass on the Pumpkin Spice - it's way too sweet, we were sick of it after a few bites.

I ordered the Black Sesame and Matcha swirl on a chocolate cone - I've been drooling after similar soft serve pictures on Instagram for a couple years now. I opted for strawberry Pocky and green tea Pocky as toppings. This did not disappoint - I'd highly recommend this combination. It's definitely not too sweet, and I think people that generally don't like sweets would enjoy this dessert. Black Sesame and Matcha is a match made in heaven.

I wasn't expecting Kuriimii to be cheap, since it's obviously a trendy spot, but it's a bit hard to justify $5 for a cup and $6 for a cone. Unlike some of the older pictures, toppings are NOT unlimited anymore - you get 2 toppings with each purchase, additional toppings are 50 cents. As y'all may know, ya girl is a fan of unlimited toppings; I think it's an easy thing to offer at little expense to the vendor and great joy to customers. They have a great selection of available toppings, so I really hope they return to offering unlimited (or at least 3, c'mon) toppings soon.

Maybe my expectations are high, but I think Kuriimii is going to have trouble keeping up with the soft serve trend AND competing with the existing hoards of Chinatown ice cream shops if they don't make some changes. I don't think I'd choose this place over Teassert, A La Mousse, or T-Swirl. That being said, I'd return for the Black Sesame and Matcha swirl if I was craving it, and to try the Charcoal Vanilla - hence 3/5 instead of 2/5.
name: Kuriimii
