categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Everything and I mean everything about this place was phenomenal.  The black sesame semifreddo dessert was one of the best desserts I have had in my life.  I've had Tabouleh and it wasn't like this
name: Saba
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Middle Eastern

text:
Yum! There was a lot of hype about this place on Facebook, and I was worried that it wouldn't be up to its hype, but surprise! It is!

I've tried the Taipei special, the boyfriend special, and one that we made ourselves (black sesame, red beans, grass jelly, condensed milk & wafer sticks). 

The matcha and the taro were both really good and full of taste, whereas the black sesame base is a little more subtle but still yummy. Great texture of shaved ice that is Taiwanese style & the 1 extra free topping for checking in or liking on FB is an awesome deal. I really love the wafer sticks as they add a great crunch and taste to the texture of the shaved ice.

The price is also really good, considering how much these would go in NYC or in Koreatown in LA (although maybe that's not a fair comparison :P) 

5 stars!! I hope that the prices & quality stay consistent as it surely will attract more customers!

Oh and. "Hold the door" is written on the entrance door for all of you that know all the emotions that this phrase invokes. :'(
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
With the new rolled ice cream fad slowly fading away, there's been a strong contender for its successor and that's soft served ice cream with Asian flavors!!!

I personally love the texture and consistency of soft served ice cream more than anything so I may be a bit bias, but you can't argue with the flavors. There's so many unique Asian flavors that are constantly being updated and a wide variety of toppings to choose from!

My classic go-to option is the black sesame because I just love black sesame. It's a hard flavor to describe, but it's definitely worth sampling when you are there! 

Overall, it's a nice place to hangout after dinner and enjoy some sweets with friends for an affordable price!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
We came during the Prix fixe deals, which is the best I could find in Tampa. So I've been there at least 10 times, the manager even knows us. He is a cool and friendly dude, always comes up to us if he see us.

The food is amazing. My husband had the best lobster bisque here (he likes to think hes a lobster bisque expert) It has a Asian twist (coconut milk and curry paste I think) which makes wonderful flavor. Sushi is also amazing, or my husband says so coz I dont eat sushi ( yes, I am ashamed as an Asian) However, I strangely love their sunrise roll. Its cooked and fried. Its so good that I forgot its sushi, they cheated a little by the drying lol. I love the rib so much but its definitely messy, not for a first date. Our favorite is the lobster tempura, which is discontinued. Its not just goood because it is lobster but more about the aioli/sauce and black sesame. Afterthat, nothing is the same again. They have beautiful presentation. 

For entree, we tried the Sampler Trio, Bone in Ribeye, Filet Mignon, and Lobster. Our favorite is the ribeye with truffle mac and cheese with BACON. The best dessert is hand down the souffle. It is not quite the same as other souffle I have. Its more like lava cake and very chocolatey. The rasberry sauce and vanilla bean compliment the dish so well. I burned my tongue twice because I was too excited and ate the hot lava as soon as it oozes out. 
Fortunately, the third time I was about to do it again my husband stopped me coz he knows too well. My husband loves the pineapple upside down cake too. Oh, and the 1980 is so good, it doesnt taste too much alcohol, which could be quite dangerous lol
name: Roy's Restaurant
categories: Restaurants, Seafood, Hawaiian, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars, Steakhouses

text:
Came here for the soft opening and was pleasantly surprised with how well everything ran! There are about 7 tables with 2-4 seats each and the space modern and clean and super grammable lol. You can try all the flavors--they had honeydew (my favorite), matcha, charcoal vanilla, black sesame, taro, and avocado. No ube sadly because it's too expensive to make and too difficult to perfect (edit: Michael reached out to me and let me know ube will be available during the grand opening SO EXCITED!!!)

A cone with unlimited toppings (including pocky, various cereals, toasted marshmallow) will set you back $7 which is a bit on the steep side but for the amount of ice cream and the quality of the flavors, it was worth it! 

Would definitely come back to get other flavors!

EDIT: id actually appreciate Kuriimii a lot more if they offered other pricing options so that we aren't forced to pay a single price for unlimited toppings. Like why if I didn't want any toppings? Or only wanted one? I don't wanna pay $6-7 just for soft serve! Charge a more reasonable amount for no toppings or just 1 topping!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Probably the best shaved ice place in Philly, hands down. From what I gathered when I first visited, it was originally from NYC and they decided to expand and boy am I glad that they decided to do so to Philly cuz the city sure could use a good place like this. In terms of how it works, you pick a size (Regular, Large, T.B.O.), a flavor base (Mango, Strawberry, Black Sesame, Lychee, Matcha Green Tea, Taro, or Honeydew), toppings ($0.50 each), and a drizzle to finish (Chocolate Sauce, Condensed Milk, Whipped Cream, Salted Caramel, Strawberry Puree, Peanut Butter Sauce, Marshmellow Creme, or Honey. I ended up getting a regular (more than enough for one person, in my opinion) matcha green tea, assorted toppings, and condensed milk for my drizzle. Boy did the result not disappoint. The shaved ice consistency and texture here is the real deal ... not as good as the real deal in Taiwan but for the States, more than adequate and blowing similar average places like these out of the water. Incredibly yummy overall as my mouth and stomach were really happy and the best part is that this particular kind of dessert is light on the diet in terms of calories. I definitely recommend a visit here for sure!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
I am way more impressed with Kuriimii now than when I first attended the soft opening. At that time, it was pricey, for $7 a cone with unlimited toppings, which were quite limited, and charcoal vanilla had a dollar premium. Now, it's $6 a cone ($5 for a cup) with 2 free toppings (each additional for 50 cents). The constant flavors seem to be matcha, black sesame, charcoal vanilla, and taro. Strawberry and pumpkin spice were new additions this visit-the strawberry was lighter in flavor, while the pumpkin spice was just strong and sweet enough. It is really nice to be able to pick two flavors even if they aren't already swirled together, and have them either side-by-side or stacked. The toppings have expanded to include crushed nuts and gold flakes (though this has an additional charge). I am looking forward to seeing Kuriimii grow as our very own local soft serve jawn, as finally, I can stop thinking about how far away I am from Soft Swerve in NYC. 

What I'll be back for: new flavors and the friendly staff!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Cute place to stop for ice cream.  Unique flavors like black sesame, charcoal vanilla, matcha, lychee etc ...some flavors vary per day. Also different flavors of cones to choose from. 2 toppings included when you buy a cone or cup.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I didn't know much about this place before being taken here. I went in with zero expectations and my mind basically exploded. 

Everything on the menu was outstanding. The spinach gomai looked like a black brick under the soft lighting of the place, but break it and give it a lil swirl in that sweet black sesame sauce, and you've got yourself probably the best tasting veggie dish I've ever had. 

The ton toro pork jowl was charred in all the right places, and the lemon we squeezed over it cut the fattiness of the meat with perfect acidity. 

Tuna guac had huge tasty chunks of fresh tuna that we mixed with the avocado mixture and that wasabi oil. I didn't want that dish to end.

We also got a salmon roll, shrimp tempura roll, and a kitchen special cold silken tofu dish, which I wasn't a huge fan of thanks to an interesting herb or floral taste. 

The house draft sake over ice was so refreshing and easy to drink, and it definitely had the potential to be super dangerous. 

I hope I get to come back here again on my next Philly visit.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text: I think I found my favorite soft-serve in the Chinatown area of Philly. Located not too far from the Chinatown Friendship Gate, this little joint is known to serve up some rather gnarly soft serve combinations. You can choose either cup ($5) or cone ($6), which comes in either vanilla, chocolate, or cinnamon. There are a total of six soft serve flavors that you can choose from: matcha, black sesame, nutella, charcoal vanilla, honeydew, and taro. Not to mention an assortment of toppings to choose from; first two are on the house, any additional is $0.50 per. As this was my first time here, I chose to get a selection of four flavors (matcha, black sesame, charcoal vanilla, nutella) in one cup with a cinnamon cone on top along with assorted toppings. The nutella is definitely my favorite flavor hands down. It's literally tastes just like nutella in soft serve form ... which is quite legit. The matcha is also pretty authentic although I found it to be a tad too bitter for my liking. Black sesame is also pretty good although it could be a little less grainy. And charcoal vanilla ... what an interesting flavor to write about. Tasted just like vanilla, the charcoal ... didn't really add or take away from the flavor. The cinnamon cone is mad legit ... quite yummy and delicious. Overall, most reasonable prices for great tasting soft serve. Would definitely recommend to others!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
First off, I took me forever to figure out the pun from their name. The same isn't said for their ice cream; their quality and service did not miss the mark. I have been a few times, so I have tried their charcoal, pumpkin spice (seasonal), black sesame, and matcha flavors. My favorite is the black sesame. So much flavor !

It is roughly $5-7 depending if you get a cup or cup then some extra cents for the taxes. You get two toppings with your purchase but can definitely get more for additional cost. I've read a few reviews about their recent reduction in cost, which is good but keep in mind it's only because of good constant business and service. Overall, I dig this place and trying to take my friend here tonight even though it's Fall.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
i have nothing but good to say about the lark and the wine bistro behind.... we arrived a little early for our dinner reservation so we sat at the bar at les marchands for a delightful, refreshing glass of wine. wonderful environment! we moved over to the lark where we sat a a booth where we could see all that was going on. we had such great service. the food kept coming, and it amazed me;  each dish served at the table got better and better (and it wasn't because of the moscow mules consumed). our party decided to share all the dishes we ordered. we started with the charcuterie plate, pork belly sliders, little gem wedge, the beet salad along with the fried olives. we moved onto the marys roasted chicken - so moist and simple yet flavorful. each dish came out at the perfect time, and each dish was more and more exceptional.  i just might have to go back for the desserts!!!  the milk chocolate pot de creme (an absolute, even if you are not a dessert person),  the cheesecake, black sesame dacquoise, and ice cream sandwich - we did share all of those with coffee. a great ending!
i can't get back soon enough. time to make another reservation!! thank you for such a wonderful evening!
ps...i had to go back the next morning to the lucky penny for a warm scone and latte! perfection!
name: The Lark
categories: Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Food, American (New), Desserts, Restaurants

text:
I've been following them since they opened. I read all the reviews, their recipes are original, the business itself seemed like it was a game changer in the baked goods community so I was dying to pay them a visit. This week I did. 
I love their location on Mag st and 9th st. It's a quite place beautifully set with natural light. Good for family, friends or when flying solo. 
Their carrot cake is very moist, I loved finding black sesame seeds. It gave a crunchy addition to the soft cake. The cream cheese icing was nice. Robust in texture but not overly sweet. 
Rye brownies are very rich in flavor, they have cocoa nibs and maldon salt. These are also moist and soft but do hold their shape quiet well. 
Croissants buttery and soft.
name: Levee Baking Co.
categories: Bakeries, Food, Coffee & Tea

text:
The name is no coincidence, Winterfell Dessert is all about the superficial homage to Game of Thrones with flavors that remind you of the critical scenes from the series, but that's about it.

Must get: taipei, king of the north
Meh: kiss me
Missed out: waffles

I love Hong Kong style shaved ice, which is more of an ice cream with finely shaved and creamy texture than the Italian cousins. The only downside is the cost, which a small (while sizable) portion is quite expensive, even with all of the trimmings. I love the green tea flavoring of taipei and thought the grass jelly added that extra texture. As for the king of the north, you can't go wrong with the black sesame, but I think the vanilla cookies could have been exchanged for something less sweet. Unfortunately, 'kiss me' was the most bland and I did not have much love for the original flavor.

Ultimately, this establishment carried a much greater hipster vibe than a Game of Throne vibe, but you can't argue against the quality of the food, which is what matters.

Sadly, this is not a geekout ice shop.

Food: 5 stars
Price: 3 stars
Service: 4 stars
Ambiance: 4 stars
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
I had a huge craving for bubble tea and lo & behold, while Yelp-ing, my friends & I found this place! I love the fact that they have authentic Asian flavors (my go-to is the black sesame) & you have the options of using other milks and altering the sugar level!

Thanks for being a life saver in my boba crisis!
name: Royal Boba
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Coffee & Tea, Desserts

text: When I saw this was opening in Philly I got super excited. I am a huge lover of green tea and taro flavored soft serve ice-cream. I got the cup which was I think was around $6? Kinda of expensive but I shared it with 2 friends. I think getting the cup is the best way to go because it seems like you get more ice cream and it is cheaper than getting it in the cone. I was able to try the green tea swirled with black sesame and it was really good! Super rich, thick, and creamy, my goodness. However, I was kind of unimpressed with their topping choices. I ended up putting Oreo crumbs on it with 2 green tea pocky sticks. I really wanted Mochi but they didn't have any.. I will definitely be back to try their Taro flavor!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
It's not every day you want the experience of an exploding nutsack of flavor in your mouth. Should that day come however, run, don't walk to Zento and order the ice cream mochi. It's two tablespoons of ice cream encased in a ball of sticky rice dough, dusted with an angel's wave of powdered sugar. You'll find green tea, strawberry, vanilla, red bean, and on all the days I'm not there, black sesame, because I really want it and it's Asian Murphy's Law that I'm to be denied.

But you probably didn't come to my review to read about dessert. How's the savory side of the menu? Excellent. I want to give special props to the miso soup, which was extra-tasty and many cuts above the average. From the turf side of town I had the crunchy spicy tuna (very nice) and the yummy Zento Square Sushi (salmon version) with eel, avocado and plum paste. 

Cute, cozy place for a fun evening out with friends -- and solid sushi. Word is they're very consistent, so any night should be fine.
name: Zento Contemporary Japanese Cuisine
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion, Event Planning & Services, Caterers

text:
We all try to eat healthy. But sometimes it's hard to have all the right ingredients on hand AND the motivation to chop a million vegetables before they start to grow mold. That's where CoreLife Eatery comes in, a new whole-food chain that recently made its way to Indianapolis in the Castleton area. They claim to be non-GMO and locally sourced with no high fructose corn syrup or artificial colors and flavors and their branding looks like a bright Chipotle. Similar to other fast-casual restaurants that are worming their way into Millennial's hearts and pockets, the restaurant offers grain, salad, and broth bowls that can be customized into a myriad of healthy offerings.

This might sound a little complicated, but it's basically like building a big salad. You pick an already-decided combination from the hanging board or design your own dish, adding things like tuna poke, black sesame seeds, and chopped almonds on top of quinoa and kale. Most bowls have a suggested dressing, which have been prepared fresh, in-house the same day. The chain also offers creative, hand-crafted beverages, such as beet lemonade or apple cider green tea.

CoreLife Eatery was really clogging my Instagram feed, so I decided to give it a try last Sunday with Husband in tow. It was pouring down rain outside, so we ran into an almost empty restaurant (sharp contrast to the lines out the door from the previous week) to see what all the fuss was about. The verdict? Underwhelming. I tried the Tuna Poke grain bowl with miso sesame ginger dressing and Husband ordered the Thai chicken with rice noodles and Thai cashew dressing. My bowl looked pretty and colorful, but became super soggy with too much dressing and the flavors all muddled together into a bland mess after a few bites. Husband's bowl was pretty bland and he was disappointed with the cold noodles and overwhelming amount of cabbage. Both bowls needed some salt or spice or something. There was also a super weird 1/2 slice of store-bought bread that accompanied my dish as a "side," but no other side options (I need my kettle chips!). I sampled almost all of the fruit beverages and was very let down with the taste and sweetness without finding any favorites.

I like so many ideas from CoreLife Eatery, like the protein-rich bowls, antibiotic-free meats, and pretty affordable entrees (around $10), but there has got to be a way to make them more palatable. Husband ran to Wendy's an hour later. If I went again, I would order something different and definitely ask for dressing on the side. Or maybe I just won't go again.
name: CoreLife Eatery
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Soup, Cafes, Salad, Noodles

text:
Came here last week with my SO because I love ice cream and I love it EVEN MORE when it's shaved and snowy with toppings and color changing spoons! I actually didn't love the shaved ice as much as I do "snowdays" in NY, but it's still really solid. PLUS the staff is really great and I love the space!

If you've ever been to 'Snowdays' the concept is really similar, with the choice of a base shaved ice cream flavor*, toppings for $.50 each*, "dressings" which are free*, and three sizes of cups (Regular $5, Large $6.5, Mountain $8.5). The other option is to get one of their "specials" which are pre-decided mixes*. ($6 regular, $8 large, $10 mountain).

*Ice cream flavors:black sesame, green tea, taro, honeydew, mango, strawberry, lychee 
*Toppings: almonds, pocky sticks, seasonal fruit, grass jelly, mochi, egg pudding, etc.
*"Dressings": condensed milk, strawberry puree, etc.
*Pre-decided mixes:
         -Boyfriend: taro, red bean, fruity pebbles, etc. 
         -Taipei: Matcha, grass jelly, red bean, mochi, condensed milk

I decided on the J.S. (John Snow) but didn't love the idea of vanilla cookies and cream, so the staff (graciously!) let me do a swap out for strawberries. ALSO when we were rung up I realized after paying that I was charged for a regular when I wanted a large, and the cashier was really great about it and gave me the large cup for no additional cost (so with that plus the 25% check in discount it ends up being super cheap). 

Hung around for a bit after eating to watch batman (which they had on the TV) and play chess! 
Definitely worth a visit!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
An instagrammable soft serve shop with flavors that remind me of traditional Asian soft serve places (matcha, black sesame, strawberry, charcoal vanilla, taro). 

A cup is $5 and a cone is $6; it comes with 2 free toppings, with additional toppings 50 cents each. Seems a little pricey, but they do give you a hefty amount of ice cream, so it's definitely shareable. Service is great and the seating, bathroom, etc. are clean. There's also free wifi! Great place to grab dessert.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS PLACE! The food and vibe are spot on for the casual cool place that it is. What really has me singing its praises is the food. It's so absolutely delicious. They were able to make most dishes vegan per my friend's dietary restrictions. I'd say the Mie Goreng is even better without the fish sauce because I tried both versions! We ALL loved the Crispy Brussel Sprouts, the Potato Wedges, the Rice Pilaf, the Crispy Duck Salad, the Crispy Rice Salad, and the Black SesameTres Leches. The Krupuk + Sambal and Signature WIngs were good. The staff was great. I can't wait to come back.
name: Sama Sama Kitchen
categories: Cocktail Bars, Farmers Market, Tapas Bars, Food, Desserts, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Indonesian

text: Ooooof. I went here a while back as soon as they had opened with a friend. She's a foodie and had heard the hype about this place and their Vietnamese Coffee ice cream?? Amazing!! I am biased though as someone who just enjoys any viet coffee flavored thing- although I did also try their matcha green tea and black sesame ice creams (which were also amazing). Can't wait til' they reopen. Worth the hype.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Vibes: bright, casual, fun, nerdy with the funko pop-filled shelves, board games, and GoT shoutouts right from the door, smells like spun sugar

Tasting notes:
-black sesame shaved ice with red beans and condensed milk: fluffy, feathery in texture, light in flavor; the ice becomes like a sticky soft serve when compacted/starts to melt; liked that the red beans were whole and not the paste kind

Other thoughts:
-love that there are DIY and set options for shaved ice in different sizes, a great variety of toppings from nuts to mochi to fruit, egg waffle sundaes, and many flavors of bubble tea (looking at the black sesame milk tea since its harder to find on menus)
-comfy armchairs to lounge and a good handful of tables for dessert dates

Will be back for: more shaved ice and that black sesame milk tea!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
Very good quality ramen, ordered the akamaru ramen and takoyaki, very hot and came out fresh 

The broth on the akamaru was creamy and had a what seems to be black sesame garlic, it's that rich flavor that you like in your soups and keeps you coming back. Charshu was the circular one And they gave plenty of scallions. 

Menu had plenty of other options such as katsu and curry dishes. 

Nothing too much to say on the decor, looks like a restaurant lol

If you're looking for a ramen fix, give this place a try
name: Rai Rai Ramen & Hawaiian BBQ
categories: Ramen, Japanese, Hawaiian, Noodles, Barbeque, Restaurants

text:
Seriously, this is one of, if not the, best pizzas I've had in my life. 

Anello is a small restaurant in Tucson's "warehouse district," an increasingly funky part of town with industrial buildings being replaced by excellent restaurants, bars, and coffee houses The interior is nicely furnished, but can't accommodate a lot of people, so expect to wait. In the back, you'll see an open, wood-fired oven, and you can watch your pizza being made. 

We started with the veggie appetizer--green beans with lemon, garlic, and black sesame seeds. Utterly delicious, and then, the pizzas: about twelve inches, and they are incredible. The crust has that burn that comes only with being cooked in an extremely hot oven, and the toppings are beyond excellent. (I should also add that Anello doesn't have an extensive menu.) One of the reviews below said that you should always order the special of the day pizza, and that's what I did: squash, roasted red onion, ricotta, and salsa verde. Utter bliss. 

So if you find yourself in Tucson, Anello is a restaurant you cannot miss. Although it's easy to, as there's no sign outside.
name: Anello
categories: Pizza, Restaurants

text:
Hmmm I was expecting more.
2.5 stars maybe?
They service was friendly and they let you try any and all flavors.
The taro was surprisingly my favorite. Mild in flavor.
The black sesame was okay, but a bit of a strange, almost artificial aftertaste. 
Pumpkin spice also had a fakeness to it.
Strawberry was decent and also mild in flavor.
Overall, The soft serve is smooth and sweet. I was pretty underwhelmed though from all the hype I heard. Not dying to go back.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
This was the first time I've been to Rook since they moved down the street, and wow!  What a cool new space.  I stepped out of Fletcher Place and into a majorly metropolitan city.  It's amazing that we can have this restaurant in Indianapolis.

Anyway, the food!  I had the Okonomiyaki Burger (this is straight from their menu:  Black sesame seed / sauerkraut / velveeta / special sauce / charred scallion mayo / pickles / brussels sprouts).  Sounds crazy, right?  Turns out everything worked amazingly well together to make an excellent burger.  I got to sit at the kitchen and watch it happen, too.  It was a bit costly for daily goings ($16 for my burger, no side), but Rook is definitely on my list of nice night out spots.  Good move, Rook!
name: Rook
categories: Chinese, Japanese, Filipino, Pan Asian, Thai, Asian Fusion, Restaurants

text:
Awhile back, Living Social had a deal offering a 7-course tasting for 2 for $70 at Sushi Zento. The normal retail for this tasting menu was $140 - so that's a 50% savings. So when I noticed the deal was about to expire, I decided to finally get off my butt and cash it in! 

So I made reservations for a Saturday evening. I called the day of the dinner as I needed to move back dinner by an hour, and it was a good thing I did. For some reason, they did not have my initial reservation down. Perhaps that was why I never received a confirmation call, despite making my reservation 3 weeks in advance. Regardless, they were able to provide a table for me that night.

Sushi Zento offers the talents of Chef Sam Ho, former sous chef at Morimoto, of Iron Chef fame. Having tried Iron Chef Morimoto's cuisine at his NYC outpost, I was excited to try Chef Ho's cuisine.

Unfortunately at Sushi Zento, there is no sushi bar (just a normal bar). Still, I was informed that omakase (traditional japanese tasting consisting primarily of sashimi/sushi/nigiri) was available. Still, one of the perks of omakase is being able to watch the sushi chef expertly prepare the nigiri right in front of you.

The decor at Sushi Zento is intimate. I loved the exposed brick and the wax coming from candle-lit openings on the walls. Still, the seating was reminiscent of Barbuzzo - in other words, really close quarters.
 
Tasting Menu ($70 pp)

Pumpkin Spice ($10)

Hiram Walker pumpkin liqueur, Hanger One spiced pear vodka, Cointreau orange liqueur, simple syrup agnostura bitters, garnished with fresh ground cinnamon 

While the Living Social deal offered free non-alcoholic drinks, we decided to opt for a few cocktails. The GF went with the pumpkin spice, which was light, subtly sweet, and frothy. 

Johnny Sokko ($10)

Muddled ginger, Bacardi rum, Coca cola, garnished with fresh ginger root and lime wheel  

Mine was sweet as well, with some definite bite from the rum. However, I didn't notice any fresh ginger root garnish and the carbonation from the Coke was slight.

Miso Soup with Mussels

We both started off with miso soup with mussels. There was balanced salinity in a typically overly salty soup. The scallions were a nice touch and the sweet, plump mussels were perfectly clean and juicy.

Crispy Calamari Salad

I could smell the crisply fried calamari before I ate anything - and that was a good thing. The calamari was light and was a nice highlight to the perfectly dressed greens, which had a prototypical ginger-sesame dressing. 

Homemade Crab Cakes

The crab cakes were crisply fried in panko - perfect pucks of meaty crab. There was a slight amount of sweet, garlic tartar sauce on each disc and some greens to break up any monotony.

Whitefish Carpaccio 

The whitefish was thinly pounded out - light and toothsome. The accompanying sauce was smoky and bright, rounding out the dish nicely.

Chicken Teriyaki 

The chicken breast was juicy and was seasoned lightly. The teriyaki sauce was saccharine and pretty standard. Frankly though, the spinach was my favorite part of the dish, especially as I'm usually not looking to get the teriyaki dish at a sushi restaurant.

Sushi/Nigiri Platter

We received white tuna (escolar) sushi with avocado. This had a slight mayo dressing, which was creamy. Topped with black sesame, this was pretty good. Next, we had amberjack (yellowtail), which had a nice delicate snap. The salmon was prototypically fatty and delicious. The super white tuna (fatty escolar) was smoky. Maguro (tuna) was fishy to me however, and was quite disappointing. A pet peeve of mine is when the wasabi is served on the side with nigiri and that was the case here. Additionally, the rice was substandard for sushi - cold and I could barely sense any vinegar.

Tofu Cheesecake

Our first of our dessert duo was the tofu cheese cake, with lychee in the middle. This had a creamy panna cotta-like texture and was subtly sweet. 

Mochi with Green Tea Ice Cream

This was the GF's first time trying mochi and she wasn't the biggest fan, mainly due to the texture. However, being used to mochi, it was perfectly dense and smooth. The green tea ice cream within was a nice palate cleanser for the meal.

Overall, I can't see the tasting at Sushi Zento being worth $70 per person. Heck, the tasting at Jose Garce's restaurants consist of more overall dishes, higher quality, and better creativity. However, thanks to Living Social, the price point justified this initial meal. Still, I was expecting a bit more though I may have been misled by the guise of Chef Ho's experience at Morimoto. While Morimoto isn't a pure sushi/sashimi/nigiri experience, the quality of the fish is still quite high. And the cuisine offered (do try the Duck, Duck Duck at Morimoto) is simply superior. I can see the uninitiated being enthralled by Sushi Zento, but I would come here for a stiff drink and a specialty roll. Not for the omakase at the bar for sure.
name: Zento Contemporary Japanese Cuisine
categories: Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion, Event Planning & Services, Caterers

text:
I've tried something almost identical to this place in California, called Fluff Ice. So I'm very much familiar with the texture of this shave ice and the toppings. 

The shave ice is definitely very fluffy and it has a nice smooth texture to it. If you have never had something similar to this, give it a try. This doesnt really have a wow factor because I've had something like this before. But judging from the taste and flavors that they offer, this place is pretty good. I got the mango and black sesame flavor with rainbow jelly, oreos, and condense milk for my topping. Sesame flavor was much sweeter than I had liked but the mango flavor was awesome. 
Perfect for a nice hot day.  

Workers were really nice as well!
name: Winterfell Dessert
categories: Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Desserts, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Taiwanese

text:
We've dined in many times before at Kona Jack's, but this was our first carry-out experience and it was a great one!
Hubby chose the New England clam chowder and Ahi black sesame-crusted tuna entrée (served with a spicy peanut sauce) with baked potato. I went for the Swordfish entrée, blackened, which comes with a side of their spicy Diavola mixture (marinated tomatoes, garlic, basil and chopped red onions) and a house salad. We were also given complimentary bread and butter.
Everything was so fresh and delicious & was packaged really well as each item was individually wrapped in clear wrap over the usual packaging. Also, the portion sizes are fairly generous so you'll likely enjoy leftovers for another nice meal!
name: Kona Jacks Fish Market & Sushi Bar
categories: Specialty Food, Sushi Bars, Food, Asian Fusion, Seafood Markets, Seafood, Restaurants

text:
Saba is a true gem. We randomly stumbled upon it while planning our weekend NOLA getaway and it was our favorite meal. If you are a huge Mediterranean/ middle eastern fan - you will fall in love with Saba as much as we did.

First off, the restaurant is located in the Audubon / west riverside area of Magazine street. The Street is super cute with walkable stores, restaurants, and coffee shops - if you have a reservation at Saba, give yourself some time to explore the area!

As for the food- the menu starts with little dips or "Salatim" the dips are 3 for $25 or 5 for $35 or you can buy them single. They all come with fresh wood oven made pita. This pita will change your life and will be the best pita you have ever had in your life time. We opted for the seasonal corn/crab hummus and the tabouleh : amazing. Everything is made from scratch , the hummus was smooth, lemony with hints of sweet corn and crab. The tabouleh was made of fresh herbs, avo, hints of cinnamon and crunchy pieces of pecan. Superb.

Our meals we got the lamb kabob and the grouper kabob over gray tahini. Everything was excellent but my personal fav was the lamb. Grilled to perfection and wonderful flavors.

For dessert we had the black sesame semifreddo - we love anything black sesame and this was a perfect and light nutty ending to our great meal.

We will definitely be back! We had the most delicious and memorable meal here. Highly highly recommend
name: Saba
categories: Mediterranean, Restaurants, Middle Eastern

text: I went to Royal Izakaya for a friend's birthday on Friday and I liked it so much that I suggested it as a date night spot for Saturday. The atmosphere was incredible on both occasions. I especially loved the Tuna Guac, the sashimi, and the pork buns. Save room for dessert! The black sesame panna cotta was phenomenal. It had the most unique flavors with fresh mango. I am in love with this restaurant (and my date).
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
Love Kuriimii! Perfect soft serve that really hits the spot. My favorite flavors are black sesame, matcha, taro, and lychee. 

I love that they added smaller sizes for cheaper ($3.50) so you don't have to commit to the larger sizes. You can also get two free toppings (love the pocky sticks and fruity pebbles)

Definitely check out kuriimii if you wanna enjoy some awesome ice cream!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: This jawn just opened and they offer a variety of soft serve jawns. I tried the black sesame jawn, matcha jawn, and the avocado jawn. They also offer different flavored cones like chocolate or vanilla, and if you don't like cones, they got a cup to serve the jawns in em. All them jawns were poppin and I can't wait to try the other jawns! Perfect dessert after having dinner in Chinatown.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
An excellent addition to the area for your dessert needs. If you're craving a soft serve, this is the place! I met one of the owners Union who runs a very professional spot with his partners. Let's dive into it:

Place - love the clean looking decor, very modern. Once you walk in you'll find only a handful of seats. You'll see that they have a huge chalkboard menu to see what they have to offer, which means to me that they can easily change up the flavors which is a great thing. Place seemed well kept and clean.

Service - people working behind the counter look young AF!!! But they listen and try their best, so I can't say anything bad about that. Keep hiring the pretty ladies ! 

Soft serve ice cream:

Black sesame - it was good but a little under sesame'd. 
Honeydew - sweet! Reminds me of a melona bar. 
Viet coffee - bits of coffee bits ? Little bit of a gritty feel. 
Taro - the winner. Not too sweet & not bland. Get this. 

Fix the above issues I mentioned and you'll be straight. 

They are new but I had an excellent experience here with the Taro flavor, service and was comfy at location. Good luck and keep up the great work !
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
The ambiance and vibe stood out the most and I will come back again just for that. The decor, music, and theme was so unique and fun. My friends and I came here for happy hour and had a pretty good experience. I ordered the spiked agua Fresca, which was very refreshing and light. We all shared the fried wonton chips which were addicting. The three salsas all tasted great and it was a fun app. Nothing mind blowing but it was a unique twist to the traditional tortilla chips and salsa. I ordered the shrimp and black bean tostada, which all my friends agreed was the best thing on the table. Filling, fresh and delicious. The beer battered fish taco was good, but very fried. The mushroom taco was also good, but extremely greasy and left massive residue of straight grease. Get the black sesame flan! Not too sweet and very addicting! 

Two things I didn't love. No food on the happy hour menu. The waitress told us the happy hour special, which were wings for $14. Sounded more like special of the day because that does not sound like happy hour prices. At least lower the price for the wonton chips during happy hour. Only other thing was this restaurant was supposed to be Mexican/Chinese inspired. Not much Asian influences. Not sure how any of the tacos had Asian influences. I thought the flavors would be more of a fusion, but it's more of a fusion of concepts.

Again, the music and vibes were everything. I would come back here again!
name: La Chinesca
categories: Nightlife, Bars, Chinese, New Mexican Cuisine, Restaurants

text:
I know I've already reviewed The Lark a couple times, but every meal I've had here has been noteworthy, including the most recent, four years after our last dinner--four years that encompassed a global pandemic and the birth of our child, both events that have only made me love a good restaurant even more. The Lark may be the best in town. It's certainly my go-to recommendation whenever friends visit Santa Barbara. 

We'd been wanting to go back ever since we got vaccinated in April, but predictably, it's almost always booked up during reasonable hours. Our dinner, at 8:45 on a Monday night last month, was a special treat, and we enjoyed every minute.

We ate indoors, and the space and service and atmosphere were as we remembered, all very pleasant and exemplary. The Lark's bar is as much of a draw as the food, and I loved both of the cocktails I ordered. The Yankee Point was a lovely daiquiri, made with Wray & Nephew, Denizen white rum, lime, strawberry, and sumac. The Summerland was a beautiful, balanced sour, with Old Overholt bonded rye, Amaro Averna, summer peach, lavender, and lemon.

The food was delicious. We started with oysters on the half shell and the bigeye tuna crudo, both outstanding. The oysters came with watermelon granita, finger lime, and basil, and the tuna in a cool, spicy fermented Fresno chile broth with black sesame, stone fruit, and Thai basil. The next thing to hit the table was a board of Mary's free range duck liver mousse, served with saffron apricots, spicy Iranian pickles, and olive oil crostini. This was a lavish portion of rich, flavorful duck liver mousse with a colorful variety of pickles, which is always what I want with my charcuterie. Grilled Caledonian prawns were meaty and succulent, prepared with black lime, tahini yogurt, cilantro zhoug, compressed cucumber, and mint. Don't sleep on those juicy heads. The centerpiece of our dinner was the grilled prime hanger steak. The steak was perfectly cooked, a rare silky red through the middle, sliced and served over a platter of blistered shishito peppers, smoked beef tallow emulsion, sungold tomato, and crispy Thai basil. We had some vegetables left over (since Matt doesn't eat many vegetables), and I had them with salmon later in the week and they made that easy at-home dinner feel positively luxurious. For dessert, we shared an olive oil cake with jam, peaches, nougat, and ice cream. The least memorable part of our meal but still great.

We had a stellar time at The Lark and can't wait to come back, hopefully before four more years have passed. It's never disappointed us, and I don't expect that it ever will.
name: The Lark
categories: Nightlife, Bars, Cocktail Bars, Food, American (New), Desserts, Restaurants

text:
I am going to be honest, I have an obsession with boba drinks. Back home near Chicago, access to boba was a lot easier than out here and I am not going to lie, my expectations were low when I searched for something decent in Nashville. Luckily I am proven wrong when it comes to Royal Boba! I thoroughly enjoyed all the drinks I've had here the classic, black sesame, winter melon and hk style. My go tos seem to be the classic and hk style. I also appreciate that they allow customization of the drinks including your choice of milk, sweetness levels and toppings! 

I have to say I got really lucky as I live about 10 min away. Glad to know Royal boba is around to feed my unhealthy drink addiction !
name: Royal Boba
categories: Food, Tea Rooms, Shaved Ice, Bubble Tea, Coffee & Tea, Desserts

text:
I mean, how freakin' great is this place? I've been wanting to get to Royal for some time and it was legit so good we came back twice in one week. I kid you not. Walked in around 6:30pm on a Tuesday and was seated right away (4 people) and again around 6:45pm on a Saturday (2 people) and were able to snag bar seats. There is seating available both inside and outside, though I prefer the inside because the atmosphere is so welcoming. It's dark, it's mysterious, and it's a great intimate setting for a dinner with friends, family, whomever! Our server Billy was so knowledgeable and helped us with recommendations on our first trip in. The cocktails were delicious (I LOVED the Cherry Blossom) and there were tons of sake options to choose from (though I had no idea how to even begin with sake so didn't go there). 

Ok, so good. Some stars of the show included: grilled avocado, spinach gomaae, tuna guac, sashimi combo, corn special, duck buns, friend fish buns,  hanger steak, chirashi bowl, and wagyu roll. There was nothing we tried that we didn't like, but these were our faves! The hanger steak was so tender and paired amazingly with the black sesame sauce. The sashimi and fish in general was so fresh and so delicious. The service was incredible and the atmosphere great too. 10/10! Can't wait to make Royal a staple in our diet!
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
I've been here at least a dozen times since it opened last year because I love it that much. This is the place to go for soft serve ice cream. I've tried the matcha, black sesame, taro, and some of my favorite rotating flavors were watermelon and honeydew. Honeydew was the best flavor of all time and I'm crushed that it's gone. I sampled charcoal vanilla out of curiosity once and it tastes just like vanilla, nothing special, but seems like people get it for the novelty. I saw a girl eating charcoal vanilla once and all her teeth were stained black and it was quite the sight to see. 

The staff is friendly and you can sample all the flavors you want before making your final choice. I usually get a cup with 2 flavors side by side (I don't like when the flavors mix together in the swirl), almost always with taro. I find the matcha to be a little bitter and the black sesame a bit grainy. Then you get 2 free toppings of your choice- I like the Oreo dust and green tea kit kats, or the mochi for an extra $1. The cost is only $5 for a sizeable portion that can be shared between 2 people. My boyfriend and I always leave this place feeling satisfied. We take all our visiting friends and family here for a treat.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: The hubby and I had a date night here and we absolutely loved the entire experience. Crab skillet and pork bun appetizers were to die for. Particularly the pork buns. They were succulent and full of flavor.. star of the show for sure. My husband had the scallops entree and I had the squid ink lobster spaghetti. These dishes were both original and tasted incredible. We ended the meal with a deconstructed peach cobbler cake thing. I don't have a name for it because it was not on the menu... there was a special guest friend of the restaurant sitting at the table over and they got it and the our server was able to get it for us as well. It was the perfect combination of cheese cake, with peach, and black sesame seeds drizzled with a delicious fruit compote.  Meal was paired with white wine and dirty martinis all night. Highly recommended for a special occasion or date night. We can't wait to be back!
name: Lulou's Restaurant
categories: Restaurants, American (New), American (Traditional)

text:
At least the price is a *little more reasonable.  Yes, $5 is a lot for soft-serve, but you can't beat the creamy consistency which is thick enough to not become a melted bowl of soupy mess. The flavors are also unique and delicious without being overbearing. Our favorite is the black sesame and matcha swirl - give it a try!  Nothing quite like it at the usual froyo places...

Enjoy!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
I have been drooling over Royal Sushi and Izakaya's Instagram posts for a while. I would see the Japanese-imported fish, the live softshell crabs, the tuna etc etc and I have been planning to visit for a while. Only thing holding me back was that you cant put a reservation, you simply have to show up and see what's available.

This restaurant did not disappoint. The place was full and vibrant on a Saturday night and we only had to wait for 15mins before we were seated. Concerning drinks, I decided not to go with their Sake, and I went for their Japanese-influenced cocktails instead. My Okinawan rum cocktail was very-well balanced and very tasty.

We then proceed to try an assortment of different dishes and flavors. Our  hot pickles showed up first and they were crunchy and tasty, the slow braised pork belly came up next, and the bun was fluffy and the pork belly tender and complex. The kewpie mayo made a difference here, adding playful notes to the palate. The Japanese eggplant was another plate we loved

Of great interest was the hanger steak that I have actually read about in one of the Philly Inquirer's articles on some of the best steaks in Philadelphia. The steak is marinated for hours before served and you can taste this japanese-inspired flavor profile.

Our menu then proceed with the sushi part of the menu: Two rolls of sushi and the Chirashi bowl. The shrimp tempura roll had one of the best tempuras I have ever tried, and the soft-shell crab was very interesting as well.

The Chirashi bowl was so fresh you could smell the sea in every bite. An assortment of fatty tuna and lean tuna, king salmon, japanese mackerel, California uni and salmon roe, the Chirasi has an amazing value considering how tasty and fresh the fish is.

We concluded our meal with the black sesame panna cotta  with the black sesame adding a compelling saltiness and complexity to this dish.

I would surely go again and again to try other elements of their menu.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
This restaurant is category at average. It is close to 3.5 stars but not yet there. The restaurant is very close to MD oriental market. It is walking distance to next door. If they lack of any ingredients, very much can get it at oriental market. 

I got the two rolls special. Tuna and fried white fish roll. The roll is not spectacular. Very basic. It does come with a choice of soup and salad. My wife has the Pork ramen. It has good charsiew Pork. It also included the fish cake. The soup base is a bit light. Most of the ramen has good bone base. This soup may need some thing like black sesame oil to enhance the flavor. 

The only thing I like is the Kama. Kama is the grilled yellowtail collar. I like it. It is not best best I have for Kama. But good enough. The service is easy since not many customers.
name: Tokai Japanese Restaurant
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: I like this place. The food are pretty good based on the American standard. We ordered the hot chicken bao, sprouts, and egg noodles. They are a little bit sweet, but in a good way. Egg noodle is pretty Asian. The bao is more delicious than I expected. The black sesame cake is very very delicious. Not so sweet and very soft. There is no parking there.
name: Sama Sama Kitchen
categories: Cocktail Bars, Farmers Market, Tapas Bars, Food, Desserts, Nightlife, Asian Fusion, Restaurants, Tapas/Small Plates, Bars, Indonesian

text:
The best matcha froyo in Philly! You can see the matcha powder in the froyo, so you know they ain't playing around. There are variety of ways to make your froyo unique, and they have peppero/pocky sticks available. Fun games inside and it's a nice hangout space with friends. All the servers are super nice! 

Highly recommend getting matcha with almond flakes.

If you get the mochi, it's $0.50 for like 5(?) pieces. I believe it was minimalistic mochi serve for artistic purposes. I can't wait to go back and try taro, black sesame, and black vanilla. You can make the flavors half-half, too!
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Today we went to Royal to celebrate my sister's 40th bday and the menu was refined a bit. Still amazing sushi and the side dishes are worth writing home to mom. 

Our most favorite appetizers are fried oysters, hotdog, and spinach in black sesame sauce 

Most favorite roll was Aka Maka roll and soft shell crab. The rest of the rolls had too much rice on them. It was okay but not normal for Royal in my previous experience. 

Best mixed cocktail of the night is the frozen Japanese mule 

5 out of 5 every time we've been here. Since covid thue closed their omakase service and only does the front room dining. However, the waitress told us that they're remodeling back there and will be opening up after July. We cannot wait to be back for omakase.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
I was so impressed and happy with my experience at Royal Sushi & Izakaya!!
The staff were extremely welcoming, so friendly and very open to answer all of our questions.
We went as group of four on a weekday and had to wait a bit for a table, but that's expected for such a great restaurant.
Appetizers- we had the Oboro Tofu, Roasted Beets, Tombo Ahi Ponzo and Eli Fry.
*Oboro Tofu, this was a unique, but pleasant dish. The dashi broth and buckwheat flakes add a nuttiness to the soft tofu and pairs well.
*Roasted Beets, a savory and delightful appetizer that acts as a nice palate cleansers
*Tombo Ahi Ponzo, this was so fresh and refreshing! I loved the sweetness of the fish with the tart citrus ponzo. 
*Ebi Fry, a classic!
Entrees- The Chirashi and Fried Fish Heads.
*The Chirashi was so fresh and a classic I always love ordering!
*Fried Fish Heads, I've grown up eating fish heads and I loved the chef's preparation of something that is so nostalgic for me. 
Desserts- Japanese fluffy cheesecake, Black Sesame Budino, and warmed spice cake. 
*Fluffy Japanese Cheesecake- light and refreshing! Not too heavy and pairs well with the fresh cream.
*Black Sesame Budino, I love black sesame and was so excited for this dessert! It was by far, my favorite and we all fought for the last bite.
*Warmed Spice cake, this wasn't my favorite dessert, but I enjoyed the warm and bold flavors of the cake. It was perfect on a cold night.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
Anytime a new place opens in Tucson I get excited. I love my (ok, our) city, and I love to see it thriving and gaining so much attention for our amazing food culture. That being said, Anello is such a perfect fit into what is becoming an excellent corner of downtown. As of Saturday evening, there was still not a sign on the outside, and the gorgeous wooden front door is your only symbol of entry. As we ate, I saw a few people through the front window who were walking around the block searching and they would stop and realize they had arrived, turn around and come in with a relieved look on their face to find that around 5:30 pm the restaurant had not filled (yet). 

We arrived just after Anello opened at 5 pm to find the restaurant was not full yet (I somewhat expected it to be, as it's Saturday and they are still new). We had our choice of seats and took the table closest to the door. The space is quite minimal, with simple, yet well-constructed wood tables that are bare wood, unpainted/unstained. The front door and ceiling are gorgeously simple flourishes. The lighting is wonderful- bright enough to see clearly and yet not harsh by any means. The entire aesthetic is a quiet modern and the design statement clearly wants you to think about the flavor of your food without imposing any personal belief upon you. 
We were happy to be left with only the responsibility of tasting our food.
We began with the simple roasted/grilled seasonal vegetable. A whole zucchini split down the middle, served piping hot and drizzled with olive oil, lemon juice, and seasoned with salt and pepper. Sprinkled all over the zucchini were pistachios. The whole dish was so flavorful, and there was nothing overdone, no pretentiousness. Just a real plate of food we shared over a good conversation with glasses of wine. 

Oh and let's take half a step backward and talk about the menu, shall we? Concise and poignant, with real ingredients. No fuss. 

For our second appetizer we ordered the wood-fired foccacia with house-made cheese. This was so good, my husband commented on how fast I ate my half. This is funny because I am the pokiest, slowest eater you will ever meet. There was plenty of cheese on the side for us both to get our fill without feeling like we needed to be careful to share and to have enough for our bread. I felt like that was worth noting. Our pizza came out, perfectly timed about 2-3 minutes after we had finished our appetizer and had a moment to savor what we had just eaten. I really felt like it was due to the fact that the chef could see where we were at in our meal with the kitchen being open and at the head of the space. Its kind of a big deal when a restaurant capacity is small enough that you can give your customers this kind of service, and it was noticed by us throughout our entire experience here. 

We ordered the Bianca and added Italian sausage. The Bianca at Anello has chiltepin on it, which is a small red chile native to the Southwest (it grows wild in Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Texas). We both felt so happy with our pizza. The chiltepin gave some good flavor and a satisfying warmth to our pizza without being overwhelming. (I would encourage people who typically don't like spicy foods to give this a try. I feel you would be pleasantly surprised at the flavor of this!) The rest of the pizza was perfectly flavored and seasoned. The crust is deliciously pillowy and perfectly wood-fired with a wonderful amount of crunch. Overall, we were in food heaven throughout the entire meal. For dessert we ordered the black sesame with anise gelato and the flourless almond cake, both of which were so good we want to eat them again and again. 

Lastly, the service here was spot-on, 10/10 fantastic. Our server knew which red wine to recommend and indulged us by geeking out with us a bit about how good the food was. We would have come back just to have this level of service, even if the food was just pretty good. But lucky for Tucson the food and the service are EXCELLENT.

Welcome to Tucson, Anello. May you have a long, happy run here.
name: Anello
categories: Pizza, Restaurants

text:
This ice cream shop offers all your favorite trendy Asian flavors in soft serve form. If you're been to soft swerve in NYC, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Flavors include matcha, black sesame, taro, Vietnamese coffee, charcoal vanilla and probably more seasonal flavors to come. 

The biggest draw about this place is definitely the insta-worthy soft serves, especially as they are served with a charcoal cone and come with unlimited toppings like fruity pebbles, picky, kit kats, and oreo dust. Of course, this type of trendiness isn't cheap. Cups are $6 and cones are $7, but this is pretty comparable to the multitudes of rolled ice cream shops in Chinatown. 

Overall, this is a promising ice cream shop and I'd definitely come again, especially as they accept credit/debit as well with no minimum.
name: Kuriimii
categories: Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Understated exterior with a red paper lantern and the interior is a dive bar with a sushi counter in the back.  

COLD APPETIZERS: (in order of yum)
#1 TUNA GUACAMOLE $8
*delicious, you should order two because it's small and you'll want an entire one for yourself
#2 ANKIMO SUNOMONO (MONKFISH LIVER) $14
*monkfish liver is similar to foie gras, rich and creamy

HOT APPETIZERS:  (in order of yum)
#1 HAMACHI KAMA (YELLOWTAIL COLLAR) $18
* nice crispy skin, melts in your mouth yellowtail, mild flavor and would definitely get this again
#2 WAGYU SKIRT STEAK YAKITORI $3
* great deep smokey flavor
#3 MISO BLACK COD $15
*really small portion, total of 4 bites, we didn't love it

SUSHI ROLLS: (in order of yum)
#1 GUAC ROLL $19
*amazing combination
#2 BLOC PARTY ROLL $19
*this was good but the guac roll was so much better

SAKE: (in order of yum)
#1 SHO CHIKU BAI HOT SAKE $12
*this is the only hot sake they offer
#2 CARAFE - HAKUTSURU SAYURI $26
*tasty

DESSERT
MOCHI - 3 pieces - $8
*Black sesame was life changing - definitely order it!

SERVICE:
Jillian was meh.  The menu is pretty extensive but we tried ordering several items and the response was "oh we're out of that, oh we're out of that too, oh that's a seasonal item..."  MAAAAAAYBE MENTION THOSE ITEMS BEFORE WE LOOK AT THE MENU!!!!  ARGHHHHH and she disappeared for extended periods of time as well.

Also although we didn't do the Omakase I thought we would be able to order some nigiri but we were limited to maki rolls and some sashimi so that was very disappointing.  I had this place bookmarked for over a year so overall the food was good definitely not amazing and the service was bad.
name: Royal Sushi & Izakaya
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Dive Bars, Izakaya, Bars, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Pubs

text:
I loved the taro ice cream! Hubby got the cookies and cream flavor I think. I did not get a chance to taste his because I was thoroughly enjoying the taro ice cream. If you like taro you will definitely like this ice cream. 

Pros: unlimited toppings if you get a bubble waffle or coconut bowl. Generous portion size, great mochi, pocky included too 
Cons: hard to eat in the container because I was afraid the toppings would fall off. The bubble waffle was not as crisp as I thought it would be. I guess u can't expect crispy due to the ice cream when I have had it before the Hong Kong bubble waffle was crispy but this was a totally different location. It's more like a regular waffle with the ice cream. 
Seating: limited. There was only a bench, some bar seating and then one more picnic bench table set up. 

Overall I would recommend this place to try out their many flavors. They even had a sesame flavor that I did not get to try. It seems to be the flavors rotate, so I'm definitely waiting for black sesame!
name: Arctic Scoop
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Desserts

text:
Ice cream as dark as my soul? Check!

Came here on a Friday night date night for a some sweet indulgence. The shop is cute and right in the middle of all the East Passyunk hustle. It's not too hard to find and the crowd that gathers around definitely serves as a pseudo street marker on spotting it!

Inside it's brightly lit with the days ice cream options displayed towards the left and the register to pay meets you as you keep walking forward. The menu has some great, and unheard of to me, options. This really tickled my curiosity. 

We chose to go with the black sesame flavor in a black vanilla cone with the dark chocolate chips - all black errrthannnggg. The other flavor we grabbed was pandan (a fruity tea leaf flavor) in the same type cone. 

Both options were so good! The flavors were truly infused throughout the frozen treats. Definitely something new and delicious! 

The workers were great in explaining the different flavors and answering our questions. Unfortunately, due to COVID, they were not offering tastings of the flavors. This definitely had us a little uneasy since these flavors were so new to us, we were unsure if we will enjoy. Thankfully we were pleasantly surprised!

The menu offers other options - including fresh waffles, smoothies, and boats - so lots of confectionary goodness to check out! 

Overall - great experience and looking forward to going back and exploring more of the menu.
name: Arctic Scoop
categories: Juice Bars & Smoothies, Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Food, Desserts

text: I have tried Iceland, Teassert, and Sweet Charlie's rolled ice cream and it all somewhat tastes the same to me. I am a sucker for black sesame so I had to get the Black Sesame ice cream here. It was very creamy and has a subtle nutty taste . The condensed milk made it sweeter, but other than that it was perfect for my taste. I also opted for red bean instead of grass jelly. By the way I love the owner David, he's awesome!
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: First time trying this place and I gotta say, not impress. Got the black sesame flavor and it's not that flavorful. I will give credit that they have unique flavors compare to other roll ice cream shops. The downside is the amount they give you. Toppings are fine but it's the little amount of ice cream that make me want to go somewhere else.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
A warm, romantic environment for all the trendy hipsters to try an all vegetarian haute cuisine.    

The tomato gazpacho was good, but it had a fairly stronger tomato base than I would want. Smells like vomit, but that's usually how those things turn out anyways.  

For the fancy radishes, the smoked tofu had a bold smoke, with a spicy aftertaste. I'm glad they used extra firm tofu. The smell of roasted black sesame was divine. 

The radish with the Shishito pepper was a different take with the sesame. Instead of black and smoked, it was green with that distinct pepper flavor. The purple radish on top of pickled cucumbers were not what I expected. Instead of bright, vinegar notes, it felt more like cucumber noodles with radish meatballs. The cucumber take this refreshing taste, while the sesame seeds gave it body. There was this umami taste that was there that I liked.The Yusuf avocado was such a good match! The tutu brought a floral tartness that was light handed, while it sat upon the elephant of mass that was the low toned body of the avocado. I wish I had thought of it myself! 

The leek tart was a little more conservative than I thought, but it was still
a decent dish. I liked the black garlic jam that came with it. I wish there was more of it. They don't put much on the plate. This definitely was more a starch dish than anything. 

The smoked carrot is worth the price of admission. If you close your eyes, it taste and feels like a bratwurst! It makes sense with the shape and infused smoke in the carrot. The carrot kraut and carrot mustard were a great addition to the carrot theme. They didn't distract from the carrot itself, yet still added for the familiar dimensions to exist. The pumpernickel slice with mashed chickpeas didn't sit that well with my stomach as I was getting full. It provided an alternative taste of a Rueben. 

The strawberry sorrel bread pudding with saffron ice cream was a trip. What looked like some type of spinach quiche surrounded in a tomato basil soup, turned out to be a dessert. I'll have to admit, it took a couple of bites to fully appreciate it. Don't scarf this one down. After a while, it turns into a lemon shortcake, along with the strawberries and saffron poking out.  

At the end of the day, this was a great place that doesn't destroy the wallet, offers an elegant atmosphere, but feels like eating at home. This wouldn't be the first place I recommend someone from out of town, but it's a great spot for locals.
name: Vedge
categories: Restaurants, Vegetarian, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Vegan, Food

text:
I really like Cafe Roze. The decor, interior space, and food & drinks are all so great. The food, especially. This review is just for the breakfast/brunch menu.

Food - I have never gone wrong with the egg bowl, burger & fries (i love their fries), savory oats, stout waffles, and country ham toast (this sandwich is HUGE and better than any other ham toast I've ever had). Everything is so flavorful, especially the savory bowls. I wish I could make these dishes at home, but I would never get the flavors to be as good, so I will never regret ordering these dishes here. Avocado shake is alright, not a big cup, but if you're craving and willing to pay, sure. I'm also excited to come back and try other sandwiches and the roze bowl too.

Drink - their drink menu is really extensive and I've only had the golden turmeric and black sesame steamers - both lovely. The right milky-ness and not sweet at all. Roze latte is pretty good. Made pretty with the rose petals on top of the drink.

Service - If you don't want to experience slow(er) and less attentive service, I'd recommend coming at off hours. I had one not so great experience, but made up by with a dish on the house. But - I'm also a very patient person, so the mishap didn't bother me that much.
name: Cafe Roze
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars

text:
Are there any Japanese sushi fanatic out there? One of the best sushi house in Edmonton can be found on Calgary Trail. It is the Nomiya Restaurant. This quaint little restaurant is nicely tucked between Yogurty's and Wild Wing. Parking is widely available but their restaurant has limited seating. If you have not been to it, it's high time you tasted some quality stuff. This isn't your daily Eat-All-You-Can restaurant because literally everything on this restaurant's menu speaks volume and taste. It has a mid-range pricing. Not too pricey that it hurts your wallet/purse. So, before you take a peek at their menu, please do yourself a favour. Wear a bib! You know you'll be drooling in no time with their many many impeccable offerings.

They offer quite a good variety of items such as ramen, donburi, appetisers, noodles, sashimi, sushi, salads, bento box and some pretty dessert to finish off the palate. The last time I was there, I had the Century Egg Maki for $15.50 which contains hamachi, salmon belly, and avocado with century egg sauce, tobiko, and green onion. Every bite was heavenly. What can I say? I even dream of it in my sleep and needless to say - that sweet tasty dream made me drool all night long. YUM! YUM! YUM! I also had the pleasure of trying the TAN TAN - Ramen flavoured with homemade peanut paste and spicy sesame, ground pork, peanuts, green onions, and nori. The ramen are served in a huge massive bowls. Enough to fill you up to the brim. For only $12? That is plenty of bang for the buck.

To finish off the palate, I joyfully picked the black sesame Mochi ice cream. This is actually made of pounded sticky rice with an ice cream filling that YOU do not ever want to miss. The texture just went perfectly well. They do have other flavours such as chocolate but I highly recommend going for the black sesame ice cream - only because the flavour works. 

The inner décor of this restaurant is clean and simple. Sticking true to the Japanese style with a nice little bar area facing the sushi prep area. I find this to be quite entertaining actually especially when for the super independent diners or a group of diners. There is always a comfortable cosy spot for diners from different walks of life.  

Nomiya Restaurant has definitely won a place in my top places for sushi in Edmonton. I give it a blazing 5 star for being so consistent with their service and the quality of the food. Needless to say, I will be back for more. What else are you waiting for? Now, go hungry and fill that belly up with some goodness of Nomiya. Your body and soul will be very pleased.
name: Nomiya
categories: Ramen, Noodles, Japanese, Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Tapas Bars

text: This place is great! I got the black sesame with Oreo mixed in with berries and whip cream toppings. It's my second time here and the staff is so nice and the ice cream is made pretty fast. It's so cool watching the ice cream be made. The texture is a little different from normal ice cream. To me it's a little chewy (not bad). The portions are huge but its so good you could finish it easily.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Had the tuna poke over rice. Great flavor profiles. Really fresh ingredients. Tuna is sashimi grade and lightly seared. The sesame oil and black sesame seeds give it a nice rich taste.  Highly recommend for the healthy eaters. Don't sleep on the beer selections.  Lots of local brews like cigar city, funky Buddha, tampa bay brewing company on tap.
name: CALI - Tampa Palms
categories: Gluten-Free, American (New), Mexican, Pizza, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, Specialty Food, Vegetarian, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Food

text:
Shiroi Hana, as many have commented, has beautiful interior with a calming, comfortable ambiance. It is memorable for the way it is minimally decorated and extremely clean. 

The food:

Gyoza: liked the flavor of the filling, but the wrapper wasn't crisp/light

Tempura: beautiful presentation with light batter. Very well-done and great portion/variety.

Tonkatsu - Lightly breaded and tender cutlet. For its price, you get two cutlets worth of katsu, and I think the real treat is the katsu sauce with kewpie mayonnaise. Really lovely.

Sashimi regular- For $25, you get a 12-piece sashimi dinner. Extremely fresh fish, and I love the shredded daikon beneath. The salmon and the yellowtail were exceptional. Filling alongside salad and rice. 

Hamachi don- Again, beautifully fresh hamachi don presented on rice with black sesame. (Chirashi must also be wonderful)

I am looking forward to trying more of their traditional dishes, and I was very taken with their service. Absolutely a gem in Philly.

-

Edit: Surprised with my second visit. Had the chicken teriyaki, which was terribly overcooked chicken breast with a very thin dressing as the "teriyaki sauce." Not moist or flavorful at all. Also, the agedashi wasn't very good, either. Tough tofu and the flavor was a little off.
name: Shiroi Hana
categories: Japanese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars

text:
Really good! Bf got pork buns and tonkotsu ramen, which filled him up and left him satisfied. I did the Lent thing and got spring rolls and the grilled mackerel. Delicious. The Japanese mashed potatoes were made with coconut milk, which gave them a tasty unique flavor. Then we tried these chocolate peanut butter marshmallow spring rolls-so good! Somehow we managed to receive some complimentary black sesame ice cream, which was good after the marshmallow thing as it was refreshing and not-as-sugary.
We look forward to going back!
name: Ban Ban Asian Bistro
categories: Food, Restaurants, Bubble Tea, Asian Fusion, Sushi Bars, Chinese

text: I've driven past this place many times and thought, " Seems like a pretty nice spot. I'll have to try it some time." Today was the day and I was completely disappointed. I'm pretty difficult to disappoint when it comes to food. As long as the server takes care of the basics, the food is decent and the portion isn't minimal, I'm good. The building and atmosphere is really nice. I ordered the "BBQ Brisket" and what I got was 4 slices of fatty pot roast in some kind of beef juice. Nothing "BBQ" about it. It was accompanied by 5 spears of asparagus and a cup of "cole slaw" which was jullienned dry cabbage with a drizzle of vinegar and black sesame seed. Honestly, how can you mess up cole slaw? The only up side to my experience was that they had Founders oatmeal stout on tap. Waitress was nothing extraordinary. I was so disappointed that I actually lost my appetite. Thats what I get for having such high hopes when trying a new spot. This is all based off of one dish but I definitely will not be going back to try any more. Did I mention how disappointing this experience was for me?
name: Churchville Inn
categories: Music Venues, Barbeque, Nightlife, Bars, Restaurants, American (Traditional), Arts & Entertainment

text:
I'm actually mad, son. I've been meaning to start leaving reviews but nothing inspired me to take the time until the overwhelming whateverness that is Sakura filled me such foodie disdain. This is real beef. Sakura is the Biggie to my Pac. Sike. It's more like the Lil B to my Pac, meaning this food was wild corny and suspect. All I wanted was a snack so I thought I'd grab some dumplings. I walked passed Dim Sum Garden because I've been there too often so I figured I'd hit up the original DSG on 11th for old times sake. I wanted to grab some regular pork and chive dumplings, not even the soup jawns. That soup dumpling/xiao long bao shit is too Iggy Azaela now. Y'all really fucked it up. 

Anyway, I passed the new DSG and was on my way to hit the old DSG but right in between that walk is Sakura. I've lived in Philly all my life and Chinatown for almost 2 years now and always seen Sakura kind of busy but it never seemed to be my thing. It bothers me when Chinese places do too much and serve volcano rolls and shit. Leave that shit alone! Just do you, booboo! That's why I always steered clear of Sakura and pretty much any other place that does like every Asian food ever. That's a tip from an Asian guy, btw. Don't fuck with those thirsty ass restaurants. If they did one thing good, they'd stick with it. But they don't, so they compensate with variety.

Aight, so I thought I'd give Sakura a shot because I saw on their neon signage (another desperate ploy that should've been a red flag) that they had pan-fried Shanghai soup dumps. I've been craving the fried jawns recently, thinking back to last year when I had them in Shanghai at Yang's Dumplings. That shit was incredible and changed my life. I'll never look at a dumpling the same ever again. I let nostalgia get the best of me and I turned back and made my way into Sakura.

I ordered and the wait was wild long but honestly, you won't see me complain too much about service ever so if that's what you're into, you're looking at the wrong reviewer. I'll actually take bad service to the neck and sacrifice all that if the food is incredible. That's just how my priorities stack.

But yo, I was looking for something that resembled Yang's Dumplings in Shanghai and what I got was bread dressed up as dumplings for Halloween. This shit a couple weeks too early for all that. These thick ass, flavorless ass, soupless ass, dressed up with black sesame seeds ass dumplings were spongy as fuck and I was soaking them in ginger sauce just to give it some type of taste. I promise every bite I took pissed me off more than the last. I shook my head as I looked at these "dumplings" like they were my children bringing home bad grades. I wasn't even mad, I was disappointed. Nah, fuck that. I was mad. 

I'm going to wrap this up. I'm honestly wild into food and you'll see that from my upcoming reviews and my palate is actually on par with y'all pretentious Michelin star mother fuckers so when I say Sakura was booty butt cheeks, then that shit was booty butt cheeks. I ain't going back and you can't make me.
name: Sakura Mandarin
categories: Chinese, Japanese, Dim Sum, Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Szechuan

text:
Pod is a great place to go when you feel like splurging a bit! The atmosphere is fantastic (especially if you are seated in a dining pod with buttons to change the colors of the lighting). I've come here several times and ordered quite a few menu items, but here are my favorites:

Cocktails: I love the Lemon Lotus (Tito's, sparkling wine, poppy seed tincture, lemon foam). Super refreshing!

Dinner: The Vegan Stephen roll (tempura zucchini, avocado, kanpyo squash, eggplant, roasted pepper) is amazing. My favorite part is that they arrange the vegetables to resemble fish - very creative! I also recommend the Japanese Eggplant (red miso, crushed peanuts, bonito); it is tender and delicious. 

Dessert: This is where the fifth star in my review comes in. I'm not ashamed to say that I've tried every dessert on the menu, but there are two standouts! The Black Sesame Cheesecake with Vietnamese coffee caramel and chocolate shortbread is absolutely fantastic.
