It has the perfect amount of sweetness, and the black sesame gives it such a depth of flavor. The Cardamom Fudge Brownie with pistachio ice cream and yuzu curd is also incredible. The balance of flavors is spot on.

Pod is pricey, but it has a great atmosphere and some delicious food (especially dessert), so it's a nice treat once in a while!
name: Pod
categories: Restaurants, Lounges, Asian Fusion, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Bars

text:
I can't say no to a man with tattoos and my experience at Pod was purely orgasmic.

The food at Pod is amazing and reasonably priced, if not underpriced. It is economical bliss.  I expected to pay way more and for appetizers, sushi, drinks and desserts for two. Our bill topped at $84 bucks. Not too bad. Killer ambiance and surprise after surprise, I find myself thinking about Pod time and time again.

Pod is futuristic, offers everything traditional with a twist and is unpretentious. The place is like an outer space playground with ever changing colored lights, bubble ceilings, and white on white interior. The sushi boat is a world of its own and if you fancy anime, the screens are like windows of cartoons.  I saw waitresses carry out birthday desserts with sparklers. It was like Fourth of July. The service is excellent (welcoming, accommodating, quick, and knowledgeable). Everything thumbs up.

The ultra hot weather called for mocktails, one Cucumber and Apple Spritzer and one White Peach and Mint Soda. Both were refreshing and full of fresh fruit. We ordered the special Lobster Ramen appetizer, Tonkatsu Sandwich, and the Rockin Spicy Tuna. The Lobster Ramen was not soupy but had a creamy rich broth-like dressing. The lobster chunks were huge and tender, the vegetable medley offered crunch and the ramen was very fresh and not over cooked. The Tonkatsu Sandwich could easily rival David Chang's pork steamed buns. The Rockin Spicy Tuna was haute sushi. Sprinkled with black sesame seeds and prepared like little works of art, the spicy tuna was like a sushi hors d'oevre. It was topped with popcornlike tempura rock shrimp and microgreens. This all created for a filling meal but without hesitation we ordered dessert.

If Pod's tactic to get people to order dessert was to send in a tattooed dessert man instead of our friendly waitress, then it surely worked. We were set on Chocolate Chocolate Chocolate (chocolate toffee bread pudding, chocolate shot with salted rim, and chocolate tart) but when the tattoo guy told us about the special Chocolate Flan we had to make our dessert choice Chocolate times 4. The tattooed guy was evil in a good way. Death by chocolate all the way at Pod. No worries, you will live to tell the tale of sweet decadence. I could easily devote a whole review to these desserts. Instead, just trust the smile on my face that they were all exquisite. I will add that the Chocolate Flan was light rather than rich and was complimented by an Early Grey Tea coulis and black cherries.

I'd make a two hour trip to Philly from NYC just to indulge at Pod. It was really that good.

For the formal writeup on Pod: http://spamisbetterfried.blogspot.com/2011/03/after-all-these-years-pod-is-still.html
name: Pod
categories: Restaurants, Lounges, Asian Fusion, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Bars

text:
This was by far the most perfect meal of my life.

My father treated me to dinner here after my college graduation. Of course, I went all out for the grande degustation menu with wine pairings for each course since it was the only event in my life that justified the price tag. If not now, when? I've outlined all the courses I was served below. I don't know shit about wine, I just drink it, so I don't remember what they all were can't really comment on them. If you're curious though, about a half-glass was served with each course, so I was QUITE tipsy by the end of it.

The courses were as follows:

Amuse Bouche: Tuna Tartare w/ Daikon
-Light and a perfect way to start the meal. I love any kind of tartare, and this was no exception.

Bread & Butter: Rolls w/ Milk & Chives, Onion French Bread, something else
-I only tried the onion but it was very good. The waiters kept bring the tray of bread around and I think my brother had about 10 pieces.

Raw Oyster w/ Caviar & Hibiscus Foam
-Absolutely perfect. It had been a while since I'd had an oyster and this one did not disappoint. The hibiscus foam was especially interesting - more fruity than I expected.

Salmon Tartare w/ Vinegrette & Essence of Lavender
-Another tartare! Perfect. The presentation on this was very interesting. The bowl sat on a plate filled with dry ice, then the server poured liquid (the lavender essence, i believe) on it at the table. I actually don't really like the smell of lavender, or anything very floral for that matter, but it didn't detract from the dish.

Foie Gras w/ Risotto Chip, Black Sesame, Berry Sauce & Cherries w/ Ice Cream
-Possibly the most creative of the dishes. On one side of the plate was the foie gras and risotto chip, and the other side had a scoop of ice cream (possibly kirsch flavored?) with macerated cherries. The sweet components and salty/rich foie gras were the perfect foils for one another.

Some Firm White Fish w/ Consomme and Zucchini Blossom
-I can't remember what the fish was, but it was cooked perfectly and delicious. Served in a shallow bowl of consomme with a tempura-fried zucchini blossom on top - nice and light.

Lamb Tenderloin w/ Crispy Potato
-Lamb is one of my favorite meats, so this was an obvious winner for me. The crispy potatoes were like a classy version of that old vending machine standard, Potato Stix - but obviously way more awesome.

Taglatelle with Porcini & Truffles
-The simplest course, with just a few beautiful ingredients. Pasta, butter, porcini mushrooms, salt, pepper, some generous shavings of truffles... that's it.

Melon Sorbet w/ Powder (palate cleanser)
-My least favorite course, but I'm biased because I hate all kinds of melons. I tried a bite and then let my dad eat it.

Cheese Tray
-This was awesome. A server came out with a gorgeous glassed-in cart containing about 10 different cheeses. You're allowed to choose as many as you want, but they recommend about 5 for a nice-sized tray. I told the server I liked soft, strong cheeses, and he made up a beautiful assortment with some grapes and 2 kinds of bread. 

Dessert: Yogurt Sorbet, Lemon Macaron, & Tomato Confit
-The first of quite a few desserts. Served in a parfait glass with a dollop of tomato confit at the bottom, the lemon macaron balanced in the center, and yogurt-flavored sorbet on top. 

Dessert: Truffles
-I was served a platter of 5 truffles: mixed nut, tarragon, saffron, curry, and red beet. The unexpected flavors were all quite good, but the saffron and curry were my favorites. I was also given a cute box of 2 chocolates to take home.

Dessert Cart
-Yes, the famous dessert cart! It was every bit as wonderful as I had hoped. I asked for a small slice each of the Grand Marnier Souffle, the Flourless Chocolate Cake, and the restaurant's Signature Chocolate cake, which consisted of rum-soaked genoise with rich chocolate buttercream. Unfortunately, by this point I was pretty full, and all the desserts were so rich I could only have a few bites.

Finally, we were served a variety of petit fours with the check.

This is really extravagance, but for a special occasion it can't be beat. The service is impeccable and treat you like royalty even if it's painfully obvious that you don't belong (like my frugal and tactless grandmother who loudly exclaimed "It looks like a roach!" when the amuse bouche was served). My only complaint is that I will probably never be able to afford a meal like this again.
name: Le Bec Fin
categories: Nightlife, Restaurants, Champagne Bars, French, Event Planning & Services, Bars, Caterers

text: I could eat here everyday! I'm so happy to have this new addition to the neighborhood. The food is top notch. My favorites so far are the Savory Oats and the Roze Bowl. And be sure to get the black sesame latte!! The owner, Julia, couldn't be sweeter and that goes without saying her staff too. Keep it up! We can't wait to see what the dinner menu looks like :)
name: Cafe Roze
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars

text: What a lovely surprise.  We ordered just appetizers and made a meal of them.  The prawns with crispy polenta came  with cloves of roasted garlic--delicious.  The carpaccio had a lot going on (I admit I'm a purist) was really nice.  The crochette (breaded fried cheese balls) were wonderful and came with a flavorful sauce.  But my fave--recommended by our waiter--was the flatbread with dipping sauces.  The sauces were all spectacular, but the flatbread on its own was something special--baked in a wood-fire oven and seasoned with a middle eastern/Asian blend of spices--and not to be missed. We finished with the black sesame-tahini ice cream sandwich--unusual and scrumptious!!  I highly recommend!!
name: Convivo Restaurant and Bar
categories: Bars, Mediterranean, Restaurants, Nightlife, Moroccan, Event Planning & Services, Venues & Event Spaces, Italian

text:
Came to this small corner of Chinatown Square on a Friday night, and it was surprisingly not very packed. We ordered the black sesame base, with lychee mix in but disappointingly, all three topping options we wanted were out (blackberries, raspberries, and mochi) so instead we just went with Kit Kat, blueberries and lychee, and then we got the condensed milk drizzle. The thing cost ~$7, and we waited about 15 minutes for it.

Overall, I can't say the whole experience was exceptional, but it was still good. The ice cream was definitely tasty, and there was a good amount of it, but for $7 there were literally two pieces of Kit Kat, 3 blueberries and maybe 3 pieces of lychee which seemed a little scarce. Perhaps I was just disappointed they didn't have any of my three topping preferences
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Good spot for ice cream in Chinatown. Was empty when we walked in mid-week at 3pm, so no wait. Ordered, got the afternoon happy hour discount and $1 off for check in to Yelp for a grand total of $9.50 for two treats. Black sesame -- yummy; Vietnamese coffee -- as expected, with a large toasted marshmallow. Only issue might be the wait with a large crowd, as there is only one ice cream roller machine in the store.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: There are a lot of places in Philly now that serve Thai rolled ice cream, so they do need to compete. We decided to give this place a try because they had some base flavors that we haven't seen at other places such as taro and black sesame. We ordered black sesame expecting some deep sesame flavor to the ice cream, but it really just tasted like cookies & creme. Overall it's tasty and doesn't take too long, but not my favorite place around for rolled ice cream.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Flavors are WONDERFUL. I love the black sesame.

More on the sweeter side, especially if you order with the condensed milk drizzled in. 

Other than that, no complaints. 

Definitely recommend!
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Since this is a new place I thought I would give it another try.  Bagel was very dense. I ordered the same order. Good iced coffee. The dense everything bagel just had a mixture of sesame seeds and black sesame seeds. I ordered chive cream cheese and got plain. Waited 15 minutes for this with one person ahead of me. What really bothered me is my order was complete and sat in a bag for 5 minutes as the expediter filled another order, waiting for sandwiches to be cooked. After that order was completed she brought both orders to the counter. Too lazy to walk three feet to hand me my order. Downgrading my review to one star. I will never be back.

Ordered an everything bagel un-toasted with chive cream cheese. One person ahead of me in line and still waited about 10 minutes for them to slice and slap some cream cheese on a bagel.  The bagel was very dense and overloaded with salt. Almost inedible. There was barely any chive taste to the cream cheese. It tasted like plain and I only observed one piece of chive in the cream cheese.  I likthe coffee ice cubes. I agree with a previous reviewer that this place is cursed. Not worth the detour on the way to work. Won't be back
name: 18 Bagels Co.
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Food, Bagels, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Spicy Pot is one of my favorite dishes, which is famous for the spicy taste and a combination of various ingredients. It is awesome to have the Spicy Pot with a bottle of iced green bean juice. However, there are not many restaurants providing the Spicy Pot here in Philly. Sakura is one of the few exceptions. 
There are Sea weed，bean sprout, enoki，sweet potato noodles in the pot at the bottom line, which price is 8 dollars. In addition to that, you must add at least four kinds of meet from the menu. My favorites are mutton, fish tofu, shrimp and Jinhua ham. You should definitely try the Jinhua Ham, which is the top-branded ham in China, which used to serve to the Royal families in the ancient time. 
We also had the Pan-Fried Dumplings. Six in a plate. There are black sesames sprinkled on the dumplings and the spicy pot to make the dishes more tasty and cute.
Since I haven't try any other dishes, I cannot say more. But I guess I would go there and try the Dongpo Pork and Fish in Vinegar Sauce next time.
name: Sakura Mandarin
categories: Chinese, Japanese, Dim Sum, Sushi Bars, Restaurants, Szechuan

text:
This place is great for real Japanese food. I'm not a huge fan of their sushi, I think it's overpriced and not that great. Though I do really like the shrimp tempura roll. If you want real and delicious Japanese cuisine, you have come to the right place!

The bento boxes are great, the Katsu Don is the best, and I love their crazy ice cream flavors. I recommend the black sesame. Yummm. Every meal comes with miso and a cucumber salad that it sooo tasty. They have a wide sake selection, including this really neat blue orb thingy. A little chintzy, but fun! 

The waitresses can be a little prickly, depending on who you get. The older ladies are gruff, but funny. You will never have to ask for more water here- They are on top of it. You will get very prompt and attentive service here. 

I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys Japanese food, or wants something new to try.
name: Seki's Japanese Restaurant
categories: Live/Raw Food, Sushi Bars, Japanese, Restaurants

text:
Came to Chop Steakhouse and Bar (downtown) last night for Downtown Dining Week 2016 and to celebrate the hubs and my 13th Wedding Anniversary.

We opted for reservations which meant the booth areas upstairs but the walk-in space in the lounge downstairs is probably my favourite here.

Our server and all the staff were pretty fabulous.  Sure there were some mistakes - missing a spoon for soup or water but when asked everyone was super friendly and took care of our needs.  I really liked how any staff member walking by was able to stop and check in on us or ask if we needed anything and our server checked back at the perfect times to make sure we were enjoying our items.

Parking can be a bit tricky here but the East Parkade in City Centre is pretty good and has an access ramp from the 2nd floor of the parkade (still requiring some stairs) that doesn't make you go outside in case it's super cold or rainy.

I absolutely love the look of this location of Chop and you can really see the attention to detail what went into the huge renovation of this space for Chop to open up paired with the Sutton Hotel.

If you haven't been to the lounge - go - it's really something to enjoy.

Anyhow, I digress.

The hubs and I opted for the following from the Downtown Dining Week $28 Menu (there was also a $48 option with killer appetizers like steak bites and crab cakes but we didn't want to have a huge meal at a late setting before bed):


For starters we selected:

Mixed Green Salad
garden vegetables, pumpkin and black sesame seeds with basil honey-lime vinaigrette

Red Pepper Bisque
creamy satin bisque of tomatoes and roasted red peppers

Both were excellent but the basil honey-lime vinaigrette was TO DIE FOR.  Seriously, I wanted to lick the plate and asked the hubs if he would try to replicate this at home!  PHENOMENAL salad and the pumpkin and sesame seeds were just killer with it!

For mains we selected: 

Maple Bourbon Haddock
blackened haddock, seared in a maple bourbon butter, served with wild rice pilaf and fresh seasonal vegetables

Top Sirloin
served with your choice of wasabi infused mashed potatoes, wild rice pilaf, baked potato, Chop cut fries or fresh seasonal vegetables


& I added lobster and gorgonzola for $5 to the Sirloin

Both were excellent.  The steak was cooked to perfection at a warm medium rare.  I loved the lobster and gorgonzola add on!  The hubs was super happy with his blackened haddock.

Both of us commented that we would order the same starters and mains again which is always a great sign!

And for desserts we opted for: 

Tiramisu
espresso soaked sponge, amaretto & mascarpone mousse, shaved chocolate

Warm Apple Crumble
granny smith apples & raspberry compote, brown sugar crumble, vanilla gelato

Both desserts were excellent and presented beautifully.  I loved the classic feel of the crumble in the oval cast iron dish and the tiramisu in a 1/2 size mason jar.  I've had mason jar desserts before that fell flat or didn't seem put together at all.  This one totally hit the mark and was not a consistency I was expecting in that it didn't appear to have layers and felt more like a mix - similar to rice pudding.  The flavour was heavenly and easily rich enough to share between two people.

I had mentioned at the very beginning of dinner that I had a walnut allergy and not only did our server come back several time stop to ask specific questions but the front end manager also stopped by to clarify before delivering the apple crumble to my husband - even the way the front end manager knelt down to our table to discuss my allergy with me at eye level was quite comforting and made us feel that they really cared.

Being that we had a late seating and it was a work night we opted for sparking water instead of wine or cocktails and I was pleased to see that they offer house bottled sparkling water with a little note on the back of the bottle that choosing to support this method is both environmentally responsible and sustainable.  And the price was fair at $3.99 a bottle (2 glasses plus a little extra from each bottle).

To finish off the night our server brought us two glasses of prosecco because she had overheard us talking about our Anniversary.

All in all it was a fabulous meal from service to ambience to presentation to taste of food.  It's not often that I can say I would 100% repeat the same meal bite for bite but I would definitely say that about Chop downtown.

TWO THUMBS WAY UP

As a side note, I had come here back in November as part of the Yelp Rodeo Week food crawl and was absolutely blown away by the food we tried and the knowledge and service we received from Stefan (the sales and special event coordinator).  The steak bites and Tuna tartar were AH-MAZING and the Alcoholic Pink Lemonade blew my mind.  The bone-in ribeye was the best I have ever had!  If you're looking to plan a work party or special event, I can't imagine  a more friendly and knowledgeable sales coordinator than Stefan!
name: Chop Steakhouse & Bar
categories: Seafood, Lounges, Steakhouses, Bars, Nightlife, Restaurants

text:
You simply must eat here. If you just have one nice meal planned or you like to eat classy every night, THIS is the place. 

Just the smell of the buns that come out before the meal was enough to put me in a 5 star mood. Incredible. 

I had one problem with my dish, they comped the dish, one drink AND dessert. Service was 5 star, absolutely stellar. Food was incredible, it would be too much work to even begin to describe how well balanced, creative, inspiring and delicious it was. 

Iberian black - 5/5
Venison Carpaccio - 5/5
Gnocchi Lobster - 5/5
Black sesame cake 5/5

Amazing. I could eat here every week. If I come back to NOLA I'll be here for sure!
name: Restaurant R'evolution
categories: Event Planning & Services, Hotels, Cajun/Creole, Restaurants, Seafood, Southern, Hotels & Travel

text: Ok went there for my 19th anniversary.. Food was good but uninspired.. As a chef.. The only dish I could not do at home was the dessert. The waiter did say that Jen Carrol did leave the week before so maybe that was the reason for soulless food.  Everything was cooked properly but just lacked a bit of Hmmppp..  However, the dessert was amazing . black sesame panna cotta with grape and miso sorbet.. That and the crabcake were the highlights.  Would i go back.. I  dont think i would.. It was good but not as good as i thought it would be.
name: 10 Arts Bistro
address: The Ritz-Carlton Philadelphia, Ten Avenue of the Arts
categories: Nightlife, Bars, American (New), Lounges, Restaurants

text:
I hadn't tried rolled ice cream before and was searching Philly for the perfect place to test my tastebuds. Out of the 3-4 rolled ice cream places in Chinatown we stepped into, we picked I CE NY for their unique ice cream flavors (thai tea, ube, black sesame and mango sticky rice to name a few!).

As there aren't many Filipino restaurants in the Philly area, the ube ice cream caught my eye. For $7, the quantity was lacking but the flavor was there. Not as strong as I would expect from ube found in halo halo or Red Ribbon pastries but still enough to give the Filipino thumbs up.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Tried again. Ordered an everything bagel with chive cream cheese- got plain cream cheese. The bagel was stale and just not that good. I was the only customer in line. I could understand messing up an order if it's busy, but it's not like there was any traffic there. The bagel was bad. Way too many sesame seeds. Tasted like a sesame bagel with a little salt added. Not the NY everything bagel taste I was looking for. Avoid this placelike the plague!

Since this is a new place I thought I would give it another try.  Bagel was very dense. I ordered the same order. Good iced coffee. The dense everything bagel just had a mixture of sesame seeds and black sesame seeds. I ordered chive cream cheese and got plain. Waited 15 minutes for this with one person ahead of me. What really bothered me is my order was complete and sat in a bag for 5 minutes as the expediter filled another order, waiting for sandwiches to be cooked. After that order was completed she brought both orders to the counter. Too lazy to walk three feet to hand me my order. Downgrading my review to one star. I will never be

Ordered an everything bagel un-toasted with chive cream cheese. One person ahead of me in line and still waited about 10 minutes for them to slice and slap some cream cheese on a bagel.  The bagel was very dense and overloaded with salt. Almost inedible. There was barely any chive taste to the cream cheese. It tasted like plain and I only observed one piece of chive in the cream cheese.  I likthe coffee ice cubes. I agree with a previous reviewer that this place is cursed. Not worth the detour on the way to work. Won't be back
name: 18 Bagels Co.
categories: Restaurants, American (New), Food, Bagels, Breakfast & Brunch

text:
Emily was a very attentive waitress on a Friday night.  The restaurant was quiet and the atmosphere, music and decor very pleasing.  Water was served as soon as we took our seats and lemon wedges brought when requested.  We ordered warm sake which was served just as promptly.

The restaurant features a patio and two indoor seating sections.  One casual and smaller with a wall mounted TV; the other more formal with large tables and spacious booths.

We ordered the Organic Miso soup, Seaweed (Kaiso) salad, Kimchee salad and Edamame croquettes.  The rolls we chose were the Erotic, and the Ginza.  Everything was delicious and arrived quickly.  We asked to sample the Black Sesame ice cream and thought it too sweet in comparison to one served at one of our favourite sushi bistros. The menu offers much variety and is extensive, even with a small "Western" (burger and fries) section. 

Prices are reasonable considering the generous portions. Our one and only demerit is for the ginger. They serve the pickled (pink) as opposed to fresh (white).

We look forward to returning to try their Phó dishes, order from the full bar and try one of the many fruit options Bubble Tea.
name: Maki Maki
categories: Sushi Bars, Vietnamese, Japanese, Restaurants

text: I enjoy going to max brenner once in a while when I am in the city. Love the Asian salad and their cocktail drinks. I only gave three stars because they are not consistent with food quality. I got a black sesame salmon one time and they served with leftover vegetables. They were yellowy, saggy looking. Didn't taste fresh. Their smoothies? Way too sweet and liquidy. It didn't taste like how it used to be.
name: Max Brenner - Philadelphia
categories: American (Traditional), Restaurants, Desserts, Food, Chocolatiers & Shops, American (New), Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Typical shake shack by the KOP mall. Good service, no complaints. I tried the new black sesame milkshake and it was delicious!!! Would highly recommend.
name: Shake Shack
address: 160 N Gulph Rd, Ste 233, King Of Prussia Mall
categories: Hot Dogs, Burgers, Food, Restaurants, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, American (Traditional)

text:
I'm a visitor from the LA area where we are known for our fantastic food and desserts, but this is hands down the best ice cream I have ever had in my almost 21 years of life.

In my four-day trip to Philadelphia, I visited three times and tried five of the flavors. I would've visited everyday, but it closed one of the days before I could get there in time. 

I highly recommend the Mango Sticky Rice, which I ate four times. My next favorite was Taro, followed by Black Sesame, Thai Ice Tea, and Matcha. 

Also shoutout to Tuan, who was the most enthusiastic and helpful employee there. 

I know I'm kind of dramatic, but seriously. Their ice cream changed my life.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: I love this place!  They took ice cream to a new level!   And I even got to meet Danny!  One of the guys who invented the ice cream roll in Thailand!  He was so nice and he made the ice cream rolls himself for my order.   I had the strawberry cheesecake one yesterday and I just had the black sesame today.  Sooooo goooooooood.  I can't wait to try the other flavors!!
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: Love ICHIBAN.  At times the service is a bit slower, but well worth the wait.  I second all positive prior reviews here.  The black sesame ice cream makes a perfect ending.
name: Ichiban Restaurant Japanese Cuisine
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Sushi Bars

text: Had lunch today with my friend. I had the Black Pearl Roll and my friend had the Shrimp Udon. Both were absolutely delicious and I would definitely come back again. We also had Black Sesame Ice Cream for desert which was also excellent! Service was great!
name: Ginza
categories: Sushi Bars, Ramen, Restaurants, Japanese

text:
Tokiwa Ramen was overall okay ramen. When we arrived around 11:45am it was busy. We hit the peak hour, but the wait was about 10-15min which is not bad! They have a sign outside saying Soup... and above it says NO. So if they run out of soup they will turn the NO on.... Pretty interesting ramen place with limited soup. Their soups are apparently boiled and simmered for a long time. The line died down very quick.

I ordered the Hokkaido Miso (chicken broth), the broth was hot! love it! noodle were good a bit soft. I asked for fatty part of the pork and they gave me a different cut of the pork. The pork reminds me of beef tongue which is a bit chewy but soft at the same time. It was okay, not what I expecting and the pork taste like boiled pork nothing special, would recommend to add a bit of a char to it. The soup was salty, but had the miso flavour. My friend ordered spicy miso chicken broth and black sesame. The black sesame broth was very good! I think i would order that next time.

After eating I was pretty thirsty... I think it was the salt...
name: Tokiwa Ramen
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Ramen, Soup

text: Came for brunch with a friend and was not disappointed. We both had black sesame steamers which were delicious. I had the savory oats and she had the egg bowl. Both were yummy. The savory oats are quite salty but enjoyed them nonetheless. Would definitely come back.
name: Cafe Roze
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars

text:
As the poke craze has taken grip, I've had the opportunity to try dozens of different bowls. Aloha Ansley is among the best I've eaten. Great to see an independent restaurateur have success. 

Tonite, tried the Maui bowl. An enormous helping of cubed Ahi tuna is served over a bed of coconut jasmine rice.   The bowl is adorned with diced tomato, mixed greens, thinly sliced picked cucumbers, sliced avocado, sauced with Asian marinate used for the tuna and sprinkled with black sesame seeds.  The tuna is super fresh, firm and flavorful and the marinate complements the taste perfectly. Rice is sticky and sweet with coconut added for an extra dimension.  Dude, this is the real deal.. I can't think of a thing I'd improve.

I was also enticed into trying a new menu addition - coconut ice cream. Wow!  It's made in-house - creamy, dense and rich with toasted coconut making each bite crunchy.  If you're a coconut fan - you've GOT to try this.  It's good enough to stop in just for dessert!

This spot rocks. RECOMMENDED!
name: Aloha Ansley Hawaiian Fusion
categories: Specialty Food, Bars, Food, Beer Bar, Salad, Nightlife, Seafood, American (New), Vegetarian, Tacos, Poke, Vegan, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Restaurants, Hawaiian, Mexican

text:
Tonight was the inauguration of hopefully an annual event, the Asian Pacific Foodie Night sponsored by NOLA Nite Market. Malaysian, Indian, Vietnamese, and Thai food trucks and stations scattered about.  It was well attended with throngs of people looking for great food and drinks.

I opted for an Indian cuisine tent featuring food from Thali Llama. Owner and Chef Tyler Stuart had a great dish called baingan bharta. Smoky, spicy eggplant roasted with spices and topped with pomegranate seeds. Accompaning this was naan straight out of the skillet. Topped with black sesame seeds. Both were amazing. I hope Thali Llama finds a permanent home where we can get great food like this all the time.
name: Gretna Farmers' and Art Market
categories: Farmers Market, Food, Shopping, Arts & Crafts, Flowers & Gifts

text:
A great new place for delicious Hawaii-inspired cuisine. It's exciting to see an accomplished young chef open a delicious new local spot. 

Aloha Ansley is in a newly renovated building along West Bay Drive. The storefront is brightly painted in a Hawaiian theme. The colorful theme carries through inside, with a hanging surfboard and Hawaiian music in the background. There are about 10 high top tables for dine-in. 

You order at the counter from the menu board; each entree is prepared fresh.  We tried the Volcano Flow Salad and the Maui Poke.

The salad is a tasty combo of mixed greens, diced tomatoes & peppers, dressed with black bean corn salsa, a dollop of guacamole and served with a side of homemade Hawaiian BBQ dressing. The dressing, with a ginger base, is excellent and enhances the combination of flavors without overpowering.  We chose BBQ chicken for a little extra protein.  This adds a big portion of shredded chicken, lightly flavored with Hawaiian BBQ seasonings.   A really good salad! 

We also tried the Maui Poke bowl. This is made up of a generous portion of imported-from-Hawaii Big Eye tuna, diced & house-marinated.  The tuna is served with diced tomatoes, mixed greens and pickled cucumbers, then garnished with sliced avocado and black sesame seeds. All of this is added to a bed of sticky coconut jasmine rice.  One of the better Poke bowls I've had - no frills but super fresh ingredients and the right proportions make this one shine. 

Honorable mention for using all biodegradable plates, bowls & forks.  Dinner for two with soft drinks is $24.

There are a few other mouthwatering options on the menu. I'll definitely be back. Recommended!
name: Aloha Ansley Hawaiian Fusion
categories: Specialty Food, Bars, Food, Beer Bar, Salad, Nightlife, Seafood, American (New), Vegetarian, Tacos, Poke, Vegan, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Restaurants, Hawaiian, Mexican

text: Visiting from LA and found this place my first night here. I've been here 3 times in 4 days and I'm a huge fan. The black sesame is delicious, banana cream is insanely good, Thai tea is off the chart, coconut is crazy and the mango sticky rice is awesome. The guys who work here are all super nice and it also fun to watch them roll the ice cream.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text: My daughter and I love this place! We tried just about all the other rolled ice cream places in the city and this place not only has the best tasting ice cream and texture but their flavors and combos are the best! I've been here so many times and haven't had a bad combo yet! Strawberry cheesecake, vietnamese coffee, black sesame and mango sticky rice are some of my faves! This is where I bring anyone who wants to try rolled ice cream and they all love it!
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
Easy and safe way to get a bubble tea fix during the pandemic.

I live about 30 minutes away from Bobacup, so it is no easy feat for us to get here. I mean, if I didn't have a two-year-old I'd consider coming a lot more often, but there is only so much Disney+ I can handle when trying to keep him from losing it during an hour round trip ride. 

However, hands down, this is one of the safest experiences when getting food. You put your order in online in their incredibly robust ordering platform, park in the parking spaces in front of the building, they walk out with a whiteboard with numbered names of orders, you hold up your finger with which number you are and then they come back with your order. The employees wear masks. Phenomenal.

The ordering platform is top notch. It gives you all the options that you would normally get in the store. I'll have to ask my friend Chris W., if he is able to get his standard order, which isn't on the menu, but if you are a normal Bobacup goer like the rest of us, you should have no problem getting what you want. (Seriously, if you want your mind blown you should go see how many check-ins Chris W. has at Bobacup.)

I got a split cup lavendar and matcha with honey boba. Honey boba is their version of boba and it is free in June. I only mention this, because Brett N. decided to forgo free honey boba, because he didn't realize that meant the normal tapioca balls. Yes, feel free to make fun of Brett N. for this. We also got 13 mochi ice cream (if you order 10 you get 3 free. We actually ended up only getting 12 because they forgot one of ours. Since it was a "free" one, I wasn't that upset about it, but check your order before you leave!)

For the mochi ice cream, we got salted caramel, thai tea (which is a new favorite of mine), matcha (always good), chocolate, ube (which isn't a flavor I'm that familiar with so I had to try it. It was good, but I'd probably keep going back to the thai tea) and black sesame (which ranks up there with thai tea for me, so good). The drinks are always on point, so I really enjoyed my lavender and matcha bubble tea. 

I'm kind of lucky we don't live closer or else I'd possibly be matching Chris W. with my visit numbers (probably not, but I can dream). If you are worried about your health during COVID-19, this is a great place to get your bubble tea fix.
name: TeaStori
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cafes, Asian Fusion, Tea Rooms, Macarons, Specialty Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies

text:
I thought all Kung Fu Tea locations were alike, but I guess I was wrong. I decided to try this location one day while I was shopping in the area. I really wanted to try Brioche Bakery which is in the same plaza but found out it was permanently closed.  Anyway, I ordered the matcha sesame milk strike which I've had at the Riverview location and loved it. I usually add herbal jelly with no issue. Something just didn't taste right with this drink. I don't know if it was too much black sesame or something off with another ingredient. All I can say is that it had a very unpleasant smell and taste. This is the first time that I didn't finish my milk tea. I usually like the matcha milk strike. 

The service was great. I didn't wait too long for it to be made. I haven't tried the food there. The drink just didn't taste right. I think I'll stick with the Riverview location.
name: Token Ramen & Kung Fu Tea
categories: Bubble Tea, Ramen, Food, Restaurants, Japanese, Coffee & Tea

text: Stopped in here tonight as guests of our son to celebrate my husband's and my birthday. We were seated right away which was great as we had a mishap with a reservation at another restaurant and since we had never been here we decided this was a great opportunity to see what we were missing. Brooke was our server and she was very knowledgeable about the menu and super friendly. We started out with a drink and appetizers. Blackberry Sage Margarita, Rum Forest Rum both delicious! If you love buffalo wings but prefer the veggie route try the Buffalo Cauliflower Popcorn. Mach Bites are creamy, crispy and a little heat makes them a well rounded tasty treat! Entrees chosen were Cedar Plank Shimburger excellent bunless option, Barry C's Stuffed Meatloaf, Eggs Barbacoa, and the Cluck Yeah served on the seasonal spooky black sesame seed bun.  Portions are plentiful so come hungry or prepare for leftovers to be enjoyed later.. Overall experience was a 5 and our server Brooke was definitely a 5 !!! Birthday cupcakes were a nice surprise!
name: Datz
categories: Burgers, Bars, Restaurants, American (Traditional), Vegan, Asian Fusion, Cocktail Bars, Breakfast & Brunch, Soul Food, Sandwiches, American (New), Gastropubs, Comfort Food, Nightlife, Wine Bars, Delis

text:
The restaurant is located on the ground floor of the hotel Californian. The decor is modern but not very intimate. Definitely not the right place for a date night. Maybe some white napkins or candles could improve the setting.
The servers on the other hand are extremely friendly and helpful.
The food in a nutshell is very good: unique presentations and great flavors.
We had several appetizers:
-The dungeness crab puffs were pillowy and flavorful.
-The octopus was tender and the cavatelli with santa barbara spiny lobster while cooked perfectly al dente could have benefited from more kick.
-The whole branzino was moist but the scallops were OK, not great.
The ora king salmon was the best dish of the evening and the ribeye while flavorful and perfectly cooked medium rare was served lukewarm: too bad !
The deserts were spectacular in taste and presentation: I would leave room to try the pumpkin brûlée and the black swan with its unusual
but tasty black sesame ice cream.
name: Blackbird
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Lounges, Cocktail Bars, Mediterranean, Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, American (New), Nightlife

text:
This boba shop is as good as it gets. Before I get to how the drinks taste, I want to talk about the environment. When you first come in, you are surrounded by a very picturesque environment. There are is an all-gender bathroom available for customers, and the walls are decorated with polaroids of customers who are posing by their "bench" with a cute little corny slogan on top such as "Love you to infiniTEA" or "Guilty AF". They also have a little Tea wall, where if you are unsure about what to order, you can open the cans up and smell the essence of them. If you are still unsure what to order, you should ask the employees. I did that the first time I came here and I've been getting the same thing over and over again! (P.S. It's the Royal Milk Tea). Throughout the years, they have also been adding more and more things to their menu, such as food items, Taiyaki ice cream, and the mochi ice cream bar (which are little pockets of ice cream, covered over rice dough. I highly recommend the black sesame, my favorite). They also have different sorts of toppings, such as the teddy bear jellies, heart jellies, or mini boba. I usually get the regular honey boba, which I am never disappointed by, each time I order this. Some other places, the boba can get too chewy or too hard if you order at a certain time, but not Bobacup. 
Now, on to the drinks. As I've said, I've usually gotten the Royal Milk Tea, but they also have a variety of options available, such as fruit teas, fruit slushes, and their split cups (which means you can try two different flavors!). Their employees are super helpful and are excellent in recommending a drink for you to try. I would definitely recommend coming here and getting something. You will not be disappointed!
name: TeaStori
categories: Food, Bubble Tea, Restaurants, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cafes, Asian Fusion, Tea Rooms, Macarons, Specialty Food, Juice Bars & Smoothies

text:
I love having Pod on Penn's campus. My boyfriend and I come here every month for our regulars.

This vibe is extremely cool - the artsy bright lights and round booths make for a really unique theme. My boyfriend is vegetarian so we order some of their non-meat specialities like the tofu bibimbap and their lettuce wraps. If you have a sweet tooth, their black sesame cheesecake is to die for - it's a delicious combination of sesame cream cheese and chocolate shortbread.

During my visits with non-vegetarian friends, my favorite dish was the lobster & pekin duck fried rice (SO good, I literally cannot stop eating it) I 
also love the spanish rock octopus - you honestly can't go wrong with any of their robata grill dishes. 

Service is excellent - we are always well-looked after and our food is served hot and fresh within minutes. Really recommend!
name: Pod
categories: Restaurants, Lounges, Asian Fusion, Nightlife, Sushi Bars, Bars

text:
To Go sushi at Rouses is better.

Ordered veggie fried rice as well as a roll to take away.  I didn't expect much, however I did expect more than a few sad strands of dehydrated carrot which was the only vegetable in the big plastic tub-o-rice.  Unless you count black sesame seeds as a vegetable.

So yay black sesame seeds, boo no real veg to speak.  Go on..add some  peas or somethin, I dare ya.
name: Sushi Village
categories: Japanese, Sushi Bars, Restaurants

text: Got take out from here. Looks like a cute mom and pop type restaurant. I tried chicken and pork katsu and both were delicious! Portions are good too. They also have this machine that gives you a free hot cup of coffee (with milk) or black sesame tea. The black sesame tea really hit the spot while I waited for my order.
name: Katsu Guys
categories: Restaurants, Japanese, Asian Fusion

text:
I see the 5-star reviews and I really wonder if we ate at the same place. A while back I gave Sushi Village a try and was seriously unimpressed, especially at the price. But it's been two or so years and Groupon had a deal, so I figured I'd see if things have improved.

First I ordered the only option they had for sake, a small, generic hot sake. I swear I heard a microwave running behind the curtain to heat up my sake. Right after my sake came the standard ginger salad and miso soup. The ginger dressing on the salad was abundant, which was nice. The soup was lackluster. It tasted...off. Something wasn't right, like maybe the mix they used was expired?

For an appetizer I ordered tuna tataki, which I hadn't had in a while and decided to treat myself. Take a moment and Google some images on what that dish should look like before you read my description of what I was served. My place was a half dozen pieces of tuna laying flat and spread out. Rather than the outside rim being seared, which means a large piece of tuna was seared and then sliced, each slice had some very mild searing on the surface. Uneven searing at that; it didn't look like it came from a heated surface, maybe from a brulé torch. Rather than the regular ponzu sauce they were drizzled with a weird, this yellow sauce, almost lemon in taste.

Usually when I get sushi I'll order chirashi. It wasn't on the regular menu but the waitress said it was on the lunch menu but they would be happy to make it. When it arrived I was again disappointed. In the continuing theme the portions were small. For $15 i got three small slices each of tuna, salmon, white tuna, and something that looked like maybe amberjack. The sashimi portion was ok, but nothing special. The seasoned rice that is part of chirashi was a tiny amount, no more than 1/3 of a cup, probably enough to do three or four nigiri. Rather than season the rice it was just sprinkled with black sesame.

After eating what should have been a filling meal I was still quite hungry. I decided to finish my order with a volcano roll. Every other place I've ordered this roll it's been four large pieces of snowcrab roll as a base then piled high with tempura, snowcrab, and sriracha mayo. What I was served was a base of small California rolls with a small pile of Krab, tempura, and a dab of spicy mayo. 

The entire meal was disappointing. I don't think I'll be coming back.
name: Sushi Village
categories: Japanese, Sushi Bars, Restaurants

text:
My husband and I went to Cafe Roze for dinner a couple of weeks ago, and, while everything was good, I just didn't think it was worth the price (compared to other places in Nashville where I'd rather spend my money). 

First of all, the restaurant is very small. I've looked in during the day, and it looks beautiful (lots of rose and rose gold, of course). At night, it's so dark in the restaurant that you kind of lose its beauty. (I'd probably try Cafe Roze again for brunch before I'd try it again for dinner.)

We had a reservation, which worked out because the restaurant was pretty much full. (There wasn't a traditional hostess stand when we entered, so we waited until someone came from around the bar to seat us.)

We started with the miso cauliflower (with Lebanese yogurt, salsa verde, and black sesame), which was good, but nothing I'd insist on ordering again. 

My husband got the pork schnitzel (with caraway, red cabbage, pickled beet, and sauce gribiche). While this dish was okay, there were several things I didn't love about it. I thought the pork was a little overcooked. Then, I didn't love that the beet and red cabbage were raw and tossed with overdressed greens (possibly the beet greens). I love a slow-cooked, caramelized cabbage, and the beets/cabbage combo on this plate ended up being vegetables on the plate that you force yourself to eat - a side salad rather than an accompaniment to dish that made sense. The sauce gribiche wasn't my favorite thing either. Overall, not a dish I loved.

I got the simple pasta with tomato, garlic, anchovy, and Parmesan. Now, this is the kind of dish I could eat every night. Homey, comforting, simple, and delicious. When you make something this simple that could be made at home, it has to be kind of perfect to be worth the money that you will spend in a restaurant. And this dish was just about there. I thoroughly enjoyed. Transported to childhood good.

We also shared one of the desserts they were offering that night: tapioca pudding with vanilla syrup and bruleed grapefruit. I wanted a lot more grapefruit and for it to be more bruleed (and a little less of the syrup), but I liked this dish. 

We also got a couple of drinks each. My husband tried the Shelby Park Swizz (mezcal, genepy, St. Germain, and pineapple) and the Melon Drama (gin, aperol, melon). He liked both, but preferred the Swizz. I got the Roze Fashioned (Old Forrester Signature, amaro, and rose water), which I liked, and then a glass of wine. 

The service was okay. Definitely on the slow side. Our waitress forgot to put in our dessert order, so it never came until she looked at us and wondered why we were still there (and put it in then). But they comped it, so no complaints there. 

I want to be clear: this was a not a bad meal. But in Nashville, where the upscale food scene is so competitive, this meal just didn't impress me compared to other restaurants where we'd spend approximately the same amount of money. It was okay, but it's not a restaurant I'd rush back to.
name: Cafe Roze
categories: American (New), Restaurants, Bars, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Cocktail Bars

text:
I scream you scream we all scream for ice cream! It is Friday and in my world, that means treat yo-self. Rolled ice cream has really blown up over the past couple of years. Originating in Thailand, rolled ice cream rolled it's way over to the United States. The first established rolled ice cream shop in the United States was located in New York. Thankfully with much achievement and high demand, ICE NY opened a shop in Philadelphia and several other locations. I just had to check it out!

Step 1: Pick your ice cream flavor & your toppings.

Flavor: 
Thai I-CE Tea
Banana Pudding
Chocorilla
Cookie Spree
Mango Sticky Rice
Matcha Mania
Strawberry Chee-se Cake
To-Taro
Ca-Ti Coconut
Black Sesame
OR CREATE YOUR OWN!

Toppings: 
Candy
Cookie
Brownie
Fruit
Cheesecake
Marshmellow
Pocky
and more toppings...and a bunch of sauces!

Step 2: POUR POUR POUR, SMASH SMASH SMASH

Watch staff pour the ice cream mix onto a cold metal place. Staff use metal paddles to quickly break up toppings you ordered to mix into your ice cream. This is the fun part!

Step 3: The final product.

If you could not tell already, I ordered the Cookie Spree ice cream. . . and I am SO happy with my choice. It was incredibly delicious with all the ooeey gooey brownie, oreo, and chocolate sauce. This was by far the best-rolled ice cream I have had in Philadelphia. I have been to several other places in the area, but what makes ICE NY PHILLY different is that their ice cream is very rich and creamy. The ice cream had a thicker consistency which really made it stand out. I can also say I was stuffed after eating this treat.

Staff was very welcoming when I first walked in. They were super helpful especially with this being my first time at ICE NY PHILLY. They were able to give recommendations and state which rolled ice cream cups were their best sellers. It was fun watching them make my ice cream treat and getting to know the staff. Not only does ICE NY PHILLY have rolled ice cream cups, but they also make rolled ice cream sandwiches. An ice cream sandwich is definitely something I would like to try next time. I wish it was acceptable to go back again tomorrow for another ice cream treat, but I will most certainly be back in the near future to cure my next craving at ICE NY PHILLY.
name: I CE NY
categories: Restaurants, Food Court, Food, Desserts, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt

text:
We were a little concerned walking into an empty restaurant at 5:30 on a weekend.  Guess it was on the early side as the restaurant was packed by the time we were done.   The menu selection is limited but the dishes are interesting.  The service was very attentive and prompt.  

We started with the pork belly and the octopus.  The octopus is a better dish, a little charred and very tender.  The pork belly only had 2 cubes of the belly so you will get a nibble if shared as an appetizer.  The ribeye was the priciest item on the menu (they offered a tomahawk steak for $120 that was off-menu).  It was tender and prepared perfectly.  The branzino was good, served whole.  I'm not a big fan of this fish and this dish didn't do anything to change that.  While served whole, the bones were not really a factor though. My least favorite was the pappardelle with venison.  It was on the saltier side and the venison was not very tender (maybe that's how venison is).  

We also had to try the black swan dessert.  The presentation was stunning, and with taste to match (almost).  If you like black sesame, the black sesame ice cream is pretty awesome.

Blackbird is great for a nice dinner.  Given the limited options, check the menu to make sure there is something for everyone.
name: Blackbird
categories: Seafood, Restaurants, Breakfast & Brunch, Lounges, Cocktail Bars, Mediterranean, Bars, Tapas/Small Plates, American (New), Nightlife

text: I am not the type of person to sit down and write a negative review, however when I receive horrible customer service I feel that I am obligated to. My boyfriend and I  came here to celebrate our 5 year anniversary. We passed this place and decided to come in on a whim which is just like us despite the fact the parking lot was pretty empty for 8:45 on a Friday night. We are both sushi lovers and always wanted to try a love boat. When it arrived we were excited and it initially looked good! We both tried about 5 pieces of sushi each before I saw a gnat crawling on our fish and after I quietly pointed it out to my man and we got over the initial shock, we called over our waitress, who really was a sweetheart. Our issue however was that all of the waitresses and staff were arguing with us over what we saw and claiming it was a black sesame seed, which was on the fish in the picture below, but the smaller black object was a gnat and we know what we saw. After we were told we would only receive 50% off and that would have been fine with us if we had eaten more than 10 pieces of sushi combined. The manager then said to me when my boyfriend wasn't looking, "Oh, what's wrong, you went out and can't afford to pay?" Keep in mind that I am a hardworking 20 something year old woman wearing about $1,100 in accessories between my purse, flats, glasses and watch. Instead of losing our composure, we gave up trying to get some type of decent customer service, paid way too much for the situation we encountered and left.
name: Osaka Japanese & Chinese Restaurant
categories: Chinese, Restaurants, Sushi Bars, Japanese

text:
My review for Amelia's is long overdue- since moving to Indy 3 years ago I have dropped by Amelia's countless times for sweet treats and delicious sourdough bread.

Favorites:
Savory city loaf: great sourdough base made even better with cheddar cheese and caramelized onions
Pimento cheese: very fancy pimento cheese that really tastes like pimentos and cheese.  No filler.
Financier: fragrant and nutty, I almost thought this was black sesame flavor but I think I was just smelling the nuttiness of buckwheat flour.  Happens to also be gluten free

Meh items:
Chocolate chip cookie: though this has many fans, this just never suited me personally.  Too much salt flakes on top

You must be careful- the breads don't have preservative so they get stale quickly if you buy it sliced.  I recommend freezing the unused bread either same-day or next-day and reheat slices as needed.
name: Amelia’s
categories: Bakeries, Food

text:
I love Nom Nom Bowl! When I came here for the first time a few months ago, I was immediately struck by how the ambiance, decor, and quality of food were reminiscent of the places I had been to in Japan. 
For appetizers I always go with the pork buns. They stuff the buns with meat and it is so tender and juicy. My go-to entrees are the Goma tuna poke bowl and the pork kakuni bowl. The tuna poke bowl is flavorful with great textures. The pork kakuni bowl is amazing, especially over the mazeman noodles which are worth the extra $2 splurge. My drink of choice is definitely the melon soda, tastes like pure candy. One time the chef was kind enough to give us a complementary dessert of black sesame ice cream in a sweet pancake bun which was delicious. 
After coming back from Japan, I longed for a place in Philly that could rival the amazing flavors and presentation of Japanese food and this is it for me. The food is a little pricy but worth it for the quality.
name: Nom Nom Bowl
categories: Restaurants, Food, Poke, Noodles, Japanese
